column1: 2020-08-12||The Oura Ring has been getting a lot of attention lately because of its role in a number of COVID-19 studies
column2: as well as its adoption by both the NBA and WNBA as a potential tool for helping prevent any outbreaks of the novel coronavirus as those two leagues get back to a regular schedule of play. Oura has released multiple generations of the Ring
column3: which is a health and fitness tracker that reports a range of data
column4: and I’ve spent the past month using one to see what all the fuss is about.

column1: The Oura Ring is a health tracker that’s unlike just about any other wearable with a similar purpose. It’s a ring that’s virtually indistinguishable from an actual ring without any smart features
column2: available in a couple of different designs and multiple finishes. The Ring has sensors located on the inside surface
column3: but these barely add to its overall thickness and are totally hidden when the ring is worn.

column1: Despite its small size and low profile
column2: the Oura Ring is still a connected device
column3: with an internal battery
column4: and the ability to talk to a smartphone via Bluetooth to transmit the data its sensors collect. In the box
column5: you also get a USB-C stand for the Oura Ring that powers it up via induction charging.

column1: The built-in battery is good for up to seven days of continuous use — and that includes wearing the Oura Ring during sleep. During my usage
column2: that seemed to be an accurate estimate. In general
column3: though
column4: the battery life just seemed to be “long enough
column5: ” prompting me not to really think about specific spans
column6: and charging is so quick that it’s easy to just remember to put it on the dock occasionally when it’s convenient (I would often do this during the work day while at my desk
column7: where I keep the Oura dock). Oura’s app also sends helpful notifications to remind you to charge before bed when you’re getting close to the end of your ring’s battery life.

column1: Oura’s design for this most recent iteration of their Ring is fantastic — both as just a piece of jewelry and doubly so as a connected health and activity tracker. It’s available in two styles
column2: called “Balance” and “Heritage
column3: ” both of which come in multiple metallic finishes. There’s a polished silver and gloss black option for both
column4: while “Balance” has a premium-priced version with inlaid diamonds
column5: and “Heritage” has a matte black finish option (which I reviewed).

column1: All the various finishes ore made of a lightweight titanium
column2: with a molded plastic inner to protect the sensors and provide transparency for them to work. The exterior finishes are all coated with a scratch-resistant outer layer — but like with just about any other metal jewelry
column3: scratch-resistant isn’t scratch-proof. The matte black finish I reviewed is definitely showing some wear and tear after multiple weeks of use
column4: but that’s something I was fully expecting
column5: and it’s surprisingly resilient
column6: given how often it comes in contact with other metal surfaces
column7: stone and whatever else you come in contact with on a daily basis. The minor blemishes that appear lend it a pleasing patina
column8: rather than negatively impacting its aesthetics
column9: in my opinion.

column1: The Oura Ring is also fixed in terms of sizing and fit
column2: and the company has come up with a clever way to handle ensuring a good fit for customers. They offer a free sizing kit that they ship out first so you can figure out which Oura size is most comfortable
column3: and decide on which finger you want to wear it. Size is important because you want the Oura Ring to fit snugly enough that it won’t fall off or shift around too much
column4: but also not too snugly that it becomes uncomfortable.

column1: Ultimately
column2: the design is fantastic because it’s both an attractive ring
column3: and an incredibly comfortable device to wear all day — and through the night. Unlike even an Apple Watch or other wrist-worn wearable
column4: there’s virtually no adjustment required for getting used to wearing it while sleeping
column5: or any discomfort from various types of bands. It’s the first wearable I’ve used where I truly was able to forget that I was wearing one at all
column6: and it’s one that no one else will realize you’re wearing
column7: either.

column1: So what does the Oura Ring actually track? A lot of things
column2: actually. It measures sleep
column3: as mentioned
column4: as well as various other metrics under two broad categories: Readiness and Activity. Sleep
column5: Readiness and Activity all provide one overall summary score out of 100 to give you a topline sense of where you are
column6: but each is actually calculated from a range of sub-metrics that add up to that larger score.

column1: Oura’s sleep tracking is much more in-depth than the forthcoming Apple Watch sleep tracking that Apple is releasing with its next watchOS update in the fall. It monitors when you go to sleep
column2: how long you sleep
column3: how much of that qualifies as “deep” and how much is “REM
column4: ” and gives you a metric or you sleep efficiency
column5: your time in bed
column6: your total sleep time and more. Readiness tracks your ambient body temperature
column7: heart rate variability
column8: respiratory rate and your resting heart rate
column9: while activity automatically measures calorie burn
column10: inactive time
column11: your steps and how close you are to your overall activity goal.

column1: For all three of these categories
column2: you can dive into each individual sub-metric and see trends over time or individual scores per day
column3: but you also can just look at the overall score
column4: which is provided in a feed-like dashboard in the app and accompanied by practical
column5: actionable advise about what to do with your day
column6: your activity or your sleep habits based on that score and how it’s trending.

column1: It’s at once both the easiest to understand health tracking app I’ve used
column2: and also one of those with the most depth when it comes to digging into what is actually being tracked
column3: and what that means in greater detail. And because the app focuses heavily on establishing a baseline and then monitoring deviations from that baseline and providing advice based on that
column4: it’s more likely to be useful and specifically relevant to you.

column1: With most wearable tech
column2: including the Apple Watch
column3: I periodically have a sort of internal revolt where I end up finding them too much of an intrusion
column4: or too much of a hassle to maintain continuous use. With the Oura Ring
column5: health self-monitoring reaches a perfect pinnacle of combining convenience with useful and actionable information
column6: with an unobtrusive and attractive design that actually makes me want to put it on.

column1: The jury remains out on whether the Oura Ring can actually accurately detect COVID-19 or anticipate the onset of its symptoms
column2: but regardless
column3: it’s a fantastic personal health tracking device and a great tool for anyone looking to take more control over how they feel on a daily basis. And by actively establishing an individual baseline and comparing your actual overall state to that every day
column4: Oura provides one of the best potential platforms for long-term personal wellness insight out there.||2

column1: 2020-08-12||Joe Biden’s decision to name California Senator Kamala Harris as his running mate in the quest to unseat President Trump means that the next vice president could be not only the first Black and Asian American woman on a presidential ticket in the U.S — historic milestones by any account — but also a Californian who built a career in the tech industry’s front yard.
Born in Oakland
column2: Harris served as San Francisco district attorney and later as the attorney general for California before being elected to the Senate in 2016. And while the newly named vice presidential nominee is likely to bring a deeper understanding of the tech industry to the race
column3: her positions on how a Democratic administration should approach tech’s most powerful companies during an unprecedented moment of scrutiny aren’t exactly crystal clear.

column1: Harris attracted considerable support from Silicon Valley executives in her bid for the Democratic nomination
column2: outpacing other candidates in donations from employees from large tech companies early on. While that support shifted around throughout the race and many donors in tech supported multiple candidates
column3: the industry is likely to be happy with Biden’s selection.

column1: Notably
column2: Harris was elected as California attorney general in 2010 and served two terms
column3: overseeing the tech industry through a large portion of its most explosive growth — a measure that likely proves more meaningful in assessing her stance toward regulating the tech industry than the things she said along the campaign trail.

column1: Still
column2: those were arguably simpler times for Silicon Valley
column3: and ones that predated current hot-button conversations around issues like election interference
column4: misinformation wars and antitrust enforcement.

column1: As the primary developed and then-rival Elizabeth Warren carved out a posture critical of big tech
column2: Harris seldom waded into thorny issues around regulating the tech industry. During an October debate
column3: Harris avoided a question asking about concerns over second order effects if big tech companies were broken up
column4: instead redirecting to the safer political territory of Trump’s Twitter account. Dodging meatier points about tech accountability
column5: Harris called on Twitter to suspend the president’s account for violating its rules
column6: calling the issue “a matter of safety and corporate accountability.”

column1: Earlier this year
column2: in response to a straightforward question asking if companies like Facebook
column3: Google and Amazon should be broken up
column4: Harris again dodged
column5: though signaled that she is concerned in how those companies handle user data.

column1: “I believe that tech companies have got to be regulated in a way that we can ensure the American consumer can be certain that their privacy is not being compromised
column2: ” Harris said. Harris also expressed her concerns about user privacy in a 2018 Twitter thread.

column1: “Millions of Americans have no idea how much data Facebook is collecting
column2: from tracking their location and IP address
column3: to following their activities on other websites
column4: ” she wrote.

column1: “In the real world
column2: this would be like someone watching what you do
column3: where you go
column4: for how long
column5: and with whom you’re with every day. For most
column6: it would feel like an invasion of privacy.”

column1: In other critiques of tech
column2: Harris has mostly concentrated on Facebook
column3: denouncing its role in spreading Russian disinformation during the 2016 presidential race and expressing worries over how the company handles the data it collects.

column1: When given the chance to press Mark Zuckerberg in person
column2: Harris zeroed in on the company’s handling of the Cambridge Analytica data misuse to its users. More recently
column3: Harris co-authored a letter to Facebook along with Colorado Senator Michael Bennett after the audit’s largely unflattering results were published
column4: pressing the company on election concerns.

column1: “Although the company has shown a recent willingness to rein in disinformation with respect to COVID-19
column2: it has not shown equal resolve to confront voter suppression and learn the lessons of the 2016 election
column3: ” the senators wrote. “We share the auditors’ concern that Facebook has failed to use the tools and resources at its disposal to more vigorously combat voter suppression and protect civil rights.”

column1: In another letter to the company
column2: Harris criticized Facebook’s fact-checking policies for climate-related misinformation in light of a New York Times report.

column1: In spite of the harsh talk
column2: Harris seems to be on fairly friendly terms with Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg
column3: who congratulated her on the nomination Tuesday. Back in 2013
column4: Harris apparently contributed to the marketing effort around Sandberg’s now-ubiquitous book Lean In
column5: sharing her own story. Harris also spoke at a cyberbullying event hosted at Facebook’s Menlo Park headquarters in 2015 and the two were photographed onstage together.

column1: While we have a handful of public statements from Harris about her views on tech
column2: there’s plenty more that we don’t know. The way she positioned herself in relation to other candidates during the primary might not wholly reflect the kind of priorities she would bring to the vice presidency
column3: and we’ll likely be learning more about those in the coming days.

column1: Right now there are many
column2: many crises on the table for the next administration. If regulating big tech looked like a huge campaign issue back in the pre-pandemic political landscape of 2020
column3: conversations around police brutality and the devastating American failure to contain the coronavirus are now at the fore. Whether issues around antitrust regulation and reining in tech’s power will make it off the back burner remains to be seen
column4: and there are plenty of national five-alarm fires to be put out in the meantime.

column1: While her potential position as the nation’s next vice president doesn’t mean that Harris would be tasked with shaping tech policy or spearheading antitrust efforts
column2: her deep connections to tech’s geographic hub could prove consequential in a Biden presidency and its priorities.

column1: In spite of some question marks around her policy approaches
column2: Harris is a known quantity for the tech industry — one who understands Silicon Valley and who
column3: per her track record
column4: doesn’t look keen to take on the industry’s biggest companies in spite of some recent tough talk. Whatever tech policies emerge out of a Biden/Harris campaign
column5: the fresh vice presidential nominee is connected to tech in a more meaningful way than any other contender for the spot. That alone is something to watch.||0

column1: Facebook took action on a far larger number of posts for violating rules against hate speech in Q2 (22.5 million

column2: the amount of content that was later restored without an appeal after being removed under the anti-organized hate and terrorism rules skyrocketed in Q2; Facebook restored 135
column3: 000 posts in the first category and 533
column4: 000 in the second. It doesn’t appear that Facebook processed a single appeal on either category in Q2
column5: suggesting the company’s human moderators have their eyes turned elsewhere. Facebook does not release the internal data which may show how prevalent hate speech or organized hate groups are on the site.

column1: Keep in mind that this is all according to Facebook
column2: which has recently faced accusations it turns a blind eye to rule violations that are politically inconvenient as well as an employee walkout and advertiser boycott pressuring the company to do more about hate speech and misinformation. By definition
column3: the report only shows the prohibited content that Facebook is already aware of. Independent assessments of the company’s handling of issues like hate speech haven’t always reflected Facebook’s insistence that progress is being made.

column1: A civil rights audit released in July 2020 that found it failed to build a civil rights infrastructure and made “vexing and heartbreaking” choices that have actively caused “significant setbacks for civil rights.” A United Nations report in 2019 assessed Facebook’s reaction to accusations of complicity in the genocide of the Rohingya people in Myanmar as slow and subpar
column2: in particular calling out the company for not doing enough to remove racist content on the site quickly or prevent it from behind uploaded in the first place. (It’s possible that some of the surge in hate speech on Facebook is due to the introduction of more tools to detect in Burmese
column3: the majority language of Myanmar.)

column1: It remains broadly unclear just how well Facebook’s AI tools are doing their job. Seattle University associate professor Caitlin Carlson told Wired hate speech is “not hard to find” on the site
column2: and the 9.6 million posts Facebook said it removed for hate speech in Q1 2020 seemed very low. In January 2020
column3: Carlson and a colleague published results of an experiment in which they assembled 300 posts they believed would violate company standards and reported them to Facebook moderators
column4: who took only about half of them down. Groups dedicated to conspiracy theories
column5: such as the far-right QAnon one
column6: continue to run rampant on the site and have millions of members. Facebook
column7: as well as other social media sites
column8: also played a major role in the spread of coronavirus misinformation this year.

column1: Many of Facebook’s moderators have begun to return to work. According to VentureBeat
column2: Facebook said that it is working to see how its metrics can be audited “most effectively
column3: ” and said that it is calling for an external
column4: independent audit of Community Standards Enforcement Report data that it expects to begin in 2021.||1

column1: 2020-05-27||When it comes to funding research
column2: South Korea is in rarefied air. As a percentage of its gross domestic product
column3: its spending on research and development is second only to Israel’s.

column1: The speed of this ascent has been dizzying
column2: up from 2.1% of its gross domestic product in 2000
column3: when it was equal to the average of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development member nations
column4: to more than 4.5% in 2018
column5: with Israel alone surpassing it at 4.9%
column6: according to the latest available figures.

column1: But this surge has not been even. Rather
column2: it has favoured top-down
column3: government-directed projects intended to boost competitiveness in fields such as artificial intelligence
column4: robotics and materials
column5: often in partnership with the private sector
column6: consistent with the post-war focus on applied research that turned South Korea into a leader in semiconductor manufacturing and wireless communication networks.

column1: New priorities
column2: however
column3: have taken root. For the past decade
column4: the necessity to invest in basic research has been a common refrain from South Korean researchers and politicians alike. To maintain economic growth
column5: the nation has sought to become a ‘first mover’
column6: instead of simply a ‘fast follower’ — rhetoric embraced by the current liberal president
column7: Moon Jae-in
column8: and his predecessor
column9: the conservative Park Geun-hye. The drive to compete more effectively in strategic fields continues
column10: but South Korea has begun emphasizing bottom-up funding for small teams of researchers
column11: betting that strength will flow from the creativity of its scientists.

column1: On paper
column2: the rhetoric is backed by funding. Under President Moon
column3: who was first elected in 2017
column4: the basic-research budget for South Korea’s main funding agency
column5: the National Research Foundation (NRF)
column6: has skyrocketed under a five-year plan to double it by 2022 to 2.5 trillion won (US$2 billion). The nation’s budget for 2020 allows for a remarkable 18% increase from the previous year in government spending on research and development (R&D)
column7: to 24.2 trillion won.

column1: In the private sector
column2: which makes up roughly three-quarters of R&D spending
column3: basic-research spending is also surging
column4: including outlays by major conglomerates such as Samsung and LG Electronics. “Industry is asking universities to produce more and more PhDs
column5: ” says Han Woong Yeom
column6: a physicist at Pohang University of Science and Technology and vice-chair of Moon’s presidential advisory council on science and technology. “The situation cannot be better than this
column7: in terms of investment.”

column1: Spending surged over the past two decades on large national projects
column2: such as a lunar orbiter scheduled for launch in 2022
column3: a nanomaterials research effort dubbed the ‘Creative Materials Discovery Program’
column4: and Korea’s branch of the International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor
column5: the main experiment of which is under construction in southern France. “Previously
column6: more emphasis was on the mission-oriented research towards immediate economic output
column7: ” says microbiologist
column8: Jung-Hye Roe
column9: whom Moon tapped to lead the NRF in 2018.

column1: There is a new emphasis on bottom-up funding through NRF grants. Currently
column2: the NRF accounts for slightly more than one-quarter of total government-funded research
column3: with a budget of close to 7 trillion won in 2020. The amount spent on basic-research grants to principal investigators is now roughly equal to that spent on top-down
column4: mission-oriented projects
column5: and Roe hopes to boost the basic-research grants still further.

column1: Recent highlights from these grants include: a gallium arsenide nanoresonator that can trap light and change its colour
column2: work published in Science1 in January and co-led by Hong-Gyu Park of Korea University in Seoul; atmospheric observations from Gosan-ri on Jeju Island as part of an international study2
column3: co-led by Sunyoung Park of Kyungpook National University in Daegu and published in Nature in 2019
column4: that identified eastern China as a major source of the emission of chlorofluorocarbons
column5: chemicals that destroy the ozone layer that are banned under the Montreal Protocol; and the finding that the development of osteoarthritis is related to how the body processes cholesterol
column6: in a 2019 Nature study3
column7: led by Je-Hwang Ryu of Chonnam National University in Gwangju and Jang-Soo Chun of the Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology.

column1: The top-down division can claim successes too
column2: including playing a key role in the nation’s ability to quickly develop and produce diagnostic kits for COVID-19
column3: says Roe. The first four companies to win urgent-use approval for their tests had all received NRF funding to research the production of such kits after the 2015 Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) outbreak in South Korea infected 186 people and killed 36. And in February
column4: the Korea Aerospace Research Institute
column5: responsible for the nation’s space programme
column6: launched the Cheollian 2B satellite; its main instrument
column7: the Geostationary Environment Monitoring Spectrometer (GEMS) is designed to monitor air pollution in the Asia-Pacific region
column8: making it the first of a new generation of satellites intended to study global air quality.

column1: An emphasis on government-mandated metrics in hiring and promotion
column2: which critics say incentivizes researchers to present work of little value in low-quality journals or conferences
column3: remains to be addressed. Last May
column4: the nation’s education ministry reported that 574 researchers had participated in international conferences organized by ‘predatory publishers’. “That happens because
column5: so far
column6: we have emphasized getting large numbers of quantitative
column7: shallow publications
column8: ” says Roe.

column1: “I think this old-style culture is prohibiting the booming of our creativity
column2: ” says Yeom. “This may still be good enough to produce many papers
column3: but not original ideas.”

column1: The outlook is uncertain. Not only does the expected heavy economic burden of recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic threaten to curb the growth in R&D budgets
column2: but South Korea’s traditional industries — including chip-making
column3: ship-making and nuclear power — face increased competition from China. Political tensions with Japan that flared in July 2019
column4: fuelled by that nation’s legacy of colonial rule
column5: threatened to cut off supplies of key materials for semiconductor production
column6: exposing how heavily the nation’s technology industry relies on Japanese manufacturers.

column1: There is talk in policy circles of a science and technology new deal — a boost in funding and programmes to combat the effects of a less globalized world in which South Korea’s access to scientific supplies and talent is reduced
column2: says So Young Kim
column3: director of the Korea Policy Center for the Fourth Industrial Revolution
column4: a think tank affiliated with KAIST in Daejeon. Yeom says researchers stand to benefit from a public appetite for societal change
column5: which also translates into support for increased science funding. Yeom and other policymakers are pushing for greater investment in research topics that meet the practical needs of South Korean society
column6: such as air pollution
column7: and an ageing population. In response
column8: the Moon administration has begun an initiative to trace and reduce fine particulate matter across northeast Asia
column9: and another to fight dementia.

column1: Some suspect it will be initiatives such as these that do most to move South Korea away from the label ‘fast follower’. “The definition of top-level research doesn’t need to be the highest impact factor or highest citation count
column2: ” says Roe. Pursuing research directions that benefit South Korean society is “making our own path
column3: a new path
column4: rather than following others”.||2

column4: I have watched committees deliberate decisions and the process does not lend itself to timely and decisive action in times of crisis. At least now we have one person to hold accountable.

column2: I could be more supportive if there was some confidence those statewide elected officials would give nonpartisan advice. column1: 2020-05-28||T of Hong Kong want two things: to choose how they are governed

column1: On May 21st China declared

column9: it will be a less attractive place for global firms to operate.

column1: China’s move also has implications far beyond Hong Kong. “One country
column2: two systems” was supposed to be a model for Taiwan
column3: a democratic island of 24m that China also sees as its own. The aim was to show that reunification with the motherland need not mean losing one’s liberty. Under President Xi Jinping
column4: China seems to have tired of this charade. Increasingly

column6: Tsai Ing-wen

column8: at the opening of China’s rubber-stamp parliament
column9: the prime minister
column10: Li Keqiang
column11: ominously cut the word “peaceful” from his ritual reference to reunification. China has stepped up war games around Taiwan and its nationalists have been braying online for an invasion.

column1: China is at odds with other countries
column2: too. In its building of island fortresses in the South China Sea
column3: it ignores both international law and the claims of smaller neighbours. This week hundreds
column4: perhaps thousands of Chinese troops crossed China’s disputed border with India in the Himalayas. Minor scuffles along this frontier are common
column5: but the latest incursion came as a state-owned Chinese paper asserted new claims to land that its nuclear-armed neighbour deems Indian (see article). And
column6: as a sombre backdrop to all this
column7: relations with the United States are worse than they have been in decades
column8: poisoning everything from trade and investment to scientific collaboration.

column1: However much all the regional muscle-flexing appals the world
column2: it makes sense to the Chinese Communist Party. In Hong Kong the party wants to stop a “colour revolution”
column3: which it thinks could bring democrats to power there despite China’s best efforts to rig the system. If eroding Hong Kong’s freedoms causes economic damage
column4: so be it
column5: party bigwigs reason. The territory is still an important place for Chinese firms to raise international capital
column6: especially since the Sino-American feud makes it harder and riskier for them to do so in New York. But Hong Kong’s is equivalent to only 3% of mainland China’s now
column7: down from more than 18% in 1997
column8: because the mainland’s economy has grown 15-fold since then. China’s rulers assume that multinational firms and banks will keep a base in Hong Kong
column9: simply to be near the vast Chinese market. They are probably right.

column1: The simple picture that President Donald Trump paints of America and China locked in confrontation suits China’s rulers well. The party thinks that the balance of power is shifting in China’s favour. Mr Trump’s insults feed Chinese nationalist anger
column2: which the party is delighted to exploit—just as it does any tensions between America and its allies. It portrays the democracy movement in Hong Kong as an American plot. That is absurd
column3: but it helps explain many mainlanders’ scorn for Hong Kong’s protesters.

column1: The rest of the world should stand up to China’s bullying. On the Sino-Indian border
column2: the two sides should talk more to avoid miscalculations
column3: as their leaders promised to in 2018. China should realise that
column4: if it tries the tactics it has used in the South China Sea
column5: building structures on disputed ground and daring others to push back

column1: In the case of Taiwan China faces a powerful deterrent: a suggestion in American law that America might come to Taiwan’s aid were the island to be attacked. There is a growing risk that a cocksure China may decide to put that to the test. America should make clear that doing so would be extremely dangerous. America’s allies should echo that
column2: loudly.

column1: Hong Kong’s options are bleaker. The Hong Kong Policy Act requires America to certify annually that the territory should in trade and other matters be treated as separate from China. This week the secretary of state

column3: declared that “facts on the ground” show Hong Kong is no longer autonomous. This allows America to slap tariffs on the territory’s exports

column9: Britain should grant full residency rights to the hundreds of thousands of Hong Kongers who hold a kind of second-class British passport—much as Ms Tsai this week opened Taiwan’s door to Hong Kong citizens. column1: A passed a grim milestone: 100
column2: 000 deaths from a novel coronavirus that began to spread half a year and half a world away. Many Americans think their president has handled the epidemic disastrously
column3: that their country has been hit uniquely hard and that there is a simple causal relationship between the two. The 100
column5: which does not include excess deaths mistakenly attributed to other causes
column6: is higher than any other country’s. It has routinely been compared with the 60
column7: 000 American casualties in the Vietnam war. A Trump Death Clock in Times Square purports to show how many lives the president’s ineptitude has cost: as we went to press it stood at 60
column8: 262. Yet this widespread conviction that America has failed because of Donald Trump is not supported by the numbers. Or
column9: at least
column10: not yet.

column1: The official death rate in America is about the same as in the European Union—which also has excess deaths
column2: but has less erratic leaders and universal health care. Overall
column3: America has fared a bit worse than Switzerland and a bit better than the Netherlands
column4: neither of which is a failed state. New York has been hit about as hard as Lombardy in northern Italy; California acted early and is currently similar to Germany; so far
column5: rural states have
column6: like central Europe
column7: been spared the worst. This reflects two things
column8: both of which will matter now that America is reopening before it has the virus fully under control.

column1: The first is that covid-19
column2: when it first hit
column3: displayed an indifference to presidents and their plans. Around the world it has killed in large
column4: dense and connected cities like New York
column5: London and Paris
column6: and where people are crammed together
column7: including care homes
column8: slaughterhouses and prisons. In some countries
column9: including America
column10: testing was snarled up in red tape.

column1: Having seen what was happening in China
column2: Mr Trump could have acted sooner—as Taiwan
column3: Singapore and Vietnam did. He has failed to do things ordinarily expected of an American president in a crisis
column4: such as giving clear government advice or co-ordinating a federal response. Instead
column5: he has touted quack remedies and spent the days when America passed its sombre milestone spreading suspicion of the voting system and accusing a television host of committing a murder that never happened. All this is reprehensible and it may have been costly. Yet
column6: tempting as it is to conclude that the president’s failures bear most of the blame for covid-19’s spread through America
column7: the reality is more complicated (see Briefing).

column1: That leads to the second feature of the country’s response to covid-19. The virus was always going to be hard on a population with high levels of poverty
column2: obesity and diseases such as diabetes
column3: especially among minorities (see Lexington). But
column4: to a remarkable degree
column5: other layers of government have adapted around the hole where the president should have been. The federal system has limited the damage

column1: Contrary to demands for nationwide rules

column1: 2020-05-28||High levels of economic activity can foster the spread of communicable diseases through frequent person-to-person interactions. This column discusses how research on high levels of employment affects the spread of influenza and other viruses transmitted via droplet-spread
column2: such as SARS-CoV-2. The results show that the high levels of employment in the US encourages the spread of influenza
column3: especially when employment in service sectors are high. Our results provide support for social distancing measures aimed to slow the growth of cases of COVID-19.

column1: Many of the characteristics or environments associated with modern daily work life may encourage the transmission of viruses
column2: including seasonal influenza (the flu) and the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2)
column3: the cause of Covid-19. These characteristics include commuting via public transportation
column4: working in climate controlled indoor offices
column5: sharing workspaces
column6: and placing young children in daycare. If the features of the working environment promote the spread of the flu and other viruses
column7: then being out of the labour force and away from these environments could help reduce the spread of diseases. This is the premise behind the current public health policies of closing down public places and requiring social distancing.

column1: Early evidence suggests that these social distancing measures may be reducing the spread of SARS-CoV-2 (e.g. Dave et al. 2020
column2: Friedson et al. 2020
column3: Courtemanche et al. 2020
column4: Baldwin and Weder di Mauro 2020). However
column5: because the COVID-19 pandemic is so recent
column6: much of this evidence is based on only a few months of data. More evidence surrounding the effects of social distancing on the spread of SARS-CoV-2 could be gathered by studying the spread of similar viruses
column7: namely the flu.

column1: Evidence that high levels of employment are associated with high rates of seasonal flu
In a recently published article (Markowitz et al. 2019)
column2: we examine the relationship between economic activity
column3: as measured by employment levels
column4: and the spread of the flu in the US. We use state-level monthly employment rates from the Bureau of Labor Statistics and state-level monthly estimates of flu activity from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column5: spanning the 2010-2011 flu season up to the 2016-2017 flu season.

column1: Our basic empirical strategy is to predict flu activity in a state and month as a function of the state’s employment levels in the previous month
column2: as well as temperature and precipitation
column3: and the previous month’s flu rate.

column1: If our hypothesis is correct
column2: we should expect that increases in employment in jobs with higher levels of interpersonal contact should be more related to the spread of the flu. Thus
column3: we construct a measure of interpersonal contact levels for each industry sector using data from O*Net and construct employment measures at the industry level using data from the BLS Current Employment Statistics (CES) data set. We find that the two sectors with the highest levels of interpersonal contact are the retail and healthcare sectors
column4: while the sectors with the lowest level of interpersonal contact are the construction and manufacturing sectors.

column1: Figure 1 summarise the results from our regression models. We plot the increases in flu prevalence from an average monthly increase in overall employment and employment in sectors with high and low measures of interpersonal contact.
We find a strong positive association between employment and the spread of the flu
column2: and the results suggest that an average monthly change in overall employment (about 0.33 percentage points) increases flu prevalence by about 6%. We find that employment changes in the retail and healthcare sectors
column3: the two sectors with the highest levels of interpersonal contact
column4: drive the aggregate results. The same average monthly increase in retail employment and healthcare employment would lead to much larger expected increases in flu prevalence of between 20% and 30%
column5: respectively. Moreover
column6: we find that employment changes in the construction sector
column7: one of the sectors with the lowest level of interpersonal contact
column8: is not associated with statistically significant changes in flu prevalence. Interestingly
column9: changes in manufacturing employment lead to a large
column10: but extremely imprecisely measured
column11: increase in flu prevalence. This may be due to underlying heterogeneity in how different types of manufacturing employment either aid or are not related to the spread of the flu. We believe this remains an interesting question for future research.

column1: Figure 1 Percent changes in flu prevalence from an average monthly increase in employment
These results are relevant for several reasons. First
column2: barring major economic shocks
column3: employment conditions can be forecast
column4: to a fairly accurate degree
column5: several months in advance. This information could be used by the public health community to plan for the severity of an upcoming flu season. For example
column6: the 2017-2018 flu season was particularly severe. Hospitals found themselves unprepared and struggling to keep up with the influx of patients. As we have recently learned
column7: the ability to predict the potential severity of future communicable diseases is vital information for hospitals and public health officials. In general
column8: if the economy is on an upswing
column9: the public health community should plan for an above normal increase in such diseases. The reverse will hold as well. This same logic can reasonably be applied to other droplet-spread
column10: respiratory diseases
column11: like COVID-19.

column1: Furthermore
column2: our results imply that employment in service industries – particularly retail and healthcare – is a particularly strong mechanism for flu spread. If our economy continues to shift to more service-oriented employment
column3: the results presented here suggest there is greater potential for virus spread in the future. The statistically insignificant findings for industries such as construction with relatively low levels of interpersonal contact support the continuation of construction and infrastructure projects during periods of social distancing. Likewise
column4: restrictions on retail business and non-essential medical visits are prudent considerations
column5: as our results suggest activity in these industries is a significant source of viral infection. Lastly
column6: employers should consider differences in the lost productivity from many employees becoming infected with viruses versus the lost productivity from a few infected individuals taking sick leave. Workers concerned about missing pay or losing their jobs as the result of staying home from work due to illness will be less likely to heed early signs of influenza or other viral infections and stay home. Since a person may be infectious while experiencing mild symptoms
column7: this greatly increases the probability that the virus will spread to other workers in the firm. This implies that firms should consider more generous ‘sick day’ policies
column8: particularly during the flu season. A recent working paper (Pichler et al. 2020) and a corresponding VoxEU column (Pichler and Ziebarth 2020)
column9: provide direct evidence of this hypothesis using variation in state-level mandated sick leave policies.

column1: 2020-05-28||CBC Calgary wants to know how you are living these days. Have you been to a restaurant yet? Had your hair cut? Are you re-imagining what summer looks like? What is bringing you joy? Let us know. Send us a page from your COVID-19 diary.

column2: Sima Chowdhury tells us about fighting to see her mother in hospital
column3: who ultimately made the decision she would be better off at home. This submission has been edited for clarity and length.

column1: Hospitalized in Lethbridge with complications from pulmonary fibrosis during COVID-19
column2: my mother had an isolation room containing a separate section for staff to don and doff personal protective equipment
column3: a private bathroom
column4: a television and beautiful natural light.

column1: A room fit for a queen
column2: as her attending physician affectionately called her. We were only allowed to see her in the room for ourselves when he didn't think she would survive the latest ordeal. During my visiting shift
column3: she insisted on a selfie of us. Sharing the photo with my friends
column4: they understood the seriousness of the situation.

column1: With a strong will to live
column2: my mother recovered enough to lose her ability to hold court with us in her hospital kingdom. Two of her favourite subjects were absent from these audiences.

column1: My two nephews were too young to see her and expressed their frustration at COVID-19 for robbing them of the opportunity to see their grandmother for what could have been the last time. Despite her doctor's misgivings of an early release
column2: "The Queen" decided to come home to see her grandchildren.

column1: Meeting her needs at home requires a team effort. My sister and I drive from Calgary to ease the burden on our father
column2: while nurses visit regularly to administer intravenous medications.

column1: • Dear Diary: Driveway visits are nice
column2: but this grandmother just wants a hug

column1: • Dear Diary: An ER doctor opens up on what keeps him coming to work each day
My heart goes out to anyone who has to fight to see loved ones sick in the hospital. Healing comes in many forms
column2: not just in medicines and vaccines

column4: love
column5: and hope from familiar faces.

column1: The attending physician told my mom that having her family around aided her recovery. She went a step further to make sure she had access to us

column1: Our health system needs to support a holistic approach for the vulnerable rather than wage germ warfare on those least able to advocate for themselves.

column2: hysteresis
column3: and the future of work

column1: Has Covid accelerated the future of work? This column argues that Covid has changed the future of work via four shocks: massive job losses
column2: massive digital transformations
column3: massive debt burdens
column4: and massive costs of socially distanced office space. These matter in two ways. First
column5: due to sunk cost hysteresis
column6: re-hiring workers is very different than retaining workers. Second
column7: the digital transformations
column8: office-space costs
column9: and debt burdens will push firms to replace domestic workers with ‘telemigrants’ or ‘white-collar robots’. The jobs that return will be those that require face-to-face interactions and involve tasks that AI cannot handle.

column1: Things have changed so much with Covid-19 that not even the future is what it used to be – or so it seems from all the predictions that analysts are making about the post-Covid world. But why should things change permanently? Things are the way they are for good reasons. If the reasons don’t change permanently
column2: the outcomes won’t change permanently.

column1: Actually
column2: it is more complicated than that. Some socio-economic-political outcomes are governed by what might be called ‘rubber-band dynamics’
column3: others by ‘paper-clip dynamics.’

column1: • When you shock a rubber band – say
column2: pull on it – the shape deforms
column3: but the shape returns when you stop pulling. Temporary shocks have temporary effects.

column1: Most economic phenomena are like this – the standard supply-and-demand mechanism
column2: for instance.

column1: • When you pull on a paper clip
column2: it deforms but the shape doesn’t return when you stop pulling. Temporary shocks have permanent effects.

column1: Technically
column2: the two types of dynamics are called non-hysteretic (rubber band) and hysteretic (paper clip).

column1: When thinking about how the Covid shock will change the future
column2: we must focus on hysteretic processes. Generally speaking
column3: hysteresis happens in systems where the level of some capital stock alters marginal costs or benefits. Here ‘capital’ includes simple versions like human
column4: physical
column5: and knowledge capital
column6: or more complex forms like organisational capital
column7: social trust
column8: aspirations
column9: and expectations. Different sources of hysteresis work with different types of shocks.

column1: Covid-19 has profoundly shocked the economy in many ways. Four are particularly pertinent to the future of work.
• An epic number of people have lost their jobs.
In America the figure is almost 40 million. In Europe
column2: fewer have been laid off
column3: but millions have been dislodged from their usual employment relationships (Boeri et al 2020). Many of these separations will last for a few quarters at least.

column1: This matters. Due to sunk costs
column2: a firm’s decision to hire a worker is very different than its decision to retain a worker
column3: and that’s why employment is a hysteretic process. The firings also matter since they boost the attractiveness of office-place automation – what I call ‘white collar robots’ in my 2019 book
column4: The Globotics Upheaval. Automating service-tasks with
column5: for example
column6: robotic process automation (RPA) systems
column7: chatbots
column8: virtual assistants
column9: or higher-end AI-systems is easier when you’ve already laid off the workers they are replacing.

column1: • A large share of workers in Europe and America have learned to work remotely.
Estimates are that from 40-70% of workers in the US and Europe worked from home due to the pandemic (Berg et al 2020
column2: Dingel and Nieman 2020
column3: Brehan 2020). To make this possible
column4: firms have invested in digital transformations – especially in the service sector. Companies have invested in hardware and bandwidth. Workers have learned how to use collaborative software
column5: access remote databases
column6: and participate in virtual meetings. Managers have learned how to manage virtual teams.

column1: This matters since the human
column2: physical
column3: and organisational investments are not going away. And anything that makes it easier to telework domestically also makes it easier to telework internationally (what I called ‘telemigration’ in my book).

column1: Now that telework is feasible for a hefty slice of their workforce
column2: firms will soon realise that they can get some of the remote work done at much lower cost by hiring workers sitting in low-wage countries. While it is certainly true that foreign talent working online is unlikely to be as good as domestic talent working in the office
column3: the foreign talent may be a whole lot cheaper. This is just service-sector globalisation
column4: so the deeper point is Covid-linked changes are lowering the technical barriers to this type of globalisation.

column1: • Office space in Europe and America got more expensive due to social distancing and other anti-contagion requirements.
This won’t last forever
column2: but it is likely to be true during much of the recovery phase.

column1: This matters since firms will face the cost-raising aspects while they are deciding whether to rehire workers in-house
column2: to sink the costs of outsourcing the jobs (domestically or internationally)
column3: or to automate the positions using white-collar robots.

column1: • Corporate and government balance sheets have already been hit hard by the Covid concussion; more red ink is predicted for many quarters to come.

This matters since firms will be under pressure to cut costs in the short and medium term. Using ‘remote intelligence’ (RI) like telemigrants and artificial intelligence (AI) like white-collar robots will be one way of reducing expenses.
The post-Covid employment landscape: What can’t RI and AI do?
As the world returns to normal
column2: private and public employers will have to decide which sorts of workers they want
column3: and how many of them – starting from something of a tabula rasa. Some may decide to just go back to doing things the old way. But on the margin
column4: the investment in remote work capacity will surely result in fewer workers in offices.

column1: So
column2: what jobs won’t be replaced by RI or AI? Applying the logic I developed in The Globotics Upheaval
column3: the jobs that will return are those that are intensive in the sorts of tasks that (1) can’t be done remotely
column4: and (2) can’t be done by white-collar robots. In other words
column5: the way to think about the future of work post-Coivd-19 is to use a process of elimination. The question then is: What can’t RI and AI do? I have a couple of chapters on this in my book
column6: but here’s the gist.

column1: As it turns out
column2: humans have unique advantages over white-collar robots in things like judgement
column3: empathy
column4: intuition
column5: creativity
column6: ethics
column7: curiosity
column8: and comprehension of complex interactions among teams of humans. Psychologist call this ‘social cognition’ and we have it for very specific
column9: very deep-seated reasons. Michael Tomasello’s book
column10: The Cultural Origin of Human Cognition
column11: asserts that social cognition allowed humans to live in large groups where survival turned on the ability of individuals to cooperate in a complex web of relationships involving trust
column12: kinship
column13: and dominance. The equipment for this is hardwired into the human brain.

column1: Machine learning has problems with social cognition
column2: as I point out at length in my book. First
column3: even today’s computers aren’t powerful enough given the combinatoric aspects of social interactions. Second
column4: we don’t have the right kind of data to train the white-collar robots. Third
column5: machine learning techniques are a shallow imitation of the biology of human learning
column6: so it may be that a whole new computer-science approach is needed if machines are to rival humans in the most human skills (Lake et al. 2017).

column1: What kind of jobs can’t be done by telemigrants? Clearly
column2: work that requires local or culture-specific knowledge will be hard to do from overseas. More generally
column3: the key is to think hard about why face-to-face communication matters. Since verbal communication is almost costless these days
column4: a good place to start is nonverbal communication – a topic that is widely studied by psychologists.

column1: When people are face-to-face in the same room
column2: psychological experiments suggest that less than 30% of the information exchanged stems from the words spoken – some communication researchers put the number as low as 7%. The rest is nonverbal. One clear upshot of this is that forming trust is much easier with face-to-face communication since it is easier to lie with words than it is to lie face-to-face. This is exactly why we trust people more when they say things straight to our face.

column1: Almost ten years ago
column2: Alan Blinder classified jobs according to offshore-ability
column3: finding that something like 40% could be done remotely. The sectors where less than 20% of the jobs were offshorable – that is
column4: could be done by telemigrants – were mostly of the have-to-be-there type: jobs in hotels and restaurants
column5: transportation and warehousing
column6: construction
column7: leisure industries
column8: education
column9: and health and social care. The most vulnerable sectors to telemigrants were professional
column10: scientific and technical sectors
column11: and the finance
column12: industry
column13: and media sectors. More recently
column14: Dingel and Neiman (2020) came up with the figure that 37% of US jobs could be done remotely.

column1: Most service-sector and professional jobs have been sheltered from globalisation (i.e. remote intelligence) and white-collar robots (i.e. artificial intelligence) since face-to-face interactions were important and computers couldn’t think. That has been changing progressively as digital technology has advanced.
Pushed by Covid-19
column2: firms and workers have invested in
column3: say
column4: ten years’ worth of digital transformation in just a few months. My guess is that this will accelerate the trend towards more service sector jobs coming into competition with ‘globotics’
column5: i.e. telemigrants working in our offices while sitting abroad (the globalisation part)
column6: and software robots replacing particular office-tasks (the robotics part). The jobs that survive competition from telemigrants will be those that require face-to-face interactions. The jobs that survive competition from white-collar robots will be those that stress humanity’s great advantages.

column1: 2020-05-29||I suspect many teachers are recoiling from the phrase “the new normal”. There is nothing normal about remote teaching and the idea that it can become a long-term replacement for the classroom or lecture hall is anathema to most in education. Also worrying is the possibility that those in charge of third-education institutions
column2: even more starved of resources than they were before Covid-19
column3: will see remote or “blended” teaching as a new
column4: cheaper
column5: streamlined way of delivering “output”
column6: rendering the university campus almost redundant.

column1: Arising out of the current crisis
column2: there is a danger of a whole new language around online educational “provision” being added to the layer of corporate management speak that has long pervaded the Irish education system. In 2015
column3: a senior UCD administrator sent this message to the university staff: “Strategic Initiative 6 is concerned with consolidating and supporting efforts across our community to enhance agility and effectiveness in university process improvement
column4: thereby continuously furthering value for the UCD community and process beneficiaries whilst simultaneously empowering faculty and staff to proactively engage in continuous process improvement initiatives”.

column1: Those with a high pain threshold can reread that “sentence” several times
column2: but it will remain what it is: a grotesque subversion of the notion of a third-level community. This jargon is a product of a trend historian Tom Dunne had written about two years earlier: “like a deadly
column3: odourless gas
column4: the elements of a quiet revolution have seeped through every area of Irish education during recent years
column5: poisoning the atmosphere . . . a relentless application of market principles . . . has shifted the focus of education from the development of the individual and the benefits flowing from this to society to the service of the economy
column6: narrowly conceived”.

column1: This took on added pace in the aftermath of the last economic collapse with an insistence that “applied research” needed to be the main priority. Teachers were increasingly seen as “service providers”
column2: the students as “service users” and the university leaders and reams of bureaucrats as “managers”. The casualisation of academic labour and short-term contracts further embedded an insecurity that is the antithesis of an academic “community” and hinders creativity. There has also been a preoccupation with what is offensively labelled “performance for growth” by university management as if the educators were stocks and shares. Parallel to this are obsessions with “impact”
column3: “globalisation” and ensuring a flow of money from China. Recently
column4: UCD management sought to change the university’s policy on academic freedom to allow for “different interpretations” of the concept due to its links with China
column5: the idea being that if UCD continues to “strengthen its international engagement” and partnerships with other universities overseas
column6: it should seek to accommodate “divergent approaches to academic freedom”. After a backlash
column7: the proposed changes were withdrawn.

column1: When I was an undergraduate
column2: the president of UCD was a philosopher. The chances of such an appointment today are negligible. How old-fashioned it appears now to strive for a university that is a pleasant place in which to work and study
column3: with pride in its self-made identity and producing independent thinkers who can conserve
column4: create and transmit knowledge.

column1: There is an onus on those in humanities – as in other areas – to effectively communicate the public value of their research; the university is supposed to be a public good and those in it have responsibilities as public servants. But so do those administering education and now is the time to think about that.
From mid-March
column2: educators responded to an emergency as best they could by switching everything online to get the academic year over the line. And that seemed to be the overwhelming priority; in the same way
column3: the discourse about this year’s Leaving Cert students seemed to be solely about the exams and what course place might come after
column4: relegating discussion of the problems in the system as it stands
column5: with or without Covid-19. A Higher Education Authority Report of 2018 highlighted that one in six third-level students drops out of their course during their first year
column6: and as pointed out by Brian Mooney this week
column7: that figure is likely to increase due to the panic and uncertainty prevalent this year for those hoping to go on to third level. An acceptance
column8: or worse still
column9: embracing of remote teaching as the norm can only exacerbate that problem; students need to learn and thrive through direct engagement not only with their course material but also with their lecturers and fellow students.

column1: It is not more technology and regularising of remoteness that is needed coming out of this crisis. It is imperative that our universities are properly funded
column2: but we do not need a new obsession with what I saw this week described as “crisis-driven innovation; adaptation through technology”. The danger is that this will further entrench the notion of “delivering” rather than teaching.||1

column1: 2020-05-29||I am a postdoctoral researcher studying retinal diseases and was recently awarded a career transition grant to start my own lab. My search for a faculty position was hit by the COVID-19 pandemic. I started sending out applications in January 2020
column2: and found out in March that my planned interviews across several US states coincided with campus closures. The interviews were postponed indefinitely.

column1: I reached out to four potential employers
column2: and we agreed to conduct online interviews. Conducting a full-day interview online was new both to me and to the interviewers
column3: but over the past eight weeks
column4: I’ve got lots of hands-on experience. Here’s what I learnt.

column1: Coronavirus and COVID-19: Keep up to date
Ask for an itinerary. Just as with an in-person interview
column2: it’s important to have a sense of what your day is going to look like. I made sure I knew who I would be meeting and what they were planning to go over. Your potential employer will probably send a series of links to connect to the scheduled meetings.

column1: I made sure I had room in my itinerary to disconnect
column2: reconnect and troubleshoot technical glitches between meetings. I also scheduled breaks throughout the day
column3: and a long break for lunch to mentally disengage and stretch out. In practice
column4: this meant I had 5 minutes between every ‘back-to-back’ meeting
column5: plus 15-minute breaks every couple of hours
column6: and an hour for lunch.

column1: Test the connection. Before the interviews
column2: I asked my potential employers what videoconferencing tool they were using
column3: and downloaded the program to my computer (often there is a web version but
column4: in my experience
column5: the downloadable app tends to be more stable and come with more options). I familiarized myself with it by setting up a call with a friend so I could explore the program’s features and get input. I also asked the meeting administrator for a test session a few days before the actual interview to make sure I could share my audio
column6: video and seminar slides properly.

column1: Set up your meeting room. I was going to be sitting in the same spot for the whole interview
column2: so I made sure to choose a quiet
column3: well-lit room.

column1: As lockdowns ease
column2: you might be able to conduct the interview from your lab
column3: but if you are still at home
column4: ask those you live with to be quiet and respect your space for the day. If you go into the office or are in a shared living space
column5: put a sign on the doorknob making it clear that you shouldn’t be disturbed. If you have children or pets that might make noise
column6: let your interviewers know ahead of time. Try not to let it worry you — we’re all getting used to background noises under lockdown and your interviewers are not going to judge you on your children’s ability to keep quiet. In my case
column7: I headed into my lab
column8: following social- distancing guidelines
column9: and informed my colleagues of the interview beforehand.

column1: Prepare your environment. I was careful to adjust the camera to be at my eye level. Some meeting programs provide a virtual background or let you upload one from your desktop
column2: but I used the neutral wall in my lab because it felt more natural. I also chose to face the door to anticipate any surprise entrances. Make sure you have what you need next to you
column3: such as your itinerary
column4: a pen and paper
column5: and your CV.

column1: Embrace Murphy’s law: ‘Whatever can go wrong
column2: will go wrong.’ In my case
column3: it was the Wi-Fi signal. Halfway into a seminar
column4: I had to move to another room to find an ethernet cable and continue my presentation. It was disruptive
column5: but I hope the interviewers took it as a sign of resilience and working through unusual circumstances. If it’s an option
column6: a back-up technical plan and computer is a good idea.

column1: Dress up. In an online interview
column2: you do not have personal interaction
column3: and therefore you want to give the best impression possible through your tiny computer camera. I made sure I dressed as if I was going to meet my prospective employer in person. Professional attire has a positive impact and helped to remind me to behave in a polished manner — I’ve found it too easy to drop the professionalism in front of a webcam
column4: because you don’t feel the same social pressure you might in a face-to-face interview. Dress well from top to bottom and do not rely on the fact that the camera shows only your upper body. You might need to stand up or walk with your laptop from one room to another
column5: as I did.

column1: Communicate clearly. When I faced connection problems during my conversations and seminar
column2: I tried to explain in a calm and timely manner. I had a mobile phone on hand
column3: and had exchanged numbers with the meeting administrator in case I needed to troubleshoot problems. I tried to pause at appropriate points during my seminar
column4: to make sure everyone was following and connected. In one of the sessions
column5: I was talking to two faculty members who could see me and each other
column6: but I could not see them owing to a software glitch. I made sure to check they were still available
column7: and let them know that I could only hear them. There were other clumsy moments — often it felt like a choice between interrupting an interviewer or letting dead silence fill the air for a moment. In these moments
column8: I made sure to keep a big smile on my face and talked only after the other side had completely finished and paused for couple of seconds.

column1: Before I accept a job offer
column2: I hope I will eventually be able to visit the facilities and lab space in-person — an important consideration that can’t be solved by videoconferencing. But overall
column3: I found online interviewing much less tiring and stressful than onsite visits. I had many more opportunities to rest outside individual meetings
column4: which I wouldn’t have had in the ‘real world’. And I had none of the travel commitments that might have been burdensome before lockdown.

column1: Be prepared to be told that your potential employer will not be hiring until COVID-19 loosens its grip. Be patient
column2: positive and understanding. Remember that this is a difficult time for everyone — and your potential employers will probably do the same for you.||2

column1: There are a myriad of perceptions floating around about the future of physical workspaces and business models as a result of the lockdown and working from home (WFH). While it’s important to understand what actions other companies are considering
column2: there’s no ‘quick fix’ or ‘one size fits all’ response. What we shouldn’t do is leave it unattended and only assume that disruption will have a negative impact.

column1: The best thing organisations can do is re-discover; re-open the dialogue with their workforce (and customer base) to seek out opportunities.
At a time overcome with physical disconnection
column2: now
column3: more than ever is the time to listen. Everyone’s experience of being an employee during Covid-19 will be different. We’ve seen organisations that were once opposed to the idea of working from home

column3: understand and anticipate change. The insight will likely nod to things you already do well

column1: So

column1: If you’re not asking the right questions

column1: If we could read minds

column4: rather than measuring how employees do their work from home

column1: To close the loop

column1: It’s hard to predict the precise effects

column1: 2020-05-30||The short-run macro implications of school and childcare closures
The COVID-19 crisis has hit women’s employment particularly hard
column2: partly because the worst-hit sectors have high female employment shares
column3: but also because schools and daycare closures have forced more mothers to leave their jobs. This column looks at Germany
column4: where 26% of the workforce has children aged 14 or younger
column5: and quantifies the macroeconomic importance of working parents. If schools and daycare centres remain closed as the economy slowly reopens
column6: 11% of workers and 8% of all working hours will be lost to the labour market. Policies to restart the economy must accommodate the concerns of these families.

column1: Economies around the world are facing massive job losses – numbers in many countries are approaching those of the Great Depression in the 1930s. The unemployment rate in the US already reached 14.7% in April 2020
column2: and real-time surveys put it as high as 24% during the week of 10–16 May (Bick and Blandin 2020).

column1: Unlike in normal business cycles
column2: where fluctuations in hours are driven largely by men (Doepke and Tertilt 2016)
column3: the COVID-19 recession has hit the employment of women particularly hard – partly because sectors with high female-employment shares (such as retail and tourism) have been strongly affected
column4: but also because schools and daycare closures forced some mothers to leave their jobs (Alon et al. 2020
column5: Torrejón et al. 2020).

column1: Germany has been impressively sheltered so far. The unemployment rate in April 2020 stands at only 5.8%
column2: but employers rely massively on short-term work. Among workers employed in January
column3: 13% are either on short-term work or employed but not working
column4: as of 24 May (Blom et al. 2020)
column5: while 28% of the workforce is working fully or partly from home.

column1: We explore the labour market consequences of slowly ‘reopening’ the economy and increasing the demand for physical presence at the workplace
column2: assuming schools and childcare centres remain at least partly closed. We first report what fraction of the workforce live with children in the household and then estimate what fraction of workers have to provide childcare if schools and childcare centres do not reopen to the extent the economy does. We also estimate what fraction of total hours will be lost in the labour market and find that the macroeconomic impact due to parents’ inability to work is likely large.

column1: We use data from the 2018 European Labour Force Survey and consider all individuals aged 20 and older for the labour force. Rather than relying on detailed microdata on childcare arrangements
column2: we follow Dingel et al. (2020) and estimate what percent of the workforce is affected by school and childcare closings based on pre-crisis data on employment
column3: hours
column4: and children across households. We assume that children aged 14 or younger cannot be left unsupervised alone at home.

column1: While many behavioural responses can be expected after a large shock
column2: adjusting the presence of children in the household seems near impossible in the short-run. Further
column3: most margins that working parents use in normal times (such as hiring babysitters
column4: sharing childcare duties with neighbours and friends
column5: or relying on grandparents) are currently either explicitly banned by state law or at least highly discouraged. Thus
column6: the most likely margin of adjustment to the closures is that one adult per household will stop working.

column1: We start by looking at the share of employed workers with children aged 14 or younger in their households. Figure 1 shows that a notable proportion of the German workforce have children: one out of four employed workers (25.9%) have children at home. This number of workers is larger than the combined share of all workers in the German manufacturing and construction sector in 2019 (22.8%).
Figure 1 Childcare obligations of the employed in Germany
Comparing the first two bars in Figure 1
column2: we see that 4% of households with children also include a non-working adult (such as a non-working mother
column3: an older sibling
column4: or grandparents). Assuming that these non-working adults could take over childcare and home-schooling obligations
column5: we still find that one in five employees (21.2%) are without childcare if school and childcare centres remain closed.

column1: Next
column2: we estimate the share of workers who will be unable to work due to childcare obligations
column3: assuming that one adult will stay home in each household. This share of employed workers therefore corresponds roughly to half of the couple households plus the share of single households.

column1: In total
column2: we estimate that about 11% of workers would have to stay at home
column3: with 9% of these workers living in couple households and 2% being single parents. To put this number into perspective
column4: we compare it to the unemployment rate of 5.8% in April 2020. Even if all unemployed workers in Germany found work immediately
column5: this would just fill half the jobs potentially left vacant due to parents’ inability to work.

column1: Couples can
column2: and likely will
column3: optimise when choosing who will stay at home. Within each household with childcare obligations
column4: we identify the household member with the lowest regular hours of work and assume that this person will stay at home. This results in a total 8.4% reduction of work hours
column5: of which 6.8% stem from workers in couple households and 1.6% from single parents. Within couple households
column6: we find that in 82% of households
column7: mothers work fewer hours than fathers. Thus the majority of hours lost to the labour market will likely be in female-dominated occupations.

column1: Table 1 reports the same numbers separately for children above and below the school-entry age of 6
column2: allowing us to separately assess work hours lost due to school closures and to daycare closures. For example
column3: if schools reopen but daycare centres stay closed
column4: still 9.8% (=6.3%+3.5%) of the employed are affected in that they have no caregiver in the household. If instead daycare centres reopen but schools stay closed
column5: 15% (=11.5%+3.5%) of the employed have a childcare problem.

column1: To gauge the macroeconomic effects
column2: we compare the 8.4% lost hours to a popular policy instrument to deal with labour underutilisation
column3: namely
column4: short-time work. Short-time work programmes were prevalent during the Global Financial Crisis and are also heavily used now. In 2009
column5: more than 1.1 million workers were on short-time work with an hours’ reduction of about one-third of their working time (28.1%). In other words
column6: during the Global Financial Crisis
column7: 3.1% of all employed workers were on short-time work and their hours’ reduction accounted for 1% of total hours worked in 2009.5

column1: While these were massive programmes
column2: the numbers are dwarfed by parents’ likely reduction in work hours during the current crisis. Based on the numbers in Table 1
column3: we estimate that close to four times as many workers and more than eight times the share of hours would be lost due to parents’ inability to work due to childcare obligations.

column1: Even if we overestimate the share of affected hours – because some children can stay alone for some time
column2: some parents can work from home while simultaneously taking care of their children
column3: or some other childcare arrangements like sharing between families or involving grandparents are used – it is clear that the impact of the childcare and school closings on hours worked is large. Most of the reduction of hours will likely come from women.

column1: From a macroeconomic perspective
column2: the labour supply of parents who would have to stay home if economic activity fully resumes but schools and childcare facilities remain closed is massive. We estimate the share of affected employed workers to be close to twice the number of all unemployed workers in Germany
column3: and their share in hours worked is eight times the work reduction due to short-time work during the Global Financial Crisis.

column1: While we acknowledge that workers might find creative solutions to organise childcare to best deal with this situation
column2: the macroeconomic labour-supply effects are still so large that policy seems well advised to take parents’ labour-market situation into account when developing plans for restarting the economy.
