column5: we’ll be in a remarkably different place.”

column1: But other researchers say that in-person conferences will once again dominate after the threat of COVID-19 has faded. For them
column2: in-person meetings offer too many opportunities that virtual meetings can’t replicate.

column1: Estimates of the carbon cost of conferences vary
column2: but range from 0.5 to 2 or more tonnes of carbon dioxide per participant in travel alone. If each of the estimated 7.8 million researchers in the world travelled to one conference every year
column3: the lower bound of the annual carbon emissions would be roughly equivalent to those of some small nations.

column1: Sputnik moment or budget breaker: How will the pandemic alter research funding?
Before the pandemic
column2: many scientific societies had already begun exploring how to make virtual participation available for researchers who were unable or unwilling to travel. When the crisis hit
column3: it forced them to speed up existing discussions and timelines. “We were going to start out with smaller meetings
column4: ” says Hunter Clemens
column5: director of meetings at the APS. Instead
column6: the society scrambled to move its annual April meeting online in a matter of weeks. Despite the accelerated timeline
column7: Clemens says
column8: the virtual meeting was “something amazing”.

column1: That gathering
column2: which took place on 18–21 April
column3: drew more than 7
column4: 000 registrants — about four times more than its in-person attendance in a normal year
column5: says Clemens. And almost all of them — around 96% — logged on to the conference at some point. The virtual sessions
column6: on average
column7: had higher attendance than in-person ones at standard APS April conferences.

column1: Attendees say that virtual meetings are better in certain respects. Submitting questions online through moderated chats
column2: for example
column3: can help graduate students to feel less intimidated and allow scientists to formulate better queries. At the annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research in April
column4: the ability of the audience to vote on questions in real time “resulted in a higher quality of question”

column6: a cancer researcher at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York City.

column1: Universities will never be the same after the coronavirus crisis
Adam Tidball

column1: The economics of online meetings are different from those of conventional ones. Clemens estimates that the virtual April meeting cost only about 45% of the equivalent in-person conference

column1: But the shift to online meetings could shrink one of the major revenue streams for societies

column4: ” says Świgoń

Anthony Watkinson

column1: Among many scientists

column1: 2020-06-02||Queries about employment rights to free legal advice centres have almost doubled since the start of the pandemic.

Figures from the Free Legal Advice Centres (Flacs) and Community Law and Mediation (CLM) indicate a surge in the number of people concerned their employers have treated them illegally during the lockdown.
The CLM
column2: which runs two community law centres
column3: in Dublin and Limerick
column4: has seen a 196 per cent increase in consultations since March on employment law – including breaches of contract
column5: unequal treatment and difficulty accessing payments – compared with the same period last year.

column1: Rose Wall
column2: CLM chief executive
column3: said the organisation had increased its usual four clinics a week to 11
column4: by phone
column5: in response to calls from workers.

column1: Flac
column2: which provides clinics across the State
column3: said employment law queries accounted for 10 per cent of its calls in April 2019 but this doubled to 20 per cent last month.

column1: In March it had 126 calls to its phone-in clinics about workers’ rights
column2: rising to 180 in April.

column1: Among its cases were: a woman who was asked to go on maternity leave early; people with underlying health conditions being told they must return to work despite their concerns for their own health; people being told to take paid annual leave
column2: when they needed it for future commitments; and people being asked to resign as they could not work from home due to childcare problems.

column1: Other cases involved people having their pay reduced while working from home or being told they must use their own phones and laptops while working from home
column2: without recompense.

column1: Other significant calls included women returning from work after maternity leave
column2: or who were about to take such leave.

column1: Other queries were from workers feeling their employers had not taken sufficient health and safety measures

column3: with no personal protective equipment provided.

column1: Ms Wall said while the impact of coronavirus on businesses was “unprecedented”
column2: it could not be used as a time to be lax about employees’ rights.

column1: “People are feeling overwhelmed and vulnerable to the added complexities that Covid-19 brings to the workforce. With the number of people unemployed or supported under the temporary wage subsidy scheme now at about 1.1million

column1: Eilis Barry
column2: chief executive of Flac
column3: said callers were “extremely stressed”. Both organisations said the number of employment-related calls was likely to increase as more people returned
column4: or hoped to return
column5: to work.

column1: This underlined “the acute need for the availability and accessibility of legal advice
column2: advocacy and legal aid during a crisis
column3: ” said Ms Barry
column4: reiterating her call for a reform of the civil legal aid system.

column1: “We must protect our workers and ensure that legal aid is accessible to all
column2: ” she said.

column1: Employment rights are not currently covered by the civil legal aid scheme.

column1: 2020-06-02||After two years of planning

column3: the only detail of its presidency plan to survive is the logo: an endless loop known as a “Möbius strip”. You can create one by taking a tape-like strip of material
column4: giving one end a short twist and fusing both ends. What makes a Möbius strip interesting is how two lines
column5: sent off in different sides and on opposite sides
column6: eventually meet. For Germany this phenomenon reflects how
column7: in the EU
column8: 27 sovereign states’ divergent positions eventually converge.

column1: Chancellor Angela Merkel will need something far stronger than Möbius strips to get her through to Christmas. Last week
column2: with characteristically laconic understatement
column3: she suggested the pandemic would require “considerable adjustment” to Germany’s EU presidency plans. German civil servants know that
column4: culturally speaking
column5: busking is not their speciality. But they are being led by a woman who
column6: in her 15 years in power

column1: The EU’s rolling schedule meant this was already going to be a crucial presidency

column4: treats politics as a long-term laboratory experiment: when new information comes in
column5: the procedures are adapted
column6: the experiment is adjusted and run again.

column1: With an eye on her political legacy

column3: health
column4: migration

column1: As Merkel’s fourth and final term enters its last year

2020-06-02||Worries about the impact of COVID-19 on pregnant mothers and their offspring are wide-spread. As a comparison
column2: the Spanish Flu pandemic had devastating health impacts on pregnant mothers and in-utero exposure to influenza is known to have negative short- and long-term consequences for children. This column
column3: however
column4: argues that the existing evidence from the COVID-19 pandemic allows for cautious optimism about the impacts of COVID-19 on pregnant women and their children.

column1: More than 2.5 million women are currently pregnant in the United States
column2: and many are worried about the impact a COVID-19 infection might have on mothers and the development of their unborn children. A large literature surrounding the foetal origins hypothesis has shown that pregnancy conditions not only impact the mother but can also impair the offspring (Almond and Currie 2011). Maternal influenza infections during pregnancy may induce premature birth (Currie and Schwandt 2013) and strong cases may even impair foetal development to the point where repercussions throughout adulthood are observed (Schwandt 2019). In his seminal paper
column3: Almond (2006) documented lower incomes and higher adult disability rates among the entire cohort of infants that was in-utero during the Spanish Flu pandemic.

column1: What about children born during the COVID-19 pandemic?
While at this moment it is still unclear whether maternal COVID-19 infections impair foetal development
column2: the existing evidence allows for cautious optimism. The rate of reported COVID-19 deaths among pregnant mothers is low (Hantoushzadeh et al. 2020) and while infections occur in pregnant mothers
column3: most are mild or remain asymptomatic (Sutton et al. 2020
column4: Luo and Yin 2020). Children of mothers infected with COVID-19 during pregnancy are born without detectable impairments and typically test negative for the virus (Chen et al. 2020; Yu et al. 2020).

column1: However
column2: it is too early to know whether in-utero exposure to COVID-19 has negative long-term consequences that are not immediately visible at birth. A potential reference point is the Spanish Flu pandemic (Aassve et al. 2020
column3: Benmelech and Frydman 2020). However
column4: it is important to keep in mind that the 1918 influenza virus had a very different
column5: more devastating impact – particularly for pregnant mothers. Figure 1 compares the age profile of COVID-19 mortality in New York City with Spanish Flu mortality in Philadelphia
column6: one of the hardest hit cities during the Spanish Flu pandemic (Markel et al. 2007). Both mortality rates are shown per 100
column7: 000 people
column8: but are plotted on different y-axes since COVID-19 deaths rates are likely to continue increasing in the ongoing pandemic.

column1: Figure 1 COVID-19 mortality (in NYC) and Spanish Flu mortality (in Philadelphia) by age and gender
Notes: Data on COVID-19 death counts for New York City
column2: 1 February 2020-20 May 2020 (CDC 2020)
column3: combined with population estimates for 2017 (NYSDH 2017). Data on Spanish Flu mortality from Rogers (1920).

column1: COVID-19 mortality increases exponentially with age
column2: with extremely low death rates among infants
column3: children
column4: and young adults (these numbers include recent cases of multi-system inflammatory syndrome
column5: Schroeder 2020). Mortality is particularly low for young women. Among a total of 16
column6: 493 COVID-19 deaths in New York City (between 1 February 2020 and 20 May 2020)
column7: not a single female fatality occurred below age 25. For women between the ages of 25 and 34
column8: only five out of every 100
column9: 000 have died —and this figure is far lower than the rate for women 65 or older
column10: where the data show more than 740 deaths per 100

column1: For the Spanish Flu
column2: the age profile of deaths looked dramatically different. Fatalities were highly concentrated among infants and young adults. Among women
column3: the majority of deaths occurred in the fertile age range and mortality was especially high among pregnant women (Almond 2006). For every death
column4: there were many cases of severe illness
column5: with recorded stillbirths more than doubling during the pandemic (Rogers 1920).

column1: In other words
column2: pregnant mothers who survived the Spanish Flu experienced extreme levels of sickness in response to influenza infections during the pandemic. This strong impact could not be more different from the current experience with COVID-19 infections
column3: which often go largely unnoticed in pregnant mothers. This brings us to the last question in assessing the relative risks between the two pandemics for a developing fetus:

column1: Are mothers’ mild responses to COVID-19 infections good or bad for an infant in utero?
Strong maternal reactions observed for influenza infections may drain the mother’s body
column2: but they could be an efficient response
column3: e.g. to protect the fetus from contracting the virus itself.

column1: However
column2: it turns out that the fetus does not usually get infected if the pregnant mother contracts an influenza virus or the COVID-19 virus (i.e. the virus does not pass the placenta). Hence
column3: it is the strong maternal response to the influenza virus that impairs foetal development. A strong immune system response of the mother can lead to broad inflammations in the pregnant body (McDade 2012) which fight not only the virus but also damage healthy tissue such as the placenta. Pregnant womens’ mild immune system response to COVID-19 is
column4: therefore
column5: a hopeful sign.

column1: Strong inflammations are also hypothesized to turn the mother’s immune system itself against the fetus. The father’s genes in the fetus are foreign to the mother’s body and are only tolerated due to the mediation of helper cells surrounding the placenta (Trowsdale and Betz 2006). A strong inflammatory response can compromise the functionality of these helper cells. As a result
column2: the fetus might not only suffer from the inflammation itself
column3: but an inflammation can actually cause the mother’s immune system to harm the fetus. It remains unclear why pregnancy makes women respond so strongly to the influenza virus (Kay et al. 2014)
column4: but it has been observed both for pandemics and seasonal influenza. Further
column5: the resulting infections have similar negative impacts on the offspring – both at birth as well as into adulthood (Almond 2006
column6: Creanga et al. 2009
column7: Currie and Schwandt 2013
column8: Schwandt 2019).

column1: It is important to emphasize that our understanding of the threats of COVID-19 is still far from complete. We are learning from new research findings on a daily basis. But there is room for cautious optimism from what we know so far: COVID-19 seems to impact pregnant women less than influenza does. While immune system responses triggered by maternal influenza have been shown to impair foetal development
column2: COVID-19 does not seem to cause such strong responses in mothers’ immune systems. Of course
column3: it is still possible that other impairments in the offspring may appear later
column4: even if they are not observable at birth. And only time will tell whether infants exposed to COVID-19 during the first or second trimester will show signs of impairment at birth. But
column5: so far
column6: the existing evidence allows for cautious hope that pregnant mothers and their offspring will fare much better during COVID-19 than they did during the last devastating global pandemic at the turn of the 20th century.

column1: This is not to say that pregnant mothers and young children are entirely unaffected by the current pandemic. Food insecurity is on the rise (Schanzenbach and Pitts 2020)
column2: and many young families face financial stress as unemployment is soaring to unprecedented levels (Conti 2020). Nutritional
column3: economic
column4: and psychological stress during pregnancy is detrimental for the fetus as it increases the risk of poor health at birth which may in turn lead to negative long-term consequences (Aizer et al. 2016 Almond et al. 2011
column5: Persson and Rossin-Slater 2018). Hence
column6: we do not want to add unfounded anxieties about COVID-19 infections to mothers’ list of worries—as fewer worries might help their developing infants most.

column4: by contrast

column3: many small businesses continue to experience significantly reduced turnover. This column reports on a firm-level analysis across 16 emerging markets
column4: and three Western European comparator countries
column5: in order to gauge the potential risks associated with debt-driven COVID-19 support. The overall goal is to prevent a wave of bankruptcies that could break valuable relationships between firms and their suppliers and employees. However
column6: liquidity support in the form of additional bank lending may create debt-overhang problems in the future and therefore requires careful targeting.

column1: Over the past decade
column2: corporate leverage has increased considerably in many developing countries and emerging markets
column3: often exacerbating financial fragility (Alfaro et al. 2019). Policymakers who aim to alleviate corporate cash shortages during the COVID-19 pandemic therefore need to avoid overloading financially vulnerable firms with more debt. This risk is real given that the most popular method of COVID-19 support to SMEs has been to provide these firms with more loans. To gauge the potential risks associated with debt-driven COVID-19 support
column4: this column reports on a firm-level analysis across 16 emerging markets
column5: and three Western European comparator countries. Our objective is to understand where ‘small and medium-sized enterprises’ (SMEs) are most in need of cash and liquidity and
column6: second
column7: where these firms still have room on their balance sheet to take on more debt. Where there is little or no such room
column8: further bank lending may come at the risk of a structural weakening of banks’ balance sheets (Galí 2020).

column1: Our analysis is based on a firm-level dataset that combines information from surveys conducted as part of the latest round of the EBRD-EIB-World Bank Enterprise Surveys (with data from Orbis). We use these data to estimate regression models of firms’ optimal capital structure or leverage (defined as formal debt to total assets) and
column2: separately
column3: their cash holdings (defined as cash and cash equivalents to total assets). The models clarify how firms’ pre-COVID-19 capital structures and cash buffers can be explained by basic firm characteristics such as their size
column4: profitability
column5: asset tangibility
column6: turnover variability
column7: and industry.

column1: Using these simple models
column2: we then calculate for each country how much the average small business’s cash buffer falls short of (or exceeds) the predicted cash buffer. Likewise
column3: we measure the available capacity for additional debt of the average SME (firms with 250 or fewer employees) in each country. Figure 1 summarises these calculations. The horizontal axis shows how SME cash holdings in countries such as Croatia
column4: Lithuania
column5: Morocco
column6: Serbia
column7: Slovenia
column8: and Ukraine fall short of the predicted value by between 3-7% of total assets. In contrast
column9: the average small business in Bulgaria
column10: Czech Republic
column11: Latvia
column12: Montenegro
column13: and Slovak Republic has greater than predicted cash buffers.

Source: Authors’ calculations based on data from ES and Orbis.
The vertical axis of figure 1 shows where small firms (on average) still have the capacity to borrow more. For instance
column2: this is the case in countries like Lithuania
column3: Morocco
column4: and Ukraine (countries where SMEs seem to have an urgent need for more liquidity)
column5: as well as in Bulgaria
column6: Montenegro
column7: and Slovak Republic (countries with excess cash). In contrast
column8: in countries such as Bosnia and Herzegovina
column9: Croatia
column10: and Slovenia (as well as Portugal
column11: ) there appears to be (on average) little room for more debt. It should be noted that even the average SME in many of these countries appears to have had limited liquidity buffers at the time pandemic first broke out.

column1: Next
column2: using the same models
column3: we calculate for each country the proportion of SMEs that operate with lower than predicted cash buffers as well as the proportion of SMEs that entered the COVID-19 pandemic with relatively ample cash reserves. Likewise
column4: for each country we calculate the proportion of SMEs that had little room for additional debt
column5: and the proportion of SMEs that still appear in a position to absorb more debt. Figure 2 summarises these results. More than 60% of SMEs in Morocco and Ukraine are both short on cash and have room to take on extra debt. In contrast
column6: we again see high shares of small businesses in Bosnia and Herzegovina
column7: Croatia
column8: Serbia
column9: and Slovenia that are short on cash but are already highly leveraged. Estonia and Poland are similar in that about a third of all SMEs are short on cash but already have borrowed a lot.

column1: Figure 2 Distribution of small businesses by pre-Covid-19 debt and cash structure
Source: Authors’ calculations based on data from ES and Orbis.
How long can small businesses survive with their existing cash buffers? As a rough indicator
column2: we calculate the number of months that a small business can afford to pay its employees out of its existing cash reserves. We then plot the distribution of businesses by different ‘survival horizons’ in Chart 3. About half of all small businesses in Ukraine have cash reserves of less than one month’s wages. Only around 20% of Ukrainian SMEs have the liquidity to pay more than six months’ wages. Similarly
column3: most small businesses in Montenegro
column4: Russia
column5: Lithuania
column6: and Slovenia were likely to run out of cash reserves to pay their workers in less than two months.

column1: Where can credit access relieve liquidity constraints the most? Figure 3 also shows how the share of small businesses with liquidity constraints would change were they to ‘load up’ on debt to a level that our model would predict is normal (given their other firm characteristics). This shows
column2: for instance
column3: that additional lending to Ukrainian SMEs could decrease the share of businesses with cash buffers that only cover up to one month of wages from 50% to 20%.

column1: Source: Authors’ calculations based on data from ES and Orbis.
Our empirical analysis is rudimentary in the sense that it disregards certain firm- and country-specific determinants of corporate debt and cash buffers. Notwithstanding
column2: the analysis provides a straightforward and micro-founded ‘traffic light system’. This can help diagnose in which countries firms’ needs for liquidity are most dire
column3: and (as importantly) in which countries these temporary cash shortages can safely be alleviated through more debt funding. For instance
column4: in countries like Bosnia and Herzegovina
column5: Croatia
column6: and Slovenia
column7: there appear to be a relatively large number of firms in need of liquidity but there are also many firms that are already highly indebted. In such countries
column8: efforts to support cash-strapped firms may take the following into consideration:

column1: • Decisions about whether to alleviate cash shortages through additional bank lending should ideally continue to be based on a case-by-case assessment of individual firms’ debt capacity. This in turn requires a view on whether the business was performing well before the pandemic
column2: or already had issues. Business exit remains an essential part of the process of creative destruction.

column1: • Where possible
column2: lending programs should require participating banks to make full use of existing credit bureaus and registries to ensure a complete picture of total outstanding debt. This holds in particular for emerging markets with a history of episodes of excessive private sector borrowing
column3: and where information sharing among lenders has proven beneficial (De Haas et al. 2020).

column1: • In countries where few firms have spare debt capacity
column2: SMEs may be better served by government-sponsored initiatives to roll over existing debt rather than to provide fresh debt. This may include temporary debt moratoriums and loan-maturity extensions.

column1: • On a structural level
column2: many emerging markets will need to gradually rebalance their financial systems towards a greater use of equity instruments and a reduced reliance on debt (EBRD 2015). In the short term
column3: interesting proposals have been made for a European Pandemic Equity Fund (Boot et al. 2020). Such a fund would provide cash-strapped SMEs with cash flow injections in return for
column4: for instance
column5: a surcharge on future corporate tax payments. In the medium term
column6: governments and (multi-)national development banks can play a proactive role in stimulating a public and private equity culture in emerging markets (for instance through improving research coverage and hence transparency of listed SMEs). As part of the COVID-19 response
column7: financial resilience can further be rebuilt by selective equity investments in financially sound
column8: high-growth
column9: and innovative small businesses with strong management already in place. Lastly
column10: in the long run
column11: policy makers could structurally reduce tax-code favouritism towards debt (for instance
column12: by giving firms equivalent tax benefits for equity and debt).

column1: Equateur Province experienced an EVD outbreak with 54 cases and 33 deaths
column2: reported between 8 May 2018 through 24 July 2018. This is the eleventh outbreak of EVD reported in the Democratic Republic of the Congo since the virus was discovered in 1976.

column1: In the context of the current COVID-19 outbreak

column1: WHO

column1: The laboratory capacity in Mbandaka is being assessed and support is on-going for appropriate set-up and additional supplies. WHO did not receive adequate EVD funding since the start of 2020

The investigations are ongoing to assess the full extent of the outbreak and therefore high vigilance should be maintained. This information will help define the risk in the coming days.
WHO advises the following risk reduction measures as an effective way to reduce Ebola virus disease transmission in humans:

• Reducing the risk of wildlife-to-human transmission from contact with infected fruit bats or monkeys/apes and the consumption of their raw meat. Animals should be handled with gloves and other appropriate protective clothing. Animal products (blood and meat) should be thoroughly cooked before consumption.
• Reducing the risk of human-to-human transmission from direct or close contact with people with Ebola symptoms
column2: particularly with their bodily fluids. Gloves and appropriate personal protective equipment should be worn when taking care of ill patients at home. Regular hand washing is required after visiting patients in hospital
column3: as well as after taking care of patients at home.

column1: • Reducing the risk of possible sexual transmission
column2: based on further analysis of ongoing research and consideration by the WHO Advisory Group on the Ebola Virus Disease Response
column3: WHO recommends that male survivors of EVD practice safe sex and hygiene for 12 months from onset of symptoms or until their semen tests negative twice for Ebola virus. Contact with body fluids should be avoided and washing with soap and water is recommended. WHO does not recommend isolation of male or female convalescent patients whose blood has been tested negative for Ebola virus.

column1: • Continue training and re-training of health work force for early detection
column2: isolation and treatment of EVD cases.

column1: 2020-06-03||COVID-19 has laid bare the weaknesses of clinical diagnostics infrastructures. Underfunded
column2: undervalued and underprepared
column3: laboratory testing has been overwhelmed by the contagion. A combination of low reimbursement
column4: low margins
column5: low capacity and low investment has stifled innovation and competition. Cost-cutting
column6: centralization and regulatory rigidity have created backlogs and slowed the tracking of infections. Given the pivotal role of diagnostics in healthcare decision-making
column7: COVID-19 shows just how much clinical testing needs a radical rethink.

column1: On May 28
column2: the United States achieved a record 416
column3: 664 tests for SARS-CoV-2 in one day (around one test per thousand people per day). The United Kingdom
column4: France
column5: Spain and much of the rest of Europe are testing at a similar level. Given that only ~3
column6: 000 tests are carried out per day during a typical flu season
column7: we are approaching the limit of testing capacity using existing clinical laboratories and supply chains. But it is nowhere near the level needed for countries to contain COVID-19 while reopening their economies.

column1: According to the World Health Organization
column2: if more than 10% of results come back positive
column3: testing capacity is insufficient; test positivity higher than 10% means many active infections are being missed. Nobel laureate economist Paul Romer has suggested 30 million daily tests are needed to reach the 10% positivity threshold in the United States. The Rockefeller Foundation Testing Action Plan projects 5 million tests by early June
column4: growing to 20 million in the following four months. Even the lowest estimates suggest 750
column6: 000 molecular tests will be needed every day — more than double what is presently available.

column1: The massive scale of testing now needed is a result of government failure at the beginning of the outbreak to quickly implement testing
column2: tracking and tracing measures — together with social distancing — to limit the community spread of SARS-CoV-2. In those countries where lockdown was decisive and stringent tracking and tracing procedures were put in place — Taiwan
column3: South Korea
column4: Hong Kong and Singapore — subsequent massive testing has been unnecessary.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: failed lockdowns and slipshod testing have gone hand in hand. In the United States
column3: the Centers for Disease Control botched its test rollout and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) dithered on Emergency Use Authorizations (EUAs)
column4: vacillating between oversight that was too stringent for RT-PCR testing and too lax for serological testing. The United Kingdom abandoned broad testing and contact tracing in March
column5: then reversed its policy. France planned widespread testing at the end of March
column6: then gave up on diagnostic testing when it became clear its clinical testing infrastructure couldn’t deliver.

column1: The shrinking number of public labs
column2: along with their centralization
column3: has meant results can take days if not weeks to come back — useless for tracking and tracing. France has only 45 testing labs; the United States just 97 public labs
column4: with a commercial sector dominated by corporate giants like Quest Diagnostics and LabCorp. Germany stands apart
column5: with a robust infrastructure of 20 national reference centers
column6: around 40 ‘consultant laboratories’ and hundreds of hospital- and clinic-based local testing centers. Results from the extended network are coordinated through a computer system adapted from Germany’s Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance network; Heidelberg even has a ‘corona taxi’ program that transports medics in protective gear to check on patients in their homes.

column1: In contrast
column2: testing in the United States is a mess. With shambolic coordination at the national level
column3: existing providers have become swamped
column4: testing backlogs have lengthened and shortages of swabs
column5: supplies and reagents have grown. As traditional labs failed to ramp up
column6: several research centers and hubs have stepped in and retooled to provide semi-automated ‘pop up’ labs for COVID-19
column7: working with regulatory authorities and partnering with clinically accredited labs to innovate around reagent shortages. One open-source effort recently won an FDA EUA for processing >10
column8: 000 samples per day using automated loop-mediated isothermal amplification
column9: circumventing RT-PCR reagent shortages and aiming to provide results in 24 hours. Another idea is to use multiplexing schemes and next-generation sequencing to pool thousands of bar-coded COVID-19 samples and then triage down to confirmatory testing for the identification of individual positives — an approach that enabled Wuhan
column10: China to test 6.5 million people in 9 days.

column1: Whatever technology is adopted
column2: with tests in such short supply
column3: strategic deployment to hotspots will be important in combination with contact tracing: clinical centers
column4: essential services
column5: travel hubs
column6: nursing homes
column7: meat-packing plants and places of congregation (bars
column8: nightclubs or religious gatherings) will remain priorities
column9: with drive-thru testing provided as an adjunct.

column1: During reopening
column2: testing volume will most likely be built by employers. Symptom reporting and contact-tracing apps built on Apple and Google’s API will be used to identify workers to prioritize for testing (Drexel University and Baylor College already offer such an app). Ultimately
column3: kits for doctors’ offices and at-home testing will become available
column4: some perhaps even using CRISPR technology
column5: like those from Mammoth Biosciences or Sherlock Biosciences.

column1: The failure of the clinical diagnostic sector to deal with the demands of a 21st century pandemic is a wake-up call. The traditional players appear incapable of innovating around the problem — probably because innovation is alien in an environment where reimbursement cuts by the 2014 Protecting Access to Medicare Act
column2: erosion of intellectual property protection
column3: and a lack of regulatory clarity has depressed profit margins and stunted investment.

column1: But infectious disease is not going away. And in an increasingly interconnected
column2: urbanized and globalized world
column3: COVID-19 has shown that present lab testing systems are clearly unfit for purpose. A reinvigoration of new ideas and new technology is urgently needed to put diagnostics back at the forefront of twenty-first-century medicine and pandemic prevention.||1

column1: 2020-06-04||Jonathan Cotliar knew he was ahead of the curve four years ago when he joined Science 37
column2: a company that supports virtual clinical trials conducted mostly online. The firm in Los Angeles
column3: California
column4: was growing slowly before March
column5: receiving about a dozen calls a week from potential clients. But since the COVID-19 pandemic began
column6: Science 37 has been running at fever pitch.

column1: Cotliar
column2: the company’s chief medical officer
column3: says Science 37 now receives hundreds of enquiries every week from potential clients
column4: such as pharmaceutical companies
column5: medical centres and even individual investigators. With hospitals forming the epicentres of COVID-19 outbreaks around the world
column6: clinical-trial participants have become reluctant to attend routine check-ups and monitoring
column7: and health-care workers are stretched beyond their capacity. This has caused researchers to put many clinical trials on hold or to shift to a virtual trial structure by performing consultations online and collecting as much paperwork and data as possible remotely.

column1: The pandemic might hasten the kind of change in clinical trials that Cotliar and Science 37 were hoping to make anyway. And there could be other lasting effects on drug development: companies that are usually competitors are now collaborating
column2: and many are trying to make their supply chains more robust to deal with disruption. Some researchers and companies in the drug-development field say the system might never be the same again.

column1: The pandemic has touched nearly all aspects of the industry
column2: says Kenneth Kaitin
column3: director of the Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development in Boston
column4: Massachusetts. “This has really turned upside down the whole drug-development process
column5: ” he says. “The entire investigative world is focused just on developing treatments for COVID-19.”

column1: Scientists’ worlds will shrink in the wake of the pandemic
Some changes are likely to be temporary
column2: Kaitin predicts. Drug regulators in the United States and other countries have acted fast to approve clinical trials of therapies and allow new uses of existing medicines to fight COVID-19
column3: without demanding as much data and paperwork as they normally would. Such changes are likely to stick only for as long as the outbreak lasts. “The flexibilities that are being granted for clinical-trial development are being granted under the auspices of a public-health declaration
column4: ” says Esther Krofah
column5: executive director of FasterCures
column6: a Washington DC think tank. “That
column7: to me
column8: is very much an emergency operation.”

column1: And Kaitin points out that these changes shave only a few months off the drug-development timeline — crucial in the middle of a pandemic
column2: but unlikely to make a significant dent in the lengthy process of developing a therapy
column3: which can stretch out over years.

column1: The pandemic could catalyse lasting change in other ways. What might linger
column2: Krofah says
column3: is the culture of collaboration across government
column4: industry and academia that has emerged during the outbreak. “We have traditional competitors working together in new ways
column5: ” she says. An alliance of more than a dozen companies — including Gilead in Foster City
column6: California
column7: Novartis in Basel
column8: Switzerland
column9: and WuXi AppTec in Shanghai
column10: China — has been working to discover and test antiviral treatments by sharing data about early results and basic science
column11: as well as collaborating on designs for clinical trials. If these group efforts bear fruit
column12: they might continue
column13: says Krofah.

column1: Pharmaceutical companies might also make long-lasting adjustments to their supply chains
column2: says David Simchi-Levi
column3: who studies operations management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. Over the past few decades
column4: drug makers have increasingly shifted their manufacturing away from the United States and Europe to countries such as India and China
column5: which can produce the drugs at lower cost. But over the past few years
column6: many firms have begun to look for ways to diversify their supplies of services and raw materials
column7: to reduce the risk of supply interruptions in the event of a US–China trade war
column8: says Simchi-Levi. The coronavirus outbreak could accelerate that trend. “Some shocks were anticipated
column9: but not at this scale
column10: ” says Krofah. “This is going to cause a fundamental re-examination of that risk.”

column1: Momentum for a shift towards virtual clinical trials has been gradually building for years. But progress had been hindered by a lack of clear guidance from regulators such as the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and a reluctance to invest in the technology needed to run such trials — until the pandemic hit
column2: says Cotliar. Companies such as Science 37 are suddenly seeing their popularity skyrocket. “It’s exponentially accelerated the adoption curve of what we were already doing
column3: ” Cotliar says. “That’s been a bit surreal.”

column1: At the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis
column2: for example
column3: infectious-disease specialist David Boulware and his colleagues conducted a randomized
column4: controlled
column5: virtual trial of the malaria drug hydroxychloroquine to find out whether it can protect people who are at high risk of contracting COVID-19. The trial
column6: which included more than 800 people and found the treatment had no benefit (D. R. Boulware et al. N. Engl. J. Med. http://doi.org/dxkv; 2020)
column7: sent participants medicine by FedEx delivery and monitored their health remotely.

column1: Patient advocates have long pushed for more virtual trials
column2: which ease the burden of clinical-trial participation. If the trend catches on
column3: it could speed up the enrolment of participants — a significant piece of the drug-development timeline.

column1: And now that the pandemic has driven medical centres to set up much-needed technology
column2: and forced the FDA to release guidelines for virtual trials during the pandemic

column1: 2020-06-04||In mid-March
column2: just after restrictions were put in place to slow the spread COVID-19
column3: Dr Nigel Stevenson looked out the window of his Dublin apartment. “It was a beautiful
column4: still evening
column5: the sun was setting and there was no traffic on the roads. It was idyllic
column6: ” he recalls. “Then I remembered why it was so quiet
column7: and I thought... that damn virus.”

column1: Stevenson
column2: who leads the Viral Immunology Lab in Trinity’s Biomedical Sciences Institute
column3: knows more about “that damn virus” than most. For more than a decade he has been working on disease-causing viruses
column4: including HIV
column5: Hepatitis C and
column6: more recently
column7: the coronaviruses SARS-CoV-1 (from the outbreak in the early 2000s) and MERS (from the outbreak in 2012). Now he has turned his lab’s attention to the pandemic virus
column8: SARS-CoV-2.

column1: His interest? The biochemical dance between an invading virus and the human cell it seeks to hijack
column2: and how understanding those interactions could help us design new therapies to stop infection.

column1: “Some viruses
column2: including the one that causes Covid-19
column3: can hide from our immune systems early in the infection
column4: and they can really get entrenched
column5: ” he explains. “By understanding how they do that
column6: we could potentially bring the viruses out of hiding and help the immune system to clear the infection early on. That would lead to less disease.”

column1: When the SARS-CoV-2 virus – that causes Covid-19 – gets into our airways
column2: it enters our cells and ejects its genetic material
column3: co-opting the infected cell into making copies of the virus
column4: which then go on to infect other cells.

column1: One way our body defends us against this takeover is by releasing a substance called interferon
column2: Stevenson explains. “Interferon is a really powerful defender
column3: because it activates hundreds of other genes and proteins that effectively stop the virus in its tracks.”

column1: But some viruses can interfere with the interferon response. Stevenson and his Trinity College Dublin colleague Prof Cliona O’Farrelly have previously shown the Hepatitis C virus can block a particular pathway of biochemical signals inside the cell
column2: thereby stopping the cell from “telling” interferon to ramp up the molecular defences. “We could see that the virus degraded this biochemical pathway inside liver and immune cells
column3: ” explains Stevenson. “And this blockade meant the body wasn’t able to switch on its normal defences against the virus.”

column1: Stevenson has found other viruses use a similar mechanism to block responses to interferon
column2: among them HIV. “We have been able to show that HIV-1 stops interferon too
column3: ” he says. “And we are looking at ways to prevent HIV-1 from doing that
column4: and thereby restore the natural interferon response.”

column1: Then
column2: last year
column3: in a case of spectacularly good timing
column4: PhD student
column5: Yamei Zhang
column6: in Stevenson’s lab started to look at the effect of the original SARS and MERS coronaviruses on the Interferon response. “Our ongoing studies are showing that both the SARS-1 and MERS viruses use a conserved mechanism to block interferon
column7: ” Stevenson adds.

column1: When Covid-19 became a serious public health concern
column2: the researchers also turned their attention to SARS-CoV-2. Their analysis of the pandemic virus genome indicates that it too may use this process to suppress response to interferon
column3: as it has a similar interferon-blocking code to the one Stevenson’s lab has studied in its coronavirus “cousins”.

column1: “We are now studying this
column2: because if this is one way through which SARS-CoV-2 evades our immune system
column3: then it’s good news for our battle against this deadly virus
column4: ” says Stevenson. “Our lab is already working on ways to restore interferon’s biochemical pathway
column5: so now we can apply these research discoveries to the pandemic virus too.”

column1: Another difficulty in Covid-19 is that when the immune system does respond to the virus later in the infection
column2: it can over-respond in some people
column3: damaging their lungs and other organs. Prof Andrew Bowie
column4: also at Trinity
column5: is trying to figure out the pathway to this response.

column1: Like Stevenson
column2: he has found himself in a good position to focus on SARS-CoV-2. “Last year
column3: we started working with RNA viruses that affect the airways
column4: trying to understand how these viruses trigger an immune response in lung cells
column5: ” Bowie says. “And now we can pivot that work to look at how the RNA virus SARS-CoV-2 does this.”

column1: Bowie
column2: along with O’Farrelly and Prof Luke O’Neill
column3: are part of a European project called INITIATE
column4: which explores how disease-causing viruses interact with human cells growing in the lab.

column1: “We are looking at how the airway cells react to the viruses when they meet them
column2: and the kind of inflammatory immune response that follows
column3: ” explains Bowie. “We and others have already discovered that viruses prompt a different kind of immune response in lung cells compared to the response we see to bacteria. Now we can look at how the inflammatory immune response gets switched on specifically in response to SARS-CoV-2
column4: and what pathways are involved. It’s a good example of how answering a basic biological question will shed light about what is going on in patients who experience this kind of immune activation in Covid-19.”

column1: Ultimately
column2: we want the answers to those biological questions to translate into better ways to prevent or treat Covid-19. Dr Virginie Gautier at University College Dublin is marshalling her lab’s resources to screen for such answers. Her expertise lies in host-virus interactions
column3: and now she has re-oriented her lab to look at SARS-CoV-2.

column1: “We are interested in the ways that cells respond biochemically to viruses
column2: so that we can identify points of vulnerability that could be targeted by drugs
column3: ” explains Gautier
column4: who is a principal investigator at the UCD Centre for Experimental Pathogen Host Research. “We also have a platform set up in the lab where we can apply specific drugs or other agents and see how that affects the virus when infecting the cells.”

column1: With funding through the Health Research Board’s national Covid-19 rapid response call
column2: Gautier is now working with UCD Prof Paddy Mallon to screen for ways to block SARS-CoV-2 using that platform.

column1: “We want to look at drugs that have already been approved for use in the clinic
column2: so they could be repurposed for treating SARS-CoV-2 if they are effective
column3: and we are looking at potential new agents against the virus too
column4: ” Gautier says.

column1: Her lab is also helping to provide reagents for hospitals to test patient samples for SARS-CoV-2
column2: she adds. “This pandemic needs us all to work together
column3: to use the insights and systems we have developed for other viruses and focus on this one.”||0

column1: 2020-06-04||The UK’s 2008 Climate Change Act has led to a 34% fall in CO 2 emissions by 2019
column2: while real GDP per capita had risen by more than 10% following the crash into the ‘Great Recession’. Can the UK achieve its recent net-zero emissions target by 2050 while still growing? This column describes some speculative routes to such a decarbonised future.

column1: Although much of the modern world is powered by fossil fuels
column2: that was not an inevitable outcome of technology and costs. The first electricity generator in the UK in 1868 was hydro-driven
column3: the first commercial photovoltaic solar panel – building on Edmond Becquerel’s 1839 creation of the first photovoltaic cell – was developed by Charles Fritts in 1881
column4: the first wind turbine to generate electricity was built by James Blyth in 1887
column5: and by the 1930s wind-generated electricity was relatively common on US farms. Moreover
column6: electric cars date back to the 1880s after Thomas Parker built a vehicle with a high-capacity rechargeable battery. Thus
column7: an all-electric-powered society is just going back to a future where we might have been 125 years ago.

column1: The rapidly falling costs of renewable energy sources like solar cells and onshore wind turbines combined with improved storage methods should substantially reduce oil and gas use in electricity production. Offshore wind turbines have also fallen greatly in cost and increased in efficiency over the past two decades so that for the UK they offer a low-cost alternative with the incidental benefit of creating marine reserves and fish sanctuaries. Wind turbines are cheaper than natural gas combined-cycle turbines even before adding the costs of carbon capture and storage.
Solar photovoltaics come next (for the UK) if carbon capture and storage is enforced
column2: though both wind and sun sources require large backup electricity storage systems for
column3: for example
column4: windless nights
column5: which we’ll discuss below. Renewable energy’s share of overall UK electricity generation reached a peak of 60.5% at one stage in April 2020
column6: according to National Grid data.

column1: Coal use has fallen to near zero in the UK since the 2008 Climate Change Act
column2: without obvious aggregate costs (Hendry 2020). However
column3: natural gas usage has increased 3.5-fold since the mid-1980s and still contributes about 140 megatons (Mt) p.a. to CO emissions despite producing less than half those of coal per Btu.

column2: the UK government amended the original Climate Change Act target to zero net emissions by 2050. All sources of greenhouse gas emissions must go to a level such that carbon capture and storage
column3: possibly combined with atmospheric CO extraction methods
column4: must remove the rest.

column1: Facing an irreducible non-zero minimum demand for oil and gas (e.g. for chemicals)
column2: to achieve zero net emissions before 2050 requires major technological change that almost certainly involves developing current research on avenues to remove (Wemyss 2014) or reuse existing CO as a fuel (Stanford University 2019). ‘Net zero’ is an excellent target but incredibly difficult to achieve and as yet
column3: there is no sensible UK strategy to do so – so we now suggest some speculative routes.

column1: To meet the net-zero target
column2: natural gas–use must be reduced to near zero
column3: like coal. Natural gas is mainly used for electricity production and household indoor- and water heating. The former could be handled in part by increased renewable sources. Household natural-gas (and some oil) usage could be reduced by increased taxes encouraging the adoption of solar panels and
column4: for example
column5: air heat pumps.

column1: More radically
column2: the UK could switch back from a national gas distribution system using natural gas to one based on hydrogen
column3: possibly made by electrolysis when there is spare renewable electricity. The UK had a hydrogen-based gas distribution system prior to 1969
column4: but the switch to natural gas required all household equipment to be converted from ones that burned coal gas (which is composed of about 50% hydrogen) to those that burned natural gas (which is mainly methane).

column1: With ever-improving technologies and cost reductions in renewable electricity generation
column2: a near-zero target for natural gas over the next 30 years should be possible without reducing GDP growth – perhaps even increasing growth with new opportunities.

column1: However
column2: as no future technology is certain
column3: more research should be devoted to developing safe small modular nuclear reactors (World Nuclear Association 2020) based on the well-developed nuclear-powered engines in submarines. Variants of small modular nuclear reactors such as molten-salt waste-burners https://www.seaborg.co/ may be able to use non-fissionable thorium or the ‘spent’ uranium fuel rods from older reactors
column4: helping to reduce the serious problem of transuranic-waste disposal. Part of those disposal-cost savings should be put towards the building of small modular nuclear reactors
column5: perhaps supplemented by reallocating the £40 billion saved by abandoning the Hinkley Point C nuclear power station.

column1: Even over our horizon of 30 years
column2: nuclear fusion seems unlikely to be a key energy contributor despite many developments
column3: such as increasing output efficiency (Bennett 2017) and reducing internal damage to tokamak materials from helium (Galeon 2017)
column4: which might then be collected
column5: offsetting a potential shortage.

column1: Reducing oil use in transport to zero will take longer following current strategies
column2: even with more efficient engines (diesel being phased out completely given its toxic pollutants)
column3: and much higher taxes on gasoline. Without a major improvement in lithium-ion-battery-powered electric vehicles
column4: their relatively short journey capacity despite taking a non-negligible time to recharge discourages the replacement of internal combustion engines.

column1: However
column2: recent advances have been made in understanding the properties of graphene
column3: with potentially large falls in its cost of production (see ‘graphene in a flash’ from plastic waste
column4: Williams 2020). Graphene nanotubes can act as electrode super-capacitors
column5: and there may be something like a variant of Moore’s law (which states that processing power of computers doubles every two years) that could lead to cost reductions stemming from a large increase in their production.

column1: Imagine sandwiching an array of graphene nanotubes (Sammed et al. 2020) between two Faraday cages in a prefabricated modular unit fitted to a vehicle’s roof (perhaps even retrofitted on existing car roofs) to power an electric motor
column2: so the vehicle becomes the battery. Graphene nanotubes seem capable of rapid charging and should be able to sustain viable distances on a single charge.

column1: Moreover
column2: if such electric vehicles are successful
column3: mandating them to be plugged in when not in use will translate into a vast electric storage system for no additional investment
column4: with cars acting as the National Grid’s storage. Thus
column5: renewable sources of electricity could be widely adopted without worrying about the security of supply.

column1: There are undoubtedly many technical issues that need to be solved before such a system could work in practice
column2: but there is much going on – such as developing 2-dimensional tri-layers of graphene (Graphene-info 2020) as an insulator
column3: superconductor
column4: and magnet.

column1: Several steps are possible for the UK to rapidly advance research on GNTs: (1) offer EPSRC significant additional funding for a general call to research the topic; (2) approach Manchester University directly as a world leader in graphene research with two Nobel Laureates; (3) offer a world-wide prize of £10m+ for the first car to successfully meet appropriate criteria
column2: with the patent to the UK Government; (4) contact major UK motor manufacturers of electric vehicles for interest and support; (5) make the call more general as other light materials could play equivalent roles as sources of electricity. Other steps include research on smart meters to be able to register both payments for taking power from fast chargers
column3: and recording kwhs withdrawn from the grid and needing replaced for free; and contemplating a grid of fast chargers.

column1: The potential benefits of such a power source would be huge as a ‘sensitive intervention point’ (Farmer et al. 2019 cite the UK’s Climate Change Act of 2008 as a timely example with a large effect).
By not demonising road transport for its CO footprint and dangerous pollution
column2: cars with internal combustion engines could be replaced at a rate matching obsolescence and the increased need for storage from the extension of renewables. The basics of electric engines are established
column3: so employment can be maintained in vehicle manufacture and many of its ancillary industries rebased on graphene nanotubes. Two side benefits are a major reduction in both mining for lithium and later disposal or recycling of the resulting toxic battery waste; and eliminating the need for expensive catalytic converters
column4: markedly cutting production costs
column5: eliminating a target for theft (which then exacerbates air pollution)
column6: and reducing palladium mining.

column1: Indirect consequences could solve the UK rail system’s problem of a lack of electrification across much of the network
column2: by replacing diesel-electric trains with graphene-nanotube-supplied electric ones
column3: although some progress is also being made with hydrogen-driven trains in Germany and the UK (University of Birmingham
column4: n.d.). As graphene nanotubes are so light
column5: they could stimulate a large increase in economical electric-powered aircraft (Travierso 2013).

column1: Agriculture
column2: construction
column3: chemical industry
column4: and waste management look more problematic
column5: although there have been some improvements in efficiency. Inner-city underground (Frangoul 2018) and vertical farms (Despommier 2009) economise on water
column6: fertiliser
column7: and energy – partly from transport reductions – and are increasingly viable given the falls in costs of LED lighting.

column2: including adding dietary fumaric acid (from plants like lichen and Ic||0

column1: 2020-06-04||The health costs of the Covid-19 pandemic are considerable
column2: and the economic and social costs of lockdown policies are even larger. This column calls for an innovative mechanism to foster the development of a vaccine against Covid-19. Governments would commit now to buy back any patent obtained by a private firm which would discover an effective vaccine
column3: at a price of €60 billion
column4: and would grant the right to produce the vaccine to any firm able to do so. This mechanism would provide strong incentives to innovate
column5: while protecting firms from the political risk of expropriation.

column1: On 4 May 2020
column2: a pledging conference convened by the EU raised €7.4 billion in funding for Covid-19 vaccines
column3: treatment
column4: and diagnostic research. Leading funders included the European Commission
column5: Germany
column6: France
column7: the UK
column8: the World Bank
column9: the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation
column10: the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunisation – even the pop singer Madonna.

column1: As of 15 May
column2: the Covid-19 pandemic has caused more than 300
column3: 000 deaths throughout the world. This pandemic may be the first major global event in the history of humankind: all countries are hit
column4: and within each country
column5: entire populations are affected negatively by the pandemic itself
column6: or potentially positively by public interventions to fight against its diffusion.

column1: For locked-down countries
column2: production losses have been estimated at 30% of usual activity (OECD 2020). EU countries pledged to donate €4 billion
column3: but each week of lockdown may cost €60 billion in foregone production. Some countries which have begun to soften their lockdown policies may have to reimpose strict measures
column4: at tremendous economic cost.

column1: Beyond the direct healthcare costs of the pandemic and the human costs of deaths and suffering
column2: the main economic consequences are not due to the virus itself
column3: but to policies aimed at flattening the curve. In April 2020
column4: half the world population was confined in some way.

column1: According to the OECD (2020)
column2: the direct costs are already enormous: the EU27 may have lost at least €280 billion in foregone production in the first month of lockdown. Baldwin et al. (2020) and Gourinchas (2020) observe the GDP loss could be tremendous if this lockdown triggers a full-scale recession.

column1: One major issue with ending policies of containment is that we don't know if they will need to be reactivated in the near future. Successful lockdowns bring new infections to zero in a population
column2: but with a low share of individuals who have gained immunity. In Europe this share ranges from 0.4% in Norway to 9.8% in Italy (Flaxman et al. 2020). This possibly underestimates true immunity
column3: but herd immunity requires levels of 50% to 66%.

column1: There is a significant probability that new imported cases will trigger new epidemic waves in Europe. And so epidemiologists argue that suppression strategies will need to be maintained until vaccines or effective treatments become available (Walker et al. 2020). Even currently undefined (and controversial) policies that would seek to balance containment with the need to restart and maintain economic production may still induce substantial production losses.

Such policies could be avoided if a vaccine were available and could be produced in large quantities. Early economic epidemiology papers have shown that complete eradication is very difficult to attain (e.g. Geoffard and Philipson 1996)
column2: but many infectious diseases are kept under control today through vaccination. If a sufficiently large proportion of the population is vaccinated
column3: we potentially achieve herd immunity by this route. Even if a vaccine fails to eradicate Covid-19
column4: it will be a major tool to reduce prevalence.

column1: The economic gains from the rapid creation and manufacture of a vaccine have been noticed by investment fund managers. The Financial Times reported on 24 April that BlackRock
column2: Fidelity International
column3: Aviva Investors
column4: Janus Henderson and Amundi all wanted drug companies to collaborate with their competitors to speed up its availability.

column1: According to Le et al. (2020) and the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations
column2: 115 vaccine candidates were in development on 8 April
column3: although even in the most optimistic case
column4: this development will take more than a year. Researchers and their employers may be motivated by the desire to contribute to human wellbeing – but money may be important too
column5: if only because it allows innovators to throw more people and resources at the research. Those financial incentives to innovate are generally determined by the expectation of a temporary patent monopoly.

column1: Though the 4 May conference was indeed a great success
column2: the total amount pledged so far still represents only a small fraction of the economic costs induced by the pandemic. Though a substantial share of that amount will be targeted towards vaccine research
column3: this research is also sensitive to the political risk of expropriation.

column1: An example: one week after the conference
column2: Paul Hudson
column3: CEO of Sanofi
column4: said that the subsidy granted by the US Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority to finance its vaccine research programme came with a commitment by Sanofi to give priority for a vaccine to US customers. In response
column5: French authorities and members of the European Parliament countered that any vaccine would have to be equitably available to all. Many MEPs went further and expressed support for compulsory licensing of any vaccine.

column1: Vaccine research takes time and resources
column2: and is a risky enterprise. The chance is high that even if a vaccine is discovered by a pharmaceutical firm
column3: political pressures will prevent this firm from making profits by the usual route of obtaining a patent and selling the vaccine at a high price.

column1: For a Covid-19 vaccine
column2: the social and political pressures for an exception to patent protection will be considerable. It is hard to believe that some
column3: if not most
column4: countries will not invoke Article 31 of the TRIPS Agreement
column5: enabling a government to use compulsory licensing to allow a local firm to produce a patented product without the consent of the patent owner
column6: or to import the product from another country.

column1: Under TRIPS
column2: governments must still pay an 'adequate' fee to the patent holder. But if the emergency is extremely urgent
column3: they don't need to try to agree a voluntary license. In short
column4: a government can impose its own price.

column1: It's a safe bet that Covid-19 satisfies these conditions and so
column2: for a private firm
column3: the risk of expropriation seems particularly important. Even if governments do not activate compulsory licensing
column4: political pressures and healthcare budget constraints mean that firms will be under pressure to lower prices.

column1: Many major pharmaceutical companies are already dedicating risky research efforts to find a vaccine against Covid-19
column2: reducing investment in other drugs or vaccines. But these hold-up risks may reduce their effort. Stockholders may gripe if there's a risk that a firm will succeed but not be granted a patent
column3: or that it gets a patent but is unable to recoup R&D spend.

column1: Kremer et al. (2020) and Athey et al. (2020) have argued for advanced market commitment. This was intended to foster research on diseases common in developing countries
column2: but it could apply here. Donors pledge to top up payments for newly introduced vaccine meeting technical benchmarks
column3: conditional on the firm’s setting the price close to marginal cost. Three pneumococcal vaccines have been developed encouraged by such a pledge and 150 million children in poor countries have been immunised
column4: saving an estimated 700
column5: 000 lives.

column1: But
column2: if production costs are difficult to observe
column3: the commitment to sell at marginal cost is impossible to verify. This generates a political risk: NGOs campaigning for lower drugs prices and transparency in price-setting would put pressure on any patent-holder to reduce prices
column4: even those claiming to sell at production cost.

column1: A more standard way to come close to marginal cost pricing is to rely on competition between producers. However
column2: since competition brings profits to zero
column3: financial incentives for research must come from another instrument.

column1: One way to get around these issues while providing incentives for vaccine research would be for donors to pledge to buy the patent at a high value. They would then allow private firms to produce the vaccine without having to pay any patent fees. The patent would have high value
column2: but it can be thought as a way to front-load the costs that would be borne in future by health insurance schemes
column3: which in European countries are mostly funded by payroll taxes – revenues from which have already been severely damaged by the drop in economic activity (Baker 2020). If pledged by the EU
column4: such a commitment would also speed up the availability of the vaccine
column5: as the producer will not have to negotiate a price in each country.

column1: Governments could even set up such a scheme as an option offered to pharmaceutical firms. The patent holder could still decide to remain the owner of the patent and to negotiate market access
column2: and prices
column3: with each healthcare financing institution.

column1: This could be financed by the Recovery Fund announced by the European Commission which
column2: according to the European Parliament
column3: could be as large as €2 trillion. A commitment by the EU to buy a vaccine patent would be a clear and transparent mechanism that would reduce the political risk of expropriation
column4: could foster investment in R&D
column5: and will speed up market access.

column1: We could argue that an investment that could hasten the end of containment by just one week in Europe would be socially profitable if it costs less than €60 billion This amount provides a lower bound for the social value of a vaccine.
A commitment to buy for
column2: say
column3: €60 billion seems an enormous sum; but if this shortens a future lockdown by a single week
column4: it would be an efficient use of public money.

column1: Athey
column2: S
column3: M Kremer
column4: C Snyder and A Tabarrok (2020)
column5: “In the Race for a Coronavirus Vaccine
column6: We Must Go Big.||0

column1: 2020-06-04||Log on to Twitter for a masterclass in gall. What claims to be the account of Iran’s supreme leader shows his concern for America’s downtrodden. The Turkish president is “deeply saddened” at their lives under an “unjust order”. As for China
column2: one official opts merely to quote the late George Floyd. “I can’t breathe
column3: ” said the man whose death after police arrest has set off US-wide protests.

column1: America’s internal schisms are being used against it
column2: and used well
column3: with the soft touch and irony that autocrats are meant to lack. But then there is so much to work with.

column1: The dividedness of the US – racial
column2: material
column3: political – is aired thoroughly enough as a domestic blight. It is the effect on its foreign policy that can get lost in the anguish. If the US is riven
column4: it must also be hampered in its outward actions. And nowhere will it suffer more than in the superpower duel.

column1: The US-China rift is so cheaply likened to the cold war that we forget how much more unified America was back then. When it took on the Soviets
column2: it was fresh from the bonding trauma of the second World War. Republicans and Democrats did not just have bipartisan manners
column3: but shared policies: a mixed economy
column4: anti-isolationism
column5: foot-dragging on civil rights.

column1: Immigration had been too low for too long to test the country’s sense of itself. Trust in government was so high as to implicate Americans in Old World deference. The distribution of incomes was much flatter than it is now. Politics rarely spilled on to the street.
With all the due caveats about silent tensions (and
column2: in McCarthyism
column3: loud ones)
column4: the US that set out on the cold war was a nation of almost quaint togetherness. It could be mobilised for an open-ended contest against a far-off rival.

column1: Achieving the same trick now would tax a Lincoln or a Roosevelt. It is not just a week’s urban unrest that has to be overcome
column2: but two or three decades of calcified partisanship. If another cold war is afoot
column3: the US goes into it with less of the cohesion that primed it for the first. The best it can hope is that the causal link runs the other way: that an external foe is what brings citizens together. If so
column4: the process is slow in working.

column1: As they consider the inflamed streets
column2: Americans of some vintage will shiver with memories of the late-1960s. It is important to follow that thought a bit further. What the turmoil over civil rights and the Vietnam war ultimately brought was a change in world affairs: the cold-war breather we know as detente.

column1: The US saw that it could not tussle with the Soviets while its own house was in such disrepair. It had to sue
column2: if not for peace then for a modus vivendi
column3: at least until it felt robust again. Foreign policy could not endlessly buck domestic weakness.

column1: Nor can it now. If anything
column2: the US is even less cohesive in 2020. Detente-era Washington was still a bipartisan place
column3: with Republicans renouncing their own president
column4: Richard Nixon
column5: and some supreme court judges being confirmed near-unanimously. It is now a pit of bad faith. Nor was income inequality such a sore point before the market reforms of the 1980s. It is now entangled with the race question and the Covid-19 pandemic.

column1: For reasons of pride or strategy
column2: confronting China might be still be right. But it matters that it coincides with the most fractured time in national life for half a century. The least to be said is that those who will the confrontation should not stoke the disunity.

column1: And so to the president. Donald Trump did not etch the faultlines into his society
column2: but he picks at them with rare abandon. We know well enough that he will not desist out of good conscience. Much odder is that he rejects the geopolitical case for doing so.

column1: If he wants the US to bed down for an indefinite struggle against China
column2: he must know that it cannot also be so nakedly at odds with itself. The president can have discord at home
column3: or he can have a tenable showdown abroad. It is ever harder to see how he can have both. A true hawk would be sweetly emollient in domestic politics.

column1: Instead
column2: the president touts a bible (unconvincingly) and pledges to get rough (convincingly). Protesters are dispersed not far from the White House. In Washington
column3: the ambient sound comes from vigilant helicopters. The past week is said to have been Trump’s most divisive yet. As such
column4: it was also the worst for his foreign goals. – Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2020||1

column2: President of the ECB

column1: Luis de Guindos
column2: Vice-President of the ECB

column1: Frankfurt am Main
column2: 4 June 2020

column1: Jump to the transcript of the questions and answers
Ladies and gentlemen
column2: the Vice-President and I are very pleased to welcome you to our press conference. We will now report on the outcome of today’s meeting of the Governing Council
column3: which was also attended by the Commission Executive Vice-President
column4: Mr Dombrovskis.

column1: Incoming information confirms that the euro area economy is experiencing an unprecedented contraction. There has been an abrupt drop in economic activity as a result of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic and the measures to contain it. Severe job and income losses and exceptionally elevated uncertainty about the economic outlook have led to a significant fall in consumer spending and investment.
