2020-06-05||The Chief Executive Leadership Institute’s Mayors College and CEO Summit, long planned for June 3, went on as planned, but in a new format—an online discussion, open to the public—and with a new theme: racism and the civil unrest sweeping the United States after the death of George Floyd at the hands of police.

“I had to pivot in real time to address the—literally—burning social issues of the day,” said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, founder and CEO of the Chief Executive Leadership Institute.

 

 Several times a year, the CEO Summit brings together corporate and government leaders and leading academics to discuss the role of business in navigating the day’s most pressing issues; the annual Mayors College convenes mayors of middle-sized and large cities from both parties.

Both events are typically in-person, closed-door gatherings, allowing for frank discussion among high-profile leaders.

“We were about to cancel,” said Sonnenfeld, Yale SOM’s senior associate dean for leadership studies and the Lester Crown Professor in the Practice of Management, “but so many top leaders requested we continue, even without the usual intimate, off-the-record exchange, that we were encouraged to instead try it with remote technology.”

The summit’s original theme was “Economic Rejuvenation: Safely Bringing Corporations and Communities out of COVID Caves.” Organizers had prepared an agenda of discussion revolving around economic recovery, community rebuilding, biotech developments and U.S./China trade issues related to the COVID-19 crisis and breakdowns in diplomacy. But after Floyd’s death and the protests that followed, Sonnenfeld said, it was clear that a change in focus was needed.

“I worried about a ‘bait and switch’ charge with such a powerful, busy collection of leaders,” said Sonnenfeld “But they, too, are experiencing a sudden new priority and thankfully embraced the shift.”

Some of the opinion leaders and experts in attendance included 47th U.S. Vice President Joe Biden; Connecticut Governor Ned Lamont; U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer; Senior Judge Douglas Ginsburg of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit; 25th U.S. Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter; the 65th U.S. secretary of state, General Colin Powell; and former U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills.

“This was a rare opportunity to have a cross-section of leaders, spanning industries, ideologies, and sectors, speak to the vital issues of the day,” said Sonnenfeld.

Summit attendees said they found the discussion deeply meaningful and helpful as they guide their organizations through turbulent times. Kay Koplovitz, the founder and former CEO of USA Network, called the meetings she attended Wednesday “extraordinary.” She added, “The challenges at hand were so well articulated by the mayors, regardless of political affiliation... same could be said for the CEO session.”

Tamara L. Lundgren, Chairman and CEO, Schnitzer Steel Industries, Inc., wrote in a note to Sonnenfeld, “Both the mayors’ meeting and the CEO Summit were terrific and the topics discussed extraordinarily timely. Thank you for your leadership, deft touch, and ability to engage hundreds of people in a conversation and yet make it feel like a gathering of only a few.”

Nicole Russo, CEO and President of Microboard, commented that she believed the discussion at the event could help all the participants have meaningful impact in coming days. “I am committed personally and professionally to help drive the change our country needs. I look forward to staying in close contact with you and fellow CEOs on how we can collaborate to stabilize and propel our neighbors, businesses, and this great country to new heights.”

Among the cities represented by the mayors present were Lincoln, Nebraska; Atlanta, Georgia; Buffalo, New York; Louisville, Kentucky; Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; Hartford, Connecticut; Oakland, California; Miami, Florida; Tampa, Florida; Phoenix, Arizona; Oklahoma City, Oklahoma; Stamford, Connecticut; and El Paso, Texas.||2
2020-06-05||SAN FRANCISCO, June 4, 2020 /PRNewswire/ -- The first class action lawsuit was filed today on behalf of the more than 2,800 passengers negligently exposed to COVID-19 on the Princess Cruise Lines Grand Princess cruise from San Francisco to Mexico from February 11, 2020 through February 21, 2020. The law firms Lieff Cabraser Heimann & Bernstein, LLP, Mary Alexander & Associates, and Nelson & Fraenkel, LLP filed the suit in the United States District Court for the Central District of California.

The complaint alleges that at least 100 passengers who traveled onboard the Grand Princess Mexico trip have tested positive for COVID-19, and two died after disembarking. One of these fatalities was, at the time, the first-reported death caused by COVID-19 in California. All told, Carnival cruises have reportedly been associated with more than 1,500 positive COVID-19 infections and nearly 40 deaths.

Carnival and Princess allowed potentially infected individuals on the Mexico cruise to share confined space with other passengers
column8: casually and callously exposing all 2
column9: 500 passengers to serious illness from COVID-19
column10:
said Lieff Cabraser partner Elizabeth Cabraser, who filed the lawsuit on behalf of the Plaintiffs.

As detailed in the complaint, before the Mexico cruise, Carnival and Princess became aware of an outbreak of COVID-19 aboard another of their cruise ships, the Diamond Princess, during cruises in Asia. Ten cases were originally diagnosed, and that number rapidly escalated to over 700 cases—over one-fifth of the passengers onboard—with 14 deaths.

On February 11, 2020, approximately ten days after Carnival and Princess learned about the infections aboard the Diamond Princess, the defendants boarded plaintiffs and approximately 2,500 other passengers onto the Grand Princess for a roundtrip voyage to Mexico without conducting any effective medical screenings for passengers and without providing any additional information about best practices to mitigate or prevent the spread of COVID-19.

The complaint alleges that on or around February 19, 2020, Carnival and Princess became aware of at least one passenger suffering from COVID-19 symptoms onboard the Grand Princess Mexico cruise, but they did not warn passengers aboard the ship, nor did they put into place any quarantine requirements, social distancing protocols, or meaningfully alter their on-ship protocols, event itineraries, or cleaning and disinfectant practices to prevent the spread of COVID-19. As alleged in the complaint, after Carnival and Princess became aware of the first case aboard the ship, they worked to keep the fun going" by "encouraging [guests] to mingle."

column1: 2020-06-05||DIRE HEADLINES had already been prepared before the release of America’s May jobs report on June 5th. Most analysts expected payroll employment to have fallen last month by several million
column2: on the heels of record declines in March and April
column3: and the unemployment rate to have jumped to nearly 20%. Instead
column4: the Bureau of Labour Statistics reported a sharp increase in employment
column5: of 2.5m
column6: and a drop in the jobless rate from 14.7%
column7: a post-Depression record
column8: to 13.3%. Although the American labour market remains deeply troubled
column9: President Donald Trump nonetheless convened a hastily called press conference to hail the news and declare the country back on the road to better days. “This is better than a V[-shaped recovery]
column10: ” he said. “This is a rocket ship!”

column1: Those bleak expectations had been set by a flow of dreadful economic news. Americans continue to file new claims for unemployment benefits by the million. Indices of economic activity showed that production kept declining across the economy in May
column2: although at a far slower pace than in April. Yet some high-frequency indicators—such as restaurant bookings and measures of personal travel—had indicated signs of revival. And investors have been bullish for weeks
column3: pushing stock indices close to new highs. They greeted the jobs data by sending the S&P 500 up by 2.6%.

column1: But the details of the report
column2: though encouraging
column3: do not suggest that a rapid return to normality is imminent. New hiring was concentrated in service industries
column4: primarily in health
column5: leisure and hospitality. But the number of new jobs in May amounted to just a fraction of the total lost since February; the leisure industry added about 1.2m last month
column6: but shed more than 8m in March and April. Part of the rebound in hiring can probably be explained by the structure of a federal aid programme intended to support small and medium businesses
column7: which provides emergency loans that will ultimately be forgiven if lay-offs are avoided. Some of it
column8: too
column9: can be explained by initial steps towards reopening
column10: as firms that were temporarily shut restarted work at dramatically reduced capacity. But although the number of Americans on temporary furlough declined
column11: permanent lay-offs rose by nearly 300
column13: taking the total to 2.3m. Disconcertingly
column14: given the protests against police violence wracking the country
column15: the jobless rate for black Americans ticked upwards
column17: while that for whites fell.

column1: Labour-market data are very likely to keep improving over the summer
column2: as state and local governments continue to ease lockdowns. The critical question for the American economy
column3: however
column4: is how many job losses and firm closures will prove permanent. Joblessness will probably remain well above normal levels
column5: and policy support for the unemployed will continue to be justified. There are signs
column6: however
column7: that this surprising gust of good news may be undercutting interest in more spending in Washington. Meanwhile
column8: the risk of new economic disruption
column9: by covid-19 or by civil unrest
column10: remains. The jobs figures were indeed a pleasant surprise. But it will be months
column11: or years
column12: until American workers can exhale without fear.||1

column1: 2020-06-05||In late May
column2: CanSino Biologics published the first data for its COVID-19 vaccine expressing spike protein. The vaccine generated neutralizing antibodies in many recipients and appeared safe
column3: but the company
column4: like others in this space
column5: remains on alert for a dangerous phenomenon known as antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE). “It’s important to talk about it [ADE]
column6: ” says Gregory Glenn
column7: president of R&D at Novavax
column8: which launched its COVID-19 vaccine trial in May. But “we can’t be overly cautious. People are dying. So we need to be aggressive here.”

column1: There are mounting theoretical concerns that vaccines generating antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 may bind to the virus without neutralizing it. Should this happen
column2: the non-neutralizing antibodies could enhance viral entry into cells and viral replication and end up worsening infection instead of offering protection
column3: through the poorly understood phenomenon of ADE. ADE “is a genuine concern
column4: ” says virologist Kevin Gilligan
column5: a senior consultant with Biologics Consulting
column6: who advises thorough safety studies. “Because if the gun is jumped
column7: and a vaccine is widely distributed that is disease enhancing
column8: that would be worse than actually not doing any vaccination at all.”

column1: The degree of ADE vaccine risk for SARS-CoV-2 is unknown.
“Most experts who look at it acknowledge the potential risk but don’t see compelling evidence for it in humans right now
column2: ” says James Crowe
column3: director of the Vanderbilt Vaccine Center. Some view coronavirus ADE as a laboratory phenomenon
column4: at least so far. “The theoretical possibility [of ADE] is there
column5: ” says Rafi Ahmed
column6: director of the Emory Vaccine Center. “The more difficult question becomes
column7: how do you balance this concern with moving forward? There’s not an easy answer.”

column1: ADE was first described in 1977 by virologist Scott Halstead
column2: then at the University of Hawaii. Halstead studied dengue
column3: caused by four related but antigenically distinct viruses known as ‘serotypes’. Halstead noted that animals previously infected with one serotype did worse if infected again with a different serotype than if never previously infected at all. He found antibodies to be responsible for this phenomenon. Instead of neutralizing the virus
column4: the antibodies facilitated viral entry into host cells in vitro. In his publication
column5: Halstead presciently wrote: “Non-neutralising antibody presumably provides a specific molecular ‘ride’ for an infectious dengue virion into the interior of a receptive phagocytic cell.”

column1: Halstead’s speculation was later proven correct
column2: not just for dengue
column3: a flavivirus
column4: but for other viruses
column5: including coronaviruses
column6: in cell culture experiments. The coronavirus uses its spike protein to bind host receptors and infect airway cells. But it also can infect immune cells
column7: typically macrophages. Anti-spike antibodies ideally bind and neutralize the virus
column8: either by blocking spike binding to its receptor or by preventing fusion of the virus with the cell. But if antibodies fail to do this because they bind unproductively to the virus
column9: these non-neutralizing antibodies may instead
column10: using the Fc region at the base of the antibody
column11: latch onto host macrophage Fc receptors and ferry the virus into these host cells
column12: at least in vitro. Once inside
column13: the viruses replicate and then exit to further spread infection to neighboring cells and tissues.

column1: Poor-quality antibodies that bind the virus without neutralizing it are one reason vaccine candidates fail
column2: and
column3: in theory
column4: could also cause ADE
column5: delivering virions to host cells.

column1: Can SARS-CoV-2 infect macrophages? “I don’t know
column2: ” answers Stan Perlman
column3: a coronavirus expert at the University of Iowa. “Those data are not out there yet.” The virus can infect macrophages in vitro
column4: but that doesn’t necessarily translate to in vivo human biology. “In tissue culture cells you can make almost any virus show this
column5: by jigging the right cells
column6: the right amount of antibody
column7: and the right virus. But that [is] not really meaningful
column8: because of the fact that it’s so artificial.”

column1: The risk that a COVID-19 vaccine will cause ADE and facilitate infection “is completely theoretical
column2: ” says Novavax’s Glenn. “It’s a lab
column3: an animal phenomenon that’s been observed. [But] in RSV it’s a real clinical event.” In a 1960s vaccine trial
column4: 80% of infants and young children immunized against RSV (respiratory syncytial virus
column5: an RNA virus in the family Paramyxoviridae) ended up hospitalized
column6: and 2 children died. Only 5% of the children in the control group required hospitalization. Vaccinated children carried high titers of non-neutralizing antibodies
column7: implicating ADE in the tragic outcome
column8: although a T 2 (inflammatory) T cell response also probably contributed.

column1: Since then
column2: some vaccine studies in animals
column3: as well as human trials where vaccinated people had worse outcomes
column4: suggest ADE at work. But definitive evidence is lacking. “We can’t say they were not due to ADE
column5: but there’s not evidence that they were
column6: ” says Ahmed. “There are many other ways that an immune response can cause damage.”

column1: For coronavirus vaccines
column2: the ADE story is similarly inconclusive. Cats vaccinated with spike protein against feline coronavirus died much faster than unvaccinated cats and carried more anti-spike antibodies
column3: implicating ADE. But macaques vaccinated against SARS-CoV-1 did not show enhanced infection or disease.

column1: In humans
column2: limited data for vaccines against earlier coronaviruses did not show ADE. Two vaccines against the closely related SARS-CoV-1 appeared safe in early trials. A DNA vaccine against the MERS coronavirus in macaques protected all eight monkeys from infection symptoms
column3: and that MERS vaccine was well-tolerated in a 2016 phase 1 human trial. MERS vaccine co-developer David Weiner
column4: director of the Vaccine & Immunotherapy Center at the Wistar Institute
column5: co-developed a very similar COVID-19 vaccine that Inovio Pharmaceuticals took into human trials in early April.

column1: “We don’t see it [ADE] with flu
column2: we don’t see it with so many other vaccines that we have
column3: ” says Ahmed. “We shouldn’t dismiss it completely
column4: but then if you look at the broader world of vaccinology
column5: this has not been seen.” But Gilligan says some earlier SARS and MERS vaccine candidates didn’t advance because of signs of ADE.

column1: ADE is a concern for monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) too
column2: at least in theory
column3: because mAbs that fail to neutralize the virus also could facilitate viral entry into cells. Many companies are working on such mAbs for either COVID-19 prevention or therapy. AstraZeneca
column4: for example
column5: is partnering with Vanderbilt
column6: which has identified
column7: expressed and evaluated virus-neutralizing antibodies from B cells recovered from convalescents. AstraZeneca will take the best ones forward into clinical trials.

column1: ADE is part of the mAb discussion. “There’s not a lot of obvious epidemiologic evidence for it yet
column2: ” says Vanderbilt’s Crowe. Nevertheless
column3: he says
column4: “we will address this.” Crowe’s group will test for ADE by seeing whether its monoclonal antibodies can deliver viruses into macrophages
column5: compared with antibodies whose Fc region has been inactivated. (An antibody lacking Fc can’t bind macrophage Fc receptors and thus can’t cause ADE. That’s why some companies are advancing mAbs with the Fc region knocked out.) Still
column6: “the animal models are so inadequate right now
column7: it would be very difficult to prove whether [ADE] is common or uncommon
column8: ” Crowe says.

column1: For mAbs
column2: the risk is probably low. “You’re already characterizing it as a highly neutralizing antibody
column3: ” says Ahmed. Convalescent antibody passive immunization trials
column4: now underway
column5: could carry some ADE risk
column6: Ahmed says. “[But] I would be less concerned with that than with the vaccine that might be inducing suboptimal response.”

column1: Vaccine companies are fully aware of ADE. “All the groups have been discussing this
column2: everyone’s on the same page
column3: everyone wants a safe [COVID-19] vaccine
column4: ” says Weiner. Inovio went forward into the clinic after showing safety in primates
column5: and is reassured by the strong human safety record of its MERS vaccine. But vaccine trials are being approved “without the usual amount of preclinical safety/tox data available for guidance
column6: ” says Gilligan.

column1: Given the urgency
column2: the US Food and Drug Administration and European Medicines Agency may have little choice but to give the go ahead to enter the clinic. Novavax launched a phase 1/2 trial of its vaccine
column3: a stable prefusion SARS-CoV-2 spike protein trimer nanoparticle vaccine with a saponin-based adjuvant
column4: in late May. The company is experienced with viral vaccines: its nanoparticle flu vaccine recently met its phase 3 endpoints. The SARS-CoV-2 virus “is not new territory
column5: ” Glenn says
column6: adding that Novavax and other vaccine companies can assay for whether antibodies can block spike protein–receptor binding
column7: or neutralize the virus
column8: or both
column9: which should prevent infection.

column1: And ADE? “One has to address it
column2: ” Glenn says
column3: but he points out that ADE is only a theoretical COVID-19 vaccine risk. “It’s hypothesized from animal studies
column4: ” he says. “I think the way forward is to take it seriously
column5: do some animal studies
column6: show you don’t have enhancement
column7: monitor during the trial. My view is
column8: we can’t let this issue keep us from getting to a vaccine that will save millions of lives.”

column1: But Anne De Groot
column2: CEO of EpiVax
column3: argues for a more nuanced approach. EpiVax develops T-cell-directed vaccines
column4: using computational tools to select viral T cell epitopes. The company found SARS-CoV-2 sequences that would appear human to T cell receptors.

column1: This could be a problem for any vaccine. “The T cells either don’t respond as strongly
column2: because they think that the [coronavirus] spike is human
column3: or that sequence can trigger a regulatory T cell response
column4: ” says De Groot. Such T cells can interfere with beneficial antibody production and “you don’t get neutralizing antibodies
column5: you get the kind of antibodies that actually potentially enhance infection.” In other words
column6: ADE.

2020-06-06||The late management guru Peter Drucker who presciently advocated “back room” outsourcing and corporate decentralisation at a time when these smart cost-saving techniques were anathema to produce-everything-hire-everyone mega corporations
column2: had a few more tricks up his sleeve.

column1: One of his key mantras – price-led costing – often overlooked even today yet something profoundly relevant to all businesses
column2: especially those connected with travel
column3: is worth re-examining in a dysfunctional Covid-19 world.

column1: The central argument is simple. Most companies tend to create a product they feel the market wants and outspend each other to produce it
column2: subsequently passing on the entire cost to consumers with a further profit slab packed with humungous CEO salaries on top of all this extravagance. This is cost-driven pricing and is typical of the sort of big ego branding popular today.

column1: Druker’s answer to this was blindingly simple. Check the price your audience might be willing to pay for a product and then keep production costs and profit margins within this budget. This is price-led costing. It is as relevant for airline seats as for luxury hotels.
Of course price-led costing (for any desirable good) is entirely predicated on scarcity
column2: which drives price. One of the problems monster brands like Louis Vuitton faced in Asia was the sort of over exposure that instantly drove down perceived value often with perverse results. At one point Hongkongers shunned LV-monogrammed travel bags due to their mass popularity with Macau casino bumpkins.

column1: As airlines posit scenarios in a Covid-19 or post-virus world it seems an inescapable truth that passengers will need to be distanced and isolated somehow to allay fears of contagion. With previous models entirely based on the sardine concept of spacing
column2: packing in seats
column3: and eliminating window exits to cram in more bodies
column4: this is jarringly revolutionary.

column1: Aircraft design will move towards more protected personal space with wraparound headrest partitions
column2: novel seating configurations and
column3: perhaps
column4: access to cargo areas reconverted into gyms or wellness escapes. Family cabins may arrive in economy
column5: modelled after the innovative Qsuites on Qatar Airways that can turn into quads for foursomes.

column1: Fewer seats will invariably mean higher ticket prices. Will air passengers accept this additional burden on groaning wallets? Or might they consider it a worthwhile investment in emotional security or a sought after ‘luxury’ perk? In other words might travel once again become something expensive
column2: rare
column3: and unattainable
column4: thereby bestowing upon it the original cachet of a romantic treat as in the days of the magnificent Pan Am Clipper flying boats?

column1: Travellers will increasingly see luxury hotels as safe havens with trustworthy corporate protocols unlike the unregulated bottom-feeder Airbnb offerings
column2: now fraught with unknown dangers. Private villa escapes will come to epitomise less is more
column3: a phrase hitherto spouted by many but believed by few. Huge cookie-cutter fairy-lights hotels will not disappear as there is always space for mid-range products but
column4: in a Covid world
column5: there can be no scrimping on safety and this in turn will push prices up factoring in guest spacing
column6: staff training
column7: enhanced hygiene
column8: lavish wellness partnerships and thermal-scanning equipment.

column1: But regardless of whether price inches up or down
column2: business models must be thoroughly reviewed and reset. Dropping oil prices (though this may be short term) and the Covid reality offer a huge opportunity for a travel rethink. It is time to abandon the sloppy cost-led pricing that has dominated monster travel projects
column3: based on the assumption of ever-increasing hordes of cash-rich Chinese consumers. That is now a mirage as travel for the near term turns inward with a focus on domestic transactions and ‘safe corridors’ (pairing cities or countries) whether in China
column4: USA
column5: India
column6: Thailand
column7: or Indonesia.

column1: Price-led costing will be the key
column2: whether aiming for the luxury traveller or the less financially frivolous. It is a sound argument for any time and a good one to take onboard as globalism goes through a major adjustment in the face of mounting ultranationalist sentiment – with some manufacturing and business travel returning home over time.

column1: Travellers willing to spend for a romantic break from the quotidian grind will make very careful choices and demand a lot more value. They will be in the driver’s seat now. Luxury travellers will not simply swarm marbled lobbies demanding free Bellinis. They will get tough.
Travellers looking for value will be equally demanding. Gone are the days when a guesthouse could say
column2: ‘You get what you pay for.’ Safety cuts both ways. Hotels and airlines will need protocols to ensure their clientele is potentially okay just as travellers will examine holiday escapes in minute detail
column3: perhaps preferring less trampled out-of-the-way places like the Maldives where privacy is ensured and social contact minimised.

column1: Business travellers cautiously venturing out may be the hardest hit as this is the segment where the travel sector will try and make up for the loss. It would do well to remember though that with work-from-home and video conferencing much the rage
column2: there is no inelastic demand anymore. Too much of a fare hike will dull corporate enthusiasm. Travel is already a significant cost for companies and medical-travel-labour insurance premiums will soar in a Covid world.

column1: For a start
column2: travel will stay close to home (and close to medical fallbacks) and we will become like kids learning to walk
column3: picking up the courage to foray farther each day. But like that infernal coronavirus
column4: travel is in the blood. We’ll find out which wins out. In the meanwhile
column5: the travel industry can restore itself by stepping away from the mirage and incorporating sound pricing practices.

column1: Vijay Verghese is a Hongkong-based journalist and columnist and the Editor of SmartTravelAsia.com and AsianConversations.com.||1

column2: the Government fast-tracked new legislation to introduce further tax changes in response to the impacts of the Covid-19 outbreak.

column1: The key tax component of the Covid-19 Response (Taxation and Other Regulatory Urgent Matters) Act 2020 is a temporary tax loss carry-back measure.
Broadly
column2: this allows businesses that anticipate being in a loss for the 2020 or 2021 tax years
column3: to carry some or all of the loss back to the preceding year to enable an immediate cash refund of prior tax paid.

To be eligible
column2: a taxpayer must have made or anticipate they will make a loss in either of the 2020 or 2021 tax years. The taxpayer must have a profit in the year prior to the loss year. This means:

column1: * Losses from the 2020 year may be carried back to the 2019 year
* Losses from the 2021 year may be carried back to the 2020 year
Taxpayers can claim a tax refund for provisional tax paid by re-estimating 2020 provisional tax where the 2020 return is not yet filed
column2: or by amending their 2019 tax return to factor in the loss carry back. The rules will apply to companies
column3: trusts and individuals (other than those deriving only PAYE income) and those that operate through partnerships and look-through companies.

column1: Overall
column2: this is a very positive initiative
column3: and one the Government should be commended for. However
column4: because of its rushed implementation
column5: it’s not perfect
column6: not necessarily as straightforward as it seems and will not suit all businesses.

column1: Each business will have different circumstances and each will need to consider whether this mechanism is the right option for them. Inland Revenue’s systems went live in early May with the changes so taxpayers can make elections to carry-back losses via the 'I want to' section of MyIR.
A few considerations and scenarios to reflect on are outlined below

Most business will be looking to use this mechanism in relation to a loss incurred in the 2021 year and carry this back to the 2020 income year which may still be profitable given Covid-19 may have only affected the last quarter of this year.
A business that needs cash urgently will want to elect to carry back its anticipated loss as soon as possible; however
column2: a business will need to be fairly confident of the level of loss and think carefully about how the rest of the year will play out.

column1: This is because
column2: if a business over-estimates its 2021 loss which results in tax payable
column3: use of money interest (UOMI) will apply from August 28
column4: 2019 (for a March balance date taxpayer)
column5: which is the first instalment date of 2020 provisional tax. Further
column6: it will not be possible to apply for relief from UOMI imposed under the remission rules recently enacted.

column1: To minimise potential exposure to UOMI
column2: the business might want to take a conservative position initially given we are only into the third month of the new tax year and re-estimate the loss later or as the year progresses.

column1: However
column2: holding off may not provide the much-needed cash now which could force some businesses to take some risks in this regard. Timing of electing
column3: filing the return and monitoring losses will be key.

column1: It will be possible to re-estimate the 2021 loss to carry back at any time prior to the earlier of the date the 2020 return is filed or the due date for filing.
The rules require the immediately preceding year to have taxable income. There will be some companies where the pattern of income and losses is such that the carry-back mechanism won’t be much
column2: or any benefit.

column1: For example
column2: taxable income in the 2019 year might have been high under normal trading conditions and so 2020 provisional tax paid to date is based on residual income tax for this year.

column1: Taxable income in the 2020 year (particularly if it is a late balance date) might have dropped
column2: but may have only dropped to a lower taxable income and so it not yet a loss.

column1: Even if there are large losses anticipated in 2021
column2: these will only be able to be carried back to the extent of the lower taxable income in the immediately preceding year
column3: which may not release that much tax paid.

column1: Likewise
column2: a company with a small loss in 2020 and a larger loss in 2021 will be constrained to only being able to use the smaller loss in 2020 to amend only the 2019 tax return
column3: such that the company is unable to carry back the larger loss incurred in 2021.

column1: Refunds might be limited or trapped
For taxpayers that are companies
column2: any refunds will be limited to the credit balance in its company imputation credit account at the date of the most recently ended tax year (ie March 31
column4: although some timing exceptions apply).

column1: Therefore
column2: if a company has been in the habit of paying most of its profits as dividends to shareholders and attaching imputation credits
column3: it may find access to cash refunds is limited.

column1: The policy rationale for this rule is that the company’s tax has been paid to shareholders already via imputation credits. Any trapped refunds may be applied to income or provisional tax liabilities
column2: if any will exist.

column1: If the company has traditionally paid out its profits for the year as shareholder salaries
column2: the company won’t have any taxable income to carry future losses back to. The shareholders and not the company in this case have paid the provisional tax.

column1: Therefore
column2: an option might be for the shareholders to estimate 2020 provisional tax to nil and have the company elect to not pay any shareholder salaries for the 2020 tax year if losses are forecast for 2021 if this is possible.

column1: However
column2: this could then expose the company to an FBT liability if there are outstanding current accounts
column3: so care is required. Other options may be feasible in this scenario.

column1: The important point to note is that companies will need to do some work and determine what the approach to paying shareholder salaries should be in light of these rules.
The new Act contains an anti-avoidance measure
column2: which could apply if shares in any company have been subject to an arrangement so that a loss company falls into the rules if the purpose of the arrangement is to defeat the intention of the rules.

column1: It is possible any cute “tax planning” of this nature to deliberately take advantage of the rules would be scrutinised down the track.
We acknowledge the Government has brought these rules in under urgency to provide assistance for businesses in need of cash flow.
It has endeavoured to strike a balance of giving the much-needed assistance
column2: accommodating the need for part year and grouping rules
column3: while still maintaining some integrity measures. Unfortunately doing all these things inevitably leads to complex legislation.

column1: The decision to use this mechanism will be heavily fact dependent on each business’s circumstances. There are policy design features that mean the rules will not be that useful to some of the SME businesses targeted.
It is clear it will not be the panacea for every business and could in some cases expose a taxpayer to significant UOMI or other taxes unless care is taken.
Robyn Walker is a tax partner and Veronica Harley is an associate director at Deloitte||2

2020-06-06||We are all Keynesians now with governments around the world shovelling cash into their economies to try to at least partially offset the economic damage of lockdowns. Even uber-prudent Germany has engaged in an extraordinary spending spree
column2: first to support businesses during the closure period and then this week announcing big VAT cuts
column3: a €300 family bonus for every child and another round of business supports.

column1: Ireland’s Achilles’ heel in the past is that the government has spent when we had the money and then been forced to cut back in times of recession. Boom and bust cycles resulted. This time around
column2: having entered the pandemic in reasonable economic shape and with the budget in surplus
column3: we have some leeway. Ireland is engaged in a big fiscal stimulus
column4: with government spending in the first five months of the year up by more than 20 per cent . Fortunately the State can still borrow money at negligible interest rates to fund the deficit that is opening up
column5: thanks in part to unprecedented intervention from the European Central Bank.

column1: So can the next government float into office on a wave of borrowed cash which it can dispense? Not really. A careful reading of the recent report from the budget watchdog
column2: the Irish Fiscal Advisory Council
column3: shows that each stage of the crisis will bring its own challenges – and that we simply can’t budget on the basis of being able to borrow at current interest rates forever. We are walking a shaky financial tightrope as we move through this.

column1: The hard calls start on day one for the next government. Yes
column2: ministers will have the cheque book out – but the queue at the hatch will be long and not everyone will get paid. You could argue about just how high the deficit could be this year – and the answer might well end up north of 10 per cent of gross domestic product – but there is a limit.

column1: As well as the contentious issue of the phasing-out of wage and income supports
column2: there are calls from business for more cash
column3: a line-up of State bodies with big financial holes and so on. There is a strong case to go the extra mile on the once-off supports – and Minister for Finance Paschal Donohoe hinted on Friday that more help to protect businesses and jobs would likely be needed. But deciding what will be subsidised through the crisis and what won’t will be hugely controversial.

column1: And as well as once-off costs
column2: the need to provide ongoing higher levels of spending – in health
column3: childcare
column4: education
column5: public transport and so on – provides a big budgetary challenge. Donohoe referred this week to the likely need to continue borrowing in the years ahead to fund higher spending levels.

column1: The programme for government
column2: if agreed
column3: and the subsequent national recovery programme may give some context to this and to how the public finances might evolve. Right now we need it . The “A” word is being thrown around in relation to every proposed reduction of an emergency support programme
column4: and every refusal to throw additional cash at some other problem.

column1: What we are facing is not austerity – which is when a government hikes taxes and cuts spending to reduce the budget deficit during a recession. That is what happened in 2009 and 2010. Now government borrowing is soaring. The issue is making decisions on where the money goes to and how much we can spend – all against a backdrop of huge uncertainty. Pretending there is some endless supply of cash and no constraint at all on borrowing into the future is just not credible.
Choices will also await in what the IFAC called phase two
column2: which is when the Government goes to stimulate the economy via higher spending
column3: probably moving into 2021 if the opening-up goes okay. The council pencilled in €10 billion as a possible stimulus
column4: though said it should be “temporary and targeted”. Again
column5: you can just imagine the queue of mendicants for this . The money will only go so far and only last so long – and continued restrictions in areas like tourism might leave some sectors unable to benefit .

column1: The council’s central expectation is that the economy might return to its pre-Covid position in a couple of years. That would be a result. With the economy growing
column2: there would then be a job in adjusting tax and spending over a period of years to get the public finances back on a sustainable path. The council guesstimated that this might involve tax hikes and spending cuts of €6 billion to €14 billion
column3: probably starting in 2023. But it should be possible to avoid another bout of severe austerity.

column1: New government programmes
column2: separate from the pandemic
column3: will have to be paid for too and any credible programme for government must face the trade-offs. Not increasing the pension age
column4: for example
column5: will leave less to spend elsewhere. Green policies are vital
column6: but come with a price tag.

column1: We are facing into unprecedented uncertainty – we really don’t have any basis to decide how the next few months will go. The IFAC analysis shows just how delicate the outlook is and how a worse health outcome could cause real challenges
Economics is all about the allocation of scarce resources. And politics
column2: over the next few years
column3: will be too
column4: and the uncertainties make this a lot more difficult. The ECB made clear this week that its programme to support the market would last until at least June of next year – and longer if needed. But it said
column5: too
column6: that it is a temporary intervention. And it would not be clever to assume current borrowing costs will continue for Ireland on the market once the ECB starts to wind down. The era of money for (almost) nothing won’t last forever. When it ends
column7: we can’t afford to get caught out again
column8: as we did in the last crisis.||1

2020-06-06||A south Dublin nursing home is closing because it is unable to meet its statutory and regulatory requirements to operate at full capacity or fund the costs needed to meet them.
St Mary’s Centre (Telford) on Merrion Road said the Covid-19 pandemic had no bearing on the decision to close and that the home
column2: which has 35 residents
column3: has remained free of the disease.

column1: The care home said the “current and projected levels of funding from the HSE mean that the nursing home will not be able to meet the necessary statutory and regulatory requirements to operate at 100 per cent capacity” and that it was currently operating at 60 per cent capacity.
“This decision was reached by the board following a number of meetings and detailed reviews concerning the funding of the nursing home
column2: the necessary implications for the viability of the nursing home and its capacity to meet statutory and regulatory requirements
column3: ” said the home.

column1: St Mary’s said in a statement it could not recruit and retain staff needed “to provide the high standard of care of the residents to which the board aspires” or ensure full compliance with the requirements sought by State watchdog the Health Information and Quality Authority (Hiqa).
The facility is located on a campus beside St Vincent’s hospital and is governed and run under the ethos of the Sisters of Charity.
“We have taken this extraordinarily difficult decision to wind down the operations of the nursing home in a careful and considered manner
column2: ” the home said.

column1: “We have not been able to secure capital funding to address necessary infrastructure issues or revenue funding to meet current and anticipated operative costs so we have no alternative but to close.”

St Mary’s was the subject of a highly critical report in 2017 by Hiqa whose inspectors found it had failed to respond effectively to the needs of frail and highly dependent residents. A follow-up inspection by Hiqa in 2018 found that the home was still not complying with some regulations.
The home said the closure is being planned and organised over “the necessary period of time”
column2: and that it intends to consult staff
column3: residents and their families and keep in regular contact to ensure the transfers of residents happen “as smoothly as possible and with the minimum of disruption”.

column1: Mervyn Taylor
column2: executive director of Sage Advocacy
column3: a support service for vulnerable adults
column4: said the closure of St Mary’s was a concern. He called for further research to assess the strength of the nursing home sector to cope in the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic.

column1: “We hope that this is not the start of a process of other closures and we think that some resilience study of the sector is required post-Covid to assess the level of risk in the event that more nursing homes

2020-06-06||Individual COVID-19 fatality risk (and the consequences for universities)

Reopening universities for the autumn term will be risky for individuals' health and safety. This column describes the latest epidemiological evidence and argues that the biggest influence on individuals’ risk of severe illness is age. Individuals in their sixties face a 30 times higher fatality risk from COVID-19 than individuals in their thirties. Being obese
column2: non-white
column3: a man
column4: and having an underlying health condition also matter – each roughly doubles the fatality risk. But chronological age still remains the biggest risk – a fact that universities should keep in mind when planning their autumnal schedules.

column1: Many European universities plan to re-open as physical spaces in the autumn of 2020. How much danger will that create? What is an individual’s risk of severe illness and death? How should university leaders take the health of their staff into account when planning for the next academic year (the economic issues were discussed recently in a VoxEU article by Peter Dolton)?
In our judgement
column2: the most reliable source of information on the risk from COVID-19 is a 2020 “Open Safely” paper written by Elizabeth Williamson of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine
column3: with a large number of colleagues. It is a piece of technical epidemiological writing. We make an attempt to convey that paper’s substance in a way that we hope might be helpful to those enrolled and working in universities and the senior management teams who head them.

column1: The first point to make is that the biggest influence on a person’s COVID-19 risk is age. The risk from age is actually an extraordinarily accelerating one (log-linear
column2: as an approximation). There have been grumpy and inaccurate discussions of this issue of age and risk in UK newspapers where lobby groups attacked the idea that chronological age is what matters. Instead
column3: the risk associated with so-called health conditions
column4: with being a man
column5: obese
column6: non-white
column7: or with having diabetes has been emphasized by the media.

column1: Further
column2: our two papers recommending a release out of the lockdown of the young have led to many older people reaching out to us voicing their beliefs that because they feel fit
column3: they face little or no risk from COVID-19. Unfortunately
column4: that belief is incorrect. Age is the crucial risk to bear in mind as shown by Williamson et al. (2020) (see Figure 1).

column1: Figure 1 Deaths from COVID-19 in England and Wales since January 2020
Note: Number of deaths registered in England and Wales where COVID-19 was mentioned in the certificate – up to 15/05/2020
Examining anonymized health records of 17 million UK citizens
column2: the authors assess who has died from COVID-19 while statistically adjusting for a large number of influences on people’s risk. Standard regression equations are then used to calculates hazard ratios. The results are the following:

column1: • People between 50-60 face a fatality risk from COVID-19 that is approximately 14 times higher than the risk faced by those around the middle of the age band of 18-40.
• For individuals between 60-70 who are in good health
column2: the risk is 30 times higher.

column1: • The fatality risk of men is double that of women.
• Individuals with middle-aged spread
column2: holding other things constant
column3: face an about 50% higher risk.

column1: • The same holds for non-white individuals as they face an almost doubled risk.
• Most standard kinds of health conditions also increase fatality risk
column2: roughly 2 to 3 times
column3: in general. The risk of individuals diagnosed with cancer is higher than the risk of men in general
column4: but it is still lower than the risk of simply being old.

column1: Hence
column2: the most prominent risk indeed stems simply from age. In essence
column3: this is due to young ‘animals’ stronger immune-response to most viruses also applying to COVID-19.

column1: Some newspapers have confusingly run headlines proclaiming obesity as a major cause of COVID-19 deaths. However
column2: while keeping ones BMI below 25 is certainly advisable and obese people undoubtedly face a higher risk of dying from COVID-19
column3: the main reason why obese people are dying much more is because obese people tend to be older.

column1: A second worrisome concern is the likelihood of misleading triumphalism in Europe over the coming summer. Premature optimism had lulled people already during the so-called Spanish Flu in the years of 1918-1919. Figure 2
column2: taken from Taubenberger and Morens (2006)
column3: depicts the three waves of deaths from the Spanish Flu. The first wave
column4: which at the time seemed very large
column5: peaked in early summer of 1918. When it died down
column6: policymakers took a more relaxed approach as they believed it to be over. Unfortunately
column7: a second wave appeared in autumn of 1918 and the number of deaths this time was five times higher. A third wave followed in the Spring of 1919 but most deaths occurred in late autumn and winter just after the pandemic was believed to be over.

column1: Figure 2 Deaths in the UK from the Spanish Flu 1918-1919

University presidents should keep this in mind when planning universities’ autumnal schedules. Our hunch is that misleading optimism about having beaten COVID-19 may appear by the end of the summer and lead to calls to open up UK universities in a really fundamental way. While it may be true that COVID-19 will really be over by then
column2: it is also worryingly possible that we are in for some form of a re-run of 1918. As early hotspots for COVID-19 were places like meat packing plants and skiing resorts
column3: which are both characterized by low temperatures
column4: it is possible that the coronavirus microbe may prefer cold environments. Studying the Spanish Flu virus
column5: He et al. (2013) conclude that every extra 10 degrees Celsius reduced the spread of this virus by nearly 50%. Of course
column6: COVID-19 is a different virus which might behave differently and much is still to be learned about COVID-19.

column1: A third concern is that the virus might mutate. However
column2: there is not much that can be done about that except to hope for the best.

column1: What should university faculty know and do?
First
column2: faculty members might want to appreciate the fact that most students are young and hence face a rather miniscule risk - current estimates suggest that it may be about the same as the risk of dying in a UK road accident in a normal year. Second
column3: university staff older than 50 may need to consider their own relative risk
column4: and might prefer to avoid front-line contact with students until a vaccine is found. Third and more encouraging
column5: current evidence suggests that even without a vaccine the great majority of Europe’s population will live through the pandemic without serious illness. Absolute risk for most people appears to be fairly low
column6: and there even remains a slight chance that the virus will disappear more quickly than standard epidemiological modelling has predicted.

column1: Still
column2: there is a long and menacing path ahead of us for the coming autumn and winter
column3: where it pays for each individual to know about their own relative risk. For university presidents and their management teams
column4: it is essential to recognize that the COVID-19 virus is much more dangerous to older members of university staff. This time
column5: age matters.

column1: 2020-06-06||The BCG vaccine does not protect against COVID-19: Applying an economist’s toolkit to a medical question

The prospect that BCG – a vaccine used primarily against tuberculosis – might offer protection from COVID-19 has become an understandably popular hypothesis. This column finds that hope misplaced. The authors exploit a natural experiment
column2: overlaying the large difference in BCG vaccination rates with the large differences in COVID-19 infection rates between the former East and West Germany. They find that the differences are attributable not to BCG
column3: but to the West’s copious commuter flow patterns and the fact that the epidemic arrived there first.

column1: As COVID-19 has spread across the globe
column2: so has an intense search for treatments and vaccines
column3: with numerous trials running in multiple countries. Several researchers (e.g. Hegarty et al. 2020
column4: Miller et al. 2020
column5: Ozdemir et al. 2020) and prominent news outlets have noticed that countries still administering an old vaccine against tuberculosis had fewer coronavirus cases and fewer deaths per capita in the outbreak’s early stages. But is that correlation evidence that the Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine provides some defence against COVID-19? In this column
column6: we describe the findings of our recent work (Bluhm and Pinkovskiy 2020) looking at the incidence of coronavirus cases along the former border between East and West Germany
column7: using modern econometric techniques to investigate whether historical differences in vaccination policies account for the lower level of infection in the East.

column1: Tuberculosis has been largely eradicated from the developed world
column2: and many rich countries have stopped using the BCG vaccine. Spain
column3: which ended mandatory BCG vaccination in 1985
column4: experienced more than 580 coronavirus deaths per million of its population and is one of the hardest-hit countries in per capita terms. Portugal
column5: Spain’s neighbour
column6: continues to perform mandatory BCG vaccination to this day and has experienced only 135 coronavirus deaths per million (all numbers as of 29 May 2020). More generally
column7: studies have documented that countries with mandatory BCG vaccination tend to have substantially fewer coronavirus cases and fewer deaths per capita than countries without mandatory vaccination
column8: and that the intensity of the epidemic is lower for countries that began vaccinating earlier (e.g. Hegarty et al. 2020
column9: Miller et al. 2020
column10: Ozdemir et al. 2020). Such cross-country correlations do not imply causation (Belloc et al. 2020) and sceptics have rushed to suggest that the passive immunisation from the BCG vaccine would at best be short-lived (Faust et al. 2020). The WHO now cautions that there is currently no evidence that the vaccine protects against the novel coronavirus (WHO 2020).

column1: Because they are often unable to perform randomised experiments
column2: economists have developed a suite of methods to exploit “natural experiments” that occur by chance as human action unfolds. We use one of these tools—a geographic regression discontinuity analysis (Dell 2010)—to determine whether coronavirus prevalence changes markedly at the Cold War-era border between East and West Germany
column3: whose vaccination policies differed prior to their reunification in 1990. East Germany had mandatory BCG vaccination until reunification
column4: while West Germany stopped voluntary but de facto universal vaccination in 1975.

column1: Our setting presents a puzzle of its own. Many observers in Germany have noticed a much lower coronavirus prevalence in the former East than in the West but found few convincing explanations for the difference. Moreover
column2: low mortality in Germany as a whole has been the subject of widespread speculation. We provide formal evidence that there is indeed a sizable discontinuity in COVID-19 cases at the border
column3: flexibly controlling for everything continuous there. Other important variables—such as disposable income and average age—also jump at the border
column4: but do not explain the discontinuity in COVID-19 cases. However
column5: the difference in coronavirus prevalence is uniform across age groups rather than being dependent on whether individuals were born before or after the cessation of (near) universal vaccination in each part of the country. This fact cannot be explained by a broader immunity acquired via the BCG vaccine.

column1: COVID-19 prevalence is much higher in former West than in East Germany
We start our analysis with a map of coronavirus cases by county as of 26 April
column2: using data from the Robert Koch Institute. The former border between East and West Germany is outlined in red. The darker the shading of a county
column3: the more coronavirus cases it has per million inhabitants. Several counties with high concentrations stand out (such as Heinsberg
column4: bordering the Netherlands
column5: and much of Bavaria – both places where the epidemic was first recorded). There is clearly a greater density of coronavirus cases around major cities (Berlin
column6: Hamburg
column7: and Stuttgart)
column8: as in the US. More importantly
column9: we immediately see that counties just to the west of the former border are a much darker shade of blue than counties just to the east.

column1: Notes: Illustration of the spatial distribution of COVID-19 cases in Germany as of 26 April 2020. The map shows the log (1 + cases/million people) in each county using population data from 2018.
To formalise the intuition of this map
column2: we use a regression discontinuity design in which we nonparametrically estimate coronavirus prevalence as a function of the distance to the border and compare estimates from the eastern and western sides. We present a graphical representation of this exercise in the chart below
column3: where the dependent variable is the logarithm of coronavirus cases per million inhabitants—a gauge of the exponential spread of the virus. The jump at the border is about 0.7 log points
column4: which implies that there are half as many cases per capita in a former East German county than in a West German county just across the border. This halving of cases dominates the variation in coronavirus prevalence among counties in the East (where it is uniformly low) and is sizable relative to the average prevalence in the West. Far-away counties in Bavaria or near the border with France have the highest cases
column5: but a smooth spread from there would imply a continuous decline
column6: and cannot explain the precipitous drop at the border.

Notes: Illustration of the discontinuity log (1 + cases/million people) across the former border between West and East Germany. The figure shows non-parametric local polynomial estimates for bins of the dependent variable

column1: BCG vaccination is not driving this discontinuity
Our key piece of evidence makes the BCG hypothesis appear very unlikely. We exploit the fact that East Germany had mandatory vaccination from 1953 to 1990
column2: while West Germany recommended vaccinating everyone from 1961 to 1975. If the vaccine protects against the virus
column3: then we would expect that discontinuities in detected cases among people aged 15-34 (most of whom did not get the vaccine anywhere) would be small or non-existent. On the other hand
column4: discontinuities among people aged 35-59 (all of whom were vaccinated in the East
column5: as opposed to only those above age 45 in the West) should be larger. The chart below shows that the discontinuities in coronavirus prevalence for both age groups are stark and roughly identical in size
column6: contradicting what we would expect to see if the BCG hypothesis were true. Moreover
column7: for early April
column8: we have more fine-grained data on cases for individual ages
column9: allowing us to form age groups that directly correspond to the policy shift in BCG vaccination. They also show discontinuities that are equal or even smaller in the older cohort.

Notes: Illustration of the discontinuity log (1 + cases/million people) across the former border between West and East Germany for different age groups. The left panel shows results for ages 15-34 and the right panel shows results for ages 35-59. Both figures show non-parametric local polynomial estimates for bins of the dependent variable
column2: where each bin is 20 km wide; 95% confidence intervals are shaded in grey.

column1: Alternative explanations: Commuter flows and the geography of the early outbreak
If the BCG vaccine does not explain the East-West differential in coronavirus cases
column2: then what does? Historically
column3: pandemics have been spread by the movement of people and trade from one area to another (Voth 2020)
column4: so in that spirit we investigate Germany’s commuting patterns. If those who live in the West work in the West and
column5: in spite of a large wave of migration post-reunification
column6: most former East Germans still work in the East
column7: it may be the case that travel flows have not readjusted completely since reunification. In other words
column8: Western counties along the former border may remain more disconnected from their Eastern neighbours than they would if a national border had never divided them. As the epidemic started in the West
column9: it may have had a harder time spreading eastward because relatively fewer people commute between East and West than commute across comparable distances within the West or within the East. The eastward spread of the virus was then further interrupted by the nation-wide lockdown instituted on 22 March.

column4: the number of cases also discontinuously declines as one crosses from West to East over the former border
column5: with a decline smaller but close in magnitude to the decline observed in the actual data. Our methodolog||0

column1: 2020-06-06||Valuating health vs wealth: The effect of information and how this matters for COVID-19 policymaking
The behavioural interventions to control the spread of COVID-19 present trade-offs between health and wealth. To be successful
column2: an understanding of how the public currently values lives over economic loss is needed. A survey experiment in the US and UK finds that people highly prioritise saving lives
column3: but this valuation will change as economic losses mount. Individual differences in valuation also predict individual compliance with COVID-19 policies
column4: and information on COVID-19 deaths and income losses can affect valuations. Caution in relaxing the lockdown will help build public support and mitigate polarising effects and
column5: through increasing compliance
column6: improve its economic efficacy.

column1: In the absence of medicine-based responses to COVID-19
column2: policymakers have to rely on behavioural interventions to control the transmission of the virus. Yet
column3: at least in the short run
column4: these interventions create a trade-off between saving lives and saving the economy – a ‘health–wealth trade-off’. The lockdown restrictions on individual freedoms
column5: for example
column6: saved lives by preventing transmission
column7: but they came at the cost of lost output and income (Baldwin and Weder di Mauro 2020).

column1: Relaxing a lockdown involves the same trade-off but in reverse: the economy recovers but at a cost of an increased threat of virus transmission. There are similar potential medium-term trade-offs in the choice between strategies of herd immunity and so-called ‘hammer and dance’ (Pueyo 2020). Faced with such health–wealth trade-offs
column2: how should policymakers decide where to locate the balance?

column1: This question has led policymakers to dust off risk-valuation manuals to see whether the proposed movement makes cost-benefit good sense. For instance
column2: the OECD (2012) suggests
column3: on the basis of evidence
column4: that a figure between $1.5–$4.5 million should be used as the statistical value of life
column5: with a base value of $3 million (the EU uses a slightly wider range and a higher base value of $3.6 million).

column1: Armed with such a figure
column2: consider the UK lockdown. The Imperial College modellers predicted that lockdown would save several hundred thousand lives (Ferguson et al. 2020)
column3: whilst current estimates point to a lockdown loss of more than 10% of GDP (Bank of England 2020); 10% of GDP is £221
column4: 489 million. Thus
column5: even if only one
column6: rather than several
column7: hundred thousand lives had been saved
column8: the lockdown would have cost about £2 million per life saved and would have produced a net benefit
column9: using the OECD’s base figure valuation of a life at $3 million. Beyond 100
column10: 000 lives saved
column11: the net benefit from lockdown quickly becomes enormous.

column1: Setting aside arguments against using cost-benefit analysis in such decisions
column2: there are two problems with recycling OECD (or other) estimates of the value of a statistical life. First
column3: the figures vary widely and – although the OECD proposes a range
column4: any part of which would probably make the lockdown yield a net benefit – they refer to the value of a statistical life. COVID-19
column5: however
column6: produces mortality disproportionately in the old and those with co-morbidities.

column1: So perhaps the alternative quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) approach – whereby quality-adjusted life-years saved are valued – should be used. With as much as 20% of those over 70 who die from COVID-19 being likely to die within one year anyway
column2: and a QALY value of between £20–30
column4: a positive net benefit from lockdown becomes much less likely.

column1: The second problem is deeper. The policy choices relate to COVID-19 deaths; not imaginary deaths in the past and not some medical intervention that might prolong life by one year. Thus
column2: what plausibly matters is how people currently value such deaths. This is for two reasons.

column1: First
column2: how people value health over wealth in this period obviously matters for the politics of these decisions. Politicians are re-elected by the people who assess government performance by their own lights; not by how well the government executed a manual’s implicit assessment.

column1: Second
column2: people’s current valuation may matter because there is evidence that people are more likely to follow rules when they agree with them (Tyler 1990). We don’t know whether this is the case for COVID-19 lockdown policies
column3: but if it is
column4: then the efficacy of any lockdown or its relaxation also depends on whether its movement on a health–wealth trade-off accords with the public’s relative valuation of health over wealth.

column1: Of course
column2: although these considerations are real
column3: they would not matter if we had reason to believe that people’s assessments in such matters were relatively constant (in that case
column4: the OECD’s summary might apply). Yet we don’t. In fact
column5: we know such assessments are extremely sensitive to exposure to the risk in question (e.g. Gigerenzer 2014) – think of the exodus from flying in the US post-9/11.

column1: So
column2: features specific to COVID-19 will influence people’s current COVID related health–wealth valuation. This is why we conducted a survey experiment in the UK and the US to see how people actually value health over wealth in the context of COVID-19 and the lockdown (Hargreaves Heap et al. 2020).

column1: The survey consists of a sequence of binary choices between pairs of health and wealth outcomes for each country. The sequence is designed so that anyone who values both ‘lives saved’ and ‘average household income’
column2: and has a preference ordering over their various combinations
column3: will switch at one point from the option that always does as well or better than the other on health
column4: to the option that does better on wealth. Where they switch is an indicator of their relative valuation of health over wealth and can be interpreted as giving the lower bound for the value of life.

column1: The experimental element comes from asking participants to make this sequence of choices a second time. After the first occasion
column2: the participants engage in another task and are then divided into three sub-groups. One sub-group receives an information prompt on the predicted number of COVID-19 deaths (per million) by August; another receives an information prompt on the predicted loss of GDP per capita through lockdown measures in 2020. The final sub-group is our control group; they hear a short piece of instrumental music instead.

column1: The participants then make the decisions over health and wealth combinations again. This experimental element allows us to test for the robustness of the health–wealth valuations (do they change much in the control?) and for whether they respond in predictable ways to information on deaths and income losses (in the two information treatments).
We find that in the peak of the pandemic in the UK and US
column2: the average implicit value of a COVID-19 life was extremely high by the standards of the OECD figures. The average value is a factor of around ten times greater than usual. This means that the lockdown policy accorded very well with the public’s preferences for health over wealth at that time. Indeed
column3: the lockdown policies were met by increased support for the governments imposing them (Blais et al. 2020).

column1: We also find that the individual variation in this valuation predicts individual compliance with the lockdown measures in both countries. So
column2: policymakers do need to care about what the people think in this matter
column3: not just for political reasons of re-election
column4: but also because it affects the efficacy of any policy change through its influence on compliance.

column1: This experimental evidence gives us a clue as to whether the valuations will change as the experience of COVID-19 deaths recedes and income losses mount (see Midoes 2020): they will.
On the one hand
column2: the high valuation of COVID-19 lives saved implies that any relaxation of the lockdown – which will produce a spike in COVID-19 deaths – will court unpopularity and lack of compliance. On the other hand
column3: information on COVID-19-related fatalities and growing income losses will lead people to adjust their relative valuation of health over wealth towards wealth (see Hargreaves Heap et al. 2020).

column1: In short
column2: the longer that relaxation of the lockdown is delayed
column3: people will become more tolerant of any increased deaths associated with the relaxation because income losses increase with delay. This insight complements an earlier one on the gains from the delay that come from better information on how to relax a lockdown (Santos-Pinot and Mata 2020).

column1: Moreover
column2: whilst unexpected deaths will
column3: in general
column4: put a brake on the drift to valuing wealth relatively more highly
column5: they also tend to polarise the valuations of health over wealth in the UK (Hargreaves Heap et al 2020); this is in a context where there is already evidence of polarisation in other respects (see Gambacorta et al. 2020). Both effects reinforce the argument for caution in relaxing the lockdown because a delay will help avoid the braking and polarising effect of unexpected deaths on people’s valuation of health relative to wealth as it otherwise drifts – in both the UK and the US – towards wealth.

column1: The politics of loosening (and potentially re-tightening) lockdowns are not straightforward (see Aksoy et al. 2020)
column2: not least because standard tools employed
column3: such as information provision (see Fetzer et al. 2020)
column4: might generate unintended consequences that undermine policy objectives. At a minimum
column5: they should at least be facilitated by analyses of the public’s relative valuations of health and wealth.

2020-06-07||Many governments are slowly unwinding their economies from nationwide lockdowns. However
column2: re-opening the economy entails a serious trade-off between fostering economic output and keeping the spread of infection low. This column reports several re-opening scenarios for the UK economy
column3: documenting their projected impacts on both GDP and the spread of the virus. The results suggest that it is best to re-open upstream industries first
column4: as they provide a large direct and indirect economic boost at a relatively lower cost in terms of further epidemic spreading.

column1: The economic disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic are large and have affected some industries and occupations more than others (Koren and Peto 2020
column2: del Rio-Chanona et al. 2020). For example
column3: labour supply shocks strongly affected construction
column4: but were absent in sectors considered essential. Yet
column5: given the interconnected nature of the economy
column6: even the sectors shielded from the direct shocks eventually face adverse consequences. First-order shocks are amplified through production networks and the interaction of supply and demand (Inoue and Todo 2020
column7: Barrot et al. 2020
column8: Mandel and Veetil 2020
column9: Bonadio et al. 2020
column10: Baqaee and Farhi
column11: 2020). For instance
column12: in Norway
column13: within a month
column14: two thirds of the layoffs happened in businesses that were not directly hit by the shocks (Alstadsæter et al. 2020).

column1: Governments that are now seeking to re-open their economies cannot ignore these network interactions. To determine the relative economic boosts of different re-opening scenarios
column2: they need to consider the risks of an unbalanced re-opening that may worsen supply chain bottlenecks. Besides
column3: they must also consider that the risk of infection faced by workers varies across industries and search for an appropriate compromise between increasing economic output and controlling the epidemic spreading.

column1: In a recent paper (Pichler et al. 2020)
column2: we investigate several scenarios for the phased re-opening of the UK economy by modelling production network effects explicitly. At one extreme
column3: we find that re-opening only a very limited number of industries can create supply chain ‘mis-coordination problems’ that may even decrease aggregate output. At the other extreme
column4: re-opening all industries without extra precautionary measures would increase the epidemic reproduction number (R ) to above one
column5: and may cause a second wave of the epidemic. Our results suggest that there is a reasonable compromise that yields a relatively small increase in epidemic spreading and delivers a substantial boost in economic output.

column1: In an interconnected economy
column2: it is intrinsically difficult to assess the economic impact of re-opening only some industries. Each industry relies on other industries
column3: sometimes critically. For example
column4: the metal manufacturing industry cannot operate without supplies from the mining industry. Opening parts of the economy without considering these relationships could cause severe supply chain disruptions.

column1: We designed a novel economic model that acknowledges the unique features of the current crisis
column2: and specifically (i) deals simultaneously with supply and demand shocks
column3: (ii) allows for sluggish consumption recovery
column4: and (iii) incorporates sectoral inventory buffers. The core of the model is an industrial production network that distinguishes between critical and non-critical inputs. To determine which inputs are critical
column5: we use a survey of IHS Markit industry analysts
column6: who were asked “Can production continue in industry X if input Y is not available for two months?”.

column1: Our model is calibrated to the UK economy and initialised with first-order supply and demand shocks derived in del Rio-Chanona et al. (2020). Validation exercises show that our model is in good agreement with recent estimates from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) and is in line with the sectoral unemployment data of the US. Our model predicts a reduction in GDP of 1.7% for the first quarter and a reduction of 21.5% for the second quarter of 2020 (compared to the last quarter of 2019). These estimates are in the range of other forecasts for the UK economy
column2: although on the more pessimistic side.

column1: Figure 1 Simulation results for implementing and unwinding the UK lockdown
As in most economic models
column2: the predicted outcomes depend fairly strongly on the choice of the production function. We assume that non-critical inputs are not necessary (to avoid the unrealistic collapse of the economy that would take place under a standard Leontief model). However
column3: we do assume that critical inputs are absolutely necessary
column4: and in fixed proportion
column5: leading to non-trivial network effects. For instance
column6: we find the counter-intuitive result that re-opening only a few industries can lower aggregate output. This happens because when some sectors of the economy are output-constrained
column7: other industries compete for these scarce inputs. Important industries may then run out of inventory and eventually lack critical inputs to operate.

column1: If re-opening only a handful of selected industries can cause problems
column2: re-opening should be broad enough. However
column3: this can of course be very risky in terms of infections. This prompted us to evaluate the effects of the re-opening scenarios on R
column4: the reproduction number of the epidemic. We decompose the epidemic transmission rate into five sources of infections: infections at the workplace
column5: at school
column6: during consumption activities
column7: during commuting
column8: and finally
column9: infections that are not influenced by whether or not an industry is open. We also estimate the infection risk in each industry. For instance
column10: the healthcare sector is responsible for more work-related infections than the forestry sector. This is because health workers have more contacts
column11: each contact has a higher infection risk
column12: and there are more healthcare than forestry workers overall. As another example
column13: the retail and restaurant sectors contribute much more to consumption infections than the mining sector
column14: because there are virtually no direct consumption activities in the mining industry.

column1: By splitting sources of infection by economic activity
column2: we can assess both the economic and epidemic impact of different scenarios.

column1: We then use this simple epidemic model to study five re-opening scenarios. First
column2: to establish a proper benchmark
column3: we quantify the effect on epidemic spreading if the lockdown continues. Second
column4: we analyse the impact of fully re-opening agriculture
column5: mining
column6: manufacturing
column7: and construction (which were not entirely closed during the UK lockdown). Third
