column1: 2020-06-14||The COVID-19 pandemic has raised concerns about the future of work. The pandemic may become recurrent and necessitate repeated adoptions of social distancing measures
column2: creating substantial uncertainty about worker productivity. This column presents a theoretical framework suggesting that such job uncertainty reduces aggregate demand
column3: and dampens business investment in general. However
column4: automation may provide one way for businesses to cope with the uncertainty about worker productivity. It appears that pandemic-induced job uncertainty could stimulate automation investment
column5: despite declines in aggregate demand.

column1: The Covid-19 outbreak is leading to a steep decline in global economic activity as countries around the world use social distancing measures to avoid exposure to the coronavirus or to limit its spread. The pandemic has also led to a surge in uncertainty. The ‘VIX’ – a frequently used measure of uncertainty – spiked to levels surpassing even those experienced during the 2007-2008 global crisis (see Figure 1). While the VIX has declined since its March peak
column2: its level remains elevated by historical standards
column3: suggesting that households and businesses are still facing a highly uncertain environment.

column1: An important source of this uncertainty stems from the unknown evolution of the virus and the effectiveness of social distancing measures. Absent the discovery of an effective vaccine with widespread availability
column2: additional waves of infections remain a possibility. Thus
column3: social distancing measures and lockdowns may need to be periodically reintroduced to deal with future infection flare-ups
column4: which may portend a ‘new normal’ in which viral infections become more pervasive and forceful. Such an uncertain environment is highly challenging for businesses that need employees to be on site
column5: since workers may be exposed to potential health risks or have to stay home due to lockdowns. Thus
column6: businesses may need to consider alternative strategies to minimise the impact of future production disruptions.

column1: For some businesses
column2: automation may be an attractive option (e.g. Kilic and Marin 2020). By reducing the need for on-site human interactions
column3: investing in robots
column4: for instance
column5: could help address concerns about future viral outbreaks (and the associated production disruptions). On the other hand
column6: businesses typically refrain from investing in the face of heightened uncertainty
column7: preferring to wait for more clarity (e.g. Bloom 2009
column8: Leduc and Liu 2016). As a result
column9: while automation may provide one way to cope with the production uncertainty induced by the pandemic
column10: it also necessitates investment spending that firms may be reluctant to actually make. Given the rarity of serious viral outbreaks in much of the world in recent decades
column11: empirical results describing how firms adapt to such situations are limited. Ma et al. (2020) provide evidence for the impact of epidemics in Asia over the past 20 years
column12: but their analysis does not apply to the rest of the world. In this context
column13: estimated theoretical models can provide a useful alternative
column14: complementing some of the emerging work on uncertainty and the pandemic. For some recent empirical studies on pandemic-induced uncertainty
column15: see Baker et al. (2020)
column16: Leduc and Liu (2020a) and Dietrich et al. (2020). Further
column17: the new eBook by Baldwin and di Mauro (2020) contains additional essays on a wide range of topics related to COVID-19 economics.

column1: In a recent paper (Leduc and Liu 2020b)
column2: we develop a quantitative New Keynesian model of the labour market. In this model
column3: firms face uncertainty about future labour productivity and have the ability to automate jobs. We focus on one channel of pandemic-induced uncertainty that we label job uncertainty
column4: emphasising the impact that future outbreaks may have on worker productivity. For simplicity
column5: we assume that productivity is impacted by labour-specific productivity shocks that are subject to ‘second-moment’ disturbances
column6: capturing variations in uncertainty.

column1: We build on our earlier work (Leduc and Liu 2019) and study the role of automation in an economy with ‘search and matching frictions’ in the labour market. Firms create
column2: and post
column3: job vacancies to hire workers and produce goods. Firms that are unsuccessful in finding a worker can decide to automate the job with a robot. Robots can perfectly substitute for workers
column4: therefore differing from physical capital in standard macro models. In this sense
column5: automation is a form of labour-saving technology.

column1: Adopting a robot entails a fixed cost
column2: and using a robot also incurs an operating cost. A firm’s decision to adopt a robot depends on the relative benefit of automating versus keeping a vacancy open. If a firm decides to keep a vacancy open
column3: it can decide to fill it with a worker or a robot in the future. Importantly
column4: in contrast to workers
column5: robots and their productivity would not be susceptible to epidemics
column6: since viruses do not impede their ability to produce. Hence
column7: whether to automate or not will partly depend on current
column8: and expected
column9: future worker productivity
column10: and pandemic-induced job uncertainty would be an important factor underlying automation decisions.

column1: To assess the quantitative effects of job uncertainty
column2: we first estimate our model to fit quarterly US time series data from 1985:Q1 to 2018:Q4. In addition to the unemployment and vacancy rates
column3: we fit the model to the time series of real wages
column4: labour productivity
column5: inflation
column6: and nominal interest rates. Since the rate of automation has important implications for productivity and wage growth
column7: including these variables helps discipline the importance of automation. In our estimation
column8: we do not consider pandemic-induced uncertainty
column9: since pandemics are not observed in our sample. After we estimate the model
column10: we introduce uncertainty shocks to worker productivity to examine its macroeconomic effects.

column1: We show that an increase in pandemic-induced job uncertainty operates through two channels: a demand-reducing channel and a technology-switching channel. First
column2: the job uncertainty raises precautionary saving and reduces household consumption. Since prices are sticky
column3: firms cut production to meet the reduced demand for their products. All else being equal
column4: the decline in economic activity reduces a firm’s incentive to invest in automation. However
column5: through the technology-switching channel
column6: the job uncertainty would incentivise a firm to automate
column7: since robots are not susceptible to viruses and can continue to operate during epidemics.

column1: Figure 2 shows that a pandemic-induced uncertainty shock raises the unemployment rate whilst also boosts automation in the benchmark model (the blue solid lines). These impulse responses reflect that the technology-switching channel dominates the demand-reducing channel under our estimation.
In general
column2: increased automation can have ambiguous impacts on employment. Since robots substitute for workers
column3: increased automation tends to reduce employment. However
column4: given the option of automation
column5: a firm would have a stronger incentive to create new job vacancies because of the reduced risks associated with hiring workers. Under our estimated parameters
column6: this latter channel boosts employment and outweighs the labour-substituting effects of automation.

column1: To illustrate the interactions between automation and unemployment in our model
column2: we consider a counterfactual model in which automation is kept constant at its steady-state value. Figure 2 shows that
column3: with no fluctuations in automation
column4: a pandemic-induced job uncertainty shock would have led to a deeper recession with a sharper increase in unemployment (the red dashed line). Therefore
column5: endogenous automation decisions help alleviate the recessionary impact of the job uncertainty shock. An alternative way to interpret our results is that automation reduces some tasks done by workers
column6: whereas it facilitates other tasks
column7: which boosts overall employment (e.g. Acemoglu and Restrepo 2019).

column1: Figure 2 Impulse responses to job uncertainty shock in the estimated model
In our model
column2: the effects of an increase in job uncertainty differ markedly from a realised decline in labour productivity such as that occurring in the current pandemic. Since social distancing measures and health concerns during a pandemic can hinder a worker’s ability to work
column3: the fall in labour productivity primarily acts as a negative supply shock that reduces potential output and increases inflation. As a result
column4: firms automate less. In contrast
column5: pandemic-induced job uncertainty leads to a recession by reducing aggregate demand
column6: such that both output and inflation decline. Despite the decline in demand
column7: firms still increase automation investment because of the positive technology-switching channel.

column1: Overall
column2: our finding suggests that pandemic-induced job uncertainty shocks can have a positive net effect on automation investment
column3: despite its negative effects on aggregate demand. Although robots can substitute for workers
column4: the increased automation (stemming from the technology-switching channel) can still mitigate job losses. The option of automating reduces the risk of hiring workers and thus boosts a firm’s incentive for creating new positions.

2020-06-14||The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has led to a massive increase in the demand for essential medical equipment. This column discusses recent findings on the role of international trade of essential medical goods in exacerbating or mitigating the impact of a pandemic. The effects depend crucially on the countries’ trade imbalances in essential medical goods. Net importers of these goods are relatively worse off during a pandemic than net exporters. Although the welfare losses of net importers are lower in a world with high trade barriers
column2: they benefit from reducing barriers once the pandemic arrives.

column1: The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has led to a massive increase in the demand for essential medical equipment to combat the spread of the disease. For instance
column2: goods such as masks
column3: gloves
column4: respirators
column5: and COVID-19 tests are playing a key role in allowing healthcare workers to respond to the ongoing pandemic. While supply has been gradually increasing to try to satisfy the high demand for these goods
column6: countries continue to face supply shortages and are increasingly forced to ration these goods.

column1: Amidst the growing fear of these supply shortages
column2: countries have been resorting to trade policy to meet domestic demand. According to Evenett (2020)
column3: “a growing number of governments have been sickening their trading partners by banning or limiting the export of medical supplies.”

column1: In our recent paper (Leibovici and Santacreu 2020)
column2: we document that the heterogeneous response of trade policy across countries is systematically related to the extent to which countries are net importers or net exporters of essential medical goods. We then develop a general equilibrium model of international trade to study the role of trade of essential goods in mitigating or exacerbating the effect of a pandemic like COVID-19.

column1: We combine data on import liberalisations and export restrictions from Global Trade Alert with international trade flow data on essential medical products to fight COVID-19 from UN COMTRADE. We find that
column2: of 109 countries studied
column3: 29 countries have implemented some type of liberalisation on essential medical products since April 2020
column4: whereas 59 countries have imposed restrictions. Moreover
column5: recent changes to trade policy for essential medical goods appear to be systematically related to countries’ positions as net suppliers or net importers of these goods. As of 24 April
column6: 86% of the countries with a trade surplus in these goods have recently imposed restrictive export policies
column7: while this has been the case for only 46% of the countries with a trade deficit.

column1: These findings suggest that international trade plays a fundamental role on the cross-country impact of a pandemic. In Leibovici and Santacreu (2020)
column2: we investigate the role of international trade of essential goods in mitigating or exacerbating this impact.

column1: We ask two questions:
1. To what extent does the impact of a pandemic depend on whether countries are net exporters or net importers of essential goods?
2. What is the role of international trade in mitigating or exacerbating the impact of the pandemic?

We address these questions using a dynamic quantitative general equilibrium model with two countries and two sectors: one sector producing essential goods (i.e. medical equipment) and the other sector producing non-essential goods. There are adjustment costs to capital and labour in each sector.
We assume that both countries are symmetric throughout except that one country is relatively more productive in essential goods while the other is relatively more productive in non-essential goods
column2: leading the former to be a net exporter of essential goods and the latter to be a net importer of essential goods.

column1: To what extent does the impact of a pandemic depend on whether countries are net exporters or net importers of essential goods?
We find that
column2: in our model
column3: a global pandemic has significant heterogeneous effects across countries: net importers of essential goods are relatively worse off during a pandemic than net exporters. There are two main forces at play. First
column4: given that it is costly to reallocate production inputs across sectors
column5: producers of essential goods cannot sufficiently boost production
column6: leading to a substantial increase in their relative price. Then
column7: while the price of essential goods increases similarly in both economies
column8: the effect on welfare depends on the countries' sectoral trade imbalances. Both countries earn relatively more for their sales of essential goods
column9: and both countries have to spend relatively more for their purchases of these goods. However
column10: given that the net importer is less productive in essential goods
column11: this country sells less than it purchases
column12: while the reverse is the case for net exporters. As a result
column13: net importers of these goods are relatively worse off.

column1: In Leibovici et al. (2020) we document that the US relies heavily on imports of essential medical goods. Thus
column2: according to the model
column3: the US is likely to be relatively worse off from the supply shortages of medical products amid the COVID-19 pandemic than if it were to be a net exporter of these goods.

column1: What is the role of international trade in mitigating or exacerbating the impact of the pandemic?
We find that the level of international trade barriers at the onset of a pandemic can significantly alter its economic implications. In our model
column2: higher initial trade costs imply that the net importer runs a smaller trade deficit of essential goods than in a world with lower trade costs
column3: while the net exporter runs a smaller trade surplus in these goods. Therefore
column4: while a pandemic continues to lead to a substantial increase in the relative price of essential goods
column5: the relative impact on the home and foreign countries is mitigated. We thus conclude that while higher trade barriers on essential goods may reduce the amount consumed of these goods
column6: they mitigate the potential vulnerability of net importers of these goods when a global pandemic hits.

column1: These findings have important implications for the design of international trade policy. Even if countries may benefit on average from having cheaper access to goods
column2: the reliance on international trade might put these countries in a vulnerable position if these goods are essential and either the supply or demand of these goods is subject to global shocks.

column1: While these findings are informative about the ex-ante design of international trade policy
column2: they are silent about the impact of trade policy changes implemented once a pandemic hits. We thus conclude our analysis by asking: What is the impact of raising trade barriers in response to a pandemic?

column1: In contrast to the previous findings
column2: we now find that raising trade barriers when the pandemic hits can significantly exacerbate the welfare cost faced by net importers of essential goods. As a net importer
column3: the home country's production structure is such that it relies considerably on the foreign country for its consumption of essential goods. Thus
column4: an increase in trade barriers on these goods exacerbates the already painful situation faced by the net importer
column5: making the relative price of essential goods even higher.

column1: These results suggest that the design of international trade policy for essential goods may suffer from a time-inconsistency problem. Net exporters of essential goods may ex-ante prefer to live in a world with low trade costs
column2: but when a global pandemic hits they might be tempted to renege on their previous commitments and increase trade barriers. The reverse is the case for net importers of essential goods
column3: as they ex-ante prefer to live in a world with high trade costs on these goods; but
column4: when a global pandemic hits
column5: they would be tempted to renege on their commitments and instead decrease trade barriers.

column1: Events such as the current pandemic can lead to increased sentiment against international trade openness. Our research suggests there are no blanket solutions. Trade openness can be effective at addressing local shocks such as domestic pandemics
column2: but it can raise tensions in the context of a global shock such as COVID-19. The design of trade policy agreements needs to be considered carefully to ensure we get the benefits of trade while minimising the potential pain when global shocks hit. This is a key challenge raised by COVID-19—one we should try to meet to avoid falling back into a world with high trade barriers and the large costs that it would entail. In Baldwin and Evenett (2020) several contributors discuss how governments should react to this type of crisis.

column1: Finally
column2: although we do not explicitly model supply chains
column3: our column is related to an ongoing discussion on the disruption of global value chains amid COVID-19. The current pandemic raised questions on the potential vulnerability of relying on foreign supply chains during a global shock
column4: leading to a surge in arguments for protectionism and self-reliance (Bonadio et al. 2020). As Pinelopi Goldberg argues
column5: global coordination is important
column6: given that global value chains can diversify risks through international trade.

column1: 2020-06-13||It pains me to say this but Boris Johnson
column2: exhausted and looking increasingly forlorn
column3: appears to have a few short weeks to salvage his reputation and save his Government from ridicule.

column1: Still recovering from his near-death experience with Covid-19
column2: the Prime Minister faces unprecedented obstacles to prevent Britain slipping into a deep recession.

column1: With so many cards stacked against him
column2: our sallow-faced and hollow-eyed leader has squandered much of the goodwill he accumulated after his landslide Election victory in December.

column1: Even his friends whisper that there is no captain on the bridge steering the ship. According to a YouGov poll
column2: Johnson’s handling of the virus is rated as the worst of all world leaders.

column1: Many will discount the criticism as unfair. Contrary to predictions of doom from the Left
column2: the NHS has performed brilliantly.

column1: Eight million workers have been protected by the Chancellor’s £80 billion furlough package. Most of the country is becoming free of Covid. Despite our economy shrinking by 20 per cent in April
column2: it still ticks over.

column1: Johnson’s misfortune is that those achievements have been drowned out by the impression of defeat. Hampered by Downing Street’s cack-handed communications
column2: Johnson is mischievously blamed for orchestrating a shambles.

column1: Some believe his seeming impassivity
column2: sporadic public appearances and blustering press conferences are proof he’s still suffering the after-effects of Covid
column3: combined with sleepless nights with a six-week-old baby.

column1: Some of his harshest critics have boldly stated that if he had still been married to Marina
column2: his long-suffering ex-wife ‘who was unafraid to dispense home truths’
column3: Johnson’s life would be more stable than with a fiancee 23 years his junior.

column1: Such censure
column2: though
column3: ignores Boris’s strength. Over the years
column4: he has successfully compartmentalised his private and public lives.

column1: And since there is no obvious leading Tory who might put themselves forward as an alternative Prime Minister
column2: his supporters are convinced that not all is lost.

column1: Just as his hero Winston Churchill led Britain out of its Darkest Hour in 1940
column2: Johnson needs to summon the courage
column3: ideas and energy to enthuse the nation with a blueprint that will stop us coming out of lockdown in tatters.

column1: He also needs to fire failing Ministers – of which there are several – and Civil Service time-servers on whom he has mistakenly relied.
The fact is he has little time. No later than July 1
column2: just 18 days away
column3: Johnson needs to address Parliament and then the nation on TV to give the country confidence to believe that his Government machine is firing on all cylinders.

column1: We all need to be reassured that we can rely on the Prime Minister to restore normality as quickly as possible.
Johnson’s priorities must be to revive the economy; reopen all schools; launch a major resurgence of Britain’s cultural institutions such as cinemas
column2: museums
column3: concert halls and theatres; encourage pubs and restaurants to reopen; and finally
column4: to rebuild his Government with inspiring and gifted politicians.

column1: It is exactly five weeks ago that Johnson lost his halo. His disastrous TV address changing the slogan from ‘Stay Home’ to ‘Stay Alert’ was confusing
column2: vague and greeted by widespread irritation.

column1: Accused of confusing the message
column2: Johnson lost a huge amount of public goodwill.

column1: Until then
column2: many had tolerated the failure to provide NHS staff with sufficient protective gowns
column3: for example
column4: blaming the global shortage. Many also understood the crisis in privately owned care homes was not politicians’ fault.

column1: But Johnson’s reputation took a second battering. His apparently flippant dismissal of the allegations against Dominic Cummings for breaking the spirit of the lockdown was a self-inflicted disaster that exposed a gross misunderstanding of the national mood.
In the past
column2: he had listened to the advice of loyal friends outside the Downing Street bunker. Suddenly
column3: to avoid criticism
column4: he is shunning their calls.

column1: In explaining his plan to relax the lockdown
column2: the PM needed senior civil servants to deliver a clear
column3: common-sense scheme. But they failed.

column1: In truth
column2: Johnson has been let down by Whitehall’s perennial bunglers. Then he refused to identify and remove the guilty parties.

column1: By character
column2: Johnson has an aversion to confrontation. To date
column3: he has accepted all the scientists’ advice. That must end.

column1: We now know that their advice until mid-March was muddled or even wrong. We also know that the scientists now disagree on the best course forward.
Johnson
column2: in his DNA a libertarian and free-marketeer
column3: must follow his instincts and unshackle himself from the scientists’ chains. He should gamble that the risk of a few extra deaths is outweighed by the urgent need to reopen the country.

column1: Admittedly
column2: confrontation often ends in bloodshed but this is the only way for Johnson to restore his credibility. Simultaneously
column3: he must change his way of governing. Until now
column4: he has delegated most critical decisions to Ministers.

column1: Unwisely
column2: he allowed Home Secretary Priti Patel to announce a 14-day quarantine on travellers entering the UK – something that is unenforceable and has been widely ridiculed.

column1: Similarly
column2: he relied on Gavin Williamson
column3: the Education Secretary
column4: but he has blundered embarrassingly over the reopening of schools.

column1: And
column2: most alarmingly
column3: he has depended on Health Secretary Matt Hancock to mastermind the ‘war’ against Covid. It is shocking that Britain is third in the world death league from the virus despite only having the 21st largest population.

column1: The public has lost trust in Hancock
column2: of whom retired Supreme Court judge Lord Sumption wrote last week: ‘With his hectoring manner
column3: authoritarian assumptions and snarling threats
column4: [he] has resembled nothing so much as the petulant headmaster of a third- rate school.’

column1: It’s not just ministerial incompetence. No 10 is staffed by people of mixed ability. At its heart is Sir Mark Sedwill
column2: the Cabinet Secretary.

column1: Having trained in the Home Office
column2: his specialism is security
column3: which means he’s been poorly equipped to mobilise the Whitehall machine to tackle Covid.

column1: He also neglected to point out to Johnson the dysfunctional performance of senior officials in Public Health England
column2: the Department of Health and hospital trusts.

column1: Johnson should ignore his benign instincts and fire Sir Mark
column2: replacing him with a thrusting agent of change. At the same time
column3: he should replace the senior civil servants at health
column4: education and defence. All have failed to deliver.

column1: Whitehall needs to be revolutionised to get Britain back on its feet.
A litmus test of whether the medicine is working will be when we hear the screams of protest by the Luddite civil service trade unions.
Just three months ago
column2: pre-Covid
column3: the Johnson Government’s first Budget spelled out an exciting One Nation vision.

column1: Chancellor Rishi Sunak unveiled a visionary £30 billion plan to rebuild our infrastructure and finance a huge expansion to reboot Britain. The Government should double that investment.
Ministers must learn that we over-relied on the power of globalisation and on China. Of course
column2: that will need an army of experts – so
column3: in the short term
column4: Britain should recruit from around the world.

column1: Spending money to rebuild is easy compared to the parallel task of winning the political battle.
Covid aside
column2: Boris Johnson is under attack by those in denial that the Tories won a landslide Election victory just six months ago and who want to reverse Brexit.

column1: Defeating those enemies requires courage and conviction. No one doubts that Johnson had both these qualities before his illness
column2: but now there are worrying signs he is lacking the energy to fight simultaneously on many fronts.

column1: Indeed
column2: his enemies smell blood. Militant teachers have seized the upper hand and shown that their selfish interests are more important than the education of the nation’s children.

column1: Anarchist mobs have hijacked the Black Lives Matter protests. Michel Barnier
column2: the EU’s Brexit negotiator
column3: thinks he can bully Britain over our exit deal. The BBC has become a mouthpiece for anti-Tory criticism.

column1: Wales
column2: run by Labour
column3: and the Nationalist government in Scotland
column4: are defiantly following different policies from those pursued in London.

column1: Boris Johnson
column2: an acute student of history
column3: will recall he has experienced a similar hiatus. Six months into his time as London Mayor
column5: his administration was mired in chaos. Key appointments were exposed as disastrous.

column1: After their swift dismissal
column2: the arrival of a new chief of staff
column3: Simon Milton
column4: transformed Johnson’s mayoralty.

column1: Now
column2: to up his game
column3: it’s not City Hall that Johnson must rejuvenate
column4: but his Cabinet and Downing Street team.

column1: On a personal level
column2: too
column3: Johnson needs to change gear. He must show he is in charge. He must offer a vision and a big strategy.

column1: Above all
column2: it is imperative that the man who has been seen for years as a great communicator actually communicates better.

column1: At least
column2: for the present
column3: he knows that whatever his critics – and they are growing in number daily – throw at him
column4: he is the only politician with the capacity to unify and lead Britain. But even that certainty can quickly disappear.

column1: • None Tom Bower’s biography of Boris Johnson will be published in October||1

2020-06-15||The worst is over. Hopefully
column2: we will never again see such a terrible death toll from an infectious disease in Ireland. The response of the public
column3: North and South
column4: has been fantastic. When it comes to safeguarding health
column5: the public has always proven to be more than willing do what is needed to avoid catastrophic illness.

column1: As Shaw wrote over a century ago
column2: the public “dreads disease and desires to be protected against it”. As we have seen
column3: sometimes communities took the initiative themselves
column4: with parents keeping their children out of school and heads closing schools ahead of central instruction.

column1: The numbers of deaths and of new positive cases in Ireland have fallen steadily North and South. As they have reached a low level there is an understandable clamour to get back to normal. The effects of the restrictions on all aspects of life have been immense.

The damage done to businesses and individuals will have health consequences that have yet to materialise or be fully appreciated. The very restricted operation of health services will take time to restore and even longer to deal with the backlogs of routine and even urgent care that have built up.
Psychiatrists have predicted a “tsunami” of mental health problems following the crisis arising from conditions exacerbated or created by all that we have been through.
The bit that no one really wishes to hear and those dutybound to deliver the message keep saying
column2: is that we are not done with this coronavirus yet. As long as the virus is present and is still being transmitted in our communities
column3: workplaces and institutions we risk significant flare-ups.

column1: Importantly
column2: if those flare-ups are not stamped out immediately
column3: the highly infectious nature of the virus has the potential to cause substantially more deaths and disruption.

column1: What is needed
column2: with great urgency
column3: is a concerted effort to achieve a “Zero Covid-19 Ireland”. This will involve getting to zero new cases in both parts of the island and then maintaining and if necessary restoring that position. The resulting economic and social benefits would be enormous.

column1: Arguments about distances of 1
column2: 1.5m or 2m would be a thing of the past and our schools
column3: theatres
column4: arts centres
column5: clubs and pubs could get back to enhancing our lives and reconnecting our communities. There is absolutely no reason why this cannot be achieved.

column1: Two things about this task are very clear. Firstly
column2: lifting a high proportion of restrictions in a country before eliminating the virus is a recipe for playing an ongoing and exhausting game of cat and mouse with this deadly foe. The consequences could be continued
column3: and possibly massive disruption.

column1: The global number of new cases per day continues to grow and resurgence is apparent in some places that have ended lockdown prematurely.
Secondly
column2: as far as Ireland is concerned the task of eliminating all new cases of the virus occurring through domestic spread
column3: ie not coming from newly imported cases
column4: can only realistically be carried out on an all-island basis.

column1: The endgame for Covid-19 is not yet in sight. Researchers around the world are working on the development of more than 135 separate vaccines. There is no guarantee that an effective vaccine will be found and we would be unwise to plan on that basis.
The best option for Ireland is a joint North-South initiative empowered and resourced to hunt down the remaining cases and hot spots for the virus and deal with them as swiftly as possible.
Learning the lessons from countries
column2: such as South Korea and Germany
column3: that are further along the path shows that the capacity to react urgently to any flare-ups must be strengthened and maintained for the foreseeable future.

column1: Changes are
column2: of course
column3: needed to harmonise efforts on the island. These include details that should have been sorted out by now anyway
column4: such as the different isolation times of seven and 14 days on either side of the Border and the fact that “shortness of breath” is a recognised and listed symptom of Covid-19 in the South but not the North. But getting a jointly agreed case finding
column5: testing
column6: contact tracing
column7: isolate
column8: and support (FTTIS) system is the big priority.

column1: In Border counties in particular
column2: the ability to deal with cases and contacts on both sides of the Border in a seamless way is crucial. In doing the job well speed is everything.

column1: Serious east-west issues will arise. As the island gets close to “zero” status the focus will be firmly on stopping the importation on new cases. Agreed measures to prevent the virus being reintroduced via ports and airports will be crucial.
These are not constitutional issues – they are public health issues. They are not about sovereignty – they are about human lives and the preservation of jobs and a functioning economy.
We can revert to tribal allegiances in due course if we really want to
column2: but in the meantime let’s get the job done. Dr Gabriel Scally is president of epidemiology and public health at the Royal Society of Medicine in
column3: London||2

column1: 2020-06-15||East Vancouver parent Christa Wagner was a bit hesitant to send her twin eight-year-old boys back to school after being off since March break due to the pandemic
column2: but she can't argue with the results.

column1: Obviously it's a little bit different, but honestly they loved it. They had so much fun, Wagner said.
The boys are back in class for two full days a week. Normally they share their teacher with 23 other children
column2: but since they've been back at their school
column3: St. Francis of Assisi
column4: classrooms are limited to only eight students.

column1: It's been fantastic, Wagner said. "The school has done an amazing job."
In March
column2: the provincial government shut down schools to help mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

column1: Starting June 1
column2: elementary students could return for 50 per cent in-class instruction
column3: while middle and secondary school children were limited to one day a week. Children of essential-service workers and those needing additional supports have been able to attend full-time.

column1: The province says less than a third have returned with more children in elementary school and fewer in secondary school. Numbers also vary from school to school
column2: the province says
column3: and class to class.

column1: Parents
column2: children and teachers are reporting mixed experiences with how that shift has gone so far. One thing that most agree on is that it's been a teachable moment for everyone

Rae-Anne Schneider
column2: whose 15-year-old daughter Neve has Trisomy 9 Mosaic
column3: a rare chromosomal disorder that causes physical and cognitive impairments
column4: says her daughter's been glad to return to school full-time.

column1: Without the routine it's really difficult for her, Schneider said. "Behaviorally
column2: that gets challenging."

column1: Schneider has been off work for the past couple of months to care for Neve full-time.
As the parent of a child with complex needs
column2: she had support available
column3: but was concerned about the risk of her daughter catching the coronavirus because her immune system is compromised.

column1: When schools opened up again
column2: she felt it was time for Neve to go back.

column1: I love her to death, but I think sometimes it's good that we get a little break from each other, she said.
For many children who have returned to school
column2: the best part has been reconnecting with their friends and teachers.

column1: I was really happy to see my friends again and it was easier to work when my brothers weren't annoying, said Lord Selkirk student Oscar Needoba.
In school
column2: children like Oscar have faced what will likely be the new normal for months to come.

column1: Teachers wearing masks
column2: lines painted on the ground to enforce social distancing and desks pushed apart in classrooms are just some measures schools have put in place.

column1: Despite those precautions
column2: many parents say the risks are still too great for their kids to return to school.

column1: Like the majority of parents in B.C.
column2: Vancouver mother Victoria Harper chose to keep her twin 10-year-old girls at home. One of them has asthma
column3: she says
column4: and the other was terrified of catching the coronavirus.

column1: It was such an emotional decision, Harper said.
Life at home
column2: Harper says
column3: has been a surprisingly enjoyable change from the fast pace of pre-COVID life when the family juggled cooking classes
column4: badminton lessons and swimming.

column1: But schooling at home and over the Internet has become a challenge.
Both of them are at the point where they don't even want to do online schooling right now, she said. "They're just losing interest."
Luckily for Harper
column2: the end is in sight as most classes break for summer on June 25.

column1: Teachers too have had some relief with the return to in-class instruction
column2: but also new challenges.

column1: Terri Mooring
column2: president of the B.C. Teachers Federation
column3: says many teachers say they're glad to see their students again. The new safety protocols were strange for teachers and students alike at first
column4: Mooring says
column5: but everyone has adapted quickly.

column1: The biggest issue Mooring says she is hearing from teachers is that with some students back and others still at home
column2: teachers are doing double duty preparing two types of instruction for the same class.

column1: It's been incredibly labour intensive and not sustainable, Mooring said. "Their workloads have exponentially increased."
Mooring says it will be important for planning to take place this summer to help teachers better manage their course loads and work schedules.
Like education and school officials

column5: clothes
column6: and other expenditures. Yet
column7: many other sponsored refugees have constricted options to look for other jobs and are compelled to work despite growing health risks.

column1: In addition to their precarious employment

2020-06-16||“I in my chair with such a crew
column2: ” says the captain of a cargo vessel in the South Atlantic en route from Bermuda to Singapore. He is eight months into a four-month contract
column3: and almost everyone on board has also already worked at least double his contracted time. He hopes Singapore will accept that sailors who have seen almost no one but each other for months pose no infection risk and permit a crew change. If not
column4: some may refuse to keep working. On June 16th an industry-wide agreement to allow emergency contract extensions expired
column5: but that is no guarantee that ports will open up. “Believe me
column6: ” he says
column7: “the situation is critical.”

column1: When Rose George
column2: a journalist
column3: wrote about the shipping industry in 2013
column4: she called her book “Ninety Percent of Everything” to convey its importance to global trade. But during the covid-19 crisis almost none of the mariners who keep the world fed
column5: warmed and entertained have been allowed on shore. At any moment 1.2m are in cargo vessels on the high seas. (Half as many again work on cruise ships or vessels transporting goods within a single country’s territory.) At least 250
column6: 000 have finished their contracts and have no idea when they will be relieved. Similar numbers are stuck at home with no idea when they will next get work. Both totals are rising by tens of thousands each week.

column1: In normal times
column2: crewing the world’s merchant fleet is a logistical miracle. Ship-management firms handle the rosters
column3: signing crew on
column4: flying them from their home countries to a convenient port
column5: and getting them off their ships again and on a plane home. Many mariners are from developing countries
column6: in particular India
column7: Indonesia and the Philippines. They often start and end their contracts in hubs such as Dubai
column8: Hong Kong and Singapore. Contracts are typically of three to nine months
column9: with one month’s variation in either direction to make planning easier.

column1: The virus has thrown an almighty spanner in the works. Countries that classified lorry drivers
column2: pilots and cabin crew as essential workers overlooked merchant seamen
column3: even though their work underpins the global economy. Some will accept their citizens
column4: but ships may not be calling at a suitable port
column5: and management companies may not be able to line up relief. With few scheduled flights
column6: the sailors who manage to disembark may not be able to get home.

column1: At first they were proud to be able to help in the global emergency
column2: says Lars Robert Pedersen of
column3: which represents the owners of about 60% of the world’s merchant fleet. They are used to hard work and long contracts. But when official neglect continued
column4: sailors’ morale became a problem. “They are fed every day
column5: and they are getting paid
column6: but that’s not the point
column7: ” he says. “They are effectively imprisoned on board their ships.”

column1: Owners and managers are trying to make confinement more bearable with free internet and wage top-ups
column2: says Andreas Hadjipetrou
column3: the managing director of Columbia Shipmanagement. “One captain asked for gym equipment and karaoke
column4: ” he says. “The crew created a band and sent us a video clip.” More importantly
column5: they are doing everything they can to facilitate crew changes—which take not just planning
column6: but a hefty dose of luck.

column1: Among the merchant seamen relieved during the lockdown is Hrisheet Barve
column2: a ship’s captain and an Indian from the state of Goa. By the end of May he and 16 crew members
column3: also Indian
column4: were months over contract. Since they were sailing along India’s coast
column5: he proposed to the ship’s management company
column6: Anglo-Eastern
column7: that it divert to the port of Cochin in the state of Kerala for a crew change. The company agreed
column8: despite the cost and delay. Even though the men were all nationals
column9: disembarking required lengthy negotiations with the shipping ministry and port and state officials. They had seen no one else for months
column10: but still had to spend two weeks in quarantine.

column1: By the end
column2: says Captain Barve
column3: he was very worried about his men’s mental state. “When you’re all in the same boat—pun not intended—you can pull each other down.” And tired
column4: miserable sailors are unsafe
column5: he adds. “It just takes one captain to make a mistake and run a tanker aground and cause an oil spill. They will say it was a navigational error but the real culprit will be that he was working way longer than he should have been.”

column1: The International Maritime Organisation
column2: the arm of the that deals with shipping
column3: has drawn up a protocol for crew changes during the pandemic. It requires governments to classify merchant seamen as essential workers
column4: thus enabling them to travel and cross borders. Ports and airports need facilities for testing and quarantine
column5: and safe connections. “We have the standard operating procedure ready to act on
column6: ” says Bjorn Hojgaard of Anglo-Eastern. “We just need help from regulators.”

column1: The industry hopes that governments will be prodded into action by the sudden expiry of so many seamen’s contracts. The International Transport Workers’ Federation ( ) says it will support any seamen who refuse to work. If that leaves too few people to operate a ship safely
column2: its insurance policy could lapse
column3: and full liability fall on the captain and owner
column4: who might then decide it was too risky to keep going. The trade that has flowed so smoothly throughout the pandemic might finally gum up. “Everyone is happy to reap the benefits of global trade
column5: ” says Stephen Cotton
column6: the ’s general secretary. “But no one seems willing to step up when it comes to safeguarding those who deliver the things they need every day.” ■||1

column1: 2020-06-16||HEATHER QUINLAN and Adam McGovern
column2: a couple from Parsipanny
column3: New Jersey
column4: intended to marry in October
column5: amid family and friends. But as covid-19 outbreaks swept through America
column6: that looked unrealistic. “We decided that

column8: traditional ceremony would take place

column10: ” says Ms Quinlan
column11: a writer who
column12: fittingly

column15: the video-calling software that in lockdown has facilitated everything from work meetings to birthday parties. Mr McGovern contacted Parsippany’s mayor
column16: Michael Soriano
column17: who in turn spoke to New Jersey’s governor. He signed an executive order allowing civil marriages to happen remotely. The marriage license was then mailed back-and-forth to witnesses. The couple were married in their home on May 20th by Mr Soriano

column1: In normal times
column2: weddings are big business. Worldwide
column3: the industry is estimated to be worth $300bn a year. Each wedding feeds a constellation of businesses
column4: from caterers and photographers to florists and entertainers. International “destination weddings”
column5: as well as stag and hen parties
column6: are a boon to the travel industry. Those in the wedding business often boast that it is “recession-proof”: people will always want to celebrate getting married. But it is not pandemic-proof. Couples have been forced to choose between delaying their nuptials and finding new ways to wed.

column1: In some countries
column2: disruption began before official restrictions were imposed. An estimated 80% of the world’s wedding gowns are made in China
column3: and those made elsewhere are often reliant on Chinese fabrics and materials. In February
column4: as China closed factories to try and curb coronavirus outbreaks

column8: a wedding planning website.

column1: Drought now may lead to deluge later. Ms Otter notes that demand for wedding dates next year has rocketed; many venues are already booked up from April to October. (More people may end up marrying on Sundays and weekday weddings.) In post-lockdown China

column2: especially in western India. In the state of Gujarat

column4: 000 weddings have already been postponed or cancelled. Those determined to keep their dates have begun getting married privately or by video. Shaadi.com

column7: Shaadi.com’s chief executive

column1: The speed at which “normal” weddings will resume will depend on how countries ease lockdown measures. column1: 2020-06-16||The magnitude of the COVID-induced economic downturn is forcing central banks around the world to rethink the set of monetary policy tools available to them. Many central banks have long shied away from negative interest rates
column2: concerned about the impact on bank profits and financial stability. This column explores how negative interest rate policies can be used by central banks to signal a commitment to a prolonged period of monetary accommodation. Using a quantitative monetary model
column3: it shows that the signalling channel of negative interest rates can result in a rise in banks’ net worth even if net interest margins shrink.

column1: Negative interest rate policies have until now been off the table for many central banks. With the COVID-19 shock and its economic repercussions
column2: however
column3: central banks such as the Bank of England and the Federal Reserve are again putting these and other policies back on the table for discussion.

column1: While the European Central Bank has pursued a negative interest rate policy since 2014
column2: influential papers such as Eggertsson et al. (2017) and Brunnermeier and Koby (2018) have argued that negative interest rates can be counterproductive because of the bank lending channel of monetary policy. The story goes like this: The central bank pays negative interest rates on reserves
column3: while the banks are unwilling (or unable) to pass these onto depositors. As a result
column4: banks’ net interest margins are squeezed
column5: and because of agency frictions in financial markets
column6: there is a contraction in credit creation in the economy.

column1: However
column2: negative interest rates
column3: like conventional monetary policy
column4: work through many channels
column5: including an expectations (or signalling) channel. For a central bank that has a preference for smoothing policy
column6: a cut in policy rates today also signals lower policy rates tomorrow. In our recent paper (de Groot and Haas 2020)
column7: we study the signalling channel of negative interest rates and illustrate the conditions under which the expansionary signalling channel dominates the contractionary net interest margin channel.

column1: The qualitative trade-off between the signalling channel and the net interest margin channel faced by an optimizing central bank can be captured in simple variant of the canonical New-Keynesian (NK) model. To do so
column2: we make just two assumptions. First
column3: policy rates can turn negative but household deposit rates cannot. This is a reasonable assumption given empirical evidence from the euro area. The second assumption is that
column4: all else equal
column5: this wedge between a negative policy rate and a zero deposit rate shifts down aggregate demand via a net interest margin-type channel.

column1: The question
column2: in this environment
column3: is whether it is optimal for a central bank to ever set negative interest rates. We establish three results:

column1: 1. If the central bank can fully commit to future policy actions
column2: then it has no need of negative rates as a policy tool. It can induce the necessary private sector expectations of the future path of (deposit) interest rates via ‘open mouth’ forward guidance
column3: without resorting to a policy that imposes a cost on banks.

column1: 2. Even if the central bank has no ability to commit to future actions (often referred to as discretion or time-consistent policy)
column2: it won’t make use of negative rates. In this case
column3: a negative policy rate provides no signal about its future actions and only imposes a cost on the banking system.

column1: So far
column2: the case for negative interest rate policies seems rather bleak. However
column3: these results capture two extreme scenarios. While both are useful benchmarks
column4: neither is likely to be a good description of monetary policy in practice. Our third result builds on work by Woodford (2003) and Nakata and Schmidt (2019) on monetary policy delegation:

column1: 3. For a central bank that cannot commit
column2: it is welfare improving to delegate monetary policy to a central banker with a preference for smoothing policy. This policymaker may find it optimal to set a negative interest rate since its preference for smoothing results in an expansionary signalling effect on the future path of interest rates.

column1: Figure 1 illustrates this result. The parameter φ captures the strength of the net interest margin channel. Consider the black line when the signalling channel is weak (i.e. the preference for smoothing in the policymaker’s objective is low) relative to the effect of a squeeze on net interest margins. In this case
column2: the optimal policy (given by the reserve rate)
column3: does not turn negative. Consider next the red-dash line when the signalling channel is relatively stronger. In this case
column4: optimal policy prescribes a negative policy rate. While the negative rate does not lower deposit rates on impact since they are constrained by the Zero Lower Bound (ZLB)
column5: the signalling channel lowers the future expected path of the deposit rate
column6: boosting aggregate demand today and mitigating some of the fall in output and inflation.

column1: Since Figure 1 is based on a variant of the canonical NK model
column2: it only provides a qualitative insight into the monetary policy trade-off. In the other half of de Groot and Haas (2020)
column3: we employ a carefully calibrated medium-scale DSGE model that quantifies the magnitude of the two channels. A key feature of this model is the banking system
column4: which we discuss in more detail below. We also replace the optimal policymaker with an inertial Taylor-type rule.

column1: Figure 2 highlights our baseline result from this quantitative exercise. In this exercise
column2: we introduce a 25 basis point cut to the policy rate which moves it into negative territory
column3: leaving the deposit rate constrained at zero. The policy in our baseline (black line) is expansionary with both output and inflation rising in response to the monetary policy cut. Output rises by eight basis points whereas inflation rises by a little over three basis points. These responses are around 40% of the effect of an interest rate cut in ‘normal times’. The figure decomposes the baseline response into the signalling and net interest margin channels. While the net interest margin channel (red-dash) causes a contraction in both output and inflation (consistent with Eggertsson et al. 2017
column4: Brunnermeier and Koby 2018)
column5: the signalling channel (blue-dot) is expansionary and dominates.

column1: Note: Impulse responses to a -25 basis point monetary policy shock at the ZLB. Inflation is annualized.

Figure 3 provides sensitivity analysis. It plots the effect on output of a -25 basis point monetary policy shock for different durations of the ZLB (x-axis); different Taylor rule inertia parameter values (left panel); and different levels of excess central bank reserves in the banking system (right panel). The baseline results correspond to a ZLB event of 4 quarters
column2: a Taylor rule inertia parameter of 0.8 and a reserve-to-deposit ratio in the banking system of 0.2. The effect on output is scaled relative to an unconstrained monetary policy shock rather than in absolute terms
column3: thus removing any “forward guidance puzzle” type effects from the analysis.

column1: There are two takeaways from this figure. First
column2: while under the baseline negative interest rates are expansionary
column3: this is not always the case. If the Taylor rule exhibits less inertia or the economy is expected to remain at the ZLB for longer
column4: the signalling channel is weakened
column5: and negative interest rates may become contractionary. Second
column6: when the quantity of reserves in the banking system is large
column7: the net interest margin channel is stronger and negative interest rates are less effective. This is because negative interest rates act as a tax on banks’ reserve holdings
column8: and when the banking system is awash with reserves (after QE)
column9: the tax base is commensurately large.

column1: Note: The x-axis scales with the size of the negative aggregate demand shock that brings the economy to the zero lower bound (ZLB). The y-axis reports the absolute peak response of output to a -25 basis point monetary policy shock in period 1 relative the outcome of the unconstrained (UNC) scenario. The scaling relative to the unconstrained scenario ensures that the results are not a consequence of the ‘forward guidance puzzle’.
A key feature of the larger
column2: quantitative model is the modelling of the banking sector
column3: which closely follows Gertler and Karadi (2011). As such
column4: it is net worth of the banking sector
column5: rather than the net interest margin per se that is key to understanding the effect of negative interest rates.

column1: Figure 4 decomposes the response of bank profits (the change in net worth) to negative interests into several components. Two things stand out: First
column2: while a shrinking of net interest margin pushes down on net worth (yellow bars)
column3: irrespective of whether policy features inertia
column4: the signalling channel can have a significant effect on banks’ balance sheets
column5: especially in terms of asset valuations. When there is no inertia and no signalling (right panel)
column6: banks’ assets experience a capital loss (blue bars). In this case
column7: bank net worth falls
column8: lending rates and credit spreads rise
column9: choking off investment demand. In contrast
column10: with policy inertia and signalling
column11: despite the contraction in net interest margins
column12: banks’ net worth rises on impact
column13: coming mainly from a capital gain in assets values. In this case
column14: agency frictions in the banking sector ease
column15: allowing lending rates to fall and supporting investment demand and further credit creation via a financial accelerator type mechanism.

The current COVID-19 crisis will test central banks’ toolkits to the limit. Negative interest rate policies may help central banks signal their commitment to a prolonged period of monetary accommodation and thus be a beneficial additional policy tool that can be employed.

column1: 2020-06-16||How we should deal with the lockdown learning loss in England’s schools
As policy attention in countries around Europe shifts to mitigating the longer-run impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic
column2: a central concern will be to prevent this one-off event from permanently blighting the life chances of the millions of children who missed weeks of school due to the lockdown. Focusing on the UK
column3: this column suggests a way to repair some of the educational damage using small group tutoring
column4: a method with widely proven effectiveness
column5: at a modest cost
column6: and on a rapid but feasible timescale.

column1: Around Europe
column2: it seems that the immediate public health crisis is beginning to fade
column3: although all are braced for a potential second wave of infection. The most intense policy attention needs to focus on mitigating the longer-run impacts of the pandemic. A central concern is to prevent this one-off event from permanently blighting the life chances of the millions of children who missed weeks of school due to the lockdown in the UK. Missed school means lost skills and reduced earnings potential.

column1: Economic analysis suggests the cost of doing nothing is huge. At a personal level
column2: this is manifested in lower earnings potential for the affected cohorts (Portes 2020
column3: Jaime and Willén 2019). This will be reflected at the national level in lower skills: from the mid-2030s
column4: and for the following 50 years
column5: about a quarter of the labour force will have lower skills
column6: implying a 50-year period of lower growth if we do nothing (Burgess and Sievertsen 2020
column7: Hanushek and Woessman 2012). As well as a fall in income
column8: all the evidence to date points to a widening of inequality. One among a number of very recent analyses
column9: the EEF (2020) for example suggest that the attainment gap between poor and non-poor students might widen by 36%. The cumulating nature of skill formation (and skill loss) means that we need to tackle this now. In this column
column10: I suggest a policy solution.

column1: 1. The policy intervention must come soon. The process through which skills are formed is dynamic – knowledge builds on knowledge
column2: or as Heckman and colleagues put it
column3: “skills beget skills” . If we do not attempt to catch up the lost learning quickly
column4: that loss will compound and essentially become untreatable. The skill complementarity over time means that if we invest in a 10 year-old today
column5: it will cost less than if we invest when that child is 15 years old to get to the same outcome at age 16.

column1: 2. Over the period of lost schooling
column2: schools have provided online resources to children to continue learning at home. There is already evidence (Andrew et al. 2020
column3: Bol 2020) that this has not been very successful
column4: with many families reporting little learning has taken place. So
column5: despite the cost temptation to try to simply catch-up lost skills at home
column6: this will not work. This implies the policy intervention must be school-based
column7: not home-based.

column1: 3. It also has to be something new
column2: something extra
column3: and something temporary. This differs from the usual policy question of simply ‘making schools better’. The quest for those policies should go on
column4: but the current situation requires something much more immediate
column5: and immediately effective.

column1: 4. While of course it is not true to say that the cost does not matter
column2: we must anticipate that a policy intervention at such scale will not be cheap. Skills have been lost that were to be taught over a 12-week period. Replacing that necessarily takes time
column3: and resource. However
column4: it is clear that the cost to individuals affected and to the UK of doing nothing is dramatically higher.

column1: 5. Finally
column2: we must use an intervention that already has substantial causal evidence supporting its effectiveness. This is by no means a trivial requirement. For example
column3: the hundred-plus randomised controlled trials funded by the Education Endowment Foundation show that
column4: in fact
column5: many much-hyped education policies have no effect.

column1: The policy that best fits these criteria is small group tutoring
column2: based in schools.

column1: My proposal is an extensive but time-limited use of small group tutoring in as many of the school years as possible
column2: to remediate the learning loss suffered by the missed months of schooling.

column1: I proposed the use of small group tutoring earlier in this crisis
column2: and here I provide details and cost estimates. Support for a very similar idea is also building in the US
column3: following an earlier proposal from Robert Slavin
column4: Director of the Center for Research and Reform in Education at Johns Hopkins University
column5: and support from leading education economist Susan Dynarski.

column1: Small group tutoring is a flexible approach
column2: with several parameters varying the ‘dose’: the number of pupils per group
column3: the amount of time per session
column4: and the number of sessions. It is fair to say that not all of these dimensions have been fully explored by suitably well-designed experiments. There is robust evidence showing that one-to-one tutoring works
column5: and we can build from there. While effectiveness declines the bigger the group
column6: it seems there are only marginal falls in impact from two in the group to six in the group
column7: and steeper falls thereafter.

column1: Taking a ‘dose’ of the intervention to be half an hour a day
column2: for each weekday
column3: for 12 weeks
column4: there is good evidence that this has an impressive effect on learning. The EEF evidence toolkit estimates that such a ‘dose’ of small group tutoring typically yields an extra four months’ progress in school. Of course
column5: these are all averages
column6: but the rough equivalence between a gain of an extra four months’ progress from the intervention and a loss of three months’ schooling from the lockdown seems appropriate. A thorough and wide-ranging meta-analysis of effective educational interventions with robust evidence in the US (Fryer 2016) also concludes that interventions that “implement ‘high-dosage’ tutoring tend to demonstrate large effects” (p. 6)
column7: reporting very high pooled impacts from 0.78 to 1.58 standard deviations.

column1: It is not possible here to set out how it would all work. But in Burgess (2020) I have provided some ideas on what some of the main features might look like
column2: including who the tutors would be
column3: the timeline
column4: the selection of pupils
column5: and so on.

column1: Most of the cost of this scheme is the time of the tutor. The extra tuition would take place in the pupil’s usual school
column2: after school
column3: and while this would likely generate additional costs
column4: these would be relatively minor. The EEF have estimated a cost for small group tutoring: for the dose noted above
column5: they estimate a cost of £700 by adding up the time and taking it relative to the annual workload of a regular teacher. This is clearly subject to a number of uncertainties
column6: not least how the different groups are bundled up into jobs
column7: and the level of training of the tutor (discussed below).

column1: Table 1 presents some rough estimates of what the overall cost might be.
They key parameters to be chosen are:
• First
column2: what fraction of a cohort would be involved? I have chosen here 40% since we know from the accumulating evidence that not many families and pupils made a success of home learning.

column1: • Second
column2: group size obviously has a clear and straightforward impact on costs and a much vaguer effect on learning; I have chosen five in the example.

column1: • Third
column2: we need to decide which cohorts to include
column3: within schooling up to year 11. Ideally
column4: all cohorts would be helped
column5: but for this example I have chosen six: years 1
column6: 2 and 3 in primary schools and years 7
column7: 10 and 11 in secondary schools. For the cost per group
column8: I have taken the EEF figure of £700 per group per ‘dose’.

column1: The total is £222 million. This figure is very modest – less than 1% of the overall schools’ budget. It suggests that the possibility of involving all the cohorts should be considered
column2: raising the cost to around £410 million.

column1: There are other ways of approaching this
column2: also with merit
column3: but I believe that this proposal has the greatest likelihood of success; I briefly discuss those in Burgess (2020).

column1: Younger generations will pay a heavy price for our response to this virus. In this column
column2: I suggest a way to repair some of the educational damage using small group tutoring
column3: a method with widely proven effectiveness (four months extra learning)
column4: at a modest cost (less than 1% of the schools budget)
column5: and on a rapid but feasible timescale (start in October
column6: finish by Easter). Many details would need to be decided
column7: but the bones are here to make a start.

column1: 2020-06-16||The Australian dollar rallied overnight having slipped back below 0.68 US cents throughout the domestic session. Risk assets suffered early as investors grappled with reports out of the US and Beijing citing new coronavirus hotspots. In the US 20 states recorded an increase in the spread of Covid-19 cases while Beijing reported a string of new cases after almost 2 months without new infections. The news served as a stark reminder of the risks of opening to quickly and forced markets to check expectations for H2 economic activity. Further downward pressure came following rumours China is considering targeting Iron Ore as diplomatic tensions increase. China’s dependence on the raw material has meant it was considered free from heightened diplomatic hostilities
column2: however if China’s program of restrictions and tariffs does extend to Iron Ore the Australian Economy almost certainly suffer more than China. Having slipped to intraday lows at 0.6780 risk assets found support overnight as the FED announced it will begin buying individual corporate bonds
column3: increasing the scope and scale of its bond buying program. With additional cash set to be in play markets bought the dip and pushed the AUD back through 0.69 to intraday highs at 0.6920.

column1: Attentions today remain squarely affixed to risk. Investors will be keenly attuned to the RBA minutes for any guidance on monetary policy. A sustained risk on move could help the AUD edged back toward 0.70
column2: while a shift in sentiment will likely prompt a move back below 0.69 US cents.

column1: The risk on move overnight saw haven assets close the day lower as investors jumped back into to risk and growth correlated currencies. The USD was the weakest of the majors with the dollar index falling half a percent
column2: while the JPY and CHF also shifted lower. The Dollar came under heavy selling pressure after the FED announced it would expand its bond buying program to include individual corporate bonds. The expansion of its monetary policy program emboldened investors to buy the dip and jump back into risk correlated assets as the availability of cash and central bank funding will seemingly continue through the medium term.

column1: With little of note on the macroeconomic docket today attentions will remain with the broader risk tone. The Bank of Japan’s monthly policy meeting will likely pass without incident while US retail sales are unlikely to tip the scales. The market continues to largely ignore backward looking fundamentals instead looking to sentiment and forward guidance as markers of future performance and signals guiding the speed of any economic recovery. That said a strong retail sales print could bolster risk appetite as consumer spending increases amid easing restrictions.

The UK claimant count will also provide a valuable insight into the health of the labour market. A front runner to official unemployment numbers it offers a sneak peak as to the trend of labour market performance. A print above 400
column2: 000 will add mounting pressure to the GBP as it continues to struggle with the coronavirus and opening up the broader economy.
