column1: 2020-05-30|"Non-performing loans are a crucial policy consideration
column2: especially in times of wider economic crisis. This article uses a new database covering 88 banking crises since 1990 to draw lessons for post-COVID-19 resolution of non-performing loans. Compared to the 2008 crisis
column3: the pandemic poses some different challenges. Despite some respite from the credit-crash of 2008
column4: policymakers today are faced with substantially higher public debt
column5: less profitable banks
column6: and often weaker corporate sector conditions
column7: making resolution of non-performing loans even more challenging.

column1: As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic
column2: the economy has come to a sudden halt. This is likely to bring about high levels of non-performing loans (NPLs)
column3: i.e. loans that are in (or close to) default. High NPLs are problematic because they impair bank balance sheets
column4: depress credit growth
column5: and delay economic recovery (Aiyar et al. 2015
column6: Kalemli-Ozcan et al. 2015). Persistently high NPL ratios were a concern in several European countries after the 2008-2012 crisis
column7: and the COVID-19 pandemic could cause a re-emergence of the NPL problem.

column1: High NPLs are a common feature of banking crises and tend to be studied around such events. Data presented in an existing report by Laeven and Valencia (2013) shows that NPL levels peak during crises
column2: but more data are needed to understand how NPLs evolve and are resolved. Our recent ECB working paper (Ari et al.
column3: 2020) bridges this gap by presenting a new dataset on yearly NPL evolution during 88 banking crises since 1990. The dataset covers major regional and global crises (including the Nordic crisis
column4: the Asian financial crisis
column5: the Global Financial Crisis) and many standalone crises in developing
column6: transition
column7: and low-income economies. For each crisis
column8: we report NPLs over an 11-year window around the crisis. What do we learn from these data?

column1: During crises
column2: NPLs typically follow an inverse U-shaped pattern. They start at modest levels
column3: rise rapidly around the start of the crisis
column4: and peak some years afterwards
column5: before stabilising and declining. Looking at all crises
column6: we see that NPL levels peak at about 20% of total loans on average
column7: but the variance is large (especially in developing countries
column8: where NPLs can exceed 50% of total loans). Only less than a fifth of banking crises avoid high NPLs
column9: which we define as NPLs exceeding 7% of total loans.

column1: Anticipating future levels of NPLs is key for formulating NPL resolution strategies. It is tempting to use pre-crisis NPLs to anchor such forecasts. Yet
column2: pre-crisis NPL levels are not a good indicator of post-crisis NPL problems. After a crisis
column3: NPLs increase to three times their pre-crisis values on average
column4: and over ten times in extreme cases (Figure 1).

column3: and Ratnovski (2020)

The left panel shows peak NPLs expressed as percent of total loans; the right panel shows peak NPL ratio (i.e. NPLs/total loans) expressed as a multiple of the pre-crisis NPL ratio. Crises that did not have high NPLs (with NPLs under 7% of total loans) are shown in light blue in the left panel.

column1: Timely NPL resolution is difficult
column2: but essential for economic recovery

column1: Countries can facilitate the resolution of high NPLs using a mix of policy measures
column2: such as:

column1: • Asset quality reviews
column2: to identify loans that are nonperforming and need restructuring

column1: • Separating good and bad assets of banks (so-called ‘good bank’-‘bad bank’ resolution). This makes the financial conditions of good banks more transparent
column2: steadies their market access
column3: and lets them focus on extending new lending. Bad banks
column4: often structured as asset management companies
column5: proceed to extracting value from bad assets

column1: More details on NPL resolution methods are provided in Balgova et al. (2016)
column2: Beck (2017)
column3: Brei et al. (2020)
column4: and in ECB Financial Stability Reviews by Grodzicki et al. (2015) and Fell et al. (2016 and 2017).

column1: Despite the economic benefits of NPL reduction and the variety of methods available
column2: the data paint a sobering picture of historic NPL resolution. While some countries resolve NPLs rapidly
column3: a third of countries are saddled with NPLs for over seven years after a crisis. The NPL reduction outcomes after the Global Crisis are direr still: two-thirds of the countries that experienced high NPLs could not resolve those within seven years of the crisis (Figure 2). Strikingly
column4: this also implies that while advanced economies tend to have lower post-crisis NPLs
column5: they also take longer on average to resolve.

column1: Note: Reproduced from Ari
column2: Chen
column3: and Ratnovski (2020)
column4: Figure 6. The left panel shows the number of countries that resolved NPLs (with NPL ratios to under 7%) in each year after the crisis. The right panel compares the number of counties that resolved and don’t resolve NPLs with 7 years. The colours distinguish the crisis waves and types.

column1: In the paper
column2: we use the ‘local projections’ method to assess the link between NPL resolution and post-crisis output dynamics
column3: while controlling for their co-dependence. The results underscore that NPL resolution is critical for economic recovery. High and unresolved NPLs are associated with deeper recessions and slower recoveries. Six years after a banking crisis
column4: output in countries that experience high NPLs is 6.5 percentage points lower in countries that don’t. Of the countries that have high NPLs
column5: output in countries that do not resolve NPLs are more than ten percentage points lower than in countries that do (Figure 3).

b) The difference in GDP after the crisis between the countries that experience high NPLs (within 7 years) compared to those that don’t

column3: and Ratnovski (2020)

column5: following a banking crisis
column6: experience NPLs exceeding 7% compared to those that have NPLs under 7% (left panel)
column7: between countries that
column8: having experienced NPLs exceeding 7%
column9: manage to resolve them compared to those that do not (right panel).

column1: NPL resolution in Europe after the 2008-2012 crisis
Further
column2: we use a model selection approach to assess which pre-crisis indicators predict the dynamics of NPLs in banking crises. We document that peak NPLs are higher in countries with lower GDP per capita
column3: after a credit boom
column4: under fixed exchange rates
column5: with less profitable banks
column6: or banks with more fragile corporate balance sheets. NPL resolution is more protracted in similar circumstances
column7: as well as in countries with high public debt and more sophisticated banking sectors. Interestingly
column8: these high-level indicators have good predictive power (the average (pseudo) adjusted R-squared across the specifications is 0.24).

column1: These results shed light on the factors behind the high
column2: and persistent
column3: NPLs in some European countries after the 2008-2012 crisis. In the paper
column4: we compare actual NPL dynamics in seven European countries (Greece
column5: Ireland
column6: Italy
column7: Portugal
column8: Spain
column9: Hungary
column10: and Slovenia) with what could have been anticipated based on historical patterns. It turns out that high NPL levels in Europe in 2010s were hard to anticipate: the crisis was extraordinarily severe for advanced economies. By contrast
column11: protracted NPL resolution was in line with historical patterns: it is common for crises that follow a credit boom (Figure 4). Indeed
column12: the long-term negative consequences of credit booms are well-documented in the literature (Caballero et al. 2008). They are related to the difficulties in resolving the debt of non-viable ‘zombie’ firms and households that are ‘underwater’ on their housing assets.

column3: and Ratnovski (2020)

column5: on average for a sample of European countries affected by the 2008-2012 crisis. The metrics of NPLs are: peak NPLs as percent of total loans (left panel) and the duration of NPL resolution in years (right panel).

column1: What does this mean for NPL resolution after COVID-19?
Even though our paper studies NPLs in the context of banking crises
column2: and therefore cannot be mapped perfectly to the COVID-19 events
column3: it provides valuable insights into impending NPL challenges. Our results highlight forces that can make NPL resolution after the COVID-19 events different from the situation after the 2008-2012 crisis. Some forces are enabling of NPL resolution. For example
column4: the COVID-19 pandemic is not a credit boom-induced crisis. If the economic downturn proves temporary
column5: many post-COVID-19 NPLs may relate to viable illiquid firms
column6: rather than unviable zombie firms. European banks have entered the COVID-19 pandemic with (on average) higher capital ratios compared to the 2008 crisis. The recently introduced IFRS-9 accounting standards may induce faster NPL recognition
column7: and hence resolution
column8: thanks to their forward-looking nature (although a ‘too fast’ NPL recognition may also constrain bank lending during downturns). Other forces point to challenges in NPL resolution. Compared to 2008
column9: most European countries have substantially higher public debt
column10: less profitable banks
column11: and often weaker corporate sector conditions (the factors that historically have complicated NPL resolution). Moreover
column12: if the economic recovery from the pandemic is slow and protracted
column13: credit losses from corporate distress will rise and could overwhelm banks
column14: further complicating NPL resolution.

column1: Given the importance of NPL reduction for economic recovery
column2: and many countries’ historical difficulties in implementing effective NPL-related interventions
column3: designing effective NPL resolution policies for the post-COVID-19 world is a key forward-looking financial policy issue for Europe today.

2020-05-30|"As debates about the future of the World Health Organization rage on
column2: the Covid-19 pandemic is a reminder of the vital importance of global public health institutions. This column considers what principles should guide WHO’s missions and tools to deal with pandemics
column3: which are distinguished from other health risks by their high contagion
column4: extreme potential outcomes in terms of mortality risk
column5: and the ‘weak-link’ aspect of global collective action. It argues that reforms should centre around having a narrower mission – Global Response to Infectious Diseases
column6: or GRID – and creating better incentives to prevent contagions from spreading globally using stronger legal and financial tools.

column1: The World Health Assembly
column2: the annual decision-making meeting of the World Health Organization (WHO)
column3: met in May over videoconference. The squabbling over the institution’s funding and political independence that erupted between the US and China highlighted the embattled state of the global public health institution facing its biggest ever challenge – the Covid-19 pandemic.

column1: WHO’s initial response has been heavily criticised
column2: and there is a real risk that without reforms
column3: it will wither into irrelevance (e.g. Buranyi 2020). Yet
column4: the pandemic has also vividly demonstrated why WHO is needed
column5: given the critical role that detecting
column6: tracing
column7: and containing contagion play in saving lives across the globe.

column1: Economists have been active in helping us think about the appropriate policy responses to mitigate economic damage from the global pandemic
column2: focusing on fiscal and monetary policies
column3: financial regulation
column4: social insurance
column5: industry
column6: and trade (Baldwin and Weber di Mauro 2020).

column1: Here
column2: we take a longer-term view and use insights from public economics and the economics of organisations to think about changes to WHO’s mission and tools that would enable it to deal more effectively with outbreaks of infectious disease that threaten to become pandemics.

column1: The emerging literature on bureaucracies and public organisations that focuses on incentive and organisation design issues in the context of the provision of public goods offers some particularly relevant lessons ( Dewatripont et al. 1999
column2: Besley and Ghatak 2018). It suggests that diffuse missions
column3: noisy output measures
column4: and task multiplicity make them appear less effective than their private sector counterparts even in the best of times
column5: and potentially disastrous in times of crisis. No wonder
column6: then
column7: that WHO looks weak now
column8: as it did when Ebola struck (Wenham 2017).

column1: Three features distinguish this pandemic from other health risks:
• First
column2: as with all infectious diseases
column3: an individual’s health depends not only on their own behaviour but on the behaviour of others – that is
column4: there is a large externality.

column1: • Second
column2: the virus’ contagiousness and capacity to travel means that all are vulnerable if one government (the weakest link) mismanages the crisis: China’s initial handling of the outbreak was very much the ‘O-ring’ of global public health (Kremer 1993).

column1: • Third
column2: the potential threat to lives and livelihoods is huge
column3: immediate
column4: and visible
column5: making the case for concerted action easier than for other global risks
column6: such as climate change.

column1: These features require swift and sustained international coordination both to respond to this pandemic and to prevent future ones. They also imply that the absence of global coordination might lead governments to opt for isolationism. Closing borders so that foreigners can’t bring disease in may seem like a reasonable short-term response
column2: but it will have enormous human and economic costs over a longer period (e.g. Trilling 2020 on the situation of refugees
column3: Freund 2020 on the costs of shortening global value chains).

column1: There is another solution. The world has already experienced a ‘trial-run’ for coping with major global risks: airline security in response to 9/11. Like the current pandemic
column2: terrorism posed a grave threat and showed that the international community is only as strong as its weakest member. Significant progress was made in countering this threat by establishing universal air-travel security standards and monitoring their enforcement.

column1: To reinvent itself to counter the threat of pandemics effectively
column2: WHO needs three things.

column1: First
column2: a narrower focus. A disease will have to meet three criteria for WHO intervention: large global externalities
column3: high mortality risk
column4: and a ‘weak-link’ aspect to government action. Eradicating malaria
column5: for example
column6: is an extremely worthwhile goal
column7: but the disease does not travel much internationally
column8: making direct intervention (as opposed to financial support of the type given by the Global Fund) by an international institution unnecessary.

column1: Following the model of recent global public health funds with a narrow focus (Sridhar and Woods 2013)
column2: WHO must redefine its core mission around the global response to infectious diseases – let us call this hypothetical division ‘GRID’.

column1: Other aspects of public health could be left to WHO’s research and advisory departments. This means a sharp departure from its current agenda
column2: which covers many aspects of global health
column3: from mental wellbeing to obesity
column4: with no clear prioritisation. WHO should focus on aspects of public health for which the externalities are truly global
column5: the potential risks high
column6: and the interdependence in outcomes across countries so strong that isolated national responses won’t suffice.

column1: The second thing WHO needs is capacity – beyond that granted by the International Health Regulations (Gostin et al. 2015) – to sanction countries that do not follow its rules. The global community gave the WTO powers to impose economic sanctions on its member states. Avoiding another pandemic is at least as worthy a goal as increasing global trade and should be backed with similar sanctioning power.
Particular care must be paid to how sanctions are designed. Sanctioning a state in which a pandemic starts may sound like a good idea
column2: but is not credible in practice. When such a disaster strikes
column3: GRID’s mission would require it to offer the afflicted country support. This means that GRID cannot sanction countries based on outcomes but on the steps taken to abide by its recommendations.

column1: Third
column2: WHO needs a budget adequate to the task. WHO’s current annual budget
column3: roughly $2 billion
column4: is not much higher than the budget of the main hospital in its host city
column5: Geneva. Determining the exact amounts needed is best left to public health specialists and epidemiologists
column6: but the current budget is clearly and grossly inadequate.

column1: Consider
column2: for example
column3: what it would cost to prevent the international spread of a highly contagious disease through air travel. Taking the estimated cost of a Covid-19 test ($10 according to Romer 2020) and the number of air passengers in 2018 (4.2 billion) as a benchmark
column4: $42 billion would be needed for testing international travellers alone. Airlines may of course be willing to foot some of the bill for these tests if their survival is at stake (and we expect the number of air passengers to fall in the short run). But even half that number is ten times WHO’s current budget.

column1: How would GRID raise money? One option would levy ‘user-fees’ on those benefitting the most from the global movement of people
column2: something that GRID would protect. Multinational corporations top that list. Torslov et al. (2020) estimate that they made $1.7 trillion in profits from their international activities in 2015
column3: a non-trivial share of which is booked in tax havens and therefore subject to little taxation. A 5% tax on these international profits alone would generate $85 billion.

column1: International air passengers and airlines could also be asked to chip in
column2: if only to pay for the testing infrastructure in airports. While clearly ambitious
column3: these proposals are not without real-world precedent. UNITAID
column4: a global health fund
column5: is already partially funded by a tax on international air travel levied by several countries.

column1: Giving GRID its own sources of funding would free it from relying on voluntary contributions by individual countries and shield it from the undue political influence of powerful countries (e.g. Huang 2020). These new sources of funding would need to raise enough funds to finance GRID’s recurring prevention
column2: monitoring
column3: and research expenditures. In addition
column4: GRID must be given the right to borrow to mobilise funds quickly when a global public health emergency occurs.

column1: If we neglect the writing on the wall about WHO
column2: the uncoordinated responses of national governments will hurt ordinary citizens across the globe
column3: especially the poorest and most vulnerable. The virus does not respect borders or walls; our response must transcend them as well.

column1: 2020-05-30|"Cities rise and fall
column2: but the city has a way of confounding its would-be obituarists. Futurists thought digital communications would kill off urban living. The growth of the suburbs threatened to hollow out the centre.

column1: The 9/11 attacks were presumed by many to mark the end of the era of the skyscraper. For centuries
column2: war
column3: pollution
column4: violence and plague have reminded us that density makes us vulnerable
column5: but still the majority of us – 55 per cent of the world’s population
column6: by the United Nations’ latest count – choose to live this way. Indeed
column7: cities often emerge stronger from their moments of greatest peril. The 1918 influenza pandemic killed millions of Europeans
column8: but within a few years Paris and Berlin were booming again.

column1: That resilience tells us the modern city will survive the Covid-19 pandemic. But it could yet be transformed by the crisis.
This has been a largely metropolitan trauma. Wherever the virus has taken hold
column2: the epicentres – Wuhan
column3: Madrid
column4: New York
column5: London – are big cities where people live in close quarters
column6: commute on cramped trains
column7: pray in big congregations and drink in crowds. What gave cities their life also helped take it away. One of the recurring visual motifs of the past three months has been the haunting image of the abandoned city
column8: with its streets deserted
column9: shops boarded up and office blocks lying empty.

column1: Some of those closures will be permanent
column2: because if and when the health crisis comes to an end – as it will if the virus burns itself out
column3: immunity levels reach critical mass or a treatment or vaccine become available – another
column4: economic
column5: crisis will continue.

column1: Many shops and restaurants will not make it out the other side. Cultural life will be reeling from the shock of the lockdown; Unesco
column2: the United Nations cultural agency
column3: has warned that the pandemic may permanently close one in eight of the world’s museums.

column1: Social distancing will result in longer queues
column2: Spartan pubs and a generally more monochrome version of urban life. And with the enforced shift towards remote working having opened people’s eyes to an alternative routine
column3: many employers (alert to the savings they can make by reducing their office space) and workers (tired of high housing costs and long commutes) may come to the same conclusion: that the office itself is obsolete. Prohibitive living costs were already resulting in population decline in some western cities. This would accelerate it.

column1: Cities have always flourished because people are drawn to the possibilities they offer: jobs
column2: trade
column3: exchange of ideas. That constant inward flow is what sustains and renews them. If the looming recession is accompanied by a nativist
column4: protectionist turn
column5: and that results in stricter migration policies
column6: it would prolong the downturn and speed up population decline in many cities. Philadelphia
column7: for example
column8: would have shrunk without immigration over the past five years.

column1: But unless pandemics become the new normal – which as the urban economist Edward Glaeser of Harvard University has noted would result in tens of millions of urban service jobs disappearing and large-scale social dislocation – then the current crisis should allow for a broader rethink about how cities are designed
column2: maintained and lived in. Just as the cholera outbreaks of the 1830s resulted in better sanitation in London and the tuberculosis epidemic in New York in the early 20th century led to better housing regulations and public transport
column3: the current crisis could turn out to be an important inflection point. Some cities have already begun to reorganise themselves by creating more room for pedestrians and cyclists
column4: improving homeless accommodation and taking steps to free up tourist housing for residents. Many of these are nominally stopgap measures
column5: but it will be difficult to reverse them.

column1: But the new momentum behind the push for urban cycling infrastructure and an expansion of public spaces is only a start. A more thorough rethink would consider how to improve sustainability
column2: food security and living standards. It would note how
column3: in many cities
column4: the poor and ethnic minorities have been particularly vulnerable
column5: and ask what that has to do with housing conditions and economic geography. It would look at ways of easing pollution and commuting times by making city life more compact. (In Paris
column6: mayor Anne Hidalgo talks of creating the “quarter-hour city”

column1: 2020-05-31|"The COVID-19 pandemic is causing a crisis in the UK universities

The COVID-19 pandemic is causing serious financial problems for UK universities. This column identifies the over-reliance on Chinese students for fee income as the main cause of the impact and considers what steps the government might take to support universities through this crisis.
The COVID-19 pandemic is having widespread effects on inequality (Overman 2020
column2: Furceri et al. 2020) and education. Its effects on the UK’s higher education (HE) system could also be dramatic (see Dolton 2020). In this column
column3: I suggest that the present financial problems of universities are rooted in their growing reliance of UK universities on the huge growth in overseas students coming to the UK for higher education. This growth has been more or less exclusively from China. Figure 1 shows how the numbers of new students arriving in the UK over the years 2006 to 2019 has changed. The numbers coming from nearly all countries other than China has remained approximately constant. But the numbers coming from China have risen from 25
column4: 000 in 2006 to approaching 90
column5: 000 by 2019. This over-reliance on recruiting Chinese students has meant that the UK HE system is vulnerable to any change in policy from the Chinese government or an exogenous event like COVID-19.

column1: Figure 2 charts how the university funding system has changed over the last 10 years. In 2010 over half of the funding came from central government. Now only approximately 25% of funding comes from central government. The remainder comes directly from student fee income. The reality is that the present UK HE funding regime involves a large-scale underinvestment in research and an element of cross subsidisation of fee income to fund research.
Source: Author’s calculations based on data from House of Commons Briefing Paper 7393.
Another major headache for UK university finances has been the Universities Superannuation Scheme (USS) and its associated problems. This is the largest private sector pension scheme in the UK
column2: with assets of over £68 billion. Recent calculations indicate that the scheme has a valuation shortfall of between £6.6 billion (Reeve 2019) and £17.5 billion (Borej 2017). This will result in rising university employer contributions to the scheme
column3: exacerbating their financial problems.

column1: Will the overseas students come to the UK to study next academic year?
How bad are the implications of COVID-19 for the short-term and long-term future of the UK higher education system? Should universities plan on opening in September
column2: or do they move their operations online? The truth of the matter is that we do not presently know the exact nature of the implications of COVID-19 for future student demand. Some universities are planning for worst-case scenarios that could involve losing up to 75% of their overseas students and a drop of 20% of home students attending university this September
column3: potentially leading to severe financial trouble. In this worst-case scenario
column4: it has been suggested that all universities except Oxford and Cambridge could become insolvent.

column1: In a survey conducted by the British Council (2020)
column2: it was suggested that up to 50% of postgraduate students who were planning to come to the UK are planning to defer and around 20% are likely to change where they go as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. If the demand for UK university education from countries like China
column3: India
column4: and many of the African countries proves to be resilient
column5: then these measures may not be necessary. Clearly there will be many overseas students who choose not to come to the UK in September 2020. But does this mean that they will never come? Surely a sizeable fraction of this demand will still be in place in September 2021 and many students will simply defer for a year. This logic may justify the government viewing the impending financial crisis of UK HE as a short run liquidity crisis.

column1: What measures can universities take in the short run?

The main issue facing universities right now is to prevent themselves from going broke in the short run and planning for the opening of campuses in September. But what will happen if universities are not allowed to open again in September? Or indeed what happens if there is a second or subsequent wave of the pandemic? Universities should have contingency plans for these eventualities. Those without reserves or endowments will have little alternative but to make representations to central government for special financial help. But it has already been signalled that this will come at the price of considerable structural reforms.
Faced with these large expected losses in income
column2: many universities in the UK are already implementing
column3: or planning to implement
column4: hiring freezes
column5: redundancies
column6: termination of short-term contracts
column7: dropping courses and even whole degree programmes
column8: and closing departments. Talk of mergers of neighbouring universities have been rumoured – although the evidence on the efficiencies to be gained is weak (Johnes 2013). Senior management at some universities has taken a voluntary pay cut and proposed that professorial staff follow suit. These measures have large adverse implications for employment in the university sector
column9: with some estimates suggesting up to 300
column10: 000 job losses (London Economics 2020).

column1: The calculations of risk liability based on the financial position of different universities suggest that between 30 to 50 of them could be in immediate danger of insolvency (London Economics 2020
column2: Brackley 2020). Brackley (2020) has calculated the universities that are at most risk of financial failure
column3: with an ‘at risk score’ that takes into account the current financial position of the university on debts and loans and their exposure to the loss of fee income from overseas students. The estimated cash loss as a fraction of total income and the ordering of the ‘at risk score’ are presented in Figure 3. Cluster 1 includes Oxford and Cambridge
column4: cluster 2 consists of the traditional universities in the Russell Group
column5: cluster 3 consists of the other pre-1992 universities
column6: and cluster 4 captures the remainder. It shows that two of the universities with the lowest risk score
column7: the green dots of Oxford and Cambridge
column8: are at the extreme right end of the at-risk ordering. Figure 3 also shows that the estimated cash loss varies across universities from 0-20%. The universities at most risk of financial failure (the vertical axis in the figure) come from Cluster 3 and 4 but there are some potential casualties from the Cluster 2 as well. So
column9: it is possible that there could be some universities with a considerable research reputation in severe financial difficulty as a result of this pandemic.

column1: What can or should the government be doing to help?

Can a government in office be seen to allow various universities to close? Politically this could result in quite a high popularity hit. This would be especially true if the universities in question were predominantly in the North of England
column2: Scotland and Wales. Arguably
column3: it is expensive to merge and restructure a university with a neighbour and there is relatively little evidence in favour of potential economies of scale (Payne 2008). But this should not prevent universities from seriously considering this option in an attempt to rationalise their provision and economise on costs. Another pertinent point to consider is whether neighbouring universities should be forced to merge by the government.

column1: In response to the potential loss of overseas student fee income
column2: UUK (2020) asked the government for a £2.2 billion boost to short run research funding. What the government decided to do instead was increase research funding by only £100 millio and allow an advance on undergraduate fee income from the Student Loans company to the tune of £2.6 billion. This represents a loan of around 10% of fee income to universities. While this loan will be a short-run lifeline for some universities
column3: it only stores up future funding problems as these loans will inflate future financial obligations. We do not presently know how this loan will be released to universities or whether it will be in direct proportion to each university’s existing level of potential fee shortfall. The latest word from the HM Treasury is that a potential financial handout to any institution in financial trouble could be possible in exchange for restructuring reforms.

column1: 2020-05-31|"Revenge of the experts: Will COVID-19 renew or diminish trust in science?

It is argued that COVID-19 will reverse the ongoing trend of challenging the value of science and the integrity of scientists. This column shows that exposure to epidemics in one’s country of residence during the ‘impressionable years’ of ages 18 to 25 has no impact on confidence in science as an enterprise
column2: but negatively affects views of the honesty and public-spiritedness of scientists.

column1: COVID-19 will change everything. (For overviews of the implications
column2: see Benassy-Quere et al. 2020 and Benassy-Quere and Weder di Mauro 2020.) One effect
column3: it has been argued
column4: will be to reverse the secular trend of challenging the value of scientific expertise. “The coronavirus crisis has put a spotlight on the importance of science in supporting our nation’s well being” (Shepherd 2020). At the same time
column5: the pandemic has put on display certain leaders’ “longstanding practice of undermining scientific expertise for political purposes” (Friedman and Plumer 2020)
column6: conceivably with negative implications for how the public views science and scientists. All of which points to the question posed by Grove (2020): “Will the coronavirus renew public trust in science?”

column1: A further question is whether any change in public opinion will mainly affect the views of the scientific endeavour or individual scientists. Does any positive or negative reassessment of the importance and validity of science apply to both the undertaking and those engaged in it? Or does the public continue to have confidence in science as a potential source of a vaccine while dismissing individual scientists who warn that the time needed to develop that vaccine may be lengthy?
In Aksoy et al. (2020)
column2: we analyse this issue using the 2018 Wellcome Global Monitor (WGM)
column3: which includes responses to questions about confidence in science and scientists from more than 70
column4: 000 individuals in 160 countries. The responses of interest are to questions asked of all WGM respondents: “In general
column5: would you say you trust science a lot
column6: some
column7: not much or not at all?” and “How much do you trust scientists” to do their work honestly
column8: with the intention of benefiting the public? The geographical dispersion of the responses is in Figure 1.

column1: Figure 1 Share of respondents who trust science and scientists

Notes: Panel A illustrates the share of respondents who trust science a lot or some. Panel B illustrates the share of respondents who trust scientists a lot or some. Countries are grouped in quintiles.
We use data on all global epidemics since 1970 to identify respondents who experienced an epidemic outbreak in their country of residence during their formative years
column2: the stage of the life course when value systems and opinions are durably formed. Krosnick and Alwin (1989) formalise this as the ‘impressionable years hypothesis’ – that core attitudes
column3: beliefs
column4: and values crystallise between the ages of 18 and 25. Spear (2000) links this to the literature in neurology describing neurochemical and anatomical differences between the adolescent and adult brain. Giuliano and Spilimbergo (2013) show
column5: for example
column6: that experiencing a recession between the ages of 18 and 25 has a powerful impact on political preferences and beliefs about the economy that persists over the life cycle.

column1: To assess the effect of past exposure to an epidemic on an individual’s trust in science and scientists
column2: we estimate models where the dependent variable is a dummy variable indicating whether or not the respondent has confidence in science or scientists.

column1: To operationalise our treatment variable (Exposure to epidemic
column2: 18-25) in the paper
column3: we calculate for each individual the number of people affected by an epidemic as a share of the population
column4: averaged over the eight years when the individual was in his or her formative years (18-25 years old)
column5: consistent with the ‘impressionable years hypothesis’. In addition
column6: we control for observable individual characteristics (age
column7: gender
column8: educational attainment
column9: marital status
column10: religion
column11: and urban/rural residence)
column12: labour market outcomes
column13: and within-country income deciles)
column14: country
column15: year and age fixed effects
column16: and country-specific age trends.

column1: We find that formative-year epidemic exposure has a consistently negative and significant effect on whether the respondent has confidence in scientists; believes that scientists working for private companies benefit the public; believes that scientists working for private companies are honest; and believes that scientists working for universities are honest. An individual with the highest exposure to epidemics (0.032
column2: that is
column3: the number of people affected by an epidemic as a share of the population in individual’s formative years) relative to individuals with no exposure has on average 11 percentage points (-3.454*0.032) less confidence in the honesty of scientists.

column1: In contrast
column2: when the dependent variable concerns science as an undertaking or endeavour (“Do you have confidence in science? Will science and technology help to improve life? Is studying diseases a part of science”)
column3: the coefficients in question are instead positive
column4: but do not differ significantly from zero. Evidently
column5: individuals who experience epidemics at first hand retain confidence in the positive potential of science as an endeavour. They continue to believe in the importance of disease-related scientific research. But they are less confident about the trustworthiness and public-spiritedness of the individuals involved in scientific endeavors.

column1: Given that previous work points to science education as shaping views of science and scientists
column2: we also estimate our main specification for two subsamples: respondents who learned about science at most at the primary school level versus respondents who learned about science at least at the secondary school level. The results suggest that our findings are driven by the sample of individuals with little or no science education. It seems that science education is at least partly able to offset the adverse impact of epidemic experience on individuals’ trust in scientists.

column1: We examined a number of sensitivity analyses to verify the robustness of the results. Placebo tests address the possibility that what we are picking up is not the impact on the perceived trustworthiness and public-spiritedness of scientists engaged in health-related research specifically
column2: but the impact on perceptions of individuals engaged in tasks related to healthcare and health outcomes more generally. In contrast to its significant negative impact on confidence in scientists
column3: the results indicate no significant impact on confidence in doctors and nurses
column4: in hospitals and health clinics
column5: in NGO workers
column6: or in traditional healers.

column1: We also confirmed the persistence of the impact of epidemic exposure as individuals age over time. Despite the fact that the confidence intervals around our estimates widen in smaller subsamples of rolling age windows
column2: we confirm that epidemic exposure between the ages of 18 and 25 continues to significantly influence public perceptions in scientists’ trustworthiness and public-spiritedness even as the respondents age over time.

column1: Lastly
column2: the effect is insignificant when individuals are exposed to epidemics in any period other than when they are between 18 and 25 years old. These results are strongly consistent with the formative-years hypothesis
column3: implying that the current generation experiencing COVID-19 in their formative years may end up distrusting scientists for a long period of their lives.

column1: COVID-19 promises to reshape every aspect of society
column2: not excluding how science is perceived. But it is not clear whether the authority of science and scientists will be enhanced or diminished
column3: or whether such changes will affect mainly science as an endeavor or scientists as individuals.

column1: If past epidemics are a guide
column2: the virus will not have an impact on the regard in which science as an undertaking is held. But it will reduce confidence in individual scientists
column3: worsen perceptions of their honesty
column4: and weaken the belief that their activities benefit the public. The strongest impact is likely to be felt by individuals in their ‘impressionable years’
column5: whose beliefs are in the process of being durably formed.

column1: Responding to these trends will not be straightforward. At a minimum
column2: our findings suggest that scientists working on public health matters and others concerned with scientific communication should think harder about how to communicate trustworthiness and honesty and
column3: specifically
column4: about how the generation currently in their impressionable years (‘Generation Z’) perceives such attributes. In addition
column5: our results suggest that scientific education will help.

column1: Aksoy
column2: C G

column1: 2020-05-31|"Protecting people now
column2: helping the economy rebound later

column1: The public health measures to ‘flatten the Covid-19 curve' will necessarily and appropriately impose large economic costs. This column
column2: taken from a VoxEU eBook
column3: identifies the constraints that policy faces during a pandemic – uncertainty
column4: time
column5: and capacity – and the implications of these constraints.

column1: The coronavirus is a shock to the economy the likes of which none of us has ever seen. A hurricane hitting every place in the United States
column2: Europe
column3: and much of the rest of the world simultaneously. And hitting every day for weeks
column4: months
column5: or perhaps even a year. It is partly a supply shock as workers can no longer work and supply chains get severed. It is also partly a demand shock as people will cut back their demand
column6: not just for restaurants and travel but likely much else throughout the economy given the extreme nervousness about their economic situation. The public health measures to flatten the curve
column7: delaying and spreading out the extent of the virus
column8: will necessarily and appropriately impose large economic costs. The job of economic policy is
column9: to the greatest extent possible
column10: to protect people from those costs now and help ensure the economy is in a position to rebound quickly when the health threat is contained. Doing this will require a multifaceted and ambitious policy response.

column1: This column is taken from the VoxEU eBook Mitigating the COVID Economic Crisis: Act Fast and Do Whatever It Takes. Download the eBook here.
Human suffering in the immediate future

The human toll will be enormous. Most profound and consequential will be the toll on health – the illnesses and deaths from COVID-19 and also the collateral damage to others from an overloaded hospital system. Less profound
column2: but even more widespread
column3: will be the economic toll on workers who lose their jobs or see dramatic reductions in their incomes
column4: either directly because they work in an industry that is shut down as a result of the pandemic or indirectly because they work in anything in the economy which is seeing less demand as a result of all of the income loss and dramatically worsened outlook for the future.

column1: The economic problems could persist well after the pandemic is contained. It would be foolish just to think of what is happening as intertemporal substitution – people not going to restaurants today but then making up for it by going to even more restaurants next year. There are four interrelated reasons why the economic problems could be very persistent:
• Labour market matching means that unemployment rates can rise sharply but not fall sharply. In the US financial crisis
column2: for example
column3: the unemployment rate took less than two and a half years to rise from 4.4% to 10% but
column4: seven years to recover. The pattern is similar in previous recoveries and in other countries
column5: and is the result of the labour market matching process in which it is hard to connect people with jobs.

column1: • Companies will go bankrupt throughout the economy
column2: although the extent and magnitude will depend on the policy response. In some cases
column3: these could be disorderly bankruptcies that separate firm-specific management capital
column4: worker capital
column5: and a nested set of arrangements and sever all of them simultaneously. Putting that back together will not be easy.

column1: • Financial institutions could come under tremendous strain and
column2: absent an ambitious policy response
column3: the economic crisis could turn into a financial crisis. Banks had substantial amounts of capital going into the crisis
column4: including both the required levels and additional countercyclical capital buffers in many countries
column5: but not the United States. Business credit lines have already been drawn
column6: loans will be extended or not repaid
column7: and funding could be increasingly difficult – all threatening to freeze up the financial system.

column1: • The global aftershocks could also be large. Some countries may succeed in containing the virus more quickly than others. Some countries may succeed in containing the economic and financial damage associated with the economy more quickly than others. A rolling set of epidemics in individual countries and economic crises in individual countries would create global limits on travel and continue to strain global supply chains.
The first is uncertainty. Macroeconomic policy is operating under substantial uncertainty at the best of times
column2: given the impossibility of definitive evidence from randomised control trials and the fact that the key structural parameters of the economy are likely fluctuating over time. Now it is operating under massive uncertainty given that we do not know the duration of the pandemic
column3: the duration of the steps that are being taken to flatten the curve
column4: the effect all of these will have on the economy
column5: and how economic policies work in this situation.

column1: The second is time. The change in economic activity has been larger and more abrupt than anything anyone has ever experienced on a global basis. The US housing bubble peaked in 2006
column2: European financial institutions started to have problems in the summer of 2007
column3: economic activity slowed over the course of 2007 in the United States
column4: Bear Stearns needed to be rescued in March 2008
column5: and Lehman Brothers collapsed in September 2008. At times events went quickly
column6: but for the most part the economic situation unfolded slowly. In contrast
column7: each day brings more news about the pandemic and more news about economic closures. Policies that are operational as quickly as possible are necessary.

column1: The third constraint is capacity. During the financial crisis
column2: government employees showed up at their jobs; now many are teleworking and likely all will be soon. Many are scared and distracted by the spread of the virus. Some will get sick and die
column3: or if they do not will care for and grieve for others who do. All of this applies to the people developing policies in places like legislatures
column4: finance ministries and central banks. It also applies to the people implementing the policies. At the best of times it is hard to implement administratively complex new policies. And these are not the best of times.

column1: These constraints have six implications:
• Better to do too much rather than too little. The current situation is one of radical uncertainty. And given this radical uncertainty
column2: policy has to be based on a risk analysis of the cost of doing too little and the cost of doing too much. In this case the risk analysis is increasingly clear: the cost of doing too much is the time value of money
column3: which right now is negative given the negative real interest rates. The cost of doing too little could potentially be enormous both in terms of immediate human suffering and a prolonged economic crisis that exceeds the one in the wake of the global financial crisis.

column1: • Use existing mechanisms as much as possible. Franklin D. Roosevelt engaged in “bold and persistent experimentation” in combatting the Great Depression. This process unfolded over a decade. We do not want to be combatting the economic fallout of the pandemic over the course of a decade. Increase funds under existing channels of assistance rather than creating new ones; repeat policies that have been tried and worked (at least administratively) in the past.
• Invent new programmes where necessary. It will not be possible to use existing mechanisms for everything. The United States
column2: for example
column3: does not have paid leave or mandatory sick days so needs to invent and implement them in the middle of the pandemic. No country has sufficient mechanisms to deal with abrupt revenue stops in a large number of sectors across the economy.

column1: • Diversify and do not fear duplication or unintended ‘winners’ in the response. Given the uncertainty about the economic situation
column2: the impact of policies
column3: and the new policies that are being invented
column4: it is worth diversifying the response. Many policies will have to be tried. Some will work; others will not. Many will be wasteful
column5: giving money to people or businesses that do not need it – or even giving it to the same ones twice. The risk of duplication is much smaller than the risk of over-targeting that leaves many out.

column1: • Enlist the private sector as much as possible. The private sector will be operating under many of the same operational constraints as the government. But it has an existing infrastructure
column2: can be nimble
column3: and can form a diversification of the response. Direct government lending is hard
column4: but loan guarantees can enlist the private sector to make the loans. The private sector will make the additional food and hospital equipment but will need financial incentives. Some will end up making a profit out of all of this
column5: now is not the time to be squeamish.

column1: • Ensure the response is dynamic and persistent. The damage is uncertain. It may vary across places. It may last a long time. Policy needs to be ready to stay in place and even grow in the places and times it is needed. The more that policies can have triggers to automatically continue and expand in places and times they are needed
column2: the better.

column1: What a policy response should look like
The exact policy response will vary from country to country but here are some ways to operationalise the principles above:
• Spare no expense on health. Testing
column2: hospital systems
column3: antiviral and vaccine research and anything else that is needed should be funded.

column1: • Targeted assistance using existing programmes. In the United States this means expanding eligibility for unemployment insurance (although that is hard because eligibility rules vary across the 50 states and the District of Columbia)
column2: increasing the amount of benefits ($50 per week added)
column3: and expanding other programmes for the most vulnerable
column4: like the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). In addition
column5: increasing federal funding for states is critical and one of the best mechanisms for this. The United States is increasing the share of Medicaid paid by the federal government.

column1: • Cash payments to households. M"|1

column1: 2020-05-30|"Friday the 13th is consistently anticipated to be an eventful day among horror film fanatics and the subtly superstitious
column2: but it is also a significant day in tattoo shops across the country. Sailors believed that tattooing the traditionally unlucky number 13 on their bodies would deter bad luck from following them
column3: which encouraged others to flaunt the symbol with simple
column4: spooky designs. Dallas tattoo artist Oliver Peck turned this trend into an event in the ‘90s and tattoo shops have been celebrating the mystic day with special events and mysteriously low prices — typically
column5: $13 mysterious — since.

column1: Ironically

column1: The March 13 event was supposed to be a party — the owners booked Wonderpuff to serve gourmet cotton candy and planned giveaways for those who joined the gathering. The festivities
column2: however
column3: were quickly adapted to address the rising concerns about COVID-19 in the state. The owners modified this notoriously-crowded celebration into a first-come

column3: ” owner Morgan Grimm said. “We just became extra aware of cleanliness

column1: Lively and inviting energy is necessary for a tattoo shop — even if buzzing needles and blood-stained gloves threaten your bravado

column1: “I feel like [tattoo shops]

column3: hairdressers
column4: massage therapists
column5: a lot of those in-person services are just in a complete standstill
column6: ” Grimm expressed. “There is really not much that can be done until we see a decline in cases.”

column1: In addition to losing a steady source of revenue

column1: Ultimately
column2: small businesses are depending on the support of consumers — their neighbors — to stay afloat. It may seem inconvenient to scope out a local business carrying the products you want instead of visiting your preferred cookie-cutter capitalist wonderland
column3: but shopping small benefits the entire community. Not to mention
column4: locally created products — from Pincho Loco’s refreshing ice cream to Heavenly Buffaloes’ late-night greasy satisfaction — allows customers to explore the city through innovative
column5: artistic products crafted by people passionate about their work. They’re working for you. And right now

column1: “Buy from local shops and local restaurants as much as possible. Buy from them instead of Amazon or a major chain store. We’ve been buying groceries from our neighbor Accordion Club

column1: As a writer and reporter

column4: even if your experience only lasts four years. Now is not the time to pretend I have some profound wisdom to share. If you are able to
column5: please shop small. Shop local. Shop Durham."|2

column1: FROM DEAGU in South Korea to Qom in Iran

column4: who says stopping Friday prayers curbed his religious liberty.

column1: The clash between religious and secular authority is felt most keenly in America. On May 29th the Supreme Court voted 5-4 to reject an appeal from a church in California
column2: South Bay United Pentecostal
column3: against restrictions imposed by the state’s Democratic governor
column4: Gavin Newsom. Conservative court members saw merit in the church’s complaint that the constitutional right to free exercise of religion was being violated
column5: but they were overruled. Often President Donald Trump’s administration has sided with churches in disputes with local or state authorities seeking to enforce stay-at-home orders. On May 22nd Mr Trump demanded the re-opening of churches
column6: deeming them “essential”.

column1: Covid-19 has exacerbated not only tension between churches and states
column2: but also disagreements between different religious tendencies. Religious figures have denounced one another
column3: either for being too reckless or for being too meekly compliant with government orders.

column1: These disputes may be a symptom of a wider phenomenon. In the words of Austen Ivereigh
column2: a biographer of Pope Francis
column3: the virus has “deepened existing fault-lines and exposed a few new ones” in the realm of religion. For example
column4: he says
column5: some believers see in the covid crisis a deadly threat to religious liberty; others dismiss that view. Those fault-lines are particularly evident in liberal-democratic countries where practising religion of any kind or style
column6: or firmly rejecting religion
column7: is an open choice
column8: not a default mode.

column1: To understand the biggest chasm
column2: imagine two camps that are defined by what they fear and dislike most. In one are religious groups whose strongest impulse is to improve the material lot of humanity
column3: by fighting poverty or pollution. They are open to working with secular agencies
column4: including governments and supra-national bodies
column5: where they can be a force for the common good. In the other camp
column6: faith communities believe the main challenge is secularism
column7: the watering-down of old certainties
column8: the threat posed by new thinking about sex and gender—all perceived evils deemed to be perpetrated by liberal elites and secular government authorities.

column1: The fault-line does not neatly separate religions; it often divides denominations. Take the split in Catholic ranks. In his response to the pandemic
column2: Pope Francis reaffirmed his preference for the more humanitarian camp by establishing a high-level panel to advise not just on the disease itself but also on the challenges that will follow: unemployment
column3: strained welfare budgets
column4: the need for new definitions of economic value. On May 31st he marked the feast of Pentecost by leading a sparse
column5: mask-wearing flock in prayers in St Peter’s Square; he urged special concern for the world’s vulnerable
column6: including the indigenous people of the Amazon
column7: “that they may not lack health care.” The readmission of a well-policed crowd marked some relief from the empty expanse which Francis faced seven weeks earlier at Easter.

column1: Yet the pope’s declared opponents
column2: including Raymond Burke
column3: an American cardinal
column4: have redoubled their attacks on him for being too compliant with worldly authorities which may have dark agendas. In chastising restrictions preventing the faithful from going to mass
column5: Cardinal Burke wrote: “We cannot simply accept the determinations of secular governments
column6: which would treat the worship of God in the same manner as going to a restaurant or to an athletic contest.” He has also aligned himself with conspiracy theorists in suggesting that the virus might lead to compulsory vaccines or even the subcutaneous microchipping of people by an all-controlling state.

column1: To a degree the divide splits Europe and America
column2: in part because of their differing collective memories. Americans abhor state-imposed religious orthodoxy
column3: whereas Europeans have a theocratic tradition whose current form is emollient. The humanitarian camp is much stronger in Europe
column4: at least among established Christian hierarchies. Bishops have raised few objections to locked-down churches
column5: but they have weighed in on social and political issues. In Britain
column6: for example
column7: the Archbishop of Canterbury
column8: Justin Welby
column9: the head of England’s established church
column10: warned the government against returning to austerity to repay the fast-rising pile of public debt. Several other bishops openly rebuked Dominic Cummings
column11: a prime-ministerial adviser who made a long road-trip during a lockdown.

column1: In some European countries
column2: observers have seen a subtle Christian influence in policy responses to the virus
column3: always working with the grain of the liberal state
column4: not against it. In Germany
column5: for example
column6: theologians have taken part in a commission that pondered how to allocate medical resources in an acute crisis: it concluded that a person’s ability to recover—but not age itself—should be a criterion.

2020-06-02|"Worries about the impact of COVID-19 on pregnant mothers and their offspring are wide-spread. As a comparison
column2: the Spanish Flu pandemic had devastating health impacts on pregnant mothers and in-utero exposure to influenza is known to have negative short- and long-term consequences for children. This column
column3: however
column4: argues that the existing evidence from the COVID-19 pandemic allows for cautious optimism about the impacts of COVID-19 on pregnant women and their children.

column1: More than 2.5 million women are currently pregnant in the United States
column2: and many are worried about the impact a COVID-19 infection might have on mothers and the development of their unborn children. A large literature surrounding the foetal origins hypothesis has shown that pregnancy conditions not only impact the mother but can also impair the offspring (Almond and Currie 2011). Maternal influenza infections during pregnancy may induce premature birth (Currie and Schwandt 2013) and strong cases may even impair foetal development to the point where repercussions throughout adulthood are observed (Schwandt 2019). In his seminal paper
column3: Almond (2006) documented lower incomes and higher adult disability rates among the entire cohort of infants that was in-utero during the Spanish Flu pandemic.

column1: What about children born during the COVID-19 pandemic?
While at this moment it is still unclear whether maternal COVID-19 infections impair foetal development
column2: the existing evidence allows for cautious optimism. The rate of reported COVID-19 deaths among pregnant mothers is low (Hantoushzadeh et al. 2020) and while infections occur in pregnant mothers
column3: most are mild or remain asymptomatic (Sutton et al. 2020
column4: Luo and Yin 2020). Children of mothers infected with COVID-19 during pregnancy are born without detectable impairments and typically test negative for the virus (Chen et al. 2020; Yu et al. 2020).

column1: However
column2: it is too early to know whether in-utero exposure to COVID-19 has negative long-term consequences that are not immediately visible at birth. A potential reference point is the Spanish Flu pandemic (Aassve et al. 2020
column3: Benmelech and Frydman 2020). However
column4: it is important to keep in mind that the 1918 influenza virus had a very different
column5: more devastating impact – particularly for pregnant mothers. Figure 1 compares the age profile of COVID-19 mortality in New York City with Spanish Flu mortality in Philadelphia
column6: one of the hardest hit cities during the Spanish Flu pandemic (Markel et al. 2007). Both mortality rates are shown per 100
column7: 000 people
column8: but are plotted on different y-axes since COVID-19 deaths rates are likely to continue increasing in the ongoing pandemic.

column1: Figure 1 COVID-19 mortality (in NYC) and Spanish Flu mortality (in Philadelphia) by age and gender
Notes: Data on COVID-19 death counts for New York City
column2: 1 February 2020-20 May 2020 (CDC 2020)
column3: combined with population estimates for 2017 (NYSDH 2017). Data on Spanish Flu mortality from Rogers (1920).

column1: COVID-19 mortality increases exponentially with age
column2: with extremely low death rates among infants
column3: children
column4: and young adults (these numbers include recent cases of multi-system inflammatory syndrome
column5: Schroeder 2020). Mortality is particularly low for young women. Among a total of 16
column6: 493 COVID-19 deaths in New York City (between 1 February 2020 and 20 May 2020)
column7: not a single female fatality occurred below age 25. For women between the ages of 25 and 34
column8: only five out of every 100
column9: 000 have died —and this figure is far lower than the rate for women 65 or older
column10: where the data show more than 740 deaths per 100

column1: For the Spanish Flu
column2: the age profile of deaths looked dramatically different. Fatalities were highly concentrated among infants and young adults. Among women
column3: the majority of deaths occurred in the fertile age range and mortality was especially high among pregnant women (Almond 2006). For every death
column4: there were many cases of severe illness
column5: with recorded stillbirths more than doubling during the pandemic (Rogers 1920).

column1: In other words
column2: pregnant mothers who survived the Spanish Flu experienced extreme levels of sickness in response to influenza infections during the pandemic. This strong impact could not be more different from the current experience with COVID-19 infections
column3: which often go largely unnoticed in pregnant mothers. This brings us to the last question in assessing the relative risks between the two pandemics for a developing fetus:

column1: Are mothers’ mild responses to COVID-19 infections good or bad for an infant in utero?
Strong maternal reactions observed for influenza infections may drain the mother’s body
column2: but they could be an efficient response
column3: e.g. to protect the fetus from contracting the virus itself.

column1: However
column2: it turns out that the fetus does not usually get infected if the pregnant mother contracts an influenza virus or the COVID-19 virus (i.e. the virus does not pass the placenta). Hence
column3: it is the strong maternal response to the influenza virus that impairs foetal development. A strong immune system response of the mother can lead to broad inflammations in the pregnant body (McDade 2012) which fight not only the virus but also damage healthy tissue such as the placenta. Pregnant womens’ mild immune system response to COVID-19 is
column4: therefore
column5: a hopeful sign.

column1: Strong inflammations are also hypothesized to turn the mother’s immune system itself against the fetus. The father’s genes in the fetus are foreign to the mother’s body and are only tolerated due to the mediation of helper cells surrounding the placenta (Trowsdale and Betz 2006). A strong inflammatory response can compromise the functionality of these helper cells. As a result
column2: the fetus might not only suffer from the inflammation itself
column3: but an inflammation can actually cause the mother’s immune system to harm the fetus. It remains unclear why pregnancy makes women respond so strongly to the influenza virus (Kay et al. 2014)
column4: but it has been observed both for pandemics and seasonal influenza. Further
column5: the resulting infections have similar negative impacts on the offspring – both at birth as well as into adulthood (Almond 2006
column6: Creanga et al. 2009
column7: Currie and Schwandt 2013
column8: Schwandt 2019).

column1: It is important to emphasize that our understanding of the threats of COVID-19 is still far from complete. We are learning from new research findings on a daily basis. But there is room for cautious optimism from what we know so far: COVID-19 seems to impact pregnant women less than influenza does. While immune system responses triggered by maternal influenza have been shown to impair foetal development
column2: COVID-19 does not seem to cause such strong responses in mothers’ immune systems. Of course
column3: it is still possible that other impairments in the offspring may appear later
column4: even if they are not observable at birth. And only time will tell whether infants exposed to COVID-19 during the first or second trimester will show signs of impairment at birth. But
column5: so far
column6: the existing evidence allows for cautious hope that pregnant mothers and their offspring will fare much better during COVID-19 than they did during the last devastating global pandemic at the turn of the 20th century.

column1: This is not to say that pregnant mothers and young children are entirely unaffected by the current pandemic. Food insecurity is on the rise (Schanzenbach and Pitts 2020)
column2: and many young families face financial stress as unemployment is soaring to unprecedented levels (Conti 2020). Nutritional
column3: economic
column4: and psychological stress during pregnancy is detrimental for the fetus as it increases the risk of poor health at birth which may in turn lead to negative long-term consequences (Aizer et al. 2016 Almond et al. 2011
column5: Persson and Rossin-Slater 2018). Hence
column6: we do not want to add unfounded anxieties about COVID-19 infections to mothers’ list of worries—as fewer worries might help their developing infants most.

column1: 2020-06-03|"As lockdown measures continue
column2: or are relaxed only gradually
column3: many small businesses continue to experience significantly reduced turnover. This column reports on a firm-level analysis across 16 emerging markets
column4: and three Western European comparator countries
column5: in order to gauge the potential risks associated with debt-driven COVID-19 support. The overall goal is to prevent a wave of bankruptcies that could break valuable relationships between firms and their suppliers and employees. However
column6: liquidity support in the form of additional bank lending may create debt-overhang problems in the future and therefore requires careful targeting.

column1: Over the past decade
column2: corporate leverage has increased considerably in many developing countries and emerging markets
column3: often exacerbating financial fragility (Alfaro et al. 2019). Policymakers who aim to alleviate corporate cash shortages during the COVID-19 pandemic therefore need to avoid overloading financially vulnerable firms with more debt. This risk is real given that the most popular method of COVID-19 support to SMEs has been to provide these firms with more loans. To gauge the potential risks associated with debt-driven COVID-19 support
column4: this column reports on a firm-level analysis across 16 emerging markets
column5: and three Western European comparator countries. Our objective is to understand where ‘small and medium-sized enterprises’ (SMEs) are most in need of cash and liquidity and
column6: second
column7: where these firms still have room on their balance sheet to take on more debt. Where there is little or no such room
column8: further bank lending may come at the risk of a structural weakening of banks’ balance sheets (Galí 2020).

column1: Our analysis is based on a firm-level dataset that combines information from surveys conducted as part of the latest round of the EBRD-EIB-World Bank Enterprise Surveys (with data from Orbis). We use these data to estimate regression models of firms’ optimal capital structure or leverage (defined as formal debt to total assets) and
column2: separately
column3: their cash holdings (defined as cash and cash equivalents to total assets). The models clarify how firms’ pre-COVID-19 capital structures and cash buffers can be explained by basic firm characteristics such as their size
column4: profitability
column5: asset tangibility
column6: turnover variability
column7: and industry.

column1: Using these simple models
column2: we then calculate for each country how much the average small business’s cash buffer falls short of (or exceeds) the predicted cash buffer. Likewise
column3: we measure the available capacity for additional debt of the average SME (firms with 250 or fewer employees) in each country. Figure 1 summarises these calculations. The horizontal axis shows how SME cash holdings in countries such as Croatia
column4: Lithuania
column5: Morocco
column6: Serbia
column7: Slovenia
column8: and Ukraine fall short of the predicted value by between 3-7% of total assets. In contrast
column9: the average small business in Bulgaria
column10: Czech Republic
column11: Latvia
column12: Montenegro
column13: and Slovak Republic has greater than predicted cash buffers.

column1: Figure 1 Excess leverage and cash holdings of the average small business
Source: Authors’ calculations based on data from ES and Orbis.
The vertical axis of figure 1 shows where small firms (on average) still have the capacity to borrow more. For instance
column2: this is the case in countries like Lithuania
column3: Morocco
column4: and Ukraine (countries where SMEs seem to have an urgent need for more liquidity)
column5: as well as in Bulgaria

column1: Next

column3: we calculate for each country the proportion of SMEs that operate with lower than predicted cash buffers as well as the proportion of SMEs that entered the COVID-19 pandemic with relatively ample cash reserves. Likewise

column5: and the proportion of SMEs that still appear in a position to absorb more debt. Figure 2 summarises these results. More than 60% of SMEs in Morocco and Ukraine are both short on cash and have room to take on extra debt. In contrast

How long can small businesses survive with their existing cash buffers? As a rough indicator
column2: we calculate the number of months that a small business can afford to pay its employees out of its existing cash reserves. We then plot the distribution of businesses by different ‘survival horizons’ in Chart 3. About half of all small businesses in Ukraine have cash reserves of less than one month’s wages. column3: most small businesses in Montenegro
column4: Russia
column5: Lithuania
column6: and Slovenia were likely to run out of cash reserves to pay their workers in less than two months.

column1: Where can credit access relieve liquidity constraints the most? Figure 3 also shows how the share of small businesses with liquidity constraints would change were they to ‘load up’ on debt to a level that our model would predict is normal (given their other firm characteristics). This shows
column2: for instance
column3: that additional lending to Ukrainian SMEs could decrease the share of businesses with cash buffers that only cover up to one month of wages from 50% to 20%.

column1: Source: Authors’ calculations based on data from ES and Orbis.
Our empirical analysis is rudimentary in the sense that it disregards certain firm- and country-specific determinants of corporate debt and cash buffers. Notwithstanding
column2: the analysis provides a straightforward and micro-founded ‘traffic light system’. This can help diagnose in which countries firms’ needs for liquidity are most dire
column3: and (as importantly) in which countries these temporary cash shortages can safely be alleviated through more debt funding. For instance
column4: in countries like Bosnia and Herzegovina
column5: Croatia
column6: and Slovenia
column7: there appear to be a relatively large number of firms in need of liquidity but there are also many firms that are already highly indebted. In such countries
column8: efforts to support cash-strapped firms may take the following into consideration:

column1: • Decisions about whether to alleviate cash shortages through additional bank lending should ideally continue to be based on a case-by-case assessment of individual firms’ debt capacity. This in turn requires a view on whether the business was performing well before the pandemic
column2: or already had issues. Business exit remains an essential part of the process of creative destruction.

column1: • Where possible
column2: lending programs should require participating banks to make full use of existing credit bureaus and registries to ensure a complete picture of total outstanding debt. This holds in particular for emerging markets with a history of episodes of excessive private sector borrowing
column3: and where information sharing among lenders has proven beneficial (De Haas et al. 2020).

column1: • In countries where few firms have spare debt capacity
column2: SMEs may be better served by government-sponsored initiatives to roll over existing debt rather than to provide fresh debt. This may include temporary debt moratoriums and loan-maturity extensions.

column1: • On a structural level
column2: many emerging markets will need to gradually rebalance their financial systems towards a greater use of equity instruments and a reduced reliance on debt (EBRD 2015). In the short term
column3: interesting proposals have been made for a European Pandemic Equity Fund (Boot et al. 2020). Such a fund would provide cash-strapped SMEs with cash flow injections in return for
column4: for instance
column5: a surcharge on future corporate tax payments. In the medium term
column6: governments and (multi-)national development banks can play a proactive role in stimulating a public and private equity culture in emerging markets (for instance through improving research coverage and hence transparency of listed SMEs). As part of the COVID-19 response
column7: financial resilience can further be rebuilt by selective equity investments in financially sound
column8: high-growth
column9: and innovative small businesses with strong management already in place. Lastly
column10: in the long run
column11: policy makers could structurally reduce tax-code favouritism towards debt (for instance
column12: by giving firms equivalent tax benefits for equity and debt).
