The investigations are ongoing to assess the full extent of the outbreak and therefore high vigilance should be maintained. This information will help define the risk in the coming days.
WHO advises the following risk reduction measures as an effective way to reduce Ebola virus disease transmission in humans:

• Reducing the risk of wildlife-to-human transmission from contact with infected fruit bats or monkeys/apes and the consumption of their raw meat. Animals should be handled with gloves and other appropriate protective clothing. Animal products (blood and meat) should be thoroughly cooked before consumption.
• Reducing the risk of human-to-human transmission from direct or close contact with people with Ebola symptoms
column2: particularly with their bodily fluids. Gloves and appropriate personal protective equipment should be worn when taking care of ill patients at home. Regular hand washing is required after visiting patients in hospital
column3: as well as after taking care of patients at home.

column1: • Reducing the risk of possible sexual transmission
column2: based on further analysis of ongoing research and consideration by the WHO Advisory Group on the Ebola Virus Disease Response
column3: WHO recommends that male survivors of EVD practice safe sex and hygiene for 12 months from onset of symptoms or until their semen tests negative twice for Ebola virus. Contact with body fluids should be avoided and washing with soap and water is recommended. WHO does not recommend isolation of male or female convalescent patients whose blood has been tested negative for Ebola virus.

column1: 2020-06-03|"COVID-19 has laid bare the weaknesses of clinical diagnostics infrastructures. Underfunded
column2: undervalued and underprepared
column3: laboratory testing has been overwhelmed by the contagion. A combination of low reimbursement
column4: low margins
column5: low capacity and low investment has stifled innovation and competition. Cost-cutting
column6: centralization and regulatory rigidity have created backlogs and slowed the tracking of infections. Given the pivotal role of diagnostics in healthcare decision-making
column7: COVID-19 shows just how much clinical testing needs a radical rethink.

column1: On May 28
column2: the United States achieved a record 416
column3: 664 tests for SARS-CoV-2 in one day (around one test per thousand people per day). The United Kingdom
column4: France
column5: Spain and much of the rest of Europe are testing at a similar level. Given that only ~3
column6: 000 tests are carried out per day during a typical flu season
column7: we are approaching the limit of testing capacity using existing clinical laboratories and supply chains. But it is nowhere near the level needed for countries to contain COVID-19 while reopening their economies.

column1: According to the World Health Organization
column2: if more than 10% of results come back positive
column3: testing capacity is insufficient; test positivity higher than 10% means many active infections are being missed. Nobel laureate economist Paul Romer has suggested 30 million daily tests are needed to reach the 10% positivity threshold in the United States. The Rockefeller Foundation Testing Action Plan projects 5 million tests by early June
column4: growing to 20 million in the following four months. Even the lowest estimates suggest 750
column6: 000 molecular tests will be needed every day — more than double what is presently available.

column1: The massive scale of testing now needed is a result of government failure at the beginning of the outbreak to quickly implement testing
column2: tracking and tracing measures — together with social distancing — to limit the community spread of SARS-CoV-2. In those countries where lockdown was decisive and stringent tracking and tracing procedures were put in place — Taiwan
column3: South Korea
column4: Hong Kong and Singapore — subsequent massive testing has been unnecessary.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: failed lockdowns and slipshod testing have gone hand in hand. In the United States
column3: the Centers for Disease Control botched its test rollout and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) dithered on Emergency Use Authorizations (EUAs)
column4: vacillating between oversight that was too stringent for RT-PCR testing and too lax for serological testing. The United Kingdom abandoned broad testing and contact tracing in March
column5: then reversed its policy. France planned widespread testing at the end of March
column6: then gave up on diagnostic testing when it became clear its clinical testing infrastructure couldn’t deliver.

column1: The shrinking number of public labs
column2: along with their centralization
column3: has meant results can take days if not weeks to come back — useless for tracking and tracing. France has only 45 testing labs; the United States just 97 public labs
column4: with a commercial sector dominated by corporate giants like Quest Diagnostics and LabCorp. Germany stands apart
column5: with a robust infrastructure of 20 national reference centers
column6: around 40 ‘consultant laboratories’ and hundreds of hospital- and clinic-based local testing centers. Results from the extended network are coordinated through a computer system adapted from Germany’s Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance network; Heidelberg even has a ‘corona taxi’ program that transports medics in protective gear to check on patients in their homes.

column1: In contrast
column2: testing in the United States is a mess. With shambolic coordination at the national level
column3: existing providers have become swamped
column4: testing backlogs have lengthened and shortages of swabs
column5: supplies and reagents have grown. As traditional labs failed to ramp up
column6: several research centers and hubs have stepped in and retooled to provide semi-automated ‘pop up’ labs for COVID-19
column7: working with regulatory authorities and partnering with clinically accredited labs to innovate around reagent shortages. One open-source effort recently won an FDA EUA for processing >10
column8: 000 samples per day using automated loop-mediated isothermal amplification
column9: circumventing RT-PCR reagent shortages and aiming to provide results in 24 hours. Another idea is to use multiplexing schemes and next-generation sequencing to pool thousands of bar-coded COVID-19 samples and then triage down to confirmatory testing for the identification of individual positives — an approach that enabled Wuhan
column10: China to test 6.5 million people in 9 days.

column1: Whatever technology is adopted
column2: with tests in such short supply
column3: strategic deployment to hotspots will be important in combination with contact tracing: clinical centers
column4: essential services
column5: travel hubs
column6: nursing homes
column7: meat-packing plants and places of congregation (bars
column8: nightclubs or religious gatherings) will remain priorities
column9: with drive-thru testing provided as an adjunct.

column1: During reopening
column2: testing volume will most likely be built by employers. Symptom reporting and contact-tracing apps built on Apple and Google’s API will be used to identify workers to prioritize for testing (Drexel University and Baylor College already offer such an app). Ultimately
column3: kits for doctors’ offices and at-home testing will become available
column4: some perhaps even using CRISPR technology
column5: like those from Mammoth Biosciences or Sherlock Biosciences.

column1: The failure of the clinical diagnostic sector to deal with the demands of a 21st century pandemic is a wake-up call. The traditional players appear incapable of innovating around the problem — probably because innovation is alien in an environment where reimbursement cuts by the 2014 Protecting Access to Medicare Act
column2: erosion of intellectual property protection
column3: and a lack of regulatory clarity has depressed profit margins and stunted investment.

column1: But infectious disease is not going away. And in an increasingly interconnected
column2: urbanized and globalized world
column3: COVID-19 has shown that present lab testing systems are clearly unfit for purpose. A reinvigoration of new ideas and new technology is urgently needed to put diagnostics back at the forefront of twenty-first-century medicine and pandemic prevention."|1

column1: 2020-06-04|"Jonathan Cotliar knew he was ahead of the curve four years ago when he joined Science 37
column2: a company that supports virtual clinical trials conducted mostly online. The firm in Los Angeles
column3: California
column4: was growing slowly before March
column5: receiving about a dozen calls a week from potential clients. But since the COVID-19 pandemic began
column6: Science 37 has been running at fever pitch.

column1: Cotliar
column2: the company’s chief medical officer
column3: says Science 37 now receives hundreds of enquiries every week from potential clients
column4: such as pharmaceutical companies
column5: medical centres and even individual investigators. With hospitals forming the epicentres of COVID-19 outbreaks around the world
column6: clinical-trial participants have become reluctant to attend routine check-ups and monitoring
column7: and health-care workers are stretched beyond their capacity. This has caused researchers to put many clinical trials on hold or to shift to a virtual trial structure by performing consultations online and collecting as much paperwork and data as possible remotely.

column1: The pandemic might hasten the kind of change in clinical trials that Cotliar and Science 37 were hoping to make anyway. And there could be other lasting effects on drug development: companies that are usually competitors are now collaborating
column2: and many are trying to make their supply chains more robust to deal with disruption. Some researchers and companies in the drug-development field say the system might never be the same again.

column1: The pandemic has touched nearly all aspects of the industry
column2: says Kenneth Kaitin
column3: director of the Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development in Boston
column4: Massachusetts. “This has really turned upside down the whole drug-development process
column5: ” he says. “The entire investigative world is focused just on developing treatments for COVID-19.”

column1: Scientists’ worlds will shrink in the wake of the pandemic
Some changes are likely to be temporary
column2: Kaitin predicts. Drug regulators in the United States and other countries have acted fast to approve clinical trials of therapies and allow new uses of existing medicines to fight COVID-19
column3: without demanding as much data and paperwork as they normally would. Such changes are likely to stick only for as long as the outbreak lasts. “The flexibilities that are being granted for clinical-trial development are being granted under the auspices of a public-health declaration
column4: ” says Esther Krofah
column5: executive director of FasterCures
column6: a Washington DC think tank. “That
column7: to me
column8: is very much an emergency operation.”

column1: And Kaitin points out that these changes shave only a few months off the drug-development timeline — crucial in the middle of a pandemic
column2: but unlikely to make a significant dent in the lengthy process of developing a therapy
column3: which can stretch out over years.

column1: The pandemic could catalyse lasting change in other ways. What might linger
column2: Krofah says
column3: is the culture of collaboration across government
column4: industry and academia that has emerged during the outbreak. “We have traditional competitors working together in new ways
column5: ” she says. An alliance of more than a dozen companies — including Gilead in Foster City
column6: California
column7: Novartis in Basel
column8: Switzerland
column9: and WuXi AppTec in Shanghai
column10: China — has been working to discover and test antiviral treatments by sharing data about early results and basic science
column11: as well as collaborating on designs for clinical trials. If these group efforts bear fruit
column12: they might continue
column13: says Krofah.

column1: Pharmaceutical companies might also make long-lasting adjustments to their supply chains
column2: says David Simchi-Levi
column3: who studies operations management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge. Over the past few decades
column4: drug makers have increasingly shifted their manufacturing away from the United States and Europe to countries such as India and China
column5: which can produce the drugs at lower cost. But over the past few years
column6: many firms have begun to look for ways to diversify their supplies of services and raw materials
column7: to reduce the risk of supply interruptions in the event of a US–China trade war
column8: says Simchi-Levi. The coronavirus outbreak could accelerate that trend. “Some shocks were anticipated
column9: but not at this scale
column10: ” says Krofah. “This is going to cause a fundamental re-examination of that risk.”

column1: Momentum for a shift towards virtual clinical trials has been gradually building for years. But progress had been hindered by a lack of clear guidance from regulators such as the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and a reluctance to invest in the technology needed to run such trials — until the pandemic hit
column2: says Cotliar. Companies such as Science 37 are suddenly seeing their popularity skyrocket. “It’s exponentially accelerated the adoption curve of what we were already doing
column3: ” Cotliar says. “That’s been a bit surreal.”

column1: At the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis
column2: for example
column3: infectious-disease specialist David Boulware and his colleagues conducted a randomized
column4: controlled
column5: virtual trial of the malaria drug hydroxychloroquine to find out whether it can protect people who are at high risk of contracting COVID-19. The trial
column6: which included more than 800 people and found the treatment had no benefit (D. R. Boulware et al. N. Engl. J. Med. http://doi.org/dxkv; 2020)
column7: sent participants medicine by FedEx delivery and monitored their health remotely.

column1: Patient advocates have long pushed for more virtual trials
column2: which ease the burden of clinical-trial participation. If the trend catches on
column3: it could speed up the enrolment of participants — a significant piece of the drug-development timeline.

column1: And now that the pandemic has driven medical centres to set up much-needed technology
column2: and forced the FDA to release guidelines for virtual trials during the pandemic
column3: it is hard to imagine clinical research going back to the way it was before
column4: says Krofah. “We’re going to see this as a new
column5: normal part of clinical research
column6: ” she says. “The cat is out of the bag.”"|0

column1: 2020-06-04|"In mid-March
column2: just after restrictions were put in place to slow the spread COVID-19
column3: Dr Nigel Stevenson looked out the window of his Dublin apartment. “It was a beautiful
column4: still evening
column5: the sun was setting and there was no traffic on the roads. It was idyllic
column6: ” he recalls. “Then I remembered why it was so quiet
column7: and I thought... that damn virus.”

column1: Stevenson
column2: who leads the Viral Immunology Lab in Trinity’s Biomedical Sciences Institute
column3: knows more about “that damn virus” than most. For more than a decade he has been working on disease-causing viruses
column4: including HIV
column5: Hepatitis C and
column6: more recently
column7: the coronaviruses SARS-CoV-1 (from the outbreak in the early 2000s) and MERS (from the outbreak in 2012). Now he has turned his lab’s attention to the pandemic virus
column8: SARS-CoV-2.

column1: His interest? The biochemical dance between an invading virus and the human cell it seeks to hijack
column2: and how understanding those interactions could help us design new therapies to stop infection.

column1: “Some viruses
column2: including the one that causes Covid-19
column3: can hide from our immune systems early in the infection
column4: and they can really get entrenched
column5: ” he explains. “By understanding how they do that
column6: we could potentially bring the viruses out of hiding and help the immune system to clear the infection early on. That would lead to less disease.”

column1: When the SARS-CoV-2 virus – that causes Covid-19 – gets into our airways
column2: it enters our cells and ejects its genetic material
column3: co-opting the infected cell into making copies of the virus
column4: which then go on to infect other cells.

column1: One way our body defends us against this takeover is by releasing a substance called interferon
column2: Stevenson explains. “Interferon is a really powerful defender
column3: because it activates hundreds of other genes and proteins that effectively stop the virus in its tracks.”

column1: But some viruses can interfere with the interferon response. Stevenson and his Trinity College Dublin colleague Prof Cliona O’Farrelly have previously shown the Hepatitis C virus can block a particular pathway of biochemical signals inside the cell
column2: thereby stopping the cell from “telling” interferon to ramp up the molecular defences. “We could see that the virus degraded this biochemical pathway inside liver and immune cells
column3: ” explains Stevenson. “And this blockade meant the body wasn’t able to switch on its normal defences against the virus.”

column1: Stevenson has found other viruses use a similar mechanism to block responses to interferon
column2: among them HIV. “We have been able to show that HIV-1 stops interferon too
column3: ” he says. “And we are looking at ways to prevent HIV-1 from doing that
column4: and thereby restore the natural interferon response.”

column1: Then
column2: last year
column3: in a case of spectacularly good timing
column4: PhD student
column5: Yamei Zhang
column6: in Stevenson’s lab started to look at the effect of the original SARS and MERS coronaviruses on the Interferon response. “Our ongoing studies are showing that both the SARS-1 and MERS viruses use a conserved mechanism to block interferon
column7: ” Stevenson adds.

column1: When Covid-19 became a serious public health concern
column2: the researchers also turned their attention to SARS-CoV-2. Their analysis of the pandemic virus genome indicates that it too may use this process to suppress response to interferon
column3: as it has a similar interferon-blocking code to the one Stevenson’s lab has studied in its coronavirus “cousins”.

column1: “We are now studying this
column2: because if this is one way through which SARS-CoV-2 evades our immune system
column3: then it’s good news for our battle against this deadly virus
column4: ” says Stevenson. “Our lab is already working on ways to restore interferon’s biochemical pathway
column5: so now we can apply these research discoveries to the pandemic virus too.”

column1: Another difficulty in Covid-19 is that when the immune system does respond to the virus later in the infection
column2: it can over-respond in some people
column3: damaging their lungs and other organs. Prof Andrew Bowie
column4: also at Trinity
column5: is trying to figure out the pathway to this response.

column1: Like Stevenson
column2: he has found himself in a good position to focus on SARS-CoV-2. “Last year
column3: we started working with RNA viruses that affect the airways
column4: trying to understand how these viruses trigger an immune response in lung cells
column5: ” Bowie says. “And now we can pivot that work to look at how the RNA virus SARS-CoV-2 does this.”

column1: Bowie
column2: along with O’Farrelly and Prof Luke O’Neill
column3: are part of a European project called INITIATE
column4: which explores how disease-causing viruses interact with human cells growing in the lab.

column1: “We are looking at how the airway cells react to the viruses when they meet them
column2: and the kind of inflammatory immune response that follows
column3: ” explains Bowie. “We and others have already discovered that viruses prompt a different kind of immune response in lung cells compared to the response we see to bacteria. Now we can look at how the inflammatory immune response gets switched on specifically in response to SARS-CoV-2
column4: and what pathways are involved. It’s a good example of how answering a basic biological question will shed light about what is going on in patients who experience this kind of immune activation in Covid-19.”

column1: Ultimately
column2: we want the answers to those biological questions to translate into better ways to prevent or treat Covid-19. Dr Virginie Gautier at University College Dublin is marshalling her lab’s resources to screen for such answers. Her expertise lies in host-virus interactions
column3: and now she has re-oriented her lab to look at SARS-CoV-2.

column1: “We are interested in the ways that cells respond biochemically to viruses
column2: so that we can identify points of vulnerability that could be targeted by drugs
column3: ” explains Gautier
column4: who is a principal investigator at the UCD Centre for Experimental Pathogen Host Research. “We also have a platform set up in the lab where we can apply specific drugs or other agents and see how that affects the virus when infecting the cells.”

column1: With funding through the Health Research Board’s national Covid-19 rapid response call
column2: Gautier is now working with UCD Prof Paddy Mallon to screen for ways to block SARS-CoV-2 using that platform.

column1: “We want to look at drugs that have already been approved for use in the clinic
column2: so they could be repurposed for treating SARS-CoV-2 if they are effective
column3: and we are looking at potential new agents against the virus too
column4: ” Gautier says.

column1: Her lab is also helping to provide reagents for hospitals to test patient samples for SARS-CoV-2
column2: she adds. “This pandemic needs us all to work together
column3: to use the insights and systems we have developed for other viruses and focus on this one.”"|0

column1: 2020-06-04|"The UK’s 2008 Climate Change Act has led to a 34% fall in CO 2 emissions by 2019
column2: while real GDP per capita had risen by more than 10% following the crash into the ‘Great Recession’. Can the UK achieve its recent net-zero emissions target by 2050 while still growing? This column describes some speculative routes to such a decarbonised future.

column1: Although much of the modern world is powered by fossil fuels
column2: that was not an inevitable outcome of technology and costs. The first electricity generator in the UK in 1868 was hydro-driven
column3: the first commercial photovoltaic solar panel – building on Edmond Becquerel’s 1839 creation of the first photovoltaic cell – was developed by Charles Fritts in 1881
column4: the first wind turbine to generate electricity was built by James Blyth in 1887
column5: and by the 1930s wind-generated electricity was relatively common on US farms. Moreover
column6: electric cars date back to the 1880s after Thomas Parker built a vehicle with a high-capacity rechargeable battery. Thus
column7: an all-electric-powered society is just going back to a future where we might have been 125 years ago.

column1: The rapidly falling costs of renewable energy sources like solar cells and onshore wind turbines combined with improved storage methods should substantially reduce oil and gas use in electricity production. Offshore wind turbines have also fallen greatly in cost and increased in efficiency over the past two decades so that for the UK they offer a low-cost alternative with the incidental benefit of creating marine reserves and fish sanctuaries. Wind turbines are cheaper than natural gas combined-cycle turbines even before adding the costs of carbon capture and storage.
Solar photovoltaics come next (for the UK) if carbon capture and storage is enforced
column2: though both wind and sun sources require large backup electricity storage systems for
column3: for example
column4: windless nights
column5: which we’ll discuss below. Renewable energy’s share of overall UK electricity generation reached a peak of 60.5% at one stage in April 2020
column6: according to National Grid data.

column1: Coal use has fallen to near zero in the UK since the 2008 Climate Change Act
column2: without obvious aggregate costs (Hendry 2020). However
column3: natural gas usage has increased 3.5-fold since the mid-1980s and still contributes about 140 megatons (Mt) p.a. to CO emissions despite producing less than half those of coal per Btu.

column2: the UK government amended the original Climate Change Act target to zero net emissions by 2050. All sources of greenhouse gas emissions must go to a level such that carbon capture and storage
column3: possibly combined with atmospheric CO extraction methods
column4: must remove the rest.

column1: Facing an irreducible non-zero minimum demand for oil and gas (e.g. for chemicals)
column2: to achieve zero net emissions before 2050 requires major technological change that almost certainly involves developing current research on avenues to remove (Wemyss 2014) or reuse existing CO as a fuel (Stanford University 2019). ‘Net zero’ is an excellent target but incredibly difficult to achieve and as yet
column3: there is no sensible UK strategy to do so – so we now suggest some speculative routes.

column1: To meet the net-zero target
column2: natural gas–use must be reduced to near zero
column3: like coal. Natural gas is mainly used for electricity production and household indoor- and water heating. The former could be handled in part by increased renewable sources. Household natural-gas (and some oil) usage could be reduced by increased taxes encouraging the adoption of solar panels and
column4: for example
column5: air heat pumps.

column1: More radically
column2: the UK could switch back from a national gas distribution system using natural gas to one based on hydrogen
column3: possibly made by electrolysis when there is spare renewable electricity. The UK had a hydrogen-based gas distribution system prior to 1969
column4: but the switch to natural gas required all household equipment to be converted from ones that burned coal gas (which is composed of about 50% hydrogen) to those that burned natural gas (which is mainly methane).

column1: With ever-improving technologies and cost reductions in renewable electricity generation
column2: a near-zero target for natural gas over the next 30 years should be possible without reducing GDP growth – perhaps even increasing growth with new opportunities.

column1: However
column2: as no future technology is certain
column3: more research should be devoted to developing safe small modular nuclear reactors (World Nuclear Association 2020) based on the well-developed nuclear-powered engines in submarines. Variants of small modular nuclear reactors such as molten-salt waste-burners https://www.seaborg.co/ may be able to use non-fissionable thorium or the ‘spent’ uranium fuel rods from older reactors
column4: helping to reduce the serious problem of transuranic-waste disposal. Part of those disposal-cost savings should be put towards the building of small modular nuclear reactors
column5: perhaps supplemented by reallocating the £40 billion saved by abandoning the Hinkley Point C nuclear power station.

column1: Even over our horizon of 30 years
column2: nuclear fusion seems unlikely to be a key energy contributor despite many developments
column3: such as increasing output efficiency (Bennett 2017) and reducing internal damage to tokamak materials from helium (Galeon 2017)
column4: which might then be collected
column5: offsetting a potential shortage.

column1: Reducing oil use in transport to zero will take longer following current strategies
column2: even with more efficient engines (diesel being phased out completely given its toxic pollutants)
column3: and much higher taxes on gasoline. Without a major improvement in lithium-ion-battery-powered electric vehicles
column4: their relatively short journey capacity despite taking a non-negligible time to recharge discourages the replacement of internal combustion engines.

column1: However
column2: recent advances have been made in understanding the properties of graphene
column3: with potentially large falls in its cost of production (see ‘graphene in a flash’ from plastic waste
column4: Williams 2020). Graphene nanotubes can act as electrode super-capacitors
column5: and there may be something like a variant of Moore’s law (which states that processing power of computers doubles every two years) that could lead to cost reductions stemming from a large increase in their production.

column1: Imagine sandwiching an array of graphene nanotubes (Sammed et al. 2020) between two Faraday cages in a prefabricated modular unit fitted to a vehicle’s roof (perhaps even retrofitted on existing car roofs) to power an electric motor
column2: so the vehicle becomes the battery. Graphene nanotubes seem capable of rapid charging and should be able to sustain viable distances on a single charge.

column1: Moreover
column2: if such electric vehicles are successful
column3: mandating them to be plugged in when not in use will translate into a vast electric storage system for no additional investment
column4: with cars acting as the National Grid’s storage. Thus
column5: renewable sources of electricity could be widely adopted without worrying about the security of supply.

column1: There are undoubtedly many technical issues that need to be solved before such a system could work in practice

column1: The result is that Assange has become a pariah. Lost is the fact that he and WikiLeaks did what all journalists should do

column3: enabling people to make evidence-based judgments about the world around them and

column1: The early attempts to discredit Assange focused on trying to prove that the WikiLeaks disclosures had led directly to the deaths of US agents and informants. The Pentagon put a great deal of effort into substantiating this allegation: it set up an Information Review Task Force headed by a senior counterintelligence officer
column2: Brigadier General Robert Carr
column3: which studied the impact of the revelations and sought to produce a list of people who might have been killed because of the information the cables contained. Carr later described the extent of his task force’s failure
column4: in testimony given at Manning’s sentencing hearing in July 2013. After long research
column5: his team of 120 counterintelligence officers hadn’t been able to find a single person
column6: among the thousands of American agents and secret sources in Afghanistan and Iraq
column7: who could be shown to have died because of the disclosures. Carr told the court that at one point his task force seemed to be getting somewhere: the Taliban claimed to have killed a US informant identified in the WikiLeaks cables. It was a sign of desperation on the part of the counterintelligence officers that in seeking evidence against WikiLeaks they were reduced to citing the Taliban as a source. And
column8: as Carr admitted during the defence cross-examination
column9: the Taliban turned out to be lying: ‘The name of the individual killed was not in the [WikiLeaks] disclosures.’ Despite all this
column10: the lawyer representing the US government at Assange’s extradition hearings in London earlier this year still argued that Assange had put the lives of US sources in Iraq and Afghanistan at risk.

column1: In Kabul in 2010

He explained that the US government wasn’t so naive as to believe that information stored on a database to which as many as half a million people had access – one of whom turned out to be Private Manning – was likely to stay confidential for very long. column1: 2020-06-05|"Two weeks after a high-profile paper in The Lancet1 reported that the antimalarial drug hydroxychloroquine might be dangerous to patients with COVID-19
column2: three of its four authors have retracted the work because they were unable to independently verify their data set
column3: a large proprietary collection of electronic health records analysed by Surgisphere
column4: a US company.

column1: On the same day
column2: 4 June
column3: the researchers and other co-authors retracted a paper in the New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM)2
column4: for the same reason. That study
column5: published a month ago
column6: had looked at the impact of certain heart medications on people with COVID-19
column7: and found no safety concerns.

column1: Scientists say the affair raises serious questions about the way researchers and journals evaluate the data underlying papers that they publish
column2: and may complicate the effort to trial drugs during the coronavirus pandemic.

column1: “This whole event is catastrophic — it is problematic for the journals involved

column3: it is problematic for medicine
column4: and it is problematic for the notion of clinical trials and evidence generation

column1: Both papers relied on proprietary data analysed from electronic health records that were apparently gathered from hundreds of hospitals around the world by Surgisphere. But after critics raised questions about the studies
column2: the firm did not make its raw data available to third-party auditors for validation. According to the retraction notice in the Lancet
column3: Surgisphere was concerned that transferring the data would violate ""client agreements and confidentiality requirements"".

column1: “Since we do not have the ability to verify the primary data or primary data source
column2: I no longer have confidence in the origination and veracity of the data

column1: Sapan Desai
column2: the founder of Surgisphere
column3: in Chicago
column4: Illinois
column5: and a co-author of the studies
column6: declined to comment to Nature on the retractions and on concerns about the quality of the data behind the studies. Desai signed the NEJM retraction but not the Lancet one.

column1: After the Lancet study appeared
column2: some regulators had paused enrolment in clinical trials of hydroxychloroquine as a treatment for COVID-19. The drug
column3: which is cheap and easy to administer
column4: has been widely endorsed in the pandemic
column5: including by US President Donald Trump
column6: despite scant evidence of its effectiveness. Some of the halted trials
column7: including one led by the World Health Organization

column1: A third study authored by Desai
column2: Mehra and others that used Surgisphere data
column3: which claimed to find a large reduction in COVID-19 mortality when patients were given the anti-parasitic drug ivermectin
column4: has disappeared from the social-sciences preprint server SSRN
column5: where it was first posted on 6 April; a second version was posted on 19 April. Mehra told Nature that he removed the study because he ""did not feel it was ready for peer review"".

column1: Although the paper was not published in a peer-reviewed journal

column4: who is running a clinical trial of ivermectin and had raised questions about the preprint’s data.

column1: Bioethicists say the retractions
column2: and the pulled preprint
column3: raise questions not only about the quality and nature of Surgisphere's data
column4: but also about why the paper’s other authors agreed to work with a large data set they couldn’t validate
column5: and how the work passed peer review at prestigious medical journals.

column1: The hydroxychloroquine study
column2: published on 22 May
column3: had purportedly analysed electronic health records gathered on 96
column4: 000 patients in 671 hospitals across six continents. But critics soon raised questions about oddities in the data
column5: and asked for more details on its origins. By 28 May

column8: 000 patients across 169 hospitals.

column1: Before they published the studies

column1: Most data on hydroxychloroquine in COVID-19 has come from in vitro studies or small clinical trials. On 5 June
column2: however
column3: researchers with a large randomized UK trial
column4: called RECOVERY
column5: announced that their data on more than 4

column7: and they were stopping that arm of the trial. And a randomized
column8: controlled study in 820 people reported on 3 June that the drug was not effective in preventing infection among people who were at high risk of infection following exposure to someone with COVID-193. In contrast to the retracted Lancet paper

column1: It is not uncommon for studies that use large data sets to be published without external scrutiny of the raw data

column4: he says
column5: it appears that extra-careful review was skipped. “It’s a rush right now
column6: ” he says. “We are desperate for knowledge
column7: and maybe we’re skipping over some of our tried-and-true checks.”

column1: Both The Lancet and the NEJM said their peer review processes were confidential
column2: and that they could not give details about how quickly the papers were reviewed. “The article had external peer review and statistical review
column3: as well as scientific and manuscript editing. However
column4: as we would do with any incident of this type

column1: Surgisphere’s ivermectin preprint may have a longer life. The Peruvian government included the drug in its national treatment guidelines a few days after a white paper cited the SSRN preprint

column1: 2020-06-05|"I awake Saturday morning. Awaiting me is a team text from Shana about IG. I lie there

You can imagine how selfish this feels.

column1: I move to the living room for my morning yoga. I watch the line of the cars on the highway. I know in my gut these cars are coming to Center City to attend the protest I am going to skip. I begin to think about my response. I watch as the city’s police force
column2: in their cars with their bicycles attached

column1: Of course my fears — because that’s what they are
column2: anxiety running amok in the midst of America’s Crisis of Violence in the midst of a Global Pandemic — are not about The Protest. And my reasons for staying home are not about not wanting to protest.

column1: My fears? Are of a police system on steroids.

The militarization of American police departments — if you remember that exploration in 2014 after the riots in Ferguson — is one of the greatest fears I live with. It has only become amplified since I have given birth and reluctantly returned with my daughter to a country that has taken the bodies of Trayvon Martin
column2: Tamir Rice
column3: Sandra Bland
column4: Michael Brown
column5: Alton Sterling
column6: Eric Garner
column7: Freddie Gray
column8: Philando Castile
column9: Atatiana Jefferson
column10: Breonna Taylor
column11: George Floyd and many more.

column1: I have no fear of a protest or protestors or even of rioters or looters. I have no fear of my fellow citizens (except maybe some of the gun-toting ones). I can get myself in and out of a dangerous situation — all the more easier when my daughter was in the seat on my bicycle than if
column2: like now
column3: she’d have to be on her own
column4: us unconnected. It is an inappropriate police response that paralyzes me
column5: imprisons me in my own home — and in my head.

column1: A
column2: K and I check in over text. K expresses her desire to head to the protest. I express my guilt over my lack of will. I feel ashamed of my response — or lack of response.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the stream of police cars with the bicycles attached (that I associate with peaceful protests) morph throughout the day into a traumatizing montage of invisible — but not silent — unrest — in a very disturbing way.

column1: I try to go about my day — Monday is looming and the housework and home admin must get done. But what does Monday even mean right now? What does work even look like on Monday? I sit at my desk to start the grocery order. I move to the kitchen to cook. I start moving plants to the balcony that have been waiting to be planted for months. I lay out a “magic screen” to hang on the balcony door. I tell Goose to get ready because we are going outside soon. I do all of this over and over and over again
column2: in circles
column3: unable to quiet the monologue in my head. Mid-afternoon
column4: I see there is no traffic on the highway — 676
column5: aka the Vine Expressway — which runs through the city. This is not a good sign.

column1: The expressway is eye-level with our apartment.
We look. The police have blocked the highway. And then it begins. The activity that will continue throughout the weekend — that continues until now. Caravans of police — police vans
column2: paddy wagons
column3: state trooper SUVs — with their sirens back and forth across the expressway. Helicopters above us. The police car that is blocking the off-ramp angled just so
column4: so that it is facing us. It is clear we are not going to go outside today
column5: that I am not going to prove to myself that I am not afraid. I anxiously check my phone for news updates. Last time I had looked
column6: the scheduled protests of the day had been peaceful; the first even socially distant. It is time to pot the plants.

column1: We go to the balcony. In front of the police
column2: with helicopters whirring above us
column3: my stomach churning
column4: Goose starts planting the herb garden my mother sent her for Easter; I am propagating plants.

column1: How can I sit here potting plants? I am a coward.
I am planting new life
column2: new life in honor of George Floyd. I feel calm for 30 seconds…or the length of that thought.

column1: I am — if that officer is white
column2: if that officer is prejudiced — defying a stereotype. I am planting plants with my daughter on a “nice” Saturday afternoon.

column1: It is a good thing we did not go on the roof of the parking lot to jump rope. Are those police helicopters or news choppers? What if we had gone to the roof
column2: and they mistook our jumping rope for aggressive behavior or got confused and thought we had weapons?

column1: You are being a good parent for staying home. You could have gone to the City Hall protest and things would have been fine
column2: and you would be continuing to model for your daughter social justice
column3: like you used to. You would be doing what countless others are doing
column4: and risking your life
column5: because at this point
column6: for us
column7: it’s eithe"|1

column1: 2020-06-05|"DIRE HEADLINES had already been prepared before the release of America’s May jobs report on June 5th. Most analysts expected payroll employment to have fallen last month by several million
column2: on the heels of record declines in March and April
column3: and the unemployment rate to have jumped to nearly 20%. Instead
column4: the Bureau of Labour Statistics reported a sharp increase in employment
column5: of 2.5m
column6: and a drop in the jobless rate from 14.7%
column7: a post-Depression record
column8: to 13.3%. Although the American labour market remains deeply troubled
column9: President Donald Trump nonetheless convened a hastily called press conference to hail the news and declare the country back on the road to better days. “This is better than a V[-shaped recovery]
column10: ” he said. “This is a rocket ship!”

column1: Those bleak expectations had been set by a flow of dreadful economic news. Americans continue to file new claims for unemployment benefits by the million. Indices of economic activity showed that production kept declining across the economy in May
column2: although at a far slower pace than in April. Yet some high-frequency indicators—such as restaurant bookings and measures of personal travel—had indicated signs of revival. And investors have been bullish for weeks
column3: pushing stock indices close to new highs. They greeted the jobs data by sending the S&P 500 up by 2.6%.

column1: But the details of the report
column2: though encouraging
column3: do not suggest that a rapid return to normality is imminent. New hiring was concentrated in service industries
column4: primarily in health
column5: leisure and hospitality. But the number of new jobs in May amounted to just a fraction of the total lost since February; the leisure industry added about 1.2m last month
column6: but shed more than 8m in March and April. Part of the rebound in hiring can probably be explained by the structure of a federal aid programme intended to support small and medium businesses
column7: which provides emergency loans that will ultimately be forgiven if lay-offs are avoided. Some of it
column8: too
column9: can be explained by initial steps towards reopening
column10: as firms that were temporarily shut restarted work at dramatically reduced capacity. But although the number of Americans on temporary furlough declined
column11: permanent lay-offs rose by nearly 300
column13: taking the total to 2.3m. Disconcertingly
column14: given the protests against police violence wracking the country
column15: the jobless rate for black Americans ticked upwards
column17: while that for whites fell.

column1: Labour-market data are very likely to keep improving over the summer
column2: as state and local governments continue to ease lockdowns. The critical question for the American economy
column3: however
column4: is how many job losses and firm closures will prove permanent. Joblessness will probably remain well above normal levels
column5: and policy support for the unemployed will continue to be justified. There are signs
column6: however
column7: that this surprising gust of good news may be undercutting interest in more spending in Washington. Meanwhile
column8: the risk of new economic disruption
column9: by covid-19 or by civil unrest
column10: remains. The jobs figures were indeed a pleasant surprise. But it will be months
column11: or years
column12: until American workers can exhale without fear."|1

column1: 2020-06-05|"In late May
column2: CanSino Biologics published the first data for its COVID-19 vaccine expressing spike protein. The vaccine generated neutralizing antibodies in many recipients and appeared safe
column3: but the company
column4: like others in this space
column5: remains on alert for a dangerous phenomenon known as antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE). “It’s important to talk about it [ADE]
column6: ” says Gregory Glenn
column7: president of R&D at Novavax
column8: which launched its COVID-19 vaccine trial in May. But “we can’t be overly cautious. People are dying. So we need to be aggressive here.”

column1: There are mounting theoretical concerns that vaccines generating antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 may bind to the virus without neutralizing it. Should this happen
column2: the non-neutralizing antibodies could enhance viral entry into cells and viral replication and end up worsening infection instead of offering protection
column3: through the poorly understood phenomenon of ADE. ADE “is a genuine concern
column4: ” says virologist Kevin Gilligan
column5: a senior consultant with Biologics Consulting
column6: who advises thorough safety studies. “Because if the gun is jumped
column7: and a vaccine is widely distributed that is disease enhancing
column8: that would be worse than actually not doing any vaccination at all.”

column1: The degree of ADE vaccine risk for SARS-CoV-2 is unknown.
“Most experts who look at it acknowledge the potential risk but don’t see compelling evidence for it in humans right now
column2: ” says James Crowe
column3: director of the Vanderbilt Vaccine Center. Some view coronavirus ADE as a laboratory phenomenon
column4: at least so far. “The theoretical possibility [of ADE] is there
column5: ” says Rafi Ahmed
column6: director of the Emory Vaccine Center. “The more difficult question becomes
column7: how do you balance this concern with moving forward? There’s not an easy answer.”

column1: ADE was first described in 1977 by virologist Scott Halstead
column2: then at the University of Hawaii. Halstead studied dengue
column3: caused by four related but antigenically distinct viruses known as ‘serotypes’. Halstead noted that animals previously infected with one serotype did worse if infected again with a different serotype than if never previously infected at all. He found antibodies to be responsible for this phenomenon. Instead of neutralizing the virus
column4: the antibodies facilitated viral entry into host cells in vitro. In his publication
column5: Halstead presciently wrote: “Non-neutralising antibody presumably provides a specific molecular ‘ride’ for an infectious dengue virion into the interior of a receptive phagocytic cell.”

column1: Halstead’s speculation was later proven correct
column2: not just for dengue
column3: a flavivirus
column4: but for other viruses
column5: including coronaviruses
column6: in cell culture experiments. The coronavirus uses its spike protein to bind host receptors and infect airway cells. But it also can infect immune cells
column7: typically macrophages. Anti-spike antibodies ideally bind and neutralize the virus
column8: either by blocking spike binding to its receptor or by preventing fusion of the virus with the cell. But if antibodies fail to do this because they bind unproductively to the virus
column9: these non-neutralizing antibodies may instead
column10: using the Fc region at the base of the antibody
column11: latch onto host macrophage Fc receptors and ferry the virus into these host cells
column12: at least in vitro. Once inside
column13: the viruses replicate and then exit to further spread infection to neighboring cells and tissues.

column1: Poor-quality antibodies that bind the virus without neutralizing it are one reason vaccine candidates fail
column2: and
column3: in theory
column4: could also cause ADE
column5: delivering virions to host cells.

column1: Can SARS-CoV-2 infect macrophages? “I don’t know
column2: ” answers Stan Perlman
column3: a coronavirus expert at the University of Iowa. “Those data are not out there yet.” The virus can infect macrophages in vitro
column4: but that doesn’t necessarily translate to in vivo human biology. “In tissue culture cells you can make almost any virus show this
column5: by jigging the right cells
column6: the right amount of antibody
column7: and the right virus. But that [is] not really meaningful
column8: because of the fact that it’s so artificial.”

column1: The risk that a COVID-19 vaccine will cause ADE and facilitate infection “is completely theoretical
column2: ” says Novavax’s Glenn. “It’s a lab
column3: an animal phenomenon that’s been observed. [But] in RSV it’s a real clinical event.” In a 1960s vaccine trial
column4: 80% of infants and young children immunized against RSV (respiratory syncytial virus
column5: an RNA virus in the family Paramyxoviridae) ended up hospitalized
column6: and 2 children died. Only 5% of the children in the control group required hospitalization. Vaccinated children carried high titers of non-neutralizing antibodies
column7: implicating ADE in the tragic outcome
column8: although a T 2 (inflammatory) T cell response also probably contributed.

column1: Since then
column2: some vaccine studies in animals
column3: as well as human trials where vaccinated people had worse outcomes
column4: suggest ADE at work. But definitive evidence is lacking. “We can’t say they were not due to ADE
column5: but there’s not evidence that they were
column6: ” says Ahmed. “There are many other ways that an immune response can cause damage.”

column1: For coronavirus vaccines
column2: the ADE story is similarly inconclusive. Cats vaccinated with spike protein against feline coronavirus died much faster than unvaccinated cats and carried more anti-spike antibodies
column3: implicating ADE. But macaques vaccinated against SARS-CoV-1 did not show enhanced infection or disease.

column1: In humans
column2: limited data for vaccines against earlier coronaviruses did not show ADE. Two vaccines against the closely related SARS-CoV-1 appeared safe in early trials. A DNA vaccine against the MERS coronavirus in macaques protected all eight monkeys from infection symptoms
column3: and that MERS vaccine was well-tolerated in a 2016 phase 1 human trial. MERS vaccine co-developer David Weiner
column4: director of the Vaccine & Immunotherapy Center at the Wistar Institute
column5: co-developed a very similar COVID-19 vaccine that Inovio Pharmaceuticals took into human trials in early April.

column1: “We don’t see it [ADE] with flu
column2: we don’t see it with so many other vaccines that we have
column3: ” says Ahmed. “We shouldn’t dismiss it completely
column4: but then if you look at the broader world of vaccinology
column5: this has not been seen.” But Gilligan says some earlier SARS and MERS vaccine candidates didn’t advance because of signs of ADE.

column1: ADE is a concern for monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) too
column2: at least in theory
column3: because mAbs that fail to neutralize the virus also could facilitate viral entry into cells. Many companies are working on such mAbs for either COVID-19 prevention or therapy. AstraZeneca
column4: for example
column5: is partnering with Vanderbilt
column6: which has identified
column7: expressed and evaluated virus-neutralizing antibodies from B cells recovered from convalescents. AstraZeneca will take the best ones forward into clinical trials.

column1: ADE is part of the mAb discussion. “There’s not a lot of obvious epidemiologic evidence for it yet
column2: ” says Vanderbilt’s Crowe. Nevertheless
column3: he says
column4: “we will address this.” Crowe’s group will test for ADE by seeing whether its monoclonal antibodies can deliver viruses into macrophages
column5: compared with antibodies whose Fc region has been inactivated. (An antibody lacking Fc can’t bind macrophage Fc receptors and thus can’t cause ADE. That’s why some companies are advancing mAbs with the Fc region knocked out.) Still
column6: “the animal models are so inadequate right now
column7: it would be very difficult to prove whether [ADE] is common or uncommon
column8: ” Crowe says.

column1: For mAbs
column2: the risk is probably low. “You’re already characterizing it as a highly neutralizing antibody
column3: ” says Ahmed. Convalescent antibody passive immunization trials
column4: now underway
column5: could carry some ADE risk
column6: Ahmed says. “[But] I would be less concerned with that than with the vaccine that might be inducing suboptimal response.”

column1: Vaccine companies are fully aware of ADE. “All the groups have been discussing this
column2: everyone’s on the same page
column3: everyone wants a safe [COVID-19] vaccine
column4: ” says Weiner. Inovio went forward into the clinic after showing safety in primates
column5: and is reassured by the strong human safety record of its MERS vaccine. But vaccine trials are being approved “without the usual amount of preclinical safety/tox data available for guidance
column6: ” says Gilligan.

column1: Given the urgency
column2: the US Food and Drug Administration and European Medicines Agency may have little choice but to give the go ahead to enter the clinic. Novavax launched a phase 1/2 trial of its vaccine
column3: a stable prefusion SARS-CoV-2 spike protein trimer nanoparticle vaccine with a saponin-based adjuvant
column4: in late May. The company is experienced with viral vaccines: its nanoparticle flu vaccine recently met its phase 3 endpoints. The SARS-CoV-2 virus “is not new territory
column5: ” Glenn says
column6: adding that Novavax and other vaccine companies can assay for whether antibodies can block spike protein–receptor binding
column7: or neutralize the virus
column8: or both
column9: which should prevent infection.

column1: And ADE? “One has to address it
column2: ” Glenn says
column3: but he points out that ADE is only a theoretical COVID-19 vaccine risk. “It’s hypothesized from animal studies
column4: ” he says. “I think the way forward is to take it seriously
column5: do some animal studies
column6: show you don’t have enhancement
column7: monitor during the trial. My view is
column8: we can’t let this issue keep us from getting to a vaccine that will save millions of lives.”

column1: But Anne De Groot
column2: CEO of EpiVax
column3: argues for a more nuanced approach. EpiVax develops T-cell-directed vaccines
column4: using computational tools to select viral T cell epitopes. The company found SARS-CoV-2 sequences that would appear human to T cell receptors.

column1: This could be a problem for any vaccine. “The T cells either don’t respond as strongly
column2: because they think that the [coronavirus] spike is human
column3: or that sequence can trigger a regulatory T cell response
column4: ” says De Groot. Such T cells can interfere with beneficial antibody production and “you don’t get neutralizing antibodies
column5: you get the kind of antibodies that actually potentially enhance infection.” In other words
column6: ADE.

2020-06-06|"The late management guru Peter Drucker who presciently advocated “back room” outsourcing and corporate decentralisation at a time when these smart cost-saving techniques were anathema to produce-everything-hire-everyone mega corporations
column2: had a few more tricks up his sleeve.

column1: One of his key mantras – price-led costing – often overlooked even today yet something profoundly relevant to all businesses
column2: especially those connected with travel
column3: is worth re-examining in a dysfunctional Covid-19 world.

column1: The central argument is simple. Most companies tend to create a product they feel the market wants and outspend each other to produce it
column2: subsequently passing on the entire cost to consumers with a further profit slab packed with humungous CEO salaries on top of all this extravagance. This is cost-driven pricing and is typical of the sort of big ego branding popular today.

column1: Druker’s answer to this was blindingly simple. Check the price your audience might be willing to pay for a product and then keep production costs and profit margins within this budget. This is price-led costing. It is as relevant for airline seats as for luxury hotels.
Of course price-led costing (for any desirable good) is entirely predicated on scarcity
column2: which drives price. One of the problems monster brands like Louis Vuitton faced in Asia was the sort of over exposure that instantly drove down perceived value often with perverse results. At one point Hongkongers shunned LV-monogrammed travel bags due to their mass popularity with Macau casino bumpkins.

column1: As airlines posit scenarios in a Covid-19 or post-virus world it seems an inescapable truth that passengers will need to be distanced and isolated somehow to allay fears of contagion. With previous models entirely based on the sardine concept of spacing
column2: packing in seats
column3: and eliminating window exits to cram in more bodies
column4: this is jarringly revolutionary.

column1: Aircraft design will move towards more protected personal space with wraparound headrest partitions
column2: novel seating configurations and
column3: perhaps
column4: access to cargo areas reconverted into gyms or wellness escapes. Family cabins may arrive in economy
column5: modelled after the innovative Qsuites on Qatar Airways that can turn into quads for foursomes.

column1: Fewer seats will invariably mean higher ticket prices. Will air passengers accept this additional burden on groaning wallets? Or might they consider it a worthwhile investment in emotional security or a sought after ‘luxury’ perk? In other words might travel once again become something expensive
column2: rare
column3: and unattainable
column4: thereby bestowing upon it the original cachet of a romantic treat as in the days of the magnificent Pan Am Clipper flying boats?

column1: Travellers will increasingly see luxury hotels as safe havens with trustworthy corporate protocols unlike the unregulated bottom-feeder Airbnb offerings
column2: now fraught with unknown dangers. Private villa escapes will come to epitomise less is more
column3: a phrase hitherto spouted by many but believed by few. Huge cookie-cutter fairy-lights hotels will not disappear as there is always space for mid-range products but
column4: in a Covid world
column5: there can be no scrimping on safety and this in turn will push prices up factoring in guest spacing
column6: staff training
column7: enhanced hygiene
column8: lavish wellness partnerships and thermal-scanning equipment.

column1: But regardless of whether price inches up or down
column2: business models must be thoroughly reviewed and reset. Dropping oil prices (though this may be short term) and the Covid reality offer a huge opportunity for a travel rethink. It is time to abandon the sloppy cost-led pricing that has dominated monster travel projects
column3: based on the assumption of ever-increasing hordes of cash-rich Chinese consumers. That is now a mirage as travel for the near term turns inward with a focus on domestic transactions and ‘safe corridors’ (pairing cities or countries) whether in China
column4: USA
column5: India
column6: Thailand
column7: or Indonesia.

column1: Price-led costing will be the key
column2: whether aiming for the luxury traveller or the less financially frivolous. It is a sound argument for any time and a good one to take onboard as globalism goes through a major adjustment in the face of mounting ultranationalist sentiment – with some manufacturing and business travel returning home over time.

column1: Travellers willing to spend for a romantic break from the quotidian grind will make very careful choices and demand a lot more value. They will be in the driver’s seat now. Luxury travellers will not simply swarm marbled lobbies demanding free Bellinis. They will get tough.
Travellers looking for value will be equally demanding. Gone are the days when a guesthouse could say
column2: ‘You get what you pay for.’ Safety cuts both ways. Hotels and airlines will need protocols to ensure their clientele is potentially okay just as travellers will examine holiday escapes in minute detail
column3: perhaps preferring less trampled out-of-the-way places like the Maldives where privacy is ensured and social contact minimised.

column1: Business travellers cautiously venturing out may be the hardest hit as this is the segment where the travel sector will try and make up for the loss. It would do well to remember though that with work-from-home and video conferencing much the rage
column2: there is no inelastic demand anymore. Too much of a fare hike will dull corporate enthusiasm. Travel is already a significant cost for companies and medical-travel-labour insurance premiums will soar in a Covid world.

column1: For a start
column2: travel will stay close to home (and close to medical fallbacks) and we will become like kids learning to walk
column3: picking up the courage to foray farther each day. But like that infernal coronavirus
column4: travel is in the blood. We’ll find out which wins out. In the meanwhile
column5: the travel industry can restore itself by stepping away from the mirage and incorporating sound pricing practices.

column1: Vijay Verghese is a Hongkong-based journalist and columnist and the Editor of SmartTravelAsia.com and AsianConversations.com."|1

column2: the Government fast-tracked new legislation to introduce further tax changes in response to the impacts of the Covid-19 outbreak.

column1: The key tax component of the Covid-19 Response (Taxation and Other Regulatory Urgent Matters) Act 2020 is a temporary tax loss carry-back measure.
Broadly
column2: this allows businesses that anticipate being in a loss for the 2020 or 2021 tax years
column3: to carry some or all of the loss back to the preceding year to enable an immediate cash refund of prior tax paid.

column1: READ MORE:
* Top tips for small businesses looking at implementing an e-commerce solution
* Small business owners hungry for advice and information as they recover from Covid-19
* Answers to common questions about the Covid-19 wage subsidy scheme
* Your questions on handling provisional tax now that Covid-19 has hit your cashflow
To be eligible
column2: a taxpayer must have made or anticipate they will make a loss in either of the 2020 or 2021 tax years. The taxpayer must have a profit in the year prior to the loss year. This means:

column1: * Losses from the 2020 year may be carried back to the 2019 year
* Losses from the 2021 year may be carried back to the 2020 year
Taxpayers can claim a tax refund for provisional tax paid by re-estimating 2020 provisional tax where the 2020 return is not yet filed
column2: or by amending their 2019 tax return to factor in the loss carry back. The rules will apply to companies
column3: trusts and individuals (other than those deriving only PAYE income) and those that operate through partnerships and look-through companies.

column1: Overall
column2: this is a very positive initiative
column3: and one the Government should be commended for. However
column4: because of its rushed implementation
column5: it’s not perfect
column6: not necessarily as straightforward as it seems and will not suit all businesses.

column1: Each business will have different circumstances and each will need to consider whether this mechanism is the right option for them. Inland Revenue’s systems went live in early May with the changes so taxpayers can make elections to carry-back losses via the 'I want to' section of MyIR.
A few considerations and scenarios to reflect on are outlined below

Most business will be looking to use this mechanism in relation to a loss incurred in the 2021 year and carry this back to the 2020 income year which may still be profitable given Covid-19 may have only affected the last quarter of this year.
A business that needs cash urgently will want to elect to carry back its anticipated loss as soon as possible; however
column2: a business will need to be fairly confident of the level of loss and think carefully about how the rest of the year will play out.

column1: This is because
column2: if a business over-estimates its 2021 loss which results in tax payable
column3: use of money interest (UOMI) will apply from August 28
column4: 2019 (for a March balance date taxpayer)
column5: which is the first instalment date of 2020 provisional tax. Further
column6: it will not be possible to apply for relief from UOMI imposed under the remission rules recently enacted.

column1: To minimise potential exposure to UOMI
column2: the business might want to take a conservative position initially given we are only into the third month of the new tax year and re-estimate the loss later or as the year progresses.

column1: However
column2: holding off may not provide the much-needed cash now which could force some businesses to take some risks in this regard. Timing of electing
column3: filing the return and monitoring losses will be key.

column1: It will be possible to re-estimate the 2021 loss to carry back at any time prior to the earlier of the date the 2020 return is filed or the due date for filing.
The rules require the immediately preceding year to have taxable income. There will be some companies where the pattern of income and losses is such that the carry-back mechanism won’t be much
column2: or any benefit.

column1: For example
column2: taxable income in the 2019 year might have been high under normal trading conditions and so 2020 provisional tax paid to date is based on residual income tax for this year.

column1: Taxable income in the 2020 year (particularly if it is a late balance date) might have dropped
column2: but may have only dropped to a lower taxable income and so it not yet a loss.

column1: Even if there are large losses anticipated in 2021
column2: these will only be able to be carried back to the extent of the lower taxable income in the immediately preceding year
column3: which may not release that much tax paid.

column1: Likewise
column2: a company with a small loss in 2020 and a larger loss in 2021 will be constrained to only being able to use the smaller loss in 2020 to amend only the 2019 tax return
column3: such that the company is unable to carry back the larger loss incurred in 2021.

column1: Refunds might be limited or trapped
For taxpayers that are companies
column2: any refunds will be limited to the credit balance in its company imputation credit account at the date of the most recently ended tax year (ie March 31
column4: although some timing exceptions apply).

column1: Therefore
column2: if a company has been in the habit of paying most of its profits as dividends to shareholders and attaching imputation credits
column3: it may find access to cash refunds is limited.

column1: The policy rationale for this rule is that the company’s tax has been paid to shareholders already via imputation credits. Any trapped refunds may be applied to income or provisional tax liabilities
column2: if any will exist.

column1: If the company has traditionally paid out its profits for the year as shareholder salaries
column2: the company won’t have any taxable income to carry future losses back to. The shareholders and not the company in this case have paid the provisional tax.

column1: Therefore
column2: an option might be for the shareholders to estimate 2020 provisional tax to nil and have the company elect to not pay any shareholder salaries for the 2020 tax year if losses are forecast for 2021 if this is possible.

column1: However
column2: this could then expose the company to an FBT liability if there are outstanding current accounts
column3: so care is required. Other options may be feasible in this scenario.

column1: The important point to note is that companies will need to do some work and determine what the approach to paying shareholder salaries should be in light of these rules.
The new Act contains an anti-avoidance measure
column2: which could apply if shares in any company have been subject to an arrangement so that a loss company falls into the rules if the purpose of the arrangement is to defeat the intention of the rules.

column1: It is possible any cute “tax planning” of this nature to deliberately take advantage of the rules would be scrutinised down the track.
We acknowledge the Government has brought these rules in under urgency to provide assistance for businesses in need of cash flow.
It has endeavoured to strike a balance of giving the much-needed assistance
column2: accommodating the need for part year and grouping rules
column3: while still maintaining some integrity measures. Unfortunately doing all these things inevitably leads to complex legislation.

column1: The decision to use this mechanism will be heavily fact dependent on each business’s circumstances. There are policy design features that mean the rules will not be that useful to some of the SME businesses targeted.
It is clear it will not be the panacea for every business and could in some cases expose a taxpayer to significant UOMI or other taxes unless care is taken.
Robyn Walker is a tax partner and Veronica Harley is an associate director at Deloitte"|2

2020-06-06|"We are all Keynesians now with governments around the world shovelling cash into their economies to try to at least partially offset the economic damage of lockdowns. Even uber-prudent Germany has engaged in an extraordinary spending spree
column2: first to support businesses during the closure period and then this week announcing big VAT cuts
column3: a €300 family bonus for every child and another round of business supports.

column1: Ireland’s Achilles’ heel in the past is that the government has spent when we had the money and then been forced to cut back in times of recession. Boom and bust cycles resulted. This time around
column2: having entered the pandemic in reasonable economic shape and with the budget in surplus
column3: we have some leeway. Ireland is engaged in a big fiscal stimulus
column4: with government spending in the first five months of the year up by more than 20 per cent . Fortunately the State can still borrow money at negligible interest rates to fund the deficit that is opening up
column5: thanks in part to unprecedented intervention from the European Central Bank.

column1: So can the next government float into office on a wave of borrowed cash which it can dispense? Not really. A careful reading of the recent report from the budget watchdog
column2: the Irish Fiscal Advisory Council
column3: shows that each stage of the crisis will bring its own challenges – and that we simply can’t budget on the basis of being able to borrow at current interest rates forever. We are walking a shaky financial tightrope as we move through this.

column1: The hard calls start on day one for the next government. Yes
column2: ministers will have the cheque book out – but the queue at the hatch will be long and not everyone will get paid. You could argue about just how high the deficit could be this year – and the answer might well end up north of 10 per cent of gross domestic product – but there is a limit.

column1: As well as the contentious issue of the phasing-out of wage and income supports
column2: there are calls from business for more cash
column3: a line-up of State bodies with big financial holes and so on. There is a strong case to go the extra mile on the once-off supports – and Minister for Finance Paschal Donohoe hinted on Friday that more help to protect businesses and jobs would likely be needed. But deciding what will be subsidised through the crisis and what won’t will be hugely controversial.

column1: And as well as once-off costs
column2: the need to provide ongoing higher levels of spending – in health
column3: childcare
column4: education
column5: public transport and so on – provides a big budgetary challenge. Donohoe referred this week to the likely need to continue borrowing in the years ahead to fund higher spending levels.

column1: The programme for government
column2: if agreed
column3: and the subsequent national recovery programme may give some context to this and to how the public finances might evolve. Right now we need it . The “A” word is being thrown around in relation to every proposed reduction of an emergency support programme
column4: and every refusal to throw additional cash at some other problem.

column1: What we are facing is not austerity – which is when a government hikes taxes and cuts spending to reduce the budget deficit during a recession. That is what happened in 2009 and 2010. Now government borrowing is soaring. The issue is making decisions on where the money goes to and how much we can spend – all against a backdrop of huge uncertainty. Pretending there is some endless supply of cash and no constraint at all on borrowing into the future is just not credible.
Choices will also await in what the IFAC called phase two
column2: which is when the Government goes to stimulate the economy via higher spending
column3: probably moving into 2021 if the opening-up goes okay. The council pencilled in €10 billion as a possible stimulus
column4: though said it should be “temporary and targeted”. Again
column5: you can just imagine the queue of mendicants for this . The money will only go so far and only last so long – and continued restrictions in areas like tourism might leave some sectors unable to benefit .

column1: The council’s central expectation is that the economy might return to its pre-Covid position in a couple of years. That would be a result. With the economy growing
column2: there would then be a job in adjusting tax and spending over a period of years to get the public finances back on a sustainable path. The council guesstimated that this might involve tax hikes and spending cuts of €6 billion to €14 billion
column3: probably starting in 2023. But it should be possible to avoid another bout of severe austerity.

column1: New government programmes

column1: We are facing into unprecedented uncertainty – we really don’t have any basis to decide how the next few months will go. The IFAC analysis shows just how delicate the outlook is and how a worse health outcome could cause real challenges
