2020-06-06|"Individual COVID-19 fatality risk (and the consequences for universities)

Reopening universities for the autumn term will be risky for individuals' health and safety. This column describes the latest epidemiological evidence and argues that the biggest influence on individuals’ risk of severe illness is age. Individuals in their sixties face a 30 times higher fatality risk from COVID-19 than individuals in their thirties. Being obese
column2: non-white
column3: a man
column4: and having an underlying health condition also matter – each roughly doubles the fatality risk. But chronological age still remains the biggest risk – a fact that universities should keep in mind when planning their autumnal schedules.

column1: Many European universities plan to re-open as physical spaces in the autumn of 2020. How much danger will that create? What is an individual’s risk of severe illness and death? How should university leaders take the health of their staff into account when planning for the next academic year (the economic issues were discussed recently in a VoxEU article by Peter Dolton)?
In our judgement
column2: the most reliable source of information on the risk from COVID-19 is a 2020 “Open Safely” paper written by Elizabeth Williamson of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine
column3: with a large number of colleagues. It is a piece of technical epidemiological writing. We make an attempt to convey that paper’s substance in a way that we hope might be helpful to those enrolled and working in universities and the senior management teams who head them.

column1: The first point to make is that the biggest influence on a person’s COVID-19 risk is age. The risk from age is actually an extraordinarily accelerating one (log-linear
column2: as an approximation). There have been grumpy and inaccurate discussions of this issue of age and risk in UK newspapers where lobby groups attacked the idea that chronological age is what matters. Instead
column3: the risk associated with so-called health conditions
column4: with being a man
column5: obese
column6: non-white
column7: or with having diabetes has been emphasized by the media.

column1: Further
column2: our two papers recommending a release out of the lockdown of the young have led to many older people reaching out to us voicing their beliefs that because they feel fit
column3: they face little or no risk from COVID-19. Unfortunately
column4: that belief is incorrect. Age is the crucial risk to bear in mind as shown by Williamson et al. (2020) (see Figure 1).

column1: Figure 1 Deaths from COVID-19 in England and Wales since January 2020
Note: Number of deaths registered in England and Wales where COVID-19 was mentioned in the certificate – up to 15/05/2020
Examining anonymized health records of 17 million UK citizens
column2: the authors assess who has died from COVID-19 while statistically adjusting for a large number of influences on people’s risk. Standard regression equations are then used to calculates hazard ratios. The results are the following:

column1: • People between 50-60 face a fatality risk from COVID-19 that is approximately 14 times higher than the risk faced by those around the middle of the age band of 18-40.
• For individuals between 60-70 who are in good health
column2: the risk is 30 times higher.

column1: • The fatality risk of men is double that of women.
• Individuals with middle-aged spread
column2: holding other things constant
column3: face an about 50% higher risk.

column1: • The same holds for non-white individuals as they face an almost doubled risk.
• Most standard kinds of health conditions also increase fatality risk
column2: roughly 2 to 3 times
column3: in general. The risk of individuals diagnosed with cancer is higher than the risk of men in general
column4: but it is still lower than the risk of simply being old.

column1: Hence
column2: the most prominent risk indeed stems simply from age. In essence
column3: this is due to young ‘animals’ stronger immune-response to most viruses also applying to COVID-19.

column1: Some newspapers have confusingly run headlines proclaiming obesity as a major cause of COVID-19 deaths. However
column2: while keeping ones BMI below 25 is certainly advisable and obese people undoubtedly face a higher risk of dying from COVID-19
column3: the main reason why obese people are dying much more is because obese people tend to be older.

column1: A second worrisome concern is the likelihood of misleading triumphalism in Europe over the coming summer. Premature optimism had lulled people already during the so-called Spanish Flu in the years of 1918-1919. Figure 2
column2: taken from Taubenberger and Morens (2006)
column3: depicts the three waves of deaths from the Spanish Flu. The first wave
column4: which at the time seemed very large
column5: peaked in early summer of 1918. When it died down
column6: policymakers took a more relaxed approach as they believed it to be over. Unfortunately
column7: a second wave appeared in autumn of 1918 and the number of deaths this time was five times higher. A third wave followed in the Spring of 1919 but most deaths occurred in late autumn and winter just after the pandemic was believed to be over.

column1: Figure 2 Deaths in the UK from the Spanish Flu 1918-1919

University presidents should keep this in mind when planning universities’ autumnal schedules. Our hunch is that misleading optimism about having beaten COVID-19 may appear by the end of the summer and lead to calls to open up UK universities in a really fundamental way. While it may be true that COVID-19 will really be over by then
column2: it is also worryingly possible that we are in for some form of a re-run of 1918. As early hotspots for COVID-19 were places like meat packing plants and skiing resorts
column3: which are both characterized by low temperatures
column4: it is possible that the coronavirus microbe may prefer cold environments. Studying the Spanish Flu virus
column5: He et al. (2013) conclude that every extra 10 degrees Celsius reduced the spread of this virus by nearly 50%. Of course
column6: COVID-19 is a different virus which might behave differently and much is still to be learned about COVID-19.

column1: A third concern is that the virus might mutate. However
column2: there is not much that can be done about that except to hope for the best.

column1: What should university faculty know and do?
First
column2: faculty members might want to appreciate the fact that most students are young and hence face a rather miniscule risk - current estimates suggest that it may be about the same as the risk of dying in a UK road accident in a normal year. Second
column3: university staff older than 50 may need to consider their own relative risk
column4: and might prefer to avoid front-line contact with students until a vaccine is found. Third and more encouraging
column5: current evidence suggests that even without a vaccine the great majority of Europe’s population will live through the pandemic without serious illness. Absolute risk for most people appears to be fairly low
column6: and there even remains a slight chance that the virus will disappear more quickly than standard epidemiological modelling has predicted.

column1: Still
column2: there is a long and menacing path ahead of us for the coming autumn and winter
column3: where it pays for each individual to know about their own relative risk. For university presidents and their management teams
column4: it is essential to recognize that the COVID-19 virus is much more dangerous to older members of university staff. This time
column5: age matters.

column1: 2020-06-06|"The BCG vaccine does not protect against COVID-19: Applying an economist’s toolkit to a medical question

The prospect that BCG – a vaccine used primarily against tuberculosis – might offer protection from COVID-19 has become an understandably popular hypothesis. This column finds that hope misplaced. The authors exploit a natural experiment
column2: overlaying the large difference in BCG vaccination rates with the large differences in COVID-19 infection rates between the former East and West Germany. They find that the differences are attributable not to BCG
column3: but to the West’s copious commuter flow patterns and the fact that the epidemic arrived there first.

column1: As COVID-19 has spread across the globe
column2: so has an intense search for treatments and vaccines
column3: with numerous trials running in multiple countries. Several researchers (e.g. Hegarty et al. 2020
column4: Miller et al. 2020
column5: Ozdemir et al. 2020) and prominent news outlets have noticed that countries still administering an old vaccine against tuberculosis had fewer coronavirus cases and fewer deaths per capita in the outbreak’s early stages. But is that correlation evidence that the Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine provides some defence against COVID-19? In this column
column6: we describe the findings of our recent work (Bluhm and Pinkovskiy 2020) looking at the incidence of coronavirus cases along the former border between East and West Germany
column7: using modern econometric techniques to investigate whether historical differences in vaccination policies account for the lower level of infection in the East.

column1: Tuberculosis has been largely eradicated from the developed world

column1: 2020-06-06|"Valuating health vs wealth: The effect of information and how this matters for COVID-19 policymaking

column2: an understanding of how the public currently values lives over economic loss is needed. A survey experiment in the US and UK finds that people highly prioritise saving lives
column3: but this valuation will change as economic losses mount. Individual differences in valuation also predict individual compliance with COVID-19 policies

column5: through increasing compliance
column6: improve its economic efficacy.

column1: In the absence of medicine-based responses to COVID-19
column2: policymakers have to rely on behavioural interventions to control the transmission of the virus. Yet
column3: at least in the short run
column4: these interventions create a trade-off between saving lives and saving the economy – a ‘health–wealth trade-off’. The lockdown restrictions on individual freedoms
column5: for example
column6: saved lives by preventing transmission
column7: but they came at the cost of lost output and income (Baldwin and Weder di Mauro 2020).

column1: Relaxing a lockdown involves the same trade-off but in reverse: the economy recovers but at a cost of an increased threat of virus transmission. There are similar potential medium-term trade-offs in the choice between strategies of herd immunity and so-called ‘hammer and dance’ (Pueyo 2020). Faced with such health–wealth trade-offs
column2: how should policymakers decide where to locate the balance?

column1: This question has led policymakers to dust off risk-valuation manuals to see whether the proposed movement makes cost-benefit good sense. For instance
column2: the OECD (2012) suggests
column3: on the basis of evidence
column4: that a figure between $1.5–$4.5 million should be used as the statistical value of life
column5: with a base value of $3 million (the EU uses a slightly wider range and a higher base value of $3.6 million).

column1: Armed with such a figure
column2: consider the UK lockdown. The Imperial College modellers predicted that lockdown would save several hundred thousand lives (Ferguson et al. 2020)
column3: whilst current estimates point to a lockdown loss of more than 10% of GDP (Bank of England 2020); 10% of GDP is £221
column4: 489 million. Thus
column5: even if only one
column6: rather than several
column7: hundred thousand lives had been saved
column8: the lockdown would have cost about £2 million per life saved and would have produced a net benefit
column9: using the OECD’s base figure valuation of a life at $3 million. Beyond 100
column10: 000 lives saved
column11: the net benefit from lockdown quickly becomes enormous.

column1: Setting aside arguments against using cost-benefit analysis in such decisions
column2: there are two problems with recycling OECD (or other) estimates of the value of a statistical life. First
column3: the figures vary widely and – although the OECD proposes a range
column4: any part of which would probably make the lockdown yield a net benefit – they refer to the value of a statistical life. COVID-19
column5: however
column6: produces mortality disproportionately in the old and those with co-morbidities.

column1: So perhaps the alternative quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) approach – whereby quality-adjusted life-years saved are valued – should be used. With as much as 20% of those over 70 who die from COVID-19 being likely to die within one year anyway
column2: and a QALY value of between £20–30
column4: a positive net benefit from lockdown becomes much less likely.

column1: The second problem is deeper. The policy choices relate to COVID-19 deaths; not imaginary deaths in the past and not some medical intervention that might prolong life by one year. Thus
column2: what plausibly matters is how people currently value such deaths. This is for two reasons.

column1: First
column2: how people value health over wealth in this period obviously matters for the politics of these decisions. Politicians are re-elected by the people who assess government performance by their own lights; not by how well the government executed a manual’s implicit assessment.

column1: Second
column2: people’s current valuation may matter because there is evidence that people are more likely to follow rules when they agree with them (Tyler 1990). We don’t know whether this is the case for COVID-19 lockdown policies
column3: but if it is
column4: then the efficacy of any lockdown or its relaxation also depends on whether its movement on a health–wealth trade-off accords with the public’s relative valuation of health over wealth.

column1: Of course
column2: although these considerations are real
column3: they would not matter if we had reason to believe that people’s assessments in such matters were relatively constant (in that case
column4: the OECD’s summary might apply). Yet we don’t. In fact
column5: we know such assessments are extremely sensitive to exposure to the risk in question (e.g. Gigerenzer 2014) – think of the exodus from flying in the US post-9/11.

column1: So
column2: features specific to COVID-19 will influence people’s current COVID related health–wealth valuation. This is why we conducted a survey experiment in the UK and the US to see how people actually value health over wealth in the context of COVID-19 and the lockdown (Hargreaves Heap et al. 2020).

column1: The survey consists of a sequence of binary choices between pairs of health and wealth outcomes for each country. The sequence is designed so that anyone who values both ‘lives saved’ and ‘average household income’
column2: and has a preference ordering over their various combinations
column3: will switch at one point from the option that always does as well or better than the other on health
column4: to the option that does better on wealth. Where they switch is an indicator of their relative valuation of health over wealth and can be interpreted as giving the lower bound for the value of life.

column1: The experimental element comes from asking participants to make this sequence of choices a second time. After the first occasion
column2: the participants engage in another task and are then divided into three sub-groups. column1: The participants then make the decisions over health and wealth combinations again. column2: policymakers do need to care about what the people think in this matter

2020-06-07|"Many governments are slowly unwinding their economies from nationwide lockdowns. However
column2: re-opening the economy entails a serious trade-off between fostering economic output and keeping the spread of infection low. This column reports several re-opening scenarios for the UK economy
column3: documenting their projected impacts on both GDP and the spread of the virus. The results suggest that it is best to re-open upstream industries first
column4: as they provide a large direct and indirect economic boost at a relatively lower cost in terms of further epidemic spreading.

column1: The economic disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic are large and have affected some industries and occupations more than others (Koren and Peto 2020
column2: del Rio-Chanona et al. 2020). For example
column3: labour supply shocks strongly affected construction
column4: but were absent in sectors considered essential. Yet
column5: given the interconnected nature of the economy
column6: even the sectors shielded from the direct shocks eventually face adverse consequences. First-order shocks are amplified through production networks and the interaction of supply and demand (Inoue and Todo 2020
column7: Barrot et al. 2020
column8: Mandel and Veetil 2020
column9: Bonadio et al. 2020
column10: Baqaee and Farhi
column11: 2020). For instance
column12: in Norway
column13: within a month
column14: two thirds of the layoffs happened in businesses that were not directly hit by the shocks (Alstadsæter et al. 2020).

column1: Governments that are now seeking to re-open their economies cannot ignore these network interactions. To determine the relative economic boosts of different re-opening scenarios
column2: they need to consider the risks of an unbalanced re-opening that may worsen supply chain bottlenecks. Besides
column3: they must also consider that the risk of infection faced by workers varies across industries and search for an appropriate compromise between increasing economic output and controlling the epidemic spreading.

column1: In a recent paper (Pichler et al. 2020)
column2: we investigate several scenarios for the phased re-opening of the UK economy by modelling production network effects explicitly. At one extreme
column3: we find that re-opening only a very limited number of industries can create supply chain ‘mis-coordination problems’ that may even decrease aggregate output. At the other extreme
column4: re-opening all industries without extra precautionary measures would increase the epidemic reproduction number (R ) to above one
column5: and may cause a second wave of the epidemic. Our results suggest that there is a reasonable compromise that yields a relatively small increase in epidemic spreading and delivers a substantial boost in economic output.

column1: In an interconnected economy
column2: it is intrinsically difficult to assess the economic impact of re-opening only some industries. Each industry relies on other industries
column3: sometimes critically. For example
column4: the metal manufacturing industry cannot operate without supplies from the mining industry. Opening parts of the economy without considering these relationships could cause severe supply chain disruptions.

column1: We designed a novel economic model that acknowledges the unique features of the current crisis
column2: and specifically (i) deals simultaneously with supply and demand shocks
column3: (ii) allows for sluggish consumption recovery
column4: and (iii) incorporates sectoral inventory buffers. The core of the model is an industrial production network that distinguishes between critical and non-critical inputs. To determine which inputs are critical
column5: we use a survey of IHS Markit industry analysts
column6: who were asked “Can production continue in industry X if input Y is not available for two months?”.

column1: Our model is calibrated to the UK economy and initialised with first-order supply and demand shocks derived in del Rio-Chanona et al. (2020). Validation exercises show that our model is in good agreement with recent estimates from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) and is in line with the sectoral unemployment data of the US. Our model predicts a reduction in GDP of 1.7% for the first quarter and a reduction of 21.5% for the second quarter of 2020 (compared to the last quarter of 2019). These estimates are in the range of other forecasts for the UK economy
column2: although on the more pessimistic side.

column1: Figure 1 Simulation results for implementing and unwinding the UK lockdown
As in most economic models
column2: the predicted outcomes depend fairly strongly on the choice of the production function. We assume that non-critical inputs are not necessary (to avoid the unrealistic collapse of the economy that would take place under a standard Leontief model). However
column3: we do assume that critical inputs are absolutely necessary
column4: and in fixed proportion
column5: leading to non-trivial network effects. For instance
column6: we find the counter-intuitive result that re-opening only a few industries can lower aggregate output. This happens because when some sectors of the economy are output-constrained
column7: other industries compete for these scarce inputs. Important industries may then run out of inventory and eventually lack critical inputs to operate.

column1: If re-opening only a handful of selected industries can cause problems
column2: re-opening should be broad enough. However
column3: this can of course be very risky in terms of infections. This prompted us to evaluate the effects of the re-opening scenarios on R
column4: the reproduction number of the epidemic. We decompose the epidemic transmission rate into five sources of infections: infections at the workplace
column5: at school
column6: during consumption activities
column7: during commuting
column8: and finally
column9: infections that are not influenced by whether or not an industry is open. We also estimate the infection risk in each industry. For instance
column10: the healthcare sector is responsible for more work-related infections than the forestry sector. This is because health workers have more contacts
column11: each contact has a higher infection risk
column12: and there are more healthcare than forestry workers overall. As another example
column13: the retail and restaurant sectors contribute much more to consumption infections than the mining sector
column14: because there are virtually no direct consumption activities in the mining industry.

column1: By splitting sources of infection by economic activity
column2: we can assess both the economic and epidemic impact of different scenarios.

column1: We then use this simple epidemic model to study five re-opening scenarios. First
column2: to establish a proper benchmark
column3: we quantify the effect on epidemic spreading if the lockdown continues. Second
column4: we analyse the impact of fully re-opening agriculture
column5: mining
column6: manufacturing
column7: and construction (which were not entirely closed during the UK lockdown). Third
column8: we open all upstream industries but leave all non-essential sectors in consumer-facing industries closed (retail
column9: accommodation and food
column10: recreational and personal services). The fourth scenario is the same as the third but assumes that schools are fully open instead of receiving only children of workers who cannot work from home. In the fifth scenario
column11: we re-open all industries for work and consumption.

column1: Figure 2 shows the economy-epidemic trade-off. There is considerable uncertainty in our predictions
column2: but one conclusion appears robust: A large part of the ‘upstream’ economy (that was closed until recently) tends to have a relatively lower risk for workers
column3: little risk for consumers
column4: and also has higher economic value. Essentially
column5: this is because large parts of manufacturing and business services have high ‘value-added’ and are upstream
column6: meaning that they provide inputs to other industries. Also
column7: these upstream industries are rarely selling directly to consumers
column8: and thus present limited risks in their contribution to the pandemic. As a result
column9: there is a ‘sweet spot’ in which we can re-open upstream industries but leave many consumer-facing industries closed. This results in a relatively small increase in risk of infection and a significant economic boost.

column1: Figure 2 How different re-opening scenarios impact R0 and GDP
Notes: The left-hand vertical axis shows the reproduction number R0 (multi-coloured bars). The right-hand vertical axis gives the share of GDP compared to pre-lockdown levels (blue bars).
As Figure 2 makes clear
column2: the scenario “All except consumer-facing industries” increases the reproduction number only marginally but increases GDP by 8%
column3: relative to lockdown a month after these industries are re-opened. In contrast
column4: re-opening the entire economy only increases GDP by an additional 2%. Thus
column5: our recommended scenario has most of the economic benefits
column6: and only minimal cost in terms of increased infections. Of course
column7: there remains a lot of uncertainty in many estimates
column8: and we cannot be sure that this scenario would not bring R above one. Similarly
column9: we cannot be sure that re-opening completely would bring R above one (if stringent physical distancing and environmental health measures are in place). However
column10: our results do indicate that the cost-benefit ratio of an industry being open is likely to be lower for upstream industries.

column1: 2020-06-07|"In and out of lockdowns: Identifying the centrality of economic activities
The effects of the Covid-19 lockdowns have been severe worldwide. Although most activities were reopened in May
column2: Italian GDP is expected to drop by around 10% in 2020. This column argues that a targeted exit from the lockdown in Italy could have been implemented instead. It identifies those activities with the greatest impact on the national economy
column3: but with low risks for those returning to work and for the country at large. The methodology could also be applied in other countries and in the in the unfortunate event of a new wave of contagion and a new lockdown.

column1: The effects of the Covid-related lockdowns are massive (see McKibbin and Fernando 2020). In Italy
column2: we estimate a 44% reduction in the value of potential output produced
column3: peaking at 69% for construction and real estate and 63% for mechanics. Activities were closed following an administrative decision of the government
column4: differently from other countries like Germany or France
column5: where the lockdown was in most cases the indirect effect of social confinement (Barrot et al. 2020
column6: Fadinger and Schymik 2020). As a result
column7: GDP in Italy is expected to drop by around 10% in 2020
column8: according to most forecasts.

column1: In Italy
column2: most activities were reopened in May
column3: although with social distancing and health safety guidelines. In this column
column4: we argue that a targeted exit from the lockdown could have been implemented instead
column5: giving priority to those activities with the greatest impact on the national economy. This targeted strategy
column6: combined with an assessment of the inherent health risks of each activity (as done by the government)
column7: would have reduced the risks of a second wave of contagion for those returning to work and for the country at large
column8: while achieving a reactivation of gross output and jobs similar to the general reopening actually implemented.

column1: In a recent paper (Barba Navaretti et al. 2020)
column2: we propose an approach to identify production activities for which total or partial closures (and consequently reopening) would have the greatest impact on the country's GDP
column3: output
column4: and employment
column5: using input-output tables and network centrality measures in production chains. Our approach provides an operative tool for clearly identifying the economic effects of lockdowns at a granular level. We show
column6: for example
column7: that the activation of just 20 core micro-sectors would raise the capacity of the Italian economy
column8: as measured by the value of gross output
column9: from 56% (under the administrative lockdown as of 4 May) to 76%
column10: with respect to the pre-Covid-19 level. The impact would be especially sizeable in core production chains. For instance
column11: the value of gross output of mechanics would increase from 37% to 84% and of constructions from 31% to 77%. We estimate that the administrative lockdown
column12: as of 4 May
column13: if kept for an entire year
column14: would have implied a drop in GDP of 52%. The reopening of the sectors identified in our analysis would limit this fall to 16% (assuming the other activities remain closed for a whole year).

column1: Understanding how to minimise the impact of the lockdown on the economy is of course important to design the re-opening strategy
column2: but it is even more crucial in the event of having to face a possible resurgence of the Covid-19 pandemic or a new pandemic in the future. We all wish these events would never happen
column3: but the main lesson from these tragic months is that we can no longer be unprepared in confronting them.

column1: Identifying core sectors of the economy is not easy
column2: because size is not the only issue. Given the tangled nature of value chains
column3: there are activities that may seem insignificant from a quantitative point of view
column4: but are fundamental links in several production chains
column5: and therefore have a significant indirect impact on the production capacity of the country. Input-output (IO) tables are the starting point to unfold the interconnections among different sectors of activity. A parallel strand of analysis
column6: closer to the business and management literature
column7: has developed from the concept of production or supply chains
column8: building on the seminal contribution of Porter (1985). We merge these two strands of the literature
column9: integrating information from the IO matrices of the Italian economy (produced by Istat)
column10: with those from the structure of the value chains of the Italian economy
column11: built by Prometeia. In our analysis
column12: we exploit two sets of analytical tools that have been developed in the recent years: the methodology to extract some sectors of economic activities from IO matrices proposed by Dietzenbacher and Lahr (2013)
column13: and the techniques used by social network analysis to identify key players within a system (Jackson 2010).

column1: The tangled web of the economy
To disentangle the intricacies of the Italian economy we move in three steps.
First
column2: among the 63 sectors of the national IO tables
column3: we identify those in which closure causes the largest drop of GDP
column4: thus simulating the effect of their total or partial lockdown as implemented by the government decrees of 22 March and 10 April (Dietzenbacher and Lahr 2013).

column1: Table 1 below lists the sectors for which a yearly closure (as of Italy’s Prime Minister Decrees of 22 March and 10 April 2020) would have an impact on GDP greater than 3%.
Table 1 Impact of one year of administrative lockdown on GDP by industry
column2: as of IO tables

column1: Notes: The table reports the estimates of the drop in GDP caused by the lockdown of a sector’s economic activities as of Italy’s Prime Minister Decrees of 22 March and 10 April 2020
column2: if kept for an entire year. Only sectors with an estimated drop larger than 3% of GDP are listed.

column1: The size of the decline in GDP can be decomposed into three factors: (i) the size of the sector
column2: (ii) the degree of interconnection between the sector and other upstream and downstream sectors
column3: and (iii) the degree of closure of the sector imposed by the Ministerial Decrees (i.e. the larger the extent of the lockdown
column4: the larger the economic impact).

column1: The sectors identified at NACE 2 digits are large and made of heterogeneous activities. At the same time
column2: activities which are relatively small and have small weights in input-output tables may provide crucial inputs or crucial outlets to more than one production chain. Hence their closure may nevertheless endanger a large share of national output. This effect would not be detected by input-output table.

column1: For this reason
column2: as our second step
column3: we revert to finer industry statistics
column4: and also to the analysis of specific production chains.

column1: Our units of analysis are the 192 micro-sectors included in production chains. We focus on those included in the core NACE 2 digits sectors identified above in Table 1. We use social network analysis to study the links among each micro-sector and identify the most central ones within and between production chains.
The literature on social networks has proposed several measures to characterise the relevance of each node in addition to the number of connections. We choose eigenvector centrality
column2: which estimates the relative relevance of a node within a network. Micro-sectors with a higher eigenvector centrality
column3: therefore
column4: are more relevant within each production chain and across a larger number of production chains.

column1: Figure 1 provides a representation of our network. Each dot represents a micro-sector
column2: with its size proportional to its eigenvector centrality. The ‘tails’ in the picture represent production chains and their dots correspond to micro-sectors which only belong to a single production chain
column3: therefore having lower centrality values. Dots in the centre represent micro-sectors with high centrality values because they interact with many micro-sectors across different production chains (e.g. wholesalers of intermediate industrial goods).

column1: The micro-sectors are then ranked according to their eigenvector centrality. We have identified three groups of micro-sectors. A first group includes the 20 most central micro-sectors
column2: with a total value of production when fully open of over €820 billion (23% of the total production of the Italian economy). As of 4 May
column3: these micro-sectors were operating at a mere 13% of their potential output. Of the approximately four million people employed before the crisis
column4: just over half a million were at work on 4 May. If these 20 micro-sectors were allowed to operate at full capacity
column5: the total value of output of the Italian economy would rise from 56% of its potential to as much 76%.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: while inspecting production chains
column3: one immediately realises that in some of them (e.g. fashion) many core activities
column4: such as clothing and footwear
column5: would still remain closed
column6: making the opening up of the identified micro-sectors ineffective for these production chains. We therefore consider a second set of the next 20 micro-sectors in terms of centrality
column7: which are less central than the initial 20
column8: but still large and with a crucial role in core production chains.

column1: Finally

column1: 2020-06-08|"Socioeconomic determinants of Covid-19 infections and mortality: Evidence from England and Wales

Targeting policy responses to Covid- 19 appropriately is important but requires information such as which groups in society are most affected by the pandemic. This column uses data on Covid-19 infections and mortality for small local areas in England and Wales to study the link of Covid-19 with socioeconomic factors. The findings suggest that areas with larger households

column1: 2020-06-08|"Contact-tracing and risk-tracing technologies could help ease the ‘health–wealth trade-off’ confronting many countries in the wake of COVID-19. But privacy and security concerns are preventing such technologies from being widely adopted. This column suggests a way to ease those concerns by endowing individuals with property rights to the digital information that concerns them. A ‘self-sovereign identity system’ could assure users that their data would be exploited only for specified purposes
column2: such as containing a pandemic. The data would revert to being private property once the pandemic is over.

column1: At present
column2: countries around the world face a terrible trade-off between a health crisis and an economic crisis
column3: which can be called the ‘health–wealth trade-off’. To avoid the health crisis
column4: many countries have implemented lockdowns
column5: which generate an enormous economic cost in terms of lost income and output (e.g. Portes 2020). This trade-off could be eased substantially through contact tracing
column6: risk tracing
column7: testing
column8: isolating
column9: and treatment.

column1: ‘Contact tracing’ involves identifying people who may have come into contact
column2: directly or indirectly
column3: with an infected person. The contacts of infected people can then be tested for infection; those infected can be isolated and treated; their contacts can be traced
column4: and so on (Galeotti et al. 2020). Implementing contact-tracing would greatly reduce the need for social distancing
column5: particularly if contact-tracing were supplemented by ‘risk tracing’
column6: which involves dividing people into risk categories on the basis of readily available information
column7: such as age
column8: occupation
column9: residence
column10: workplace
column11: and pre-existing health conditions (Mesnard and Seabright 2020). The effectiveness of contact- and risk-tracing can be enhanced significantly through the application of AI technologies in areas such as early warnings
column12: tracking and prediction
column13: visualisation
column14: diagnosis and prognosis
column15: monitoring crowds
column16: and treatment support (e.g. Vaishya et al. 2020).

column1: If AI-enhanced contact and risk tracing were implemented
column2: social distancing would be necessary primarily for people who have not been tested and are in high-risk categories. Consequently
column3: the health–wealth trade-off would be vastly improved because it would no longer be necessary for countries to send most of their residents into lockdown. Many people would return to work
column4: with social distancing regulations becoming more stringent for the more vulnerable groups.

column1: For countries where contact and risk tracing is feasible
column2: people are generally willing to provide the requisite data in return for protection from infection
column3: with three provisos: that others do the same
column4: that their data are used only for the purpose of containing the pandemic
column5: and that their data are adequately protected from hacking and malicious use. The great interest in providing data in return for health security is exemplified by the widespread attention and positive response PwC has received for its plans to deploy an Automatic Contact Tracing check-in app for its employees
column6: also to be made available to its clients (e.g. Leswing 2020).1 Other companies
column7: such as Locix and Microshare
column8: are working on tools permitting not only people but the surfaces with which infected people have come into contact to be retraced. Such initiatives will help companies reopen operations after lockdown by ensuring employees’ workplace safety. Though contact tracing at the workplace is certainly welcome
column9: it is far less effective than systems providing comprehensive contact tracing throughout time and space.

column1: In order for contact and risk tracing to become manageable in countries with significant infection rates
column2: it needs to be done automatically through digital technologies rather than through personal interviews. Apple and Google have partnered to assist in contact-tracing through a system that includes application programming interfaces (APIs) and operating system-level technology. These companies also plan to offer a Bluetooth-based contact-tracing platform “that would allow more individuals to participate
column3: if they choose to opt in
column4: as well as enable interaction with a broader ecosystem of apps and government health authorities” (Government Technology 2020). The opt-in condition is meant to overcome privacy and security concerns. As Apple and Google emphasise
column5: “privacy
column6: transparency and consent are of utmost importance in this effort” (Apple 2020).

column1: But the opt-in condition is expected to limit severely the uptake of this system.2 Opt-in policies produce far lower participation rates than opt-out policies in a wide variety of settings
column2: from organ donations to pensions. This is so for a variety of well-known reasons: changing the default requires mental effort; the default is usually considered the preferable or acceptable choice; and people are more sensitive to losses than to gains relative to the default
column3: making them more likely to retain the default. Governments and businesses are increasingly using opt-out design to promote socially desirable outcomes in many domains though not
column4: as noted
column5: in pandemic containment (e.g. Johnson and Goldstein 2003
column6: Sunstein 2017
column7: Thaler and Sunstein 2008).

column1: Needless to say
column2: contact tracing software is effective only when it is widely deployed. The system only has a high chance of detecting when a person in the system has been in contact with an infected person if a large proportion of the population has signal-emitting devices. Thus
column3: the Apple-Google contact-tracing system is widely deemed unlikely to play a major role in tackling the Covid-19 pandemic in many Western countries.

column1: The opt-in policy of Apple and Google with respect to their contact-tracing app stands in stark contrast to their standard policy with regard to the use of private data for advertising purposes
column2: as well as derivative digital strategies designed to attract user attention. In practice
column3: smartphones can be understood as surveillance devices
column4: used by digital network providers (such as Amazon
column5: Apple
column6: Facebook
column7: Google
column8: Microsoft
column9: and others) to target advertising individually to users. These users implicitly consent to this surveillance by agreeing to the digital services’ terms and conditions
column10: which they rarely attempt to read and which they would be unable to read (with all hyperlinks to other relevant documents) even if they wished to
column11: due to the time and effort required.3 In some cases
column12: users have the possibility of opting out of some surveillance
column13: but often in return for significant loss of service.

column1: Currently
column2: most people are highly sensitive to the potential misuse of their data with regard to contact tracing
column3: but remain largely unaware that their smartphones are de facto surveillance devices for advertising and attention-capturing purposes. Since the digital network providers earn their incomes from pursuing these purposes
column4: they have a natural incentive to keep this asymmetric awareness intact. Apple
column5: Google
column6: and other digital network providers’ sensitivity to privacy and security concerns in contact tracing is understandable.

column1: Because policymakers are often afflicted with the same asymmetric awareness
column2: or are unwilling to address the problem of surveillance for advertising openly
column3: the central questions concerning the future of contact and risk tracing are never asked. How can users be given the opportunity to share information for containing the pandemic while safeguarding their privacy and security? Can the degree of surveillance that is standard for advertising also be applied to saving lives?

column1: To address these questions productively
column2: we need to think beyond the existing institutional framework. The critical insight is simple: the current obstacles to trustworthy information sharing arise from a fundamental misallocation of digital property rights. In the current digital world
column3: users generally do not have property rights to the data about them
column4: not even to the data that they generate about themselves. This data usually belongs to digital network providers
column5: such as Apple
column6: Amazon
column7: Facebook
column8: Google
column9: and Microsoft. Users are free to leave these networks
column10: but information about users remains in the hands of the networks.4

column1: In the absence of individual digital property rights
column2: it is not surprising that users are highly concerned about the privacy and security of their data. Living in a world in which much of the data about themselves are not in their own hands
column3: they are understandably worried about the possibility of making these data available to a new set of decision makers
column4: including government agencies fighting the pandemic. After all
column5: it is difficult to assure them that data which do not belong to them will not be used by third parties for other purposes.

column1: The straightforward way of tackling this problem is to give users residual property rights to the digital information about them. This solution is feasible and implementable. People can be made ‘sovereign’ over their digital identities (i.e. the information representing them) by implementing a ‘self-sovereign identity system’ whose properties have been well-explored (Der et al. 2017
column2: Tobin and Reed 2017; the economic implications of a self-sovereign identity system are described in Snower 2018). In such a system
column3: each person is given a private digital key to certified
column4: encrypted data about himself or herself for a potentially unlimited number of recipients who can access the data
column5: provided that they have the corresponding public key. The system can be implemented through distributed ledger applications (such as blockchain) and smart contracts (e.g. Jacobovitz 2016
column6: Meitinger 2017). These applications permit search for decentralised identifiers without centralised directory
column7: so that data can be authenticated with decentralised
column8: verifiable credentials. Digital identities need to be persistent
column9: portable
column10: interoperable
column11: and secure (see Allen 2016 for a more detailed description of these requirements). Then each person can choose what inf"|0

column1: 2020-06-08|"The German administration has just released their €130 billion economic stimulus package
column2: the most prominent measure of which is an unconventional fiscal policy in the form of a sudden drop in VAT. The aim is to create a future path of increasing sales taxes by increasing prices and hence stimulating inflation expectations and aggregate demand today. This column argues that earlier episodes have shown that unconventional policy is effective because it is easily understood by non-expert households and households react to it strongly. Alternative unconventional measures
column3: instead
column4: such as forward guidance
column5: are largely ineffective in part because households do not understand what such policies imply for their consumption.

column1: As many economies are planning a slow reopening after the COVID-19 containment measures
column2: the question of how to jumpstart the economy and stimulate aggregate demand has taken centre stage (Furman 2020). When conventional monetary policy is constrained and high debt burdens limit the scope of conventional fiscal policy
column3: unconventional policies enter the policy toolbox.

column1: On 3 June 2020
column2: the German government released the measures that will constitute an unprecedented €130 billion stimulus plan. The most unexpected and prominent measure is a form of unconventional fiscal policy (Feldstein 2002
column3: D’Acunto et al. 2016
column5: whereby the government changes VAT rates to create a future path of increasing sales taxes and hence stimulate inflation expectations and spending at impact. Germany will implement an unexpected
column6: sudden
column7: and temporary drop in VAT
column8: starting in July 2020 until the end of 2020
column9: which will increase households’ expected inflation for 2021 and hence should stimulate spending for the rest of 2020
column10: until prices increase again. The same exact effect could also be obtained by pre-announcing a future increase in VAT
column11: without first cutting the tax. Both measures incentivise households to move their spending forward as long as VAT is lower
column12: although the measures differ in terms of implications for government budgets.

column1: Unconventional fiscal policy is part of a set of non-conventional policies designed and implemented to tackle the main conundrum of the euro area since the Great Recession: stimulating inflation expectations and ultimately aggregate demand in a setting in which traditional monetary policy measures are not viable
column2: and governments can barely support growth with fiscal spending because of their large debt-to-GDP ratios. Another popular unconventional policy that has entered the standard toolbox of many central banks is forward guidance – central banks’ explicit commitment to keep interest rates low until after the end of a liquidity trap
column3: which will generate inflation then and hence should increase inflation expectations today.

column1: In theory
column2: unconventional fiscal policy and forward guidance act through the same channels. They both aim to increase households’ inflation expectations in times in which the effective lower bound on nominal rates binds
column3: and hence changes in inflation expectations should translate one-to-one into changes in perceived real rates by households. Because households perceive lower real interest rates
column4: their incentives to save decline and their willingness to consume should increase based on the consumer Euler equation. These channels are unconventional in the sense that policymakers aim to manage households’ behaviour directly
column5: as opposed to changing the incentives of financial intermediaries and firms and transmitting policy measures indirectly to households.

column1: Despite the same theoretical channels
column2: in the aggregate
column3: forward guidance seems to have been ineffective (Del Negro et al. 2015)
column4: and only scant evidence exists to assess the effectiveness of unconventional fiscal policy (D’Acunto et al. 2019). Given the prominence of these measures to jump start the economy after the COVID-19 crisis
column5: in this column
column6: we discuss whether any of these policies appears to have been successful using the same identical microdata and surveys for both policy measures.

column1: Figure 1 reports the central findings in D’Acunto et al. (2020) using data from the harmonised European Commission Consumer Confidence survey for Germany. The figure compares German households’ reaction to a measure of unconventional fiscal policy in 2005 and two forward guidance announcements in 2013-2014.
Figure 1 Inflation expectations and readiness to spend on durables: German households

The top panels report the fraction of the German population expecting higher inflation over the following 12 months; the bottom panels report their average willingness to purchase durable goods. The left panels plot these measures for the unconventional fiscal policy episode. In November 2005
column2: the German government unexpectedly announced a rise in VAT from 16% to 19%
column3: but the increase was only effective in January 2007 and hence
column4: the government engineered a path of future price increases. The right panels plot these measures for the first two explicit forward guidance announcements by former ECB President Draghi in July 2013 and January 2014.

column1: Although theoretically both policies should raise households' inflation expectations and spending on impact
column2: only unconventional fiscal policy has produced these outcomes in the micro data. Forward guidance announcements do not appear to manage expectations or spending plans. The raw data time-series evidence in Figure 1 is interesting
column3: but any unobserved shock contemporaneous to the policy announcements could explain those dynamics.

column1: Methodologically
column2: we need a scientific approach that helps reduce the endogeneity concerns inherent to these policy measures. We propose an identification strategy in the spirit of Poterba (1996)
column3: in which other EU consumers not exposed directly to the German VAT shock and/or to the ECB measures of forward guidance act as counterfactual for the behaviour of Germans had the policy announcements not happened. Because different households with different demographics react differently to changes in inflation expectations (Bachmann et al. 2015)
column4: we match German households to similar foreign households based on observables. Moreover
column5: our data allow us to control directly for important determinants of spending plans
column6: such as households' income expectations
column7: financial outlook
column8: employment status
column9: and housing choices.

column1: Figure 2 plots the average treatment effect (ATE) of the unconventional fiscal policy announcement on durable purchases (top panel) and of forward guidance (bottom panel). We find no differences in the readiness to spend on durable goods between German and matched households before the announcement of the VAT change. Starting in December 2005
column2: after the future VAT change was announced
column3: German households' willingness to spend increased relative to matched households: German households were 3.8 percentage points more likely to declare it was a good time to purchase durable goods after the announcement relative to before and to matched foreign households. The effect increased in magnitude throughout 2006 and peaked at 34 percentage points in November 2006. The average treatment effect dropped to zero in January 2007 once the VAT increased and higher inflation materialised.

column1: For forward guidance
column2: instead
column3: we find no difference in the readiness to spend on durable goods between German and matched households before the first forward guidance announcement in July 2013. Germans' propensity to spend did not change after the first forward guidance announcement relative to before and relative to matched foreign households. Even around the second announcement in January 2014
column4: the announcement had no effect on the willingness to spend. The propensity to spend did not move after the second announcement either. Ultimately
column5: forward guidance announcements had no effect on impact nor delayed indirect effects through financial intermediaries
column6: such as due to an effect of lower long-term interest rates on credit-financed consumption.

column1: Given the novelty of unconventional fiscal policy
column2: we now discuss in more detail its features and intellectual background. Feldstein (2002) introduced the notion of unconventional fiscal policy measures at times of liquidity traps. Among several possible interventions
column3: he proposed a series of pre-announced increases in VAT to generate consumer price inflation
column4: and hence increase private spending via intertemporal substitution. In his words: “This [VAT] tax-induced inflation would give households an incentive to spend sooner rather than waiting until prices are substantially higher.” The intuition for this proposal is based on a simple logic: announcing higher prices in the future – either with a sudden but temporary cut
column5: or with an outright future increase in VAT – will increase current inflation expectations. Higher inflation expectations at times of fixed nominal interest rates should reduce real interest rates (Fisher equation)
column6: and lower real interest rates should increase households’ incentives to consume rather than save (Euler equation). Because imposing higher VAT reduces households’ wealth (especially poorer households’ wealth) and might affect households’ labour supply
column7: lower income taxes (or transfers to those households that do not pay any income tax) should accompany the increase in VAT.

column1: Designing such a measure with a sudden but temporary VAT cut with a pre-specified date in which the VAT will revert back to its original level is exactly what the German administration announced as part of their €130 billion stimulus package. A pre-announced tax increase and a sudden temporary drop in VAT differ in terms of budget neutrality: the former policy is budget neutral for the government if paired with income tax cut or even generates revenues
column2: whereas the latter policy creates budget deficits. In both cases
column3: unconventional fiscal policy incentivises households to consume immediately
column4: jump-tart the economy
column5: and hence help the economy "|0

column1: 2020-06-09|"From trade-offs to synergies: COVID-19
column2: populism
column3: and sustainable development

column1: Concerns are growing that the COVID-19 crisis could be exploited by populists claiming to be the voice of those who have been ‘left behind’. This column presents a new framework which could help shed light on the relationship between sustainable development and populism. Progress on the Sustainable Development Goals may be associated with diminishing electoral support for populism
column2: but humanity must still get better at turning the trade-offs between SDGs into synergies. During the COVID-19 recovery
column3: an effective way to prevent populists from exploiting the crisis may involve making the SDGs the policy blueprint.

column1: This column is a lead commentary in the VoxEU debate on ""Populism""
In the academic literature
column2: as well as within the VoxEU debate
column3: a number of reasons for the recent rise of populism have been brought forward (for an overview of the literature
column4: see Norris and Inglehart 2018). However
column5: no study has yet looked systematically at the relationship between the rise of populism on the one hand
column6: and the historic Agenda 2030 for Sustainable Development on the other. To address this gap
column7: we recently introduced the first systematic classification of Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) performance and populism (Kroll and Zipperer 2020). We performed the first empirical analysis of the relationship between populism and the SDGs by examining how countries have progressed on the SDGs over time
column8: and how their development in terms of sustainability relates to subsequent electoral support for populism. We used data from the SDG Index and Dashboards (Sachs et al. 2019 and www.sdgindex.org) which provides “the most comprehensive picture of national progress on the SDGs and offers a useful synthesis of what has been achieved so far” (Nature Sustainability 2018).

column1: The SDGs provide a new and enlarged understanding of sustainability as an economic
column2: social
column3: and environmental challenge. The goals are firmly rooted in the concept of sustainable development
column4: i.e. “development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs” (Brundtland Commission 1987
column5: Sachs 2015). They comprise 17 goals and 169 targets that span a range of topics
column6: from ending extreme poverty (SDG 1) to affordable and clean energy (SDG 7)
column7: or a global partnership for the goals (SDG 17) (UN 2015) (see Figure 1).

column1: What makes pursuing the SDGs a particularly challenging task is the fact that these goals have
column2: at present
column3: antagonist tendencies among themselves. In other words
column4: there are numerous trade-offs between SDGs
column5: such as between reducing poverty and climate action
column6: which
column7: in the future
column8: will need to be turned into mutually reinforcing synergies in order to achieve a “virtuous cycle of SDG progress” (Kroll et al. 2019). Colleagues and I have performed a first analysis of future interactions for projected SDG trends until 2030 within and between goals. We analysed how trade-offs and synergies have evolved globally in the recent past. We found an alarming inability to overcome certain persistent trade-offs
column9: as well as the deterioration for some SDGs. These findings seriously threaten the achievement of the Agenda 2030 (ibid).

column1: In order to enable a structured and fine-grained interpretation of the nexus between sustainability and populism in future research and policy debate
column2: we have recently proposed a Sustainability–Populism Framework (Kroll and Zipperer 2020
column3: see Figures 2 and 3). It elaborates on the four possible outcomes for the relationship between SDG performance over time
column4: and subsequent electoral support for populism.

column1: • Quadrant I: “disillusioned performers” (SDG improvement
column2: rising populism). The countries named “disillusioned performers” have been making progress towards the SDGs. However
column3: populist parties were able to gather increased support (e.g. by capitalising on potential fear of regress or scapegoating towards minorities).

column1: • Quadrant II: “failing prey (to populists)” (SDG deterioration
column2: rising populism). Countries in this category have been failing to advance on the SDGs
column3: and they are falling prey to populists and the political recipes they propose.

column1: • Quadrant III: “resilient believers (in liberal democracy)” (SDG deterioration
column2: falling populism). Even though the situation with regard to the SDGs has deteriorated over the last years
column3: countries in this group keep their faith in traditional mainstream parties and the solutions they propose to overcome the challenges.

column1: • Quadrant IV: “consolidating achievers” (SDG improvement
column2: falling populism). These countries have been making progress towards the SDGs
column3: and the calls by populists to steer in a different direction are not heeded by voters.

column1: The SDGs as an answer to populism
For illustrative purposes of the framework’s analytical value
column2: we examined data on SDG progress and populist vote shares that were available for 39 countries (SDG progress data for 2010 – 2015). Although
column3: due to a time lag
column4: the raw data sometimes precede that period; populist vote share data represent the change from second-last to last election
column5: with the last election mainly taking place between 2015 and 2018 (for details
column6: see Kroll and Zipperer 2020). Most countries fall into Quadrant I and IV. In other words
column7: while most of the countries examined have experienced progress towards the SDGs
column8: they differ in terms of whether the electorate has subsequently turned to populists or not. A number of countries have also experienced SDG regress
column9: and subsequently seen an increase in electoral support for populists (Quadrant I). Almost no countries can be found in Quadrant III
column10: with Greece being an exception where possibly a disillusionment with populists has meant that voters turned away from them. An additional analysis for each SDG separately can be found in the paper.

column1: As political systems in many nations continue to be faced with growing populist parties
column2: our analysis sheds some light onto examples where mainstream political parties prevailed as unchallenged political hegemons in light of their good performance on economic
column3: social
column4: and environmental SDGs. A particularly promising avenue for future research may be dissecting the political discourses in the countries where populists have triumphed despite progress towards the SDGs being made (Quadrant I: “disillusioned performers”)
column5: and what differentiates such a political discourse from that taking place in countries of the other categories
column6: especially the “consolidating achievers” group. In other words: Why does success on the SDGs result in diminishing support for populists in certain countries but not in some others?

column1: In order to further explore the nature of the statistical relationship between the two concepts beyond the aforementioned framework
column2: we also performed a linear regression analysis. We thereby examined the SDG performance over time as a potential determinant of the populist vote share in the subsequent election. We find a significant negative effect of overall SDG country performance over time on the change in populist vote share (controlling for GDP per capita change PPP). For each one-point increase on the aggregate SDG Index (out of 100)
column3: the vote share of populist parties on average drops by about two percentage points. We also find significant negative effects of progress in SDG 1 (No poverty)
column4: SDG 2 (Zero hunger)
column5: SDG 11 (Sustainable cities and communities)
column6: and SDG 15 (Life on land). The effect sizes vary as follows. For each one-point increase on the SDG 1 indicator (out of 100)
column7: the vote share of populist parties on average drops by about 0.3 percentage points
column8: while for SDG 2 it drops by about 2.4 percentage points. For SDG 11
column9: the drop is by about one percentage point
column10: and for SDG 15 by about half a percentage point.

column1: Figure 3 The Sustainability–Populism Framework with data for 39 countries
Making the SDGs the blueprint for the COVID-19 recovery
As countries are now beginning to organise the recovery after COVID-19
column2: many commentators have expressed concerns that the hardship associated with the crisis might be exploited by populists in numerous countries
column3: potentially leading to a new wave of electoral support for populism. The lessons from recent findings discussed here lend support to the notion that a strong commitment to the SDGs (overall
column4: as well as in particular to the SDGs 2
column6: and 15) could be part of an appropriate and effective answer to populism. The SDGs would therefore be a very suitable blueprint for the COVID-19 recovery.

column1: 2020-06-09|"Since the first case of Covid-19 was found in New Zealand on 28th February we have all had to change our way of life. These Wellington images and video portray some of that journey.
Real estate agents are adopting new strategies to survive the lockdown and do business in the transformed economic landscape
column2: writes Rakesh Krishnan.

column1: Not surprisingly
column2: the lack of ability to conduct business face to face during the lockdown has caused major disruption in the way people function in this sector.

column1: With people generally insecure about their jobs or maybe even having lost their jobs
column2: many potential home buyers are – at least for the short term – reluctant to plonk down their cash on a big-ticket purchase. Consequently
column3: many real estate agents have adopted innovative strategies to cope during these unprecedented times.

column1: READ MORE:
* Sports bra exporter waiting for uplift in sales as global freight costs triple
* Wellington business confidence in the doldrums
column2: new survey findings show

column1: * Southland interior designer diversifies to save her business

Some of the agents Prosper talked to said the first few days of the lockdown felt really strange and it took a bit of getting used to
column2: but after a week or so a new normal emerged. There was a realisation that you had to make the best of a dicey situation.

column1: Green Bay-based Vicky Ingham of Ray White had a new listing ready to go live in the week of the lockdown but after discussion with the vendor she held it over until level 3. ""I made myself available to buyers and sellers who needed advice over the lockdown period but took care not to contact people who may have been under stress during that time
column2: she said.

column1: The new normal in real estate is that if you can't hit the bricks
column2: go online. Ingham points out that some of her colleagues were able to secure contracts over the lockdown which included a clause 'subject to the purchaser viewing in level 3'. ""This worked well for buyers who loved the look of a home online
column3: with the option of being able to view at a later date before declaring a contract unconditional
column4: she said.

column1: Ingham
column2: who has been in the industry for close to a decade
column3: points out that many aspects of real estate work can be effectively managed online. FlexiSign is a product which allows for signing of contracts online; virtual tours are now offered by most real estate photographers; and online auctions are being further developed.

column1: So what's in store for Auckland's real estate industry?
Contactless online marketing will become more dominant than ever and being up to speed with product development will be vital
column2: Ingham said.

column1: Going forward
column2: technology will just get better and while it allows us to do a high quality job
column3: everything in the short term will run at a slower pace to enable us to keep buyers and vendors and their properties safe.""

column1: Robbie Bhullar and Vish Bhati of Barfoot & Thompson agree technology is rapidly transforming the real estate industry. Until recently
column2: the two West Auckland agents were selling a property every 4.74 days
column3: so the Covid-19 pandemic has been especially hard on them.

column1: However
column2: being early adopters of technology helped them mitigate some of the after-effects of the slowdown. ""Even as trading remained restricted during the lockdown
column3: we were able to do digital negotiation and contactless transactions with existing customers
column4: they said. ""Electronic platforms such as DocuSign
column5: Trello and CRM systems made things easy during the lockdown.""

column1: South Auckland-based Heather Obern and Kevin Arthur of Ray White Manukau observe online marketing and communication has already become the primary medium of selling in the industry. ""During the lockdown it was our window on the world
column2: they said. ""Properties can and are being sold without physical viewing
column3: especially for investment
column4: but most home buyers still want to view the home and see what it 'feels' like. Enhanced digital viewings will help people decide whether they really want a physical viewing.""

column1: According to Heather and Kevin
column2: off-market listings are becoming a significant segment of the market and may be more appealing in the post-Covid marketplace. These are listed properties that are not widely advertised but available through an agent. ""This gives tighter control around viewing
column3: more vendor privacy and better qualified buyers. We also think more salespeople will work away from their offices
column4: using virtual communications and online meetings at times. Offices may shrink in size as a result.""

column1: Clearly
column2: the real estate landscape has changed
column3: and not everyone will come unscathed through the current crisis. The industry is based on commission-only income

2020-06-09|"Ireland is facing a “tsunami” of mental health problems due to the coronavirus pandemic
column2: with early indications showing an increase in suicide and self-harm
column3: health experts warn.

column1: Data collection on suicides by Irish hospitals were suspended as a result of the lockdown
column2: meaning there are no current figures on suicide and self-harm rates
column3: according to the National Self-Harm Registry.

column1: However other data sources point to a significant upward trend. In March and April of this year
column2: 17 per cent of patients admitted to the National Spinal Injuries Unit in the Mater Hospital had sustained injuries in a suicide attempt compared to one per cent in the same period last year.

column1: The numbers involved are small but they reflect a trend which is being seen elsewhere. According to a recent US study
column2: 45 per cent of people with suicidal thoughts explicitly linked them to Covid-19
column3: the disease caused by coronavirus.

column1: On Monday
column2: the College of Psychiatrists of Ireland (CPI) concluded a survey of 615 consultants. The data is still being analysed but there are early indications of a worrying trend
column3: the college said.

column1: “A large proportion of consultants are reporting that they are now seeing an increase in people experiencing both new-onset and relapse of mental illness compared to the early stages of the lockdown but also to before the lockdown came into place
column2: ” said Andrea Ryder of the CPI.

column1: Increasing numbers of patients are presenting with suicidal ideation and signs of self-harm
column2: she said.

column1: “We can see and we know that a tsunami of mental health issues are coming. We know that anecdotally from us working as clinicians in emergency hospitals and in community settings
column2: ” said Professor Fiona McNicholas
column3: a consultant child and adolescent psychiatrist.

column1: There is particular concern about the mental health of young people already prone to anxiety and the elderly who have been forced to cocoon since the start of the pandemic.
In one young person
column2: the lockdown exacerbated an eating disorder
column3: said Prof McNicholas.

column1: “The loss of their ability to engage in their usual exercises led them to over focus on eating. They presented in a very malnourished state with typical anorexic behaviour.”
In a second case
column2: a previously healthy young boy started exercising on his own to maintain his fitness during lockdown.

column1: “Unfortunately for him
column2: it led to exercise addiction
column3: ” said Prof McNicholas. “To the point where he lost 20 per cent of his body weight and was medically compromised.”

column1: Dr John Lyne
column2: a consultant general adult psychiatrist and editor of the IJPM
column3: said there is potential for an increase in suicides
column4: particularly if there is a severe economic depression. In the past social upheavals such as the Troubles or the 2008 recession

column1: 2020-06-09|"In times of crisis
column2: humans have a tendency to turn to religion for comfort and explanation. The COVID-19 pandemic is no exception. Using daily data on Google searches for 95 countries

column1: The COVID-19 pandemic has brought sizeable costs for societies across the globe. A pandemic of this size potentially changes our societies for years to come

column4: it should be noted that earthquakes increase religiosity permanently across generations (Bentzen 2019). Previous research has documented a multitude of correlations between religiosity and socio-economic factors: from peoples’ ability to cope with stress and uncertainty

column1: In my recent paper

column4: and who prays in times of crisis. Google searches for religious terms

column4: Allah

column7: Bible

column1: Figure 1 Worldwide Google searches for “prayer” during the past 4 years
Notes: Google searches for prayer relative to the total number of Google searches. The maximum shares were set to 100. The searches encompass all topics related to prayer

column2: Toronto Region Immigrant Employment Council and World Education Services to recruit

column1: Over the past number of years

column5: internationally trained medical professionals and Canadians in need of health care.

This column examines hospital closures in California from 1995 to 2011 to assess the effects of rural and urban hospital closures on inpatient mortality. Mortality increases after a rural hospital closure not only in the local rural area but in the neighbouring urban areas as well. This adverse effect is larger for Medicaid patients and racial minorities.

column3: and hospital administrators. Closures may seem reasonable and inevitable if hospitals are suffering financially
column4: but they can severely fracture patient access and cause enormous harm to patient health (Kaufman et al. 2016).

column1: In a well-functioning market
column2: a firm’s shutdown often signals underlying inefficiency or low product demand. Previous studies have shown this to be the case for the hospital industry
column3: where closures – especially urban ones – were positively associated with inefficiency (Capps et al. 2010

column1: A large body of literature suggests that the risk of closure is higher for smaller and non-profit hospitals. Large hospitals can achieve greater efficiency through economies of scale and for-profit hospitals are more responsive to competitive pressures and can ‘cream-skim’ or choose patients that enhance profitability (Allen 2017
column2: Hodgson
column3: et al. 2015
column4: Lindrooth et al. 2003).

column1: The natural divide between rural and urban hospitals
The cost structure
column2: profit motives
column3: and patient mix of hospitals thus engender a natural divide between rural and urban hospitals

column5: Thomas et al. 2016

column1: Effects of rural hospital closures on patient access and health outcomes
Efficiency considerations of closures must
column2: nonetheless
column3: account for their effect on patient welfare. Urban closures may increase overall patient welfare through by way of cost savings for all patients from the closure of inefficient hospitals (Capps et al. 2010)
column4: but patient access and outcomes are also crucial components of patient welfare (Gaynor and Town 2011).

column1: Even if market forces drive hospital shutdowns

column4: and adverse health outcomes

column1: 2020-06-10|"The role of social capital in promoting social distancing during the COVID-19 pandemic in the US

column2: and that community-level social capital can explain the geographic variations in mobility trends. Individuals reduced mobility earlier and to a higher degree in counties with high levels of social capital. Many counties
