2020-06-14|"The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has led to a massive increase in the demand for essential medical equipment. This column discusses recent findings on the role of international trade of essential medical goods in exacerbating or mitigating the impact of a pandemic. The effects depend crucially on the countries’ trade imbalances in essential medical goods. Net importers of these goods are relatively worse off during a pandemic than net exporters. Although the welfare losses of net importers are lower in a world with high trade barriers
column2: they benefit from reducing barriers once the pandemic arrives.

column1: The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has led to a massive increase in the demand for essential medical equipment to combat the spread of the disease. For instance
column2: goods such as masks
column3: gloves
column4: respirators
column5: and COVID-19 tests are playing a key role in allowing healthcare workers to respond to the ongoing pandemic. While supply has been gradually increasing to try to satisfy the high demand for these goods
column6: countries continue to face supply shortages and are increasingly forced to ration these goods.

column1: Amidst the growing fear of these supply shortages
column2: countries have been resorting to trade policy to meet domestic demand. According to Evenett (2020)
column3: “a growing number of governments have been sickening their trading partners by banning or limiting the export of medical supplies.”

column1: In our recent paper (Leibovici and Santacreu 2020)
column2: we document that the heterogeneous response of trade policy across countries is systematically related to the extent to which countries are net importers or net exporters of essential medical goods. We then develop a general equilibrium model of international trade to study the role of trade of essential goods in mitigating or exacerbating the effect of a pandemic like COVID-19.

column1: We combine data on import liberalisations and export restrictions from Global Trade Alert with international trade flow data on essential medical products to fight COVID-19 from UN COMTRADE. We find that
column2: of 109 countries studied
column3: 29 countries have implemented some type of liberalisation on essential medical products since April 2020
column4: whereas 59 countries have imposed restrictions. Moreover
column5: recent changes to trade policy for essential medical goods appear to be systematically related to countries’ positions as net suppliers or net importers of these goods. As of 24 April
column6: 86% of the countries with a trade surplus in these goods have recently imposed restrictive export policies
column7: while this has been the case for only 46% of the countries with a trade deficit.

column1: These findings suggest that international trade plays a fundamental role on the cross-country impact of a pandemic. In Leibovici and Santacreu (2020)
column2: we investigate the role of international trade of essential goods in mitigating or exacerbating this impact.

column1: We ask two questions:
1. To what extent does the impact of a pandemic depend on whether countries are net exporters or net importers of essential goods?
2. What is the role of international trade in mitigating or exacerbating the impact of the pandemic?

We address these questions using a dynamic quantitative general equilibrium model with two countries and two sectors: one sector producing essential goods (i.e. medical equipment) and the other sector producing non-essential goods. There are adjustment costs to capital and labour in each sector.
We assume that both countries are symmetric throughout except that one country is relatively more productive in essential goods while the other is relatively more productive in non-essential goods
column2: leading the former to be a net exporter of essential goods and the latter to be a net importer of essential goods.

column1: To what extent does the impact of a pandemic depend on whether countries are net exporters or net importers of essential goods?
We find that
column2: in our model
column3: a global pandemic has significant heterogeneous effects across countries: net importers of essential goods are relatively worse off during a pandemic than net exporters. There are two main forces at play. First
column4: given that it is costly to reallocate production inputs across sectors
column5: producers of essential goods cannot sufficiently boost production
column6: leading to a substantial increase in their relative price. Then
column7: while the price of essential goods increases similarly in both economies
column8: the effect on welfare depends on the countries' sectoral trade imbalances. Both countries earn relatively more for their sales of essential goods
column9: and both countries have to spend relatively more for their purchases of these goods. However
column10: given that the net importer is less productive in essential goods
column11: this country sells less than it purchases
column12: while the reverse is the case for net exporters. As a result
column13: net importers of these goods are relatively worse off.

column1: In Leibovici et al. (2020) we document that the US relies heavily on imports of essential medical goods. Thus
column2: according to the model
column3: the US is likely to be relatively worse off from the supply shortages of medical products amid the COVID-19 pandemic than if it were to be a net exporter of these goods.

column1: What is the role of international trade in mitigating or exacerbating the impact of the pandemic?
We find that the level of international trade barriers at the onset of a pandemic can significantly alter its economic implications. In our model
column2: higher initial trade costs imply that the net importer runs a smaller trade deficit of essential goods than in a world with lower trade costs
column3: while the net exporter runs a smaller trade surplus in these goods. Therefore
column4: while a pandemic continues to lead to a substantial increase in the relative price of essential goods
column5: the relative impact on the home and foreign countries is mitigated. We thus conclude that while higher trade barriers on essential goods may reduce the amount consumed of these goods
column6: they mitigate the potential vulnerability of net importers of these goods when a global pandemic hits.

column1: These findings have important implications for the design of international trade policy. Even if countries may benefit on average from having cheaper access to goods
column2: the reliance on international trade might put these countries in a vulnerable position if these goods are essential and either the supply or demand of these goods is subject to global shocks.

column1: While these findings are informative about the ex-ante design of international trade policy
column2: they are silent about the impact of trade policy changes implemented once a pandemic hits. We thus conclude our analysis by asking: What is the impact of raising trade barriers in response to a pandemic?

column1: In contrast to the previous findings
column2: we now find that raising trade barriers when the pandemic hits can significantly exacerbate the welfare cost faced by net importers of essential goods. As a net importer
column3: the home country's production structure is such that it relies considerably on the foreign country for its consumption of essential goods. Thus
column4: an increase in trade barriers on these goods exacerbates the already painful situation faced by the net importer
column5: making the relative price of essential goods even higher.

column1: These results suggest that the design of international trade policy for essential goods may suffer from a time-inconsistency problem. Net exporters of essential goods may ex-ante prefer to live in a world with low trade costs
column2: but when a global pandemic hits they might be tempted to renege on their previous commitments and increase trade barriers. The reverse is the case for net importers of essential goods
column3: as they ex-ante prefer to live in a world with high trade costs on these goods; but
column4: when a global pandemic hits
column5: they would be tempted to renege on their commitments and instead decrease trade barriers.

column1: Events such as the current pandemic can lead to increased sentiment against international trade openness. Our research suggests there are no blanket solutions. Trade openness can be effective at addressing local shocks such as domestic pandemics
column2: but it can raise tensions in the context of a global shock such as COVID-19. The design of trade policy agreements needs to be considered carefully to ensure we get the benefits of trade while minimising the potential pain when global shocks hit. This is a key challenge raised by COVID-19—one we should try to meet to avoid falling back into a world with high trade barriers and the large costs that it would entail. In Baldwin and Evenett (2020) several contributors discuss how governments should react to this type of crisis.

column1: Finally
column2: although we do not explicitly model supply chains
column3: our column is related to an ongoing discussion on the disruption of global value chains amid COVID-19. The current pandemic raised questions on the potential vulnerability of relying on foreign supply chains during a global shock
column4: leading to a surge in arguments for protectionism and self-reliance (Bonadio et al. 2020). As Pinelopi Goldberg argues
column5: global coordination is important
column6: given that global value chains can diversify risks through international trade.

column1: 2020-06-13|"It pains me to say this but Boris Johnson
column2: exhausted and looking increasingly forlorn
column3: appears to have a few short weeks to salvage his reputation and save his Government from ridicule.

column1: Still recovering from his near-death experience with Covid-19
column2: the Prime Minister faces unprecedented obstacles to prevent Britain slipping into a deep recession.

column1: With so many cards stacked against him
column2: our sallow-faced and hollow-eyed leader has squandered much of the goodwill he accumulated after his landslide Election victory in December.

column1: Even his friends whisper that there is no captain on the bridge steering the ship. According to a YouGov poll
column2: Johnson’s handling of the virus is rated as the worst of all world leaders.

column1: Many will discount the criticism as unfair. Contrary to predictions of doom from the Left
column2: the NHS has performed brilliantly.

column1: Eight million workers have been protected by the Chancellor’s £80 billion furlough package. Most of the country is becoming free of Covid. Despite our economy shrinking by 20 per cent in April
column2: it still ticks over.

column1: Johnson’s misfortune is that those achievements have been drowned out by the impression of defeat. Hampered by Downing Street’s cack-handed communications
column2: Johnson is mischievously blamed for orchestrating a shambles.

column1: Some believe his seeming impassivity
column2: sporadic public appearances and blustering press conferences are proof he’s still suffering the after-effects of Covid
column3: combined with sleepless nights with a six-week-old baby.

column1: Some of his harshest critics have boldly stated that if he had still been married to Marina
column2: his long-suffering ex-wife ‘who was unafraid to dispense home truths’
column3: Johnson’s life would be more stable than with a fiancee 23 years his junior.

column1: Such censure
column2: though

2020-06-15|"The worst is over. Hopefully
column2: we will never again see such a terrible death toll from an infectious disease in Ireland. The response of the public

column1: The numbers of deaths and of new positive cases in Ireland have fallen steadily North and South. As they have reached a low level there is an understandable clamour to get back to normal. The effects of the restrictions on all aspects of life have been immense.

The damage done to businesses and individuals will have health consequences that have yet to materialise or be fully appreciated. The very restricted operation of health services will take time to restore and even longer to deal with the backlogs of routine and even urgent care that have built up.
Psychiatrists have predicted a “tsunami” of mental health problems following the crisis arising from conditions exacerbated or created by all that we have been through.

column2: is that we are not done with this coronavirus yet. As long as the virus is present and is still being transmitted in our communities
column3: workplaces and institutions we risk significant flare-ups.

column1: Importantly
column2: if those flare-ups are not stamped out immediately
column3: the highly infectious nature of the virus has the potential to cause substantially more deaths and disruption.

column1: What is needed
column2: with great urgency
column3: is a concerted effort to achieve a “Zero Covid-19 Ireland”. This will involve getting to zero new cases in both parts of the island and then maintaining and if necessary restoring that position. The resulting economic and social benefits would be enormous.

column1: Arguments about distances of 1
column2: 1.5m or 2m would be a thing of the past and our schools
column3: theatres
column4: arts centres
column5: clubs and pubs could get back to enhancing our lives and reconnecting our communities. There is absolutely no reason why this cannot be achieved.

column1: Two things about this task are very clear. Firstly
column2: lifting a high proportion of restrictions in a country before eliminating the virus is a recipe for playing an ongoing and exhausting game of cat and mouse with this deadly foe. The consequences could be continued
column3: and possibly massive disruption.

column1: The global number of new cases per day continues to grow and resurgence is apparent in some places that have ended lockdown prematurely.
Secondly
column2: as far as Ireland is concerned the task of eliminating all new cases of the virus occurring through domestic spread
column3: ie not coming from newly imported cases
column4: can only realistically be carried out on an all-island basis.

column1: The endgame for Covid-19 is not yet in sight. Researchers around the world are working on the development of more than 135 separate vaccines. There is no guarantee that an effective vaccine will be found and we would be unwise to plan on that basis.
The best option for Ireland is a joint North-South initiative empowered and resourced to hunt down the remaining cases and hot spots for the virus and deal with them as swiftly as possible.
Learning the lessons from countries
column2: such as South Korea and Germany
column3: that are further along the path shows that the capacity to react urgently to any flare-ups must be strengthened and maintained for the foreseeable future.

column1: Changes are
column2: of course
column3: needed to harmonise efforts on the island. These include details that should have been sorted out by now anyway
column4: such as the different isolation times of seven and 14 days on either side of the Border and the fact that “shortness of breath” is a recognised and listed symptom of Covid-19 in the South but not the North. But getting a jointly agreed case finding
column5: testing
column6: contact tracing
column7: isolate
column8: and support (FTTIS) system is the big priority.

column1: In Border counties in particular
column2: the ability to deal with cases and contacts on both sides of the Border in a seamless way is crucial. In doing the job well speed is everything.

column1: Serious east-west issues will arise. As the island gets close to “zero” status the focus will be firmly on stopping the importation on new cases. Agreed measures to prevent the virus being reintroduced via ports and airports will be crucial.

column1: 2020-06-15|"[We repeat the reviewers’ points here in italic
column2: and include our replies point by point
column3: as well as a description of the changes made
column4: in Roman.]

column1: We want to thank the editor and the reviewers for their excellent comments and suggestions. We have gone over them all and made changes accordingly. Most importantly
column2: some of the comments have caused an update of the data set
column3: which changes some of the findings and allows us to fine-tune the analysis. Since we initially harvested data in April 2020
column4: PubMed has changed its interface and now provides better (and more consistent) information on author affiliations. This allows a much more precise analysis of author country
column5: as requested by one of the reviewers. This was not possible previously.

column1: We address this data update in the paper
column2: in an effort to be as transparent about the process as possible
column3: but for good measure
column4: we would like to mention here the original sample
column5: which was 9
column6: 050 COVID-19 papers
column7: of which 1
column8: 179 had gender for first and last author
column9: and at least one US-based author. These numbers are now 15
column10: 839 and 1
column11: 893 respectively. When analyzing first-authors
column12: we restrict to US-based first authors and vice versa for last authors.

column1: Below
column2: we list the comments from the reviewers and editor in italics and our responses in regular font face.

column1: We have uploaded the data and the analytical scripts to OSF. The project is private right now
column2: but we will make it public when/if our paper is published. An R script is provided
column3: which will allow full analysis from the most raw data set we are able to provide (gender is inferred and information from PubMed is extracted into a table).

column1: 2) The robustness of author gender determination is not clear
column2: and the methods should be described in more depth. For example
column3: the text states ""Gender was reliably estimated for 81.9% of the entire sample"": what does ""reliably estimated"" mean here? How is the accuracy of the gender estimation tool established? What is the likelihood that a given gender was determined correctly? Doing spot checks of a random sample of authors can be helpful. Additionally
column4: adding more information on the specific methods used for inferring gender from author names would be useful.

column1: Checking the correctness of gender assignment is of course important. Our data relies on an algorithm
column2: which we have previously used and checked for robustness. We realize that this was not apparent from the very short comment in the paper
column3: and have added a little more detail about which algorithm we used and that robustness checks have previously been performed.

column1: We have adjusted the method so that we now only compare US first and last authors. We believe this is a strength of the study because it allows us to isolate the effect to a single country and the timing of both disease and social constraints. For the analysis of the full author group
column2: there could potentially be a bias
column3: which we address in the limitations.

column1: 4) I am not convinced by the authors' argument that the observed differences are not due to a specialty bias. By looking at COVID-19-specific papers only
column2: they are looking at the gender distribution of authors in a specific field
column3: and comparing them to the gender distribution of authors in a variety of other fields who happen to publish in similar journals. It is entirely possible that there is a gender bias in coronavirus research
column4: for example- this would not be captured by journal specialty
column5: but would be seen in gender proportions for COVID-19 papers. Please add additional columns to table 1 looking at all research published in these journals in 2020 (not just COVID-19-related research)
column6: and/or discuss at greater length the possibility of specialty bias in your results.

column1: While this is certainly an important point
column2: we also have to disagree
column3: for two reasons. COVID-19 specific papers are not from a specific field. On the contrary
column4: the vast majority of medical specialties have picked up research on COVID-19 in one way or another. The search for cures or vaccines are likely limited
column5: but discussions about implications for treatment of other diseases span all of clinical medicine. Secondly

2020-06-16|"“I in my chair with such a crew
column2: ” says the captain of a cargo vessel in the South Atlantic en route from Bermuda to Singapore. He is eight months into a four-month contract

column6: ” he says

column1: When Rose George

column1: In normal times

column1: The virus has thrown an almighty spanner in the works. Countries that classified lorry drivers
column2: pilots and cabin crew as essential workers overlooked merchant seamen
column3: even though their work underpins the global economy. Some will accept their citizens

column1: At first they were proud to be able to help in the global emergency

column7: that it divert to the port of Cochin in the state of Kerala for a crew change. The company agreed

column1: The International Maritime Organisation

column1: The industry hopes that governments will be prodded into action by the sudden expiry of so many seamen’s contracts. The International Transport Workers’ Federation ( ) says it will support any seamen who refuse to work. If that leaves too few people to operate a ship safely

column1: 2020-06-16|"The magnitude of the COVID-induced economic downturn is forcing central banks around the world to rethink the set of monetary policy tools available to them. Many central banks have long shied away from negative interest rates
column2: concerned about the impact on bank profits and financial stability. This column explores how negative interest rate policies can be used by central banks to signal a commitment to a prolonged period of monetary accommodation. Using a quantitative monetary model
column3: it shows that the signalling channel of negative interest rates can result in a rise in banks’ net worth even if net interest margins shrink.

column1: Negative interest rate policies have until now been off the table for many central banks. With the COVID-19 shock and its economic repercussions
column2: however
column3: central banks such as the Bank of England and the Federal Reserve are again putting these and other policies back on the table for discussion.

column1: While the European Central Bank has pursued a negative interest rate policy since 2014
column2: influential papers such as Eggertsson et al. (2017) and Brunnermeier and Koby (2018) have argued that negative interest rates can be counterproductive because of the bank lending channel of monetary policy. The story goes like this: The central bank pays negative interest rates on reserves
column3: while the banks are unwilling (or unable) to pass these onto depositors. As a result
column4: banks’ net interest margins are squeezed
column5: and because of agency frictions in financial markets
column6: there is a contraction in credit creation in the economy.

column1: However
column2: negative interest rates
column3: like conventional monetary policy
column4: work through many channels
column5: including an expectations (or signalling) channel. For a central bank that has a preference for smoothing policy
column6: a cut in policy rates today also signals lower policy rates tomorrow. In our recent paper (de Groot and Haas 2020)
column7: we study the signalling channel of negative interest rates and illustrate the conditions under which the expansionary signalling channel dominates the contractionary net interest margin channel.

column1: The qualitative trade-off between the signalling channel and the net interest margin channel faced by an optimizing central bank can be captured in simple variant of the canonical New-Keynesian (NK) model. To do so
column2: we make just two assumptions. First
column3: policy rates can turn negative but household deposit rates cannot. This is a reasonable assumption given empirical evidence from the euro area. The second assumption is that
column4: all else equal
column5: this wedge between a negative policy rate and a zero deposit rate shifts down aggregate demand via a net interest margin-type channel.

column1: The question
column2: in this environment
column3: is whether it is optimal for a central bank to ever set negative interest rates. We establish three results:

column1: 1. If the central bank can fully commit to future policy actions
column2: then it has no need of negative rates as a policy tool. It can induce the necessary private sector expectations of the future path of (deposit) interest rates via ‘open mouth’ forward guidance
column3: without resorting to a policy that imposes a cost on banks.

column1: 2. Even if the central bank has no ability to commit to future actions (often referred to as discretion or time-consistent policy)
column2: it won’t make use of negative rates. In this case
column3: a negative policy rate provides no signal about its future actions and only imposes a cost on the banking system.

column1: So far
column2: the case for negative interest rate policies seems rather bleak. However
column3: these results capture two extreme scenarios. While both are useful benchmarks
column4: neither is likely to be a good description of monetary policy in practice. Our third result builds on work by Woodford (2003) and Nakata and Schmidt (2019) on monetary policy delegation:

column1: 3. For a central bank that cannot commit
column2: it is welfare improving to delegate monetary policy to a central banker with a preference for smoothing policy. This policymaker may find it optimal to set a negative interest rate since its preference for smoothing results in an expansionary signalling effect on the future path of interest rates.

column1: Figure 1 illustrates this result. The parameter φ captures the strength of the net interest margin channel. Consider the black line when the signalling channel is weak (i.e. the preference for smoothing in the policymaker’s objective is low) relative to the effect of a squeeze on net interest margins. In this case
column2: the optimal policy (given by the reserve rate)
column3: does not turn negative. Consider next the red-dash line when the signalling channel is relatively stronger. In this case
column4: optimal policy prescribes a negative policy rate. While the negative rate does not lower deposit rates on impact since they are constrained by the Zero Lower Bound (ZLB)
column5: the signalling channel lowers the future expected path of the deposit rate
column6: boosting aggregate demand today and mitigating some of the fall in output and inflation.

column1: Since Figure 1 is based on a variant of the canonical NK model
column2: it only provides a qualitative insight into the monetary policy trade-off. In the other half of de Groot and Haas (2020)
column3: we employ a carefully calibrated medium-scale DSGE model that quantifies the magnitude of the two channels. A key feature of this model is the banking system
column4: which we discuss in more detail below. We also replace the optimal policymaker with an inertial Taylor-type rule.

column1: Figure 2 highlights our baseline result from this quantitative exercise. In this exercise
column2: we introduce a 25 basis point cut to the policy rate which moves it into negative territory
column3: leaving the deposit rate constrained at zero. The policy in our baseline (black line) is expansionary with both output and inflation rising in response to the monetary policy cut. Output rises by eight basis points whereas inflation rises by a little over three basis points. These responses are around 40% of the effect of an interest rate cut in ‘normal times’. The figure decomposes the baseline response into the signalling and net interest margin channels. While the net interest margin channel (red-dash) causes a contraction in both output and inflation (consistent with Eggertsson et al. 2017
column4: Brunnermeier and Koby 2018)
column5: the signalling channel (blue-dot) is expansionary and dominates.

column1: Note: Impulse responses to a -25 basis point monetary policy shock at the ZLB. Inflation is annualized.

Figure 3 provides sensitivity analysis. It plots the effect on output of a -25 basis point monetary policy shock for different durations of the ZLB (x-axis); different Taylor rule inertia parameter values (left panel); and different levels of excess central bank reserves in the banking system (right panel). The baseline results correspond to a ZLB event of 4 quarters

column1: There are two takeaways from this figure. First

column1: 2020-06-16|"How we should deal with the lockdown learning loss in England’s schools
As policy attention in countries around Europe shifts to mitigating the longer-run impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic
column2: a central concern will be to prevent this one-off event from permanently blighting the life chances of the millions of children who missed weeks of school due to the lockdown. Focusing on the UK
column3: this column suggests a way to repair some of the educational damage using small group tutoring
column4: a method with widely proven effectiveness
column5: at a modest cost
column6: and on a rapid but feasible timescale.

column1: Around Europe
column2: it seems that the immediate public health crisis is beginning to fade
column3: although all are braced for a potential second wave of infection. The most intense policy attention needs to focus on mitigating the longer-run impacts of the pandemic. A central concern is to prevent this one-off event from permanently blighting the life chances of the millions of children who missed weeks of school due to the lockdown in the UK. Missed school means lost skills and reduced earnings potential.

column1: Economic analysis suggests the cost of doing nothing is huge. At a personal level
column2: this is manifested in lower earnings potential for the affected cohorts (Portes 2020
column3: Jaime and Willén 2019). This will be reflected at the national level in lower skills: from the mid-2030s
column4: and for the following 50 years
column5: about a quarter of the labour force will have lower skills
column6: implying a 50-year period of lower growth if we do nothing (Burgess and Sievertsen 2020
column7: Hanushek and Woessman 2012). As well as a fall in income
column8: all the evidence to date points to a widening of inequality. One among a number of very recent analyses
column9: the EEF (2020) for example suggest that the attainment gap between poor and non-poor students might widen by 36%. The cumulating nature of skill formation (and skill loss) means that we need to tackle this now. In this column
column10: I suggest a policy solution.

column1: 1. The policy intervention must come soon. The process through which skills are formed is dynamic – knowledge builds on knowledge
column2: or as Heckman and colleagues put it
column3: “skills beget skills” . If we do not attempt to catch up the lost learning quickly
column4: that loss will compound and essentially become untreatable. The skill complementarity over time means that if we invest in a 10 year-old today
column5: it will cost less than if we invest when that child is 15 years old to get to the same outcome at age 16.

column1: 2. Over the period of lost schooling
column2: schools have provided online resources to children to continue learning at home. There is already evidence (Andrew et al. 2020
column3: Bol 2020) that this has not been very successful
column4: with many families reporting little learning has taken place. So
column5: despite the cost temptation to try to simply catch-up lost skills at home
column6: this will not work. This implies the policy intervention must be school-based
column7: not home-based.

column1: 3. It also has to be something new
column2: something extra
column3: and something temporary. This differs from the usual policy question of simply ‘making schools better’. The quest for those policies should go on
column4: but the current situation requires something much more immediate
column5: and immediately effective.

column1: 4. While of course it is not true to say that the cost does not matter
column2: we must anticipate that a policy intervention at such scale will not be cheap. Skills have been lost that were to be taught over a 12-week period. Replacing that necessarily takes time
column3: and resource. However
column4: it is clear that the cost to individuals affected and to the UK of doing nothing is dramatically higher.

column1: 5. Finally
column2: we must use an intervention that already has substantial causal evidence supporting its effectiveness. This is by no means a trivial requirement. For example
column3: the hundred-plus randomised controlled trials funded by the Education Endowment Foundation show that
column4: in fact
column5: many much-hyped education policies have no effect.

column1: The policy that best fits these criteria is small group tutoring
column2: based in schools.

column1: My proposal is an extensive but time-limited use of small group tutoring in as many of the school years as possible
column2: to remediate the learning loss suffered by the missed months of schooling.

column1: I proposed the use of small group tutoring earlier in this crisis
column2: and here I provide details and cost estimates. Support for a very similar idea is also building in the US
column3: following an earlier proposal from Robert Slavin
column4: Director of the Center for Research and Reform in Education at Johns Hopkins University
column5: and support from leading education economist Susan Dynarski.

column1: Small group tutoring is a flexible approach
column2: with several parameters varying the ‘dose’: the number of pupils per group
column3: the amount of time per session
column4: and the number of sessions. It is fair to say that not all of these dimensions have been fully explored by suitably well-designed experiments. There is robust evidence showing that one-to-one tutoring works
column5: and we can build from there. While effectiveness declines the bigger the group
column6: it seems there are only marginal falls in impact from two in the group to six in the group
column7: and steeper falls thereafter.

column1: Taking a ‘dose’ of the intervention to be half an hour a day
column2: for each weekday
column3: for 12 weeks
column4: there is good evidence that this has an impressive effect on learning. The EEF evidence toolkit estimates that such a ‘dose’ of small group tutoring typically yields an extra four months’ progress in school. Of course
column5: these are all averages
column6: but the rough equivalence between a gain of an extra four months’ progress from the intervention and a loss of three months’ schooling from the lockdown seems appropriate. A thorough and wide-ranging meta-analysis of effective educational interventions with robust evidence in the US (Fryer 2016) also concludes that interventions that “implement ‘high-dosage’ tutoring tend to demonstrate large effects” (p. 6)
column7: reporting very high pooled impacts from 0.78 to 1.58 standard deviations.

column1: It is not possible here to set out how it would all work. But in Burgess (2020) I have provided some ideas on what some of the main features might look like
column2: including who the tutors would be
column3: the timeline
column4: the selection of pupils
column5: and so on.

column1: Most of the cost of this scheme is the time of the tutor. The extra tuition would take place in the pupil’s usual school
column2: after school
column3: and while this would likely generate additional costs
column4: these would be relatively minor. The EEF have estimated a cost for small group tutoring: for the dose noted above
column5: they estimate a cost of £700 by adding up the time and taking it relative to the annual workload of a regular teacher. This is clearly subject to a number of uncertainties
column6: not least how the different groups are bundled up into jobs
column7: and the level of training of the tutor (discussed below).

column1: Table 1 presents some rough estimates of what the overall cost might be.
They key parameters to be chosen are:
• First
column2: what fraction of a cohort would be involved? I have chosen here 40% since we know from the accumulating evidence that not many families and pupils made a success of home learning.

column1: • Second
column2: group size obviously has a clear and straightforward impact on costs and a much vaguer effect on learning; I have chosen five in the example.

column1: • Third
column2: we need to decide which cohorts to include
column3: within schooling up to year 11. Ideally
column4: all cohorts would be helped
column5: but for this example I have chosen six: years 1
column6: 2 and 3 in primary schools and years 7
column7: 10 and 11 in secondary schools. For the cost per group
column8: I have taken the EEF figure of £700 per group per ‘dose’.

column1: The total is £222 million. This figure is very modest – less than 1% of the overall schools’ budget. It suggests that the possibility of involving all the cohorts should be considered
column2: raising the cost to around £410 million.

column1: There are other ways of approaching this
column2: also with merit
column3: but I believe that this proposal has the greatest likelihood of success; I briefly discuss those in Burgess (2020).

column1: Younger generations will pay a heavy price for our response to this virus. In this column
column2: I suggest a way to repair some of the educational damage using small group tutoring
column3: a method with widely proven effectiveness (four months extra learning)
column4: at a modest cost (less than 1% of the schools budget)
column5: and on a rapid but feasible timescale (start in October
column6: finish by Easter). Many details would need to be decided
column7: but the bones are here to make a start.

column1: 2020-06-16|"The Australian dollar rallied overnight having slipped back below 0.68 US cents throughout the domestic session. Risk assets suffered early as investors grappled with reports out of the US and Beijing citing new coronavirus hotspots. In the US 20 states recorded an increase in the spread of Covid-19 cases while Beijing reported a string of new cases after almost 2 months without new infections. The news served as a stark reminder of the risks of opening to quickly and forced markets to check expectations for H2 economic activity. Further downward pressure came following rumours China is considering targeting Iron Ore as diplomatic tensions increase. China’s dependence on the raw material has meant it was considered free from heightened diplomatic hostilities
column2: however if China’s program of restrictions and tariffs does extend to Iron Ore the Australian Economy almost certainly suffer more than China. Having slipped to intraday lows at 0.6780 risk assets found support overnight as the FED announced it will begin buying individual corporate bonds
column3: increasing the scope and scale of its bond buying program. With additional cash set to be in play markets bought the dip and pushed the AUD back through 0.69 to intraday highs at 0.6920.

column1: Attentions today remain squarely affixed to risk. Investors will be keenly attuned to the RBA minutes for any guidance on monetary policy. A sustained risk on move could help the AUD edged back toward 0.70
column2: while a shift in sentiment will likely prompt a move back below 0.69 US cents.

column1: The risk on move overnight saw haven assets close the day lower as investors jumped back into to risk and growth correlated currencies. The USD was the weakest of the majors with the dollar index falling half a percent
column2: while the JPY and CHF also shifted lower. The Dollar came under heavy selling pressure after the FED announced it would expand its bond buying program to include individual corporate bonds. The expansion of its monetary policy program emboldened investors to buy the dip and jump back into risk correlated assets as the availability of cash and central bank funding will seemingly continue through the medium term.

column1: With little of note on the macroeconomic docket today attentions will remain with the broader risk tone. The Bank of Japan’s monthly policy meeting will likely pass without incident while US retail sales are unlikely to tip the scales. The market continues to largely ignore backward looking fundamentals instead looking to sentiment and forward guidance as markers of future performance and signals guiding the speed of any economic recovery. That said a strong retail sales print could bolster risk appetite as consumer spending increases amid easing restrictions.

The UK claimant count will also provide a valuable insight into the health of the labour market. A front runner to official unemployment numbers it offers a sneak peak as to the trend of labour market performance. A print above 400
column2: 000 will add mounting pressure to the GBP as it continues to struggle with the coronavirus and opening up the broader economy.

2020-06-16|"Inequality and poverty effects of the lockdown in Europe
Enforced social distancing and lockdown measures to contain COVID-19 restrict economic activity
column2: especially among workers in non-essential jobs who cannot ‘telework’. These have implications for inequality and poverty. This column analyses the capacity of individuals in 29 European countries to work under lockdown and the potential impact of a two-month lockdown on wages and inequality levels. There will be substantial and uneven wage losses across the board and poverty will rise. Inequality within countries will worsen
column3: as it will between countries although to a lesser extent.

column1: The economic impact of COVID-19 is dramatic. The global economy is expected to shrink by 3% this year. Asia will not have economic growth for the first time in 60 years
column2: the US and European economies are projected to contract between 6% and 8% (International Monetary Fund 2020)
column3: and global job losses are estimated to be over 200 million (International Labour Organization 2020).

column1: The economic effects of the pandemic
column2: however
column3: will not be equally distributed (Dorn et al. 2020
column4: McKibbin and Fernando 2020) and are likely to have distributional implications (Furceri et al. 2020
column5: Lustig and Mariscal 2020).

column1: Our findings strongly support this statement (Palomino et al. 2020). We estimate that the burden of the pandemic will be disproportionately borne by low-wage earners which
column2: in the absence of compensating policies
column3: will significantly increase poverty and inequality across Europe.

column1: The lockdown and partial closure of economic activities were crucial to stop the pandemic and save lives
column2: but their economic effects are likely to diminish economic cohesion between and within European countries.

column1: Teleworking and lockdown ability to work in Europe
Even without considering the subsequent effects that may occur on the demand side (del Rio-Chanona et al. 2020)
column2: the lockdown and social distancing imposed by governments to limit the spread of COVID-19 have direct asymmetric effects on the labour market: in principle
column3: only the jobs that can be done from home (‘teleworkable’) are unimpeded by the lockdown. Some occupations like health services and food sales are considered essential
column4: so workers are not affected by their capacity to work from home. Meanwhile
column5: certain economic activities like hospitality are closed under a lockdown and working is not at all possible.

column1: To measure the capability of each worker to keep active under the lockdown
column2: we calculate a ‘lockdown working ability’ index of workers (see Palomino et al. 2020). This measure takes into account the level of teleworking for each occupation (Dingel and Neiman 2020) and whether the occupation is considered essential or closed.

column1: As shown in Figure 1
column2: the average lockdown working ability index varies significantly across European countries with the Netherlands (0.61) the best prepared and Bulgaria (0.37) the worst prepared.

column1: In Table 1 we highlight that our index varies significantly not only by country but also by:
• Gender: Women are less affected by social distancing than men.
• Type of job: Temporary and part-time workers are in general worse-prepared than their permanent and full-time counterparts.
• Education: There is a strong positive relationship between the level of education and the capacity to work under a lockdown in all European countries.
Teleworking capability is strongly correlated with higher wages both across occupations and across average levels by country (r = 0.76). However
column2: the correlation between the lockdown working ability index and the average annual salary in a country is positive but very small (0.06).

column1: Once essential and closed occupations are taken into consideration
column2: the changes in wage inequality caused by the lockdown are difficult to foresee based only on the average level of ability to work under lockdown
column3: and one needs to look at how potential wage losses are distributed.

column1: Because not all workers are able to perform their job at home and some activities are closed
column2: there will be potential wage losses for a significant part of the labour force that cannot fully work during the lockdown.

column1: To simulate these wage losses
column2: we consider several possible scenarios. Here
column3: we show the results for (i) two months of lockdown and (ii) two months of lockdown plus six additional months of de-escalation with only partial functioning of the closed activities (80% of capacity).

column1: Although each European country may have followed slightly different lockdown and de-escalation strategies
column2: we simulate the same scenarios for all countries to ensure that differences across countries are exclusively due to their productive structure.

column1: After ordering workers by wage centiles
column2: we represent the relative change in their wage in ‘lockdown incidence curves’ (Figure 2)
column3: which makes it easy to appreciate which part of the wage distribution (low
column4: middle
column5: high) suffers the largest relative wage losses.

column1: For a lockdown of two months
column2: wage losses are sizeable across the wage distribution but vary significantly with the centile
column3: being above 10% (of the annual salary) at certain percentiles in some countries.

column1: Figure 2 Lockdown incidence curves in Europe (two months of lockdown)
Notes: The four panels show lockdown incidence curves (wage distribution versus wage loss
column2: two-month lockdown scenario) for different groups of countries with similar curves.

column1: As noted above
column2: there is no straightforward relationship between the average wage of a country and its distribution of wage losses. Thus
column3: we observe that the distribution of wage losses is similar for Norway and Greece (panel b)
column4: and Ireland and Cyprus (panel c)
column5: despite the fact that these countries have significantly different average wages.

column1: Changes in poverty and wage inequality
The lockdown increases poverty in all countries. First
column2: we find a 10.0% mean loss rate (P) for poor workers − those below 60% of the median wage − for the average of European countries under a lockdown of two months. This mean loss rate for poor workers goes up to 22.5% when an additional 6-month period with partial functioning of closed activities is considered. The mean loss rates are also sizeable by country (Table 2).

column1: Second
column2: the proportion of poor workers (headcount index
column3: H) increases significantly for all European countries. The average increase is 4.9 percentage points under two months of lockdown and 14.5 percentage points with an additional partial closure period of six months.

column1: These values imply that − in the absence of counteracting government measures − the percentage of poor people in Europe may substantially increase
column2: even if lockdown does not last long.

column1: By country
column2: under the two-month lockdown scenario
column3: we find the highest increase in poverty in Croatia by the headcount index
column4: and the smallest increase in Switzerland.

column1: When comparing wage inequality after the lockdown with the baseline
column2: we observe that inequality increases in all European countries (Table 2). The countries with the lowest increases in the Gini coefficient under a two-month lockdown are the Netherlands (2.2%)
column3: Norway (2.3%)
column4: France (2.3%)
column5: Switzerland (2.6%)
column6: and Germany (2.6%). On the other extreme of the spectrum
column7: we find Cyprus (4.9%)
column8: Czechia (4.8%)
column9: Hungary (4.7%)
column10: Slovenia (4.7%)
column11: and Slovakia (4.6%).

column1: With an additional six-month period during which closed activities are functioning at 80%
column2: the countries with the lowest increases in the Gini coefficient are Denmark (9.5%)
column3: France (9.9%)
column4: the Netherlands (10.5%)
column5: the UK (10.8%)
column6: and Germany (10.9%). Countries with the highest increases are Slovakia (21.2%)
column7: Cyprus (20.0%)
column8: Hungary (19.6%)
column9: Czechia (16.0%)
column10: and Slovenia (15.9%).

column1: Table 2 Poverty and inequality changes in Europe
Notes: P is the mean loss rate for the poor
column2: H is the headcount index
column3: and G is the Gini inequality index. CL is partial closure
column4: while 2m refers to 2 months. ∆RG is the relative change in the Gini index.

column1: Finally
column2: wage inequality both within and between European countries increase under a two-month lockdown
column3: but inequality of wages inside countries increases more (5.04%) than inequality between countries (2.44%). Countries’ average wages diverge with the lockdown
column4: although the main change in wage inequality happens within (not between) European countries.

column1: In sum
column2: our analysis reveals that the lockdown and de-escalation periods will potentially increase poverty and inequality sizeably in all European countries
column3: even without accounting for second-round effects. Given that early relaxation of containment measures could have devastating effects for the health of citizens
column4: we advocate for public policies that alleviate the distributional consequences that the lockdown may otherwise have.

column1: 2020-06-17|"Recent academic discussions have sought to understand whether the economic impact of the COVID-19 crisis and associated lockdown should be ascribed to demand or supply shocks. This debate is of some importance since the underlying shock can have significant implications for stabilisation policy. This column tries to answer these questions by using data on hours worked and wages to estimate labour demand and supply shocks for the aggregate economy and for different sectors through an econometric model. It finds that while labour supply shocks accounted for a larger share of the fall in hours
column2: both shocks were important.

column1: In response to the COVID-19 outbreak
column2: governments and public health authorities around the world implemented confinement and mitigation measures such as social distancing. These measures effectively led to the controlled shutdown of entire sectors of the economy
column3: especially those that supply economic activities and services involving high physical contact with other people
column4: such as restaurants
column5: hairdressers
column6: airlines
column7: etc. On one hand
column8: authorities forced many such establishments to close and send their workers home (the so-called lockdowns). On the other hand
column9: consumers themselves also reduced their consumption of these services
column10: regardless of public health policy recommendations. Furthermore
column11: as workers in some of these services lose their jobs and income
column12: they also reduce their purchases of other goods and services. This
column13: combined with uncertainty about the evolution of the pandemic
column14: leads to a reduction in demand for goods and services across the board
column15: affecting not just these locked down sectors (Gourinchas 2020).

column1: For this reason
column2: most economists would agree that the economic effects of the outbreak and mitigation measures combine aspects of so-called ‘supply’ and ‘demand’ shocks (Baldwin and Weder di Mauro 2020). A supply shock is something that reduces the economy’s ability to produce goods and services at given prices. Public health authorities and employers preventing service workers from doing their jobs can be thought of as a supply shock. A demand shock
column3: on the other hand
column4: is something that reduces consumers’ ability or willingness to purchases goods and services at given prices. People staying at home and not going to restaurants or movie theaters for fear of contagion is an example of a demand shock. Additionally
column5: as service workers lose their jobs they may stop purchasing other goods such as cars or appliances
column6: which can also be thought of as a demand shock in those specific sectors.

column1: Conventional monetary and fiscal policy can be used to offset aggregate demand shocks
column2: but other policies may be more appropriate to stabilise the economy after a supply shock. Understanding whether a shock is caused by supply or demand is therefore very important for the design and implementation of stabilisation policies. Due to the nature of this specific shock
column3: it is not clear that the government wants to stimulate/stabilise activity in certain service sectors
column4: as that could run counter to the objectives of public health policy. The government could
column5: however
column6: target policies (such as fiscal or credit policy) to sectors that are not part of the lockdown but are subject to aggregate shocks. This implies that it is not just important to understand whether this shock in the aggregate has to do with supply and demand
column7: but it is also crucial to understand this at the sector level (Guerrieri et al. 2020).

column1: In a recent paper (Brinca et al. 2020)
column2: we try to answer these questions by using data on hours worked and wages to estimate labour demand and supply shocks for the aggregate economy and for different sectors
column3: using an econometric model. The basic assumptions we use for identifying supply and demand shocks are very simple: if we observe hours and wages (prices and quantities) moving in the same direction
column4: we assign more probability to those movements being caused by a demand shock. On the other hand
column5: if we observe hours and wages moving in opposite directions
column6: we assign that to a supply shock.

column1: Figure 1 plots the shock decomposition we estimate for March 2020
column2: when the lockdown began
column3: for the growth rate of hours worked. The sum of the red and blue bars is the percentage point change in the growth rate of hours worked relative to its historical average; the size of the red bar relative to the blue bar shows how important supply shocks were relative to demand shocks in that sector. The first ‘sector’ is total private employment
column4: and our results show that two-thirds of the decline in hours were attributable to supply shocks. By far the most affected sector was leisure and hospitality
column5: where the growth rate of hours worked fell by almost ten percentage points. Again
column6: supply played a slightly larger role than demand. While most sectors experienced negative supply shocks
column7: some sectors experienced positive demand shocks; for example
column8: retail trade likely benefitted as people stopped going to restaurants and started buying more groceries and cooking at home. The information sector also benefitted
column9: likely due to increased interest of firms by telework software and arrangements.

column1: Figure 2 repeats the exercise for April 2020
column2: the first full month of lockdown. The total effect on hours worked during this month was much larger across sectors
column3: with total private employment falling by almost 17 percentage points. Again
column4: for most sectors
column5: two-thirds of the decrease seemed to be associated with supply. Also
column6: during this month
column7: the positive demand shocks in sectors such as retail and information vanished
column8: or even reversed.

column1: There are some potential caveats with our approach
column2: ranging from potential nonlinearities caused by such large shocks (our model is linear)
column3: and composition effects driving the joint dynamics of hours and earnings. To address these
column4: we take our estimated measures of shocks in April 2020 and compare them to a sectoral measure of how many jobs can be done at home (Dingel and Neiman 2020)
column5: something that should affect labour supply more than labour demand. We show that there is a stronger (positive) correlation between the April 2020 supply shocks and the fraction of jobs that can be done at home. We believe that this helps validate our methodology and decomposition.

column1: All in all
column2: our results seem to suggest that labour supply shocks accounted for a larger share of the fall in hours caused by the pandemic shock in the months of March and April
column3: but that both shocks were important. In particular
column4: there were significant demand shocks in sectors that should not be directly affected by the lockdown
column5: such as manufacturing. This suggests that targeted stabilisation policy could help assuage some of the effects of the current crisis.

column1: The yellow fever vaccine was introduced into routine immunization in 2000. Yellow fever vaccination coverage in Gabon is reported to be suboptimal (less than 85%) (WHO/UNICEF estimates

column1: • An epidemiological investigation was conducted in the case’s village of residence.

Yellow fever is an acute viral haemorrhagic disease that has the potential to spread rapidly and cause serious public health impact in unvaccinated populations.

The detection of the confirmed case of yellow fever in Nyanga Province shows the possibility of spill-over of sylvatic yellow fever in endemic areas to unvaccinated people in a rural area even in the context of moderately high population immunity (70%). This highlights the importance of achieving and maintaining high population immunity in all high-risk areas for yellow fever.

There is currently a risk of disruption to routine immunization activities due to COVID-19 related impacts on the health system and a decreased demand for immunization due to physical distancing requirements or community reluctance. Disruption of immunization services
column2: even for brief periods
column3: will increase the numbers of susceptible people and the likelihood of outbreaks of vaccine preventable diseases. As of 12 June 2020
column4: there have been 3
column5: 463 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Gabon.

column1: Gabon is a high priority country for the Eliminate Yellow Fever Epidemic (EYE) strategy. Vaccination is the primary intervention for the prevention and control of yellow fever. In urban centres
column2: targeted vector control measures are also helpful to interrupt transmission. WHO and partners will continue to support local authorities to implement these interventions to control the current outbreak.

column1: WHO recommends vaccination against yellow fever for all international travellers to Gabon

column1: Yellow fever vaccination is safe

column3: the validity of the international certificate of vaccination against yellow fever extends to the life of the person vaccinated. A booster dose of yellow fever vaccine cannot be required of international travellers as a condition of entry.

column1: WHO has published guiding principles for immunization activities during the COVID-19 pandemic and has developed specific operational guidance for conducting mass vaccination campaigns in the COVID-19 context. The EYE Strategy will support rapid resumption of preventive yellow fever activities according to WHO guidance.
WHO encourages its Member States to take all actions necessary to keep travellers well informed of risks and preventive measures
column2: including vaccination. Travellers should also be made aware of yellow fever signs and symptoms and instructed to rapidly seek medical advice if experiencing signs and symptoms suggestive of yellow fever infection. Travellers returning to Gabon who may be infected with yellow fever may pose a risk for the establishment of local cycles of yellow fever transmission in areas where the competent vector is present.

column1: 2020-06-18|"The COVID-19 Catastrophe: What’s Gone Wrong and How to Stop It Happening Again Richard Horton Polity (2020)
Since the coronavirus crisis began
column2: Richard Horton

column5: the national broadcaster

Horton has never shied away from controversy (his journal published the retracted
column7: fraudulent paper by Andrew Wakefield that alleged a non-existent link between vaccines with autism) or crusades (against the Iraq war and for political action on climate change). In coronavirus

column7: and cause such ongoing pain for their citizens?

column1: We were warned what to expect in the pandemic
column2: shows health-care league table

column1: The easy answer is in their leadership. Horton levels the accusation that US President Donald Trump is committing a “crime against humanity” for defunding the very World Health Organization that is trying to help the United States and others. UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson
column2: in Horton’s view
column3: either lied or committed misconduct in telling the public that the government was well prepared for the pandemic. In fact
column4: the UK government abandoned the world-standard advice to test
column5: trace and isolate in March
column6: with no explanation
column7: then scrambled to ramp up testing in April
column8: but repeatedly failed to meet its own targets
column9: lagging weeks behind the rest of the world. A BBC investigation in April showed that the UK government failed to stockpile neccessary personal protective equipment for years before the crisis
column10: and should have been aware that the National Health Service wasn’t adequately prepared.

column1: Politicians are easy targets
column2: though. Horton goes further
column3: to suggest that although scientists in general have performed admirably
column4: many of those advising the government directly contributed to what he calls “the greatest science policy failure for a generation”.

column1: Again using the United Kingdom as an example
column2: he suggests that researchers were insufficiently informed or understanding of the crisis unfolding in China
column3: and were too insular to speak to Chinese scientists directly. The model for action at times seemed to be influenza
column4: a drastic underestimation of the true threat of the new coronavirus. Worse
column5: as the UK government’s response went off the rails in March
column6: ostensibly independent scientists would “speak with one voice in support of government policy”
column7: keeping up the facade that the country was doing well. In Horton’s view
column8: this is a corruption of science policymaking at every level. Individuals failed in their responsibility to procure the best scientific advice
column9: he contends; and the advisory regime was too close to — and in sync with — the political actors who were making decisions. “Advisors became the public relations wing of a government that had failed its people

column1: The situation deteriorated to the point that former UK chief government scientific adviser David King set up an alternative scientific-advice committee on 3 May to both be more transparent to the public and exercise the independence of mind and tongue that he felt the official committees had ceded. It is a move Horton approves. It’s not clear that the group has swayed government policy

column1: Elsewhere

column4: and the rare successes

column7: and after experiencing the past six months through the fragmented lenses of social media and short news reports

column1: We practised for a pandemic
column2: but didn’t brace

column1: Such synthesis is a bulwark
column2: too
column3: against the blizzard of misinformation — the ‘infodemic’ — that has blanketed the crisis. Horton rightly points out that it isn’t just quacks and conspiracy theorists promulgating false information. There is a chilling effort by governments as well. Examples include the United Kingdom’s bizarre recent assertions that it never pursued a ‘herd immunity’ strategy

column5: too

column1: Like much of the scientific work produced during the pandemic

column1: 2020-06-18|"Resilience versus robustness in global value chains: Some policy implications
Some governments assert that global value chains create economic vulnerabilities in times of a pandemic. This column
column2: taken from a recent Vox eBook
column3: examines recent experiences and the risk-management literature. It concludes that it is a mistake to equate self-sufficiency with robustness – putting all the eggs in one basket is still not a good idea. It is also a mistake to focus on production location when the imperative is to radically scale up production of vital medical supplies. Importantly
column4: international supply chains will be needed to produce the billions of doses of COVID-19 vaccine we will soon need to manufacture and distribute.

column1: With the COVID-19 crisis
column2: a new debate has emerged with respect to global value chains (GVCs)
column3: examining whether excessive globalisation of production has not created new economic vulnerabilities. For example
column4: Beata Javorcik recently wrote in the Financial Times that “businesses will be forced to rethink their global value chains” and that “while just-in-time manufacturing may be the optimal way of producing a highly complex item such as a car
column5: the disadvantages of a system that requires all of its elements to work like clockwork have now been exposed”.1 Even the World Economic Forum has recommended to “aggressively evaluate near-shore options to shorten supply chains and increase proximity to customers” as a response to COVID-19.2

column1: This column first appeared in the Vox eBook COVID-19 and Trade Policy: Why Turning Inward Won’t Work
column2: available to download here.

column1: While some lessons will have to be drawn
column2: and both firms and consumers are likely to make different choices after the crisis
column3: it may be premature to call for the end of GVCs or to conclude that shorter supply chains would be less vulnerable. This chapter reviews the relevant management and business literature and highlights evidence to show that the relationship between GVCs and resilience or robustness in the supply of inputs is more complicated than it looks. Even in the midst of the COVID-19 crisis
column4: we see how efficient GVCs are in answering the most urgent needs of countries. Policies in the future should support business efforts to build more robust and resilient supply chains and not add to health and other dangers a policy risk built on misconceptions about GVCs.

column1: The vulnerability of supply chains during COVID-19
What are we exactly talking about when speaking of risk? On the supply side
column2: firms face risks such as plant fires
column3: natural disasters
column4: financial risks
column5: political instability
column6: cyber-attacks
column7: quality issues with suppliers and delivery failures. On the demand side
column8: those risks include reputation of products
column9: new competitors
column10: policies restricting market access
column11: macroeconomic crisis
column12: and exchange rate volatility.

column1: COVID-19 is first and foremost a global health crisis and has impacted the production of firms in GVCs in several ways.
• Production was stopped or disrupted because firms were directly affected by the presence of the virus at production sites.
Whether it was a decision coming from the government or from the firm itself
column2: either there was a need to stop producing or to maintain production with new rules guaranteeing the safety of employees (with an impact on production such as delays or reduced output). This type of risk is related to the production site and applies to all firms in the same location. However
column3: firms that source inputs from different locations confront an additional risk - even if the virus does not affect the production site
column4: they nevertheless need inputs originating from a potentially affected area.

column1: This is a supply chain risk. For example
column2: such risk materialised in the fourth week of January 2020 when China decided to lock down the city of Wuhan and start taking measures to prevent the spread of the virus to the rest of the country. Manufacturing companies in the rest of the world (unaware at this stage of the tsunami that was about to hit them) were quickly hit. Car manufacturer Hyundai halted all production in Korea on 7 February 2020 due to a shortage of components coming out of China. This type of contagion flowing through GVCs has also been observed with some natural disasters
column3: such as the earthquake and tsunami in Japan in 2011
column4: or the floods in Thailand that same year.

column1: Within a matter of only a few weeks during February 2020
column2: the virus spread rapidly to other regions
column3: first to Europe and then to North America. Such was the speed of its spread that supply chains were hardly disrupted. It wasnít until 19 March that Ford stopped its production of cars in both North America and Europe. And there only four days separated Volkswagen closing its factories in Europe (17 March) and in the US (21 March).3 And whether domestic or not
column4: suppliers of parts and components also closed their plants because they were affected by similar measures - not because their inputs could not be delivered; the contagion became more of a concussion (Baldwin 2020).

column1: Transportation is also a source of risk. For those companies still producing during the lockdowns (and possibly for all companies once lockdowns are lifted and the virus is still present)
column2: the vulnerability of international supply chains will depend on whether international transportation networks are still operating and without significant increases in trade costs.

column1: • While limiting trade in goods was not part of the health response (with the important exception of export bans and restrictions to trade for some key medical supplies and medicines)
column2: measures taken by governments limiting the movement of people or reinforcing border controls have
column3: to some extent
column4: led to the disruption in international trade.

column1: Trade in services is directly impacted when it relies on the movement of consumers (e.g. tourism) or the movement of producers (e.g. many business services but also transport services).
Goods are moved across countries through services
column2: and trade in goods is indirectly impacted by the measures affecting (those) services. This is especially the case for air freight
column3: which has been relying on cargo holds in passenger planes and is favoured during the crisis to reduce the delivery time of key inputs and supplies. Quarantine measures for air or sea crews and additional sanitary controls related to COVID-19 (or measures to protect the people in charge of controls) are also delaying trade.

column1: While domestic transport networks and logistics are also disrupted
column2: there is an additional vulnerability for international freight and a risk specific to international production networks. However
column3: it is difficult to assess the level of disruption to international trade currently. Most logistics firms report no strong impact on their operational capabilities with the exception of some air routes or specific destinations that may be more impacted by the virus.4 Volatility in freight rates has risen
column4: but with falling demand
column5: international trade costs are more likely to decrease than to increase.

column1: All the above risks are on the supply side and were mainly the focus of most debates on the level of vulnerability in international supply chains. However
column2: on the demand side
column3: an even greater risk may be on the horizon – culminating in a profound worldwide economic crisis triggered by lockdowns and restrictions to movement of people (which also restrict consumers ability to consume).

column1: Contagion through GVCs will again become a concern if regions lift these restrictions sequentially and if the economic impact
column2: although profound
column3: is more or less severe across different areas. The mechanisms
column4: which were observed during the 2008-2009 Global Financial Crisis via contagion through declining demand and amplification effects (Bems et al. 2009) will resurface. However
column5: the COVID-19 crisis is of a different nature
column6: with the recession likely to stem from services and domestic activities rather be associated than trade finance issues
column7: as in 2008-2009. The macroeconomic implications are also different (Guerrieri et al. 2020).

column1: No current evidence that complex supply chains are more impacted by COVID-19
Numerous statements have been made about complex value chains being more impacted during the COVID-19 crisis
column2: possibly due to additional risks and costs related to international trade.5 However
column3: the available evidence – while limited at this stage ñ does not support such a view. The most impacted industries are those relying on the movement of people
column4: such as hotels and restaurants
column5: or passenger transport. And for countries under a lockdown
column6: the bulk of the impact is through the fall in domestic demand and not international tourists.
