2020-06-18|"The Swedish policy response to Covid-19 is exceptional by international comparison. This column explains how the approach is decided by three articles in the Swedish constitution. The first guarantees the freedom of movement for Swedish citizens
column2: ruling out nationwide lockdowns. The second establishes unique independence for public agencies
column3: allowing them to design the policy response to the pandemic. The third grants exceptional powers to local government. In addition
column4: the Swedish approach is fostered by strong trust in the government.

column1: Covid-19 has triggered drastic policy measures in many countries
column2: including lockdowns and severe restrictions on the freedom of movement of people. Sweden is one clear exception to this pattern: no nationwide mandatory lockdown has been enforced. Swedes are able to move freely within their country as well as across the Swedish border – although they are likely to be stopped from entering other countries.

column1: True
column2: there are restrictions concerning the maximum size of public gatherings. Restaurants that do not adhere to social distancing rules can be forced to shut down. High schools and universities have been closed while daycare facilities and elementary schools have remained open. Still
column3: the public authorities rely essentially on recommendations and information concerning hand-washing
column4: social distancing
column5: self-isolation
column6: travelling and working from home rather than on any legally binding measures.

column1: The Swedish approach of keeping an open society during the pandemic has drawn immense international interest. Why is the policy response in Sweden so different? Many explanations for its exceptionalism have been presented. As a rule
column2: the main reason for the Swedish policy response has not been brought out. It is dictated by the legislative framework
column3: more precisely by the rules of the constitution concerning the freedom of personal movement and concerning the independence of public authorities and of local authorities.

column1: A lively debate about the pros and cons of the Swedish approach has evolved in terms of public health outcomes. However
column2: these consequences are not dealt with here. Instead
column3: my focus is solely on the determinants of the Swedish policy response to Covid-19.

column1: The economic consequences of the present pandemic are enormous. These are determined to a large extent by the measures taken by government authorities
column2: which in turn depend on the incentives and restrictions facing policymakers. Thus
column3: the institutional framework for the policymaking process is the key to understanding the whole Covid-19 story for Sweden.

column1: The role of the constitution

Two paragraphs in the Swedish constitution dictate the character of the policy response. The first concerns personal freedom of movement and the second concerns the particular independence enjoyed by public agencies or authorities. In addition
column2: the constitution gives extensive powers to local government in designing policy measures regarding public health issues
column3: in this way limiting the role of the central government.

column1: The Swedish government is not allowed to declare a state of emergency in peacetime. Thus
column2: the main factor behind Swedish exceptionalism during the present pandemic is that the Swedish constitution prohibits the use of lockdowns as seen from Chapter 2
column3: Article 8 in the Swedish constitution (Regeringsformen).

column1: Everyone shall be protected in their relations with the public institutions against deprivations of personal liberty. All Swedish citizens shall also in other respects be guaranteed freedom of movement within the Realm and freedom to depart the Realm.

The above paragraph thus guarantees full freedom of movement for Swedish citizens within Sweden and across the Swedish border under peacetime conditions. The paragraph is not absolute. There are exceptions for example for prisoners and conscripts for military service
column2: as stated in Chapter 2
column3: Article 20-21 in Regeringsformen. Local restrictions on the movement of people can be adopted for health reasons. However
column4: there is no exception for a contingency like a pandemic. Thus
column5: these rules cannot be adopted for a full nationwide lockdown similar to those put in place in other countries.

column1: The Regeringsform (Chapter 2
column2: Article 24) allows the government to restrict the freedom of meeting and of demonstration due to an “epidemic”:

column1: Freedom of assembly and freedom to demonstrate may be limited in the interests of preserving public order and public safety at a meeting or demonstration
column2: or with regard to the circulation of traffic. These freedoms may otherwise be limited only with regard to the security of the Realm or in order to combat an epidemic.

column1: The freedom of assembly has also been restricted by a ban of all public meetings with more than 50 participants as part of the government’s strategy to deal with Covid-19.
The constitution guarantees the independence of public agencies

Public agencies are independent from the government in their daily business according to the constitution. The tradition goes far back in history. A first step was taken in the Regeringsform of 1634 designing the structure of public agencies after the death of King Gustavus Adolphus II in the Thirty Years War while Crown Princess Christina was coming of age. A second step was the Regeringsform of 1720
column2: following the death of Charles XII
column3: restricting the power of the King and establishing independent public agencies.

column1: Today
column2: the Swedish system is based on administrative dualism
column3: where the public agencies are set up outside the ministries of the central government. As stated by Nergelius (2018: 300)
column4: the independence of public agencies from the government “is unusual or even unique in an international perspective”.

column1: As explained in the English introduction to the Regeringsform
column2: the government

column1: has no powers to intervene in an agency's decisions in specific matters relating to the application of the law or the due exercise of its authority. In many other countries
column2: it is common for an individual minister to have the power to intervene directly through a decision in an agency's day-to-day operations. This possibility does not exist in Sweden
column3: however. Collective Government decision-making and the ban on instructing agencies on individual matters are expressions of the prohibition of 'ministerial rule'
column4: as it is often called.

column1: This approach reflects the wording of the constitution in Chapter 12
column2: Article 2 of the Regeringsform:

column1: No public authority
column2: including the Riksdag
column3: or decision-making body of any local authority
column4: may determine how an administrative authority shall decide in a particular case relating to the exercise of public authority vis-à-vis an individual or a local authority
column5: or relating to the application of law.

column1: The constitution thus prevents interference by ministers of government in affairs that are assigned to various public authorities. Public agencies are given a status to some extent similar to the independence of the courts and of the Riksbank
column2: the Swedish central bank. Still
column3: the government appoints the heads of public agencies
column4: determines their budgets and the legislation relevant for their tasks.

column1: The Public Health Agency of Sweden (Folkhälsomyndigheten) is such a public authority
column2: now in charge of framing and designing the policy response to the pandemic. It is run by experts in epidemiology
column3: not by political appointees. The collaborative work of health economists and epidemiologists at the Swedish Public Health Agency has produced a response that considers the overall impact of its measures and recommendations.

column1: To sum up
column2: the constitution insulates the public authorities from direct political meddling to a much greater degree than in any other democracy
column3: allowing experts to design the policy response. Although the government is not formally bound to follow the recommendations of public agencies
column4: by tradition this is the case.

column1: The constitution guarantees self-government at the local level
In addition
column2: the Swedish constitution gives a strong role to local self-government. This tradition goes back to the late Middle Ages. The autonomy of the local authorities is anchored in Chapter 14 in Regeringsformen on local authorities.

column1: Art. 2. The local authorities are responsible for local and regional matters of public interest on the principle of local self-government.
Self-government through the municipalities at the local level and the regions at the regional level actually covers the major share of the large Swedish public sector
column2: including the healthcare sector and the care of the elderly. Thus
column3: the power of the central government in these health-related areas is limited by the independence of the local authorities. This decentralised structure of 290 municipalities and 21 regions contributes to the exceptional Swedish response to the pandemic.

column1: As the Swedish constitution prohibits the use of lockdowns and state of emergency as policy tools
column2: the government has to rely primarily on information and recommendations to influence the behaviour of the public. The impact of this type of policy tools is closely related to the degree of trust in society.

column1: The Swedish public holds a strong trust in public institutions
column2: in government effectiveness and honesty
column3: in the accountability of elected politicians
column4: in the democratic process and in the rule of law. This can be seen from the Eurobarometer surveys covering all EU member states. Here the Swedish respondents display a high trust in their national government
column5: while citizens in many EU member states hold considerably lower trust in their governments (as demonstrated in Figure 1).

In the debate on the Swedish exception
column2: a host of other factors have been suggested. They emphasise
column3: for example
column4: the strong liberal tradition in Swedish history or the long period of peace

column1: 2020-06-18|"T a lot going on in Britain in early March. London staged an England-Wales rugby match on March 7th
column2: which the prime minister attended along with a crowd of 81
column3: 000; on March 11th Liverpool played Atletico Madrid
column4: in front of a crowd of 52
column5: 000 fans
column6: including 3
column7: 000 from Spain; 252
column8: 000 punters went to the Cheltenham Festival
column9: one of the country’s poshest steeplechase meetings
column10: which ended on March 13th.

column1: As Britons were getting together to amuse themselves and infect each other
column2: Europe was shutting down. Borders were closing
column3: public gatherings being banned. Italy went into full lockdown on March 9th
column4: Denmark on March 11th
column5: Spain on March 14th and France on March 17th. Britain followed only on March 23rd.

column1: Putting in place sweeping restrictions on everyday life was a difficult decision
column2: fraught with uncertainty. Yet the delay is just one example of the government’s tardiness. Britain has been slow to increase testing
column3: identify a contact-tracing app
column4: stop visits to care homes
column5: ban big public events
column6: provide its health workers with personal protective equipment ( )
column7: and require people to wear face coverings on public transport. As this wave of the disease ebbs
column8: Britons are wondering how they came to have the highest overall death rate of any country in the rich world
column9: and why leaving lockdown is proving so difficult.

column1: The evidence so far suggests that the British government played a bad hand badly. The country was always going to struggle. The virus took off in London
column2: an international hub. Britain has a high proportion of ethnic-minority people
column3: who are especially vulnerable to the disease. And Britons are somewhat overweight
column4: which exacerbates the impact of the infection.

column1: Britain has got some things right. Its researchers have been in the forefront of the race to find drugs and create vaccines against the disease. On June 16th a trial by Oxford University
column2: the first to identify a life-saving medicine
column3: showed that a cheap steroid can reduce mortality among the sickest patients by a third. A swift reorganisation of the National Health Service put paid to fears that it would be overwhelmed. But the government has wasted the most precious commodity in a crisis: time. In a federal system
column4: like America’s
column5: the central government’s failings can be mitigated by state and local authorities. In a centralised system
column6: they cannot.

column1: Hindsight is a fine thing
column2: and offers a clarity that is absent in the blizzard of events. Yet it is now plain that Britain’s scientists initially argued for the wrong approach: accepting that the disease would spread through the population
column3: while protecting the vulnerable and the health service. Neil Ferguson
column4: an epidemiologist at Imperial College London
column5: estimates that had Britain locked down a week earlier
column6: at least half of the 50
column7: 000-or-so lives that have been lost would have been saved. This is more Britons than have died in any event since the second world war.

column1: In retrospect
column2: the government should have probed the scientists’ advice more deeply. Some of it was questionable. The received wisdom that people would tire of social distancing
column3: and that shutting down early would mean loosening early too
column4: was just a hunch. Even after the evidence changed
column5: and it became clear the country was heading for catastrophe
column6: the government was slow to impose the sort of lockdown seen across Europe.

column1: Yet you do not need hindsight to identify other mistakes. Delays in fixing supply chains
column2: promoting face coverings and increasing testing capacity were clearly errors at the time. Despite the urging of the country’s scientists and the World Health Organisation
column3: by the middle of April Britain was still carrying out just 12
column4: 000 tests a day
column5: compared with 44
column6: 000 in Italy and 51
column7: 000 in Germany. Because most testing was reserved for hospitals
column8: care homes struggled to find out which of their residents and staff were infected. Competition for was fierce
column9: so they also struggled to get the kit they needed to protect their workers.

column1: The government is not solely to blame. The pandemic made new demands on the system. Some crucial bits of machinery did not work. The publicly owned company which supplies the health service with failed. Public Health England
column2: which was responsible for testing and tracing
column3: failed. But there was a failure of leadership
column4: too. When systems break it is the government’s job to mend them; when the evidence argues for drastic measures ministers need to take them.

column1: Britain is still living with the consequences. The spread of the virus and the devastation it has wrought have made leaving lockdown difficult
column2: as shown by the halting return of pupils to school. Only five year-groups have gone back
column3: many parents are choosing to keep their children at home
column4: and the government has abandoned an earlier ambition to get more in. The “world-beating” contact-tracing system still lacks its app
column5: which is not due to arrive until winter. Slow progress at suppressing the virus will have grave economic consequences
column6: too.

column1: These shortcomings have claimed many victims. Among them is public trust. Britain went into this crisis with a powerful sense of unity and goodwill towards the government. Now Britons think worse of their government’s performance during the crisis than do the citizens of any of 22 countries polled by YouGov
column2: aside from Mexico. That reflects the government’s mistakes and its hypocrisy
column3: after the prime minister’s main adviser broke its own rules about when to travel—and kept his job. While the world waits for a vaccine this lack of trust will make managing the disease a lot harder.

column1: The painful conclusion is that Britain has the wrong sort of government for a pandemic—and
column2: in Boris Johnson
column3: the wrong sort of prime minister. Elected in December with the slogan of “Get Brexit Done”
column4: he did not pay covid-19 enough attention. Ministers were chosen on ideological grounds; talented candidates with the wrong views were left out in the cold. Mr Johnson got the top job because he is a brilliant campaigner and a charismatic entertainer with whom the Conservative Party fell in love. Beating the coronavirus calls for attention to detail
column5: consistency and implementation
column6: but they are not his forte.

column1: The pandemic has many lessons for the government
column2: which the inevitable public inquiry will surely clarify. Here is one for voters: when choosing a person or party to vote for
column3: do not underestimate the importance of ordinary
column4: decent competence. ■"|1

column1: 2020-06-18|"The bank business model in the post-Covid-19 world
The Covid-19 pandemic has induced a deep global economic crisis. While so far banks have shown their resilience
column2: partly thanks to major reforms after the crisis of 2007-2009
column3: the crisis will put them under stress. Moreover
column4: the traditional banking model was already being challenged pre-Covid by three trends: persistently low interest rates
column5: enhanced regulation
column6: and increased competition from shadow banks and digital entrants. This column introduces the second report in the Future of Banking series from the IESE Business School and CEPR
column7: which provides a perspective on how the current crisis and these trends will shape the future of the banking sector.

column1: The world is witnessing a large and synchronised economic crisis. Forecasts for 2020 suggest a drop in global GDP of 6% with a record number of countries growing at negative rates (OECD 2020). Advanced economies will suffer a much larger drop in GDP
column2: of a size not seen since the Great Depression. No doubt
column3: banks will come under stress as large-scale insolvencies among firms will arise and a wave of bankruptcies among households may follow. In addition
column4: while banks entered the crisis better capitalised and more liquid
column5: the size of the crisis will likely strain them to a degree exceeding that envisioned in many stress tests conducted so far (ECB 2020).

column1: The crisis comes on top of the combination over the past decade of several trends that have meant increased competitive pressure on banks and that
column2: in particular in some regions
column3: have lowered their profitability. In the second report in CEPR/IESE series on The Future of Banking (Claessens et al. 2020)
column4: we argue that the global pandemic is likely to prolong
column5: if not accelerate
column6: many of these trends – digitalisation in particular. While the economic crisis has triggered policy responses to stimulate lending to the real economy while assuring the stability of the banking sector that provides breathing space in the short run
column7: deep restructuring of many banking systems will be needed in the medium-term.

column1: Download The Bank Business Model in the Post-Covid-19 World here.

We have now been living in a world of low interest rates and subdued growth rates for more than a decade. These persistently low rates have negatively affected bank profitability through reduced net interest margins and weakened monitoring incentives and lending standards
column2: in particular for those institutions more reliant on maturity transformation and net interest income. In the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis
column3: we also witnessed over this period an increase in prudential requirements
column4: regulatory scrutiny and compliance costs
column5: as analysed in the first report in this series (Bolton et al. 2019). These policy steps have contributed to a more resilient banking sector
column6: which is very beneficial in the current context. At the same time
column7: however
column8: the tighter rules have lessened banks’ competitiveness relative to shadow banks and added to a migration of some business activities away from the banking sector towards shadow banks. Moreover
column9: stricter regulation has put pressure on banks’ profitability.

column1: The Covid-19 crisis most likely means interest rates will remain low for much longer. Although in the short run banks are bound to benefit from being the channel of liquidity support and having access to central bank support
column2: the deep crisis hitting the real economy is likely to bring a new surge in non-performing loans and could threaten banks’ solvency once again.

column1: An additional development during the pre-Covid world was the massive application of digital technologies and the emergence of new competitors. While these have allowed for many new products and services and helped improve the efficiency of incumbent banks
column2: they have also favoured the entry of new firms
column3: increasing competition with traditional bank business models.

column1: The impact of technology on bank business models has been profound (Vives 2019). Technological advances have affected payment systems
column2: capital markets activities
column3: credit extension and deposit collection. In the report
column4: we analyse in detail the area where much activity is happening – namely
column5: digital money and payments. For decades
column6: banks have controlled digital forms of money and payments through regulatory protection of deposits
column7: exclusive access to the central bank settlement system and close partnerships with credit card companies. The challenge today comes from a variety of digital assets that do not sit on the balance sheet of banks: cryptocurrencies
column8: electronic wallets
column9: stablecoins
column10: or balances with a telecom provider. The competitive advantage of the new entrants is not based on the asset itself
column11: but on the payment technology associated with it. The convenience of payments and the connections to other parts of the growing digital life of consumers and business alike
column12: accelerated by the Covid crisis
column13: has been the key to success. The dominance in payments of tech companies in China or mobile telecom providers in parts of Africa are examples of the extent of disruption.

column1: Disruption from technology has happened in many other areas
column2: not just payments. Entry in the different financial service segments has come from new types of providers: ‘FinTech’ and ‘BigTech’. FinTech providers of credit are more present when the country’s general development is higher and its banking system is less competitive
column3: but less so when the country’s regulation is stricter. Non-bank entry is not yet meaningful in demand deposit-like taking activities
column4: possible due to concerns about regulatory burdens. BigTech platforms
column5: with their advanced technology and especially their (associated) greater access to (big) data
column6: could make major inroads
column7: but have not done so to date.

column1: The entry of new players greatly affects banks through downward pressures on fees and prices and more compressed margins. Banks have responded
column2: but many argue that they are far from adopting technology effectively themselves. As a result
column3: their profitability comes further under threat.

column1: The technological advances and new entry require regulatory responses. The technologies used by the new entrants can create new risks
column2: including fresh consumer and investor protection issues
column3: as the accumulating evidence on risk of discrimination associated with greater use of technology and big data shows. Since more entities now provide financial services and in new forms
column4: it is also crucial to ensure a level playing field. A related important question is where to draw the regulatory ‘perimeter’
column5: given that the overall industrial organisation of the various financial services markets is changing. The technology-induced changes also call for reassessments of competition and data policies.

column1: In the short run
column2: banks may enjoy a revitalisation as they continue lending to their customers during the crisis
column3: notably as soft information can more valuable today than hard information. They also enjoy the protection of the safety net and access to deposit financing.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: Covid-19 will likely accelerate the digitalisation and the shift over the medium term of activities away from the sector. Medium-sized banks will likely be suffering the most since reaping cost efficiencies with large IT investments
column3: crucial in a persistently low interest environment
column4: will be out of reach. As a result
column5: the banking sector will need deep restructuring; winding up banks and consolidating the remaining ones will be preferred. Whether in the post-Covid-19 world
column6: political obstacles to cross-border mergers will prevent
column7: as states become more protective of their national banking champions
column8: is a major policy question.

column1: BigTech companies have many of the ingredients to get ahead in the post-Covid world. They are digital natives; they have the technology
column2: customer base and brand recognition
column3: as well as vast amounts of data and deep pockets. Banking may thus move from the traditional oligopoly to a system with a few dominant platforms that control access to a fragmented customer base
column4: with a few BigTech firms
column5: together with some platform-transformed incumbents
column6: monopolising the interface with customers. In this scenario
column7: ensuring customer data ownership and portability for individuals
column8: and data interoperability between platforms
column9: will be key to keeping switching costs for customers low and the market sufficiently competitive.

column1: Digital disruption poses a formidable challenge to regulators
column2: which must adapt by balancing facilitating competition and allowing the benefits of innovation to pervade the system with protecting financial stability. In order to so
column3: regulators must coordinate prudential regulation and competition policy so that compliance does not becomes a barrier to entry while at the same time entry does not becomes destabilising. Competition can be fostered by light regulation of the entrants
column4: but at the potential cost of decreasing the profitability of incumbents and thus increasing their risk-taking incentives. In addition
column5: this may mean the generation of systemic risks to non-bank entities.

column1: The current crisis will test the resilience of the financial system and the regulatory reforms implemented after the global financial crisis of 2007-2009
column2: which were examined in the first report from the Banking Initiative. In particular
column3: it will stretch the limits of central bank intervention
column4: and put to the test the incomplete Banking Union in the euro area.

column1: 2020-06-19|"The Australian dollar drifted lower through trade on Thursday following a larger than anticipated up tick in unemployment and a consolidated shift in risk demand. The Australian dollar fell to 0.6843 after labour market data showed the unemployment rate jumped to 7.1%
column2: as almost 230
column3: 000 jobs were lost in May
column4: a print well beyond conservative estimates. Alarmingly the upturn in unemployment came despite a reduction in the participation rate. With many Australian’s giving up the search for re-employment
column5: unemployment statistics fail to capture the true scale of labour market turmoil. Having fallen below 63% the dip in the participation rate masks a much higher rate of unemployment. Had active participation in the workforce remained at January’s high (66.1%) then unemployment would sit nearer 11.5%. With labour market conditions continuing to worsen
column6: yesterday’s print offers a stark reminder of the economic costs sparked by the COVID-19 pandemic. Having touched intraday lows
column7: the AUD found some support in the promise of easing Chinese Monetary policy. The PBOC announced a 20-basis point cut to its reverse repo rate in a bid to stimulate the flow of credit and drive the Chinese recovery. The AUD crept back toward 0.69 before a shift in risk demand prompted another downward correction and push to safe haven assets. With the number of new infections across the US continuing to rise at an alarming rate and Beijing still battling its own outbreak
column8: there is real concern a second wave of infections will derail any economic rebound through the short/medium term. Having slipped back below 0.6850
column9: the AUD opens this morning buying 0.6847 US cents.

column1: A modest risk-off mood prompted a broader push to safe haven currencies overnight
column2: propping up the USD
column3: JPY and CHF. Concerns surrounding an alarming uptick in new infections across the US and a second outbreak in Beijing have prompted investors to reassess expectations surrounding the pace and path of economic recovery. Texas
column4: Arizona and North Carolina all reported a record number of coronavirus related hospitalisations on Wednesday as case numbers across the country continue to rise amid lifting social distancing restrictions. The US dollar edged higher as growth correlated currencies fell.

column1: The Great British pound was the day’s big loser
column2: falling over 1% in the wake of the Bank of England’s policy announcement. The MPC elected to leave the cash rate at 0.1% while confirming an uptick of 100billion pounds to its current QE program. The increase takes the total purchase facility to 745bn and means the program will now run into the end of the year. While the move was largely expected

column4: the disappointment forced sterling below 1.2450 to intraday lows at 1.2406.

column1: Attentions today remain squarely affixed to the broader risk narrative
column2: with the risk on – risk off environment creating ongoing short term volatility.

2020-06-19|"EA showed off a much longer look at Star Wars: Squadrons during its EA Play presentation
column2: including our first look at gameplay. The dogfighting game looks to be a modernization of the classic X-Wing and TIE Fighter series. In an interview with GameSpot as part of our summer gaming celebration Play For All
column3: creative director Ian Frazier suggested that inspiration runs deep
column4: and shared more details on game balance and team composition.

column1: For one thing
column2: unlike the Rogue Squadron series
column3: there is no option to switch to third-person view. You'll be engaging in all of your dogfights through the first-person cockpit view
column4: in part for game balance. Frazier said that third-person would give players a competitive advantage over the limited field-of-view of first-person. But it goes a step further
column5: to the point that you could turn off all the game HUD elements for full immersion.

column1: The whole game is designed from the ground up to be first-person all the way through
column2: Frazier said. ""Now if you're in spectator mode
column3: you're observing
column4: there's a third-person perspective there. You are the pilot. All the diegetic information is built into the hud
column5: so you could turn off all the game layer UI if you want and rely entirely on your instruments. We want that to be the core experience.""

column1: That decision inevitably leads to a disparity in the types of craft. Star Wars fans know that X-Wing pilots occupy a clear wraparound cockpit window with a wide field of view
column2: while TIE pilots have only a small circular window and two wide paneled wings that would block vision anyway. This
column3: paired with the lack of shields on a TIE
column4: would appear to give the New Republic ships a clear competitive advantage.

column1: But Frazier says it's not that simple
column2: and for the reason why he went back to the Lucasarts X-Wing and TIE Fighter games. He said when researching for the game
column3: he looked at old competitive forums where players would ask how the TIE isn't strictly worse than the X-Wing.

column1: The answer then
column3: was you have a lot less stuff to deal with in an Imperial ship. And that is
column4: in a sense
column5: an advantage. I've actually found that to be shockingly true in our game
column6: he said. ""The TIE Fighter doesn't have shields--which
column7: you don't have shields
column8: which is a downside
column9: right? But that also means you don't have to manage shields. It's one less thing to manage
column10: so there's less head-space required for that. … The counterbalance of what you're losing is what you're gaining in focus.""

column1: As for how those head-to-head fights play out functionally
column2: he also said that the studio has put some time into giving players more options. In a dogfighting game
column3: it's easy to get caught in what he calls the ""death loop
column4: where each ship is chasing each other until one of them gets shot down. To give more strategic improvisation
column5: Squadrons lets you shift power to three core systems: lasers
column6: engines
column7: and shields. If you max out your engines you get to use a boost
column8: and you can further iterate on that by doing a drift--cutting your engines to turn and then suddenly boosting
column9: for more evasive maneuvers.

column1: Finally
column2: Frazier touched on how team composition and planning your loadouts can help complement each other for advanced strategies.

column1: It's not one person against the world
column2: it's always a team of five
column3: he said. ""Everything is built against that idea of a tight-knit squadron. In PvP it's not just what loadout are you taking
column4: but what are your buddies taking? How can you get synergies between those things? So
column5: okay
column6: I've got the tractor beam that's going to hold them in place for a couple of seconds
column7: she's got the Goliath missile that can kick the crap out of them but it doesn't track very well
column8: and those two things in combination are really dangerous.""

column1: 2020-06-19|"Winning a mandate from their members to go into government is just the first hurdle facing the leaders of the three potential coalition parties. They will each have to raise their game by a considerable measure to have any chance of surviving the inevitable storms ahead.
Leo Varadkar had the bonus of being able to bask in the spectacularly good approval ratings revealed in the latest Irish Times/Ipsos MRBI poll
column2: just as the coalition deal was being announced
column3: but that raises the question as to why Fine Gael did so badly in the general election.

column1: “I’m pleased for Leo that he is getting public recognition for his leadership in the Covid crisis but I’m angry that he has only shown his true abilities after the horse has bolted
column2: ” said one senior Fine Gael figure. “He picked the wrong date for the election
column3: the preparations were appalling and the campaign was a disaster.”

column1: By contrast
column2: his handling of the Covid crisis was sure-footed and might even be described as inspiring. Once the seriousness of the threat became apparent he took decisive action and
column3: more importantly
column4: communicated the scale of the threat to the public and generated a mood of solidarity that was vital to make the lockdown successful.

column1: That mood was summed up in a child’s poem about the lockdown read out on Lyric FM a few weeks ago which contained the lines: “And thank God we have Leo
column2: not Boris or Trump”.

column1: The question facing Varadkar now is how
column2: back in government as tánaiste
column3: he will be able to contribute to a similar level of public support for the difficult process of exiting the lockdown and coping with the cost.

column1: Another if less important question is whether
column2: in his new role as tánaiste
column3: he will be able to sustain anything like the level of support shown for Fine Gael in the poll or whether in government the party will slide back to the dismal rating it achieved in the general election.

column1: For Micheál Martin the conundrum is the opposite. He will finally achieve his ambition of becoming taoiseach but at a time when his party is sinking in the polls and the man he is replacing has managed to generate a record level of public trust. Establishing his authority as taoiseach will be his first priority and that will not be easy given the scale of the task ahead.

Martin will have to demonstrate leadership skills in office as that will be crucial to rebuilding the image of Fianna Fáil as a competent party of government. Maintaining a distinctive image will be a challenge but
column2: after nine years in opposition
column3: a spell in government offers the best opportunity to do that.

column1: In the past Fianna Fáil’s great strength was its ability to bring people along with it while it was in government. That gave it the platform to win re-election on a regular basis. It is a political skill that always eluded Fine Gael and it will be a vital ingredient in making the three-party coalition a success.
For Eamon Ryan
column2: the process of attempting to bring his party into government has been a daunting experience. After the February election it was widely assumed that
column3: having led his party to a record 12 Dáil seats
column4: he would be in a strong position to set its future direction.

column1: Instead
column2: as often happens in politics
column3: great success can be every bit as dangerous as failure for a leader. Ryan has had to move very carefully in an effort to bring most of his new TDs with him along the path to government.

column1: Some of them are clearly not enamoured with his leadership and regard him as every much part of the establishment as Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil.
As if that wasn’t enough
column2: he is also facing a leadership challenge from his deputy Catherine Martin and there is no guarantee that even if the members vote to go into coalition he will remain as leader. All of that adds a huge element of instability to the potential government and Ryan will have his work cut out to maintain control even if he survives the leadership challenge.

column1: The ability of the coalition to govern effectively will depend on a high level of trust between the three party leaders. If Ryan is removed from the leadership it is difficult to see how cohesion will be maintained in the face of the difficult decisions ahead. Still
column2: the likelihood must be that if a majority of Green party members endorse going into coalition they will stick by the leader who has brought them there.

column1: As far as implementing a Green agenda goes
column2: there was never a better time for the party to be in power. They have extracted serious commitments from the other two parties on climate change while the current moves by the EU to implement a green deal mean that there is an effective guarantee they will get a lot of their priorities implemented.

column1: As they weigh up their options
column2: Green members could do worse than ponder the wise saying of Indian Nobel literature prize winner Rabindranath Tagore. “You can’t cross the sea merely by standing and staring at the water”."|1

column1: 2020-06-19|"The stock market and the economy: Insights from the COVID-19 crisis
During the COVID-19 pandemic and the related economic fallout
column2: the response of the stock markets has raised concerns as well as questions. This column explores the surprising trends. There is some evidence that shareholders have favoured the less vulnerable firms
column3: and that credit facilities and government guarantees
column4: lower policy interest rates
column5: and lockdown measures mitigated the decline in stock prices. However
column6: fundamentals only explain a small part of the stock market variations at the country level. Overall
column7: it is hard to deny that the links between stock prices and fundamentals have been loose at best.

column1: On 08 June 2020
column2: the World Health Organization (WHO) announced that the COVID-19 pandemic was worsening around the globe and warned against complacency: “most people globally are still susceptible to infection. (...) More than six months into this pandemic
column3: this is not the time for any country to take its foot off the pedal”. On the very same day
column4: the US stock market began its fourth consecutive week of rally. The S&P 500 index is back to where it was at the beginning of 2020
column5: erasing the historic plunge (one-third of its value) that took place between 20 February and 23 March 2020
column6: as if nothing had ever happened. This is simply unprecedented
column7: as illustrated in the figure below.

column1: Figure 1 The US stock market in the time of COVID-19
Note: This figure compares the drop of the S&P 500 index during the dot-com crisis (which peaked on March 24
column3: the subprime crisis (peaked on Oct. 9
column4: 2007) and the COVID-19 crisis (peaked on Feb. 19
column5: 2020). In March 2020
column6: it took only one month for the S&P 500 to lose one-third of its value
column7: while it took one year for the subprime crisis to decline the same amount
column8: and one year and half for the dotcom bust. Authors’ computation.

column1: Is anything strange about the stock market behaviour in the time of COVID-19? As the world suffered from the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression (Baldwin and Weder di Mauro 2020a
column3: Bénassy-Quéré and Weder di Mauro 2020
column4: Coibon et al. 2020)
column5: the reaction of stock markets raises serious concerns. Since the beginning of the crisis
column6: stock prices seem to be running wild. They first ignored the pandemic
column7: then panicked when Europe became its epicentre. Now
column8: they are behaving as if the millions of people infected
column9: the 400
column10: 000 deaths
column11: and the containment of half the world’s population will have no economic impact after all.

column1: In one of his influential New York Times columns
column2: Paul Krugman (2020) said out loud what many people were thinking: “Whenever you consider the economic implications of stock prices
column3: you want to remember three rules. First
column4: the stock market is not the economy. Second
column5: the stock market is not the economy. Third
column6: the stock market is not the economy (…). The relationship between stock performance – largely driven by the oscillation between greed and fear – and real economic growth has always been somewhere between loose and nonexistent”. The no less famous Malkiel and Shiller (2020) have also discussed the seemingly odd behaviour of stock markets in the face of the pandemic. According to Malkiel
column7: the alleged stock market irrationality is only “apparent”
column8: and the COVID-19 crisis does not “impl[y] that markets are inefficient” inasmuch as there are no arbitrage opportunities
column9: and stock markets remain hard to beat. Shiller is more nuanced: “Speculative prices may indeed statistically resemble a random walk
column10: but they are not so tied to genuine information (…). The contagious stories about the coronavirus had their own internal dynamics only loosely related to the information about the actual truth”.

column1: What new insights on stock markets behaviour can be drawn from the COVID-19 crisis? This debate is of special importance for financial economists
column2: but also because the general public has a very negative view of the stock markets
column3: which should not leave us unconcerned (Rajan 2015) – all the more so since the COVID-19 crisis put science and ‘experts’ to the test (Aksoy et al. 2020)
column4: without sparing economists.

column1: There is a fast-growing body of research looking at the responses of stock markets to the COVID-19 pandemic
column2: which is already giving some insights. While the dynamic of stock markets during the pandemic might look random
column3: irrational
column4: or even insane at first glance
column5: on closer inspection they did not react blindly. Several studies have shown that stock markets were effective in discounting the most exposed companies: those who were more financially fragile
column6: subject to the disruption of international value chains
column7: vulnerable in terms of corporate social responsibility
column8: or less resilient to social distancing (Alburque et al. 2020
column9: Ding et al. 2020
column10: Fahlenbrach et al. 2020
column11: Pagano et al. 2020
column12: Ramelli and Wagner 2020). Moreover
column13: it seems that stock market losses are related to analyst forecast revisions
column14: at least in the medium term (Landier and Thesmar 2020). In relation to these papers
column15: we take a macroeconomic perspective. Indeed
column16: the above-mentioned studies provide valuable information
column17: but some questions remain open.

column1: How have stock markets reacted to the COVID-19 pandemic? How do we explain differences in responses between countries? Are these differences in stock market response across countries related to macroeconomic or institutional characteristics
column2: and if so
column3: which ones? Are these differences due to the way governments have handled the pandemic? How have stock markets have reacted to lockdowns and economic policies implemented countrywide to ‘flatten’ the curve of infection and the curve of recession? (Gourinchas 2020)

column1: In our recent paper (Capelle-Blancard and Desroziers 2020)
column2: we assess how stock markets have integrated public information about the COVID-19 pandemic and the subsequent lockdowns. Although the COVID-19 shock has been global
column3: not all countries have been impacted in the same way
column4: and they have not reacted in the same way. We take advantage of this strong heterogeneity. We aim to explain the difference in stock markets response by the situation in each country before the crisis
column5: as well as subsequent containment measures (social distancing and stay-at-home orders) and economic policies (fiscal and monetary) implemented during the crisis. We consider a panel of 74 countries from January to April 2020
column6: which might be divided into four phases: Incubation
column7: Outbreak
column8: Fear
column9: and Rebound. For each country
column10: we collected daily data about stock index prices
column11: the number of COVID-19 cumulative cases and deaths
column12: global market sentiment and volatility
column13: government measures taken in response to the outbreak
column14: and various indicators of mobility (or lack thereof).

column1: Three main findings about stock market reactions during the COVID-19 pandemic arise. First
column2: after initially ignoring the pandemic (until 21 February 2020)
column3: stock markets reacted strongly to the increase in the number of infected people in each country (23 February to 20 March 2020)
column4: while volatility surged as concerns about the pandemic grew. However. following the intervention of central banks (23 March to 20 April 2020)
column5: shareholders no longer seemed troubled by news of the health crisis
column6: and prices rebounded all around the world. Second
column7: country-specific characteristics appear to have had
column8: at best
column9: little influence on stock market responses. Stock markets did not react more strongly in countries more susceptible to the pandemic
column10: either due to structural economic fragility (for instance
column11: indebted countries)
column12: or through exposure to transmission vectors (for instance
column13: countries with ‘at-risk’ populations). Third
column14: investors were sensitive to the number of COVID-19 cases in neighbouring (but mostly wealthy) countries. Fourth
column15: credit facilities and government guarantees
column16: lower policy interest rates
column17: and lockdown measures mitigated the decline in stock prices.

column1: In conclusion
column2: do stock markets incorporate all available information? Actually
column3: it transpires that we can see the glass as half-full or half-empty. On the one hand
column4: the dynamic of stock markets during the COVID-19 pandemic is not completely accidental. In particular
column5: our study suggests that it was not the situation of countries before the crisis that influenced the reaction of stock markets
column6: but rather the health policies implemented during the crisis to limit the transmission of the virus and the macroeconomic policies aiming to support companies. On the other hand
column7: fundamentals only explain a (very) small part of the stock market variations. Just like Krugman and Shiller have claimed
column8: it is hard to deny that the link between stock prices and fundamentals have been anything other than loose.

column1: 2020-06-19|"My seven-year-old triplets — two girls and a boy — were having trouble doing classwork at home. The coronavirus pandemic meant that they did not have access to a classroom
column2: with desks to sit down at. It is hard to study at the dining-room table with your siblings (their school
column3: sensibly
column4: tries to put them in separate classrooms so that they don’t distract each other) as dad gives the baby a bottle and e-mails his students. This was something we all had to get used to.

column1: A more upsetting issue was my children’s anxiety concerning the virus and social distancing. This anxiety became clear when I returned from grocery-shopping one day to find one of my daughters crying uncontrollably because she was afraid I would not make it back alive. My other daughter had nightmares that my wife
column2: a health-care worker
column3: would get COVID-19 and give it to the baby. My son was afraid that we would run out of food and starve.

column1: I was able to find a solution that helped with working and schooling from home. Taking a cue from a local science museum’s space-station simulator
column2: we turned our guest bedroom into a spaceship-themed classroom. We decorated it to resemble the International Space Station and USS Enterprise. Each child had their own computer station on the ‘bridge’
column3: and I had a standing workstation. We were able to embark on a learning experience using our imaginations.

column1: However
column2: the triplets’ anxiety endured. My son cried when
column3: after the closure of schools
column4: parks
column5: museums and the library
column6: he found out that the arcade at our local shopping mall was closed
column7: too. I told my children that experts were telling everyone to engage in social distancing
column8: and I showed them the COVID-19 prevention guidelines issued by the chief medical officer of the US Coast Guard. Rear admiral Dana Thomas is a highly qualified physician
column9: and the consensus of the triplets was that we should therefore listen to her. I told my children about a paper I had published
column10: about how expert opinion influences people’s attitudes towards climate change. We decided that we would do our own study about who people trust for information about COVID-19 prevention.

column1: Although the study would be small
column2: rushed and nowhere near the quality threshold for peer review
column3: I saw it as an opportunity to teach my children about the scientific method
column4: and to address their coronavirus anxiety head-on. We devised an experiment in which people would hear messages from four sources about preventing the spread of COVID-19. We decided that the sources would be a group of health-care workers
column5: the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column6: social media and a fictitious politician. For an educator such as myself
column7: explaining the experimental set-up to seven-year-olds after years of teaching undergraduates was an eye-opening experience.

column1: We collected data through an online survey. When it came to data analysis
column2: I showed the triplets how the pictures used in their mathematics workbook from school are similar to charts and figures that are used in research. This provided a breakthrough in their understanding of some mathematical concepts. Then we used the data to work on representing groups of numbers such as tens and ones to look at in our sample. This helped my children to form a more concrete idea of large numbers
column3: and made working on mathematics with them more enjoyable and less of an arduous task.

column1: My children were not fond of having to sit down and do writing assignments
column2: so I told them that even daddy has to do these. I wrote up our results as a paper that conformed to American Psychological Association style
column3: and showed it to them. This made the kids more open to working on writing tasks.

column1: Aside from the education they received at home
column2: my children now show less anxiety about COVID-19
column3: but they are still sad at missing friends. Although social distancing and working from home can derail many plans
column4: it can also be an excellent opportunity to share your passion for science with your children. Turning my kids’ anxiety into curiosity was one of the most rewarding experiences I have had as a scientist. During this difficult time
column5: we may have the opportunity to connect with our children in ways that inspire the next generation of scientists. And my triplets already have an idea for our next experiment.

2020-06-19|"Ladies and gentlemen
column2: good afternoon. It’s a pleasure to be speaking with you today.

column1: Let me start by saying that never before in Europe have we seen such a level of interest about hydrogen as we have today. The reason is twofold: we need hydrogen to achieve climate-neutrality and we should use this opportunity to invest in the clean energy technologies
column2: to restart the economy and promote innovation after the devastating economic effects of the COVID crisis.

column1: This new Commission took office last December and since the beginning we have set our sights on a very clear goal – a climate neutral Europe within thirty years. This is the corner stone of our Green Deal strategy.
The first half of this year has definitely not gone to plan as we found ourselves combating the biggest health crisis in living memory.
Still
column2: we are turning adversity into opportunity. We have published a Recovery Plan for Europe - the Next Generation EU - putting the green transformation at its heart. In this way
column3: the Green Deal and the clean energy transition act as a new growth strategy. One that creates new investments and jobs for our people. One example is wind energy: over the last decade the cost of electricity generated by offshore wind fell by almost 30% and it is becoming more and more competitive compared to fossil fuel sources.

column1: Our power sector is decarbonising rapidly and by 2030 almost 76% will come from low-carbon sources renewables (54.8%) and nuclear (21.1%). By 2050
column2: our electricity supply is expected to be fully decarbonised with over 80% coming from renewables.

column1: But electricity alone cannot get us there. We know that we will also need other carriers.
We also know that to keep energy costs in check
column2: we must harness all the synergies and exploit the complementarities between the electricity sector
column3: our vast gas infrastructure
column4: our industry and the transport sector.

column1: Hydrogen is a vital missing piece of the puzzle to help us reach this deeper decarbonisation and to reach it at a lower cost to people.

We have recognised this opportunity and are working on two key strategies to be launched on the 8th of July: a strategy for energy system integration and a dedicated strategy on hydrogen. They will set out how we intend to accelerate the transition to the energy system of the future. A system in which hydrogen will play a key role.
Today
column2: we use hydrogen mostly in chemical processes. Tomorrow
column3: hydrogen can decarbonise these industrial processes
column4: it can be a new fuel for heavy-duty transport and clean jet fuel for aviation
column5: or replace coal in steel-making.

column1: To make this happen we need to focus our work in four areas.
First
column2: we need to activate a virtuous circle of increased supply and demand for hydrogen
column3: boosting demand in end uses
column4: like industrial applications and transport
column5: and investing in developing electrolysers with greater capacity. Part of this is bringing down the cost of clean hydrogen to make it competitive. For this
column6: we need more and cheaper renewable energy
column7: and an efficient electricity market.

column1: We have laid the ground for this through the Clean Energy for all Europeans market design legislation which we are currently implementing.
But we will go even further to create an ecosystem approach to hydrogen production. To do this
column2: we are creating a Clean Hydrogen Alliance to bring the full value chain of hydrogen together: investors
column3: governmental
column4: institutional and industrial partners. This template of an industrial alliance has proven its worth before in Europe. We aim to involve all actors upstream and downstream to accelerate hydrogen deployment and achieve cost reductions and greater competitiveness.

column1: Second
column2: we need a regulatory framework to shape an open and competitive market with unhindered cross border trade and infrastructures to transport hydrogen where it is needed. This could mean a need to repurpose or re-use some of our existing natural gas infrastructure and helps us to avoid stranded assets.

column1: Third
column2: we need to continue our research and innovation. Because developing a clean hydrogen economy poses a technological challenge.

column1: We need to vastly scale up electrolyser technologies to support the ambition. But at this point
column2: we still do not have the production capacity we need.

column1: Demonstration projects are starting at 20 Mega Watts in Europe. But we need Giga Watt scale electrolysers. We also need research in fuel cells and storage. So in September we will adopt a Green Deal call of 950 million EUR under Horizon 2020
column2: which will also cover hydrogen. Of that
column3: more than one third will be dedicated to energy topics
column4: including a call for a large-scale electrolyser. It is our hope that these will help us to gather the right minds and unleash their research and innovation in all the relevant areas across the hydrogen value chain.

column1: And finally
column2: we need international cooperation. The EU imports today just over 58% of the energy it needs. Tomorrow
column3: we need to transform these imports of fossil fuels into clean energy partnerships. We want to work with our neighbours in the first place
column4: but also with global partners. We need common understanding and possibly even the harmonisation of codes and standards for trading hydrogen internationally

column1: I have seen our focus on hydrogen mirrored across the globe. The number of countries joining the International Hydrogen Council has more than quadrupled in the past three years.
And Director-General Matsuyama
column2: I have seen that Japan has announced the next Olympic Games to be the “Hydrogen Olympics”. This is excellent!

column1: Working side by side with our international partners is also a fundamental part of the research and innovation I mentioned earlier. This is why we are taking part in all major initiatives related to hydrogen
column2: such as co-leading the Hydrogen Initiative of the Clean Energy Ministerial supported by the IEA. We are also involved in designing activities on hydrogen under Mission Innovation.

column1: This is how we see the way forward – a strong approach on both an EU and an international level. This is how we scale up
column2: exchange ideas and solidify the position of hydrogen in the energy sector.

column1: I look forward to hearing your own views on hydrogen’s role in the energy system of tomorrow. And more about where we can work together further to shape that future."|2
