column1: 2020-06-20|"Despite the growing importance of services in output and trade
column2: there has been relatively little information on how services policies have evolved over the past decades. This column presents evidence on services trade policies from a new database created by the World Bank and WTO. It reveals that higher income economies are more open on average than developing economies
column3: but the chronology of reform varies across sectors. In addition
column4: while explicit restrictions are being lowered
column5: regulatory scrutiny is increasing in most sectors
column6: especially in higher income economies.

column1: Economic policy has changed dramatically since the Great Recession. The post-WWII liberalising trend in goods trade is being reversed and multilateral cooperation is ceding ground to a more nationalistic view of policy (World Bank 2020). At the same time
column2: technological change is accelerating
column3: especially in response to the COVID-19 shock. In this changing environment
column4: it has been possible to closely track goods trade policies
column5: but there is much less information on how services policies have evolved despite the growing importance of services in output and trade (WTO 2019).

column1: This gap in information matters because services are intimately linked to developments over the last decade. For instance
column2: the Great Recession originated in financial markets where regulation failed to keep step with liberalisation (Rajan 2010); the emergence of new digital platforms is transforming business
column3: retail
column4: communication
column5: transport
column6: and financial services; and the improvements in information and communication technology could be ushering in a new era of cross-border trade in services (Baldwin 2019). Are governments reacting to these developments proactively through radical reform
column7: defensively by imposing new restrictions
column8: or inertially by doing nothing?

column1: To answer this question and to facilitate the empirical analysis of policy change
column2: the World Bank and the WTO engaged in a major policy data collection and quantification exercise
column3: which resulted in a new World Bank-WTO Services Trade Policy Database (STPD). This database contains information on the services trade policies in five broad areas – financial
column4: telecommunication
column5: distribution
column6: transportation
column7: and professional services. The STPD contains information not just on core trade policies but also on other increasingly relevant regulatory measures such as licensing conditions and restrictions on cross-border data flows.

column1: Policy restrictiveness is quantified following an improved Services Trade Restrictions Index (STRI) that aggregates the qualitative information within a single consistent and transparent measure. Data previously collected by the World Bank over 2008-2011 were adjusted to the new classification and quantified based on the updated STRI methodology. The harmonised data make it possible for the first time to compare services trade policies over a long period of time – between 2008 and 2016 – for a large cross-section of 55 advanced and developing economies.
On the basis of that information
column2: it is possible to identify patterns of services trade policies across economies and sectors as well as secular trends in policy making over the past decade. On the face of it
column3: services trade regimes are generally becoming more open
column4: at least as far as explicit restrictions are concerned
column5: in apparent contrast to recent changes in goods trade policy. Most recently
column6: however
column7: services trade policy is also becoming more restrictive
column8: especially in digitally traded computer and audio-visual services (OECD 2020). Tightening measures in 2019 mostly affected foreign investment and the movement of people.

column1: This most recent turn of events notwithstanding
column2: higher income economies are still more open on average than lower income economies in most sectors. The decrease in policy restrictiveness since 2008
column3: i.e. over nearly a decade
column4: is slightly more pronounced for high-income economies (Figure 1). At the same time
column5: some dynamic developing economies such as Bangladesh
column6: India
column7: and China have also liberalised significantly in the past decade. Other lower-income and middle-income economies that have liberalised their services trade policies appreciably (by at least five points on average) are Ecuador
column8: Uruguay
column9: Indonesia
column10: Tunisia
column11: Thailand
column12: Colombia
column13: Costa Rica
column14: and Pakistan. Underlying these patterns of overall liberalisation across economies are differences in the sectoral pattern of liberalisation. We illustrate these below by focusing on two sectors: financial services (especially commercial banking) and professional services (auditing).

column1: Figure 1 Services trade policy has become more open since the Great Recession (Changes in STRI between 2008-2011 and 2016 by level of income)
All sectors have been liberalized but by varying degrees. Broad waves in services policy reform can be identified. Higher income economies have led the way
column2: pioneering the opening up of telecommunications and finance to foreign competition in the 1980s and 1990s. Hence
column3: the picture already emerging a decade ago in these two sectors was of general openness in higher income economies
column4: and of varying degrees of liberalisation in developing economies. The new database reveals that since 2008 developing economies have started to reform those sectors that were first liberalised by higher income economies
column5: while the latter have embarked on the liberalisation of other sectors
column6: notably professional and transport services. Hence
column7: the picture emerging more recently is of policy convergence in telecommunications and finance driven by liberalisation by hitherto more restrictive developing economies
column8: and divergence and dispersion in sectors such as professional and transport services.

column1: There are particularly striking examples of recent reforms in financial services in some of the most dynamic developing countries such as Bangladesh
column2: Kenya
column3: the Philippines or Vietnam (Figure 2).

column1: Figure 2 Limited convergence in financial services trade openness (Changes in STRI between 2008-2011 and 2016 by level of income)

Digging deeper into the policy data on commercial banking services reveals certain patterns. A large majority of economies now allow entry into their markets through the acquisition and control of domestic entities
column2: through the establishment of wholly owned subsidiaries
column3: or through direct branching. The preferred avenue is the acquisition of already licensed institutions
column4: which may be explained by the host regulators' wish to recapitalise local banks (notably after the 2008-2009 financial crisis) while maintaining the existing market structure and therefore the current intensity of competition. Both fully owned subsidiaries and direct branches have been increasingly allowed in most economies
column5: but the former remains a preferred option for local regulators
column6: given the potential for risk transmission that foreign bank branches present
column7: as was evident in the financial crisis. Interestingly
column8: no economy in our sample abrogated access through branching – the increased share of governments allowing this form of entry is the result therefore of additional liberalisation in emerging economies (e.g. Colombia
column9: Egypt
column10: Indonesia
column11: Philippines
column12: Russian Federation).

column1: Even though there are now fewer explicit restrictions on entry
column2: scrutiny of foreign banks has remained intense or even been strengthened. For instance
column3: even when the presence through branching is allowed
column4: stringent regulatory conditions (e.g. imposition of endowment capital requirements
column5: limitations on the expansion of the branching network) are imposed in a majority of economies. In addition
column6: roughly a quarter of our sample now applies different licensing criteria for foreign banks. Finally
column7: more than half of the economies in our sample subject foreign banks to either economic needs tests
column8: investment screening requirements or non-automatic licensing approvals (even when all formal licensing criteria have been fulfilled).

column1: Figure 3 Divergence in auditing services trade openness (Changes in STRI between 2008-2011 and 2016 by level of income)
Policy dispersion is still the norm in sectors that joined the liberalisation wave more recently and in a more limited number of economies. In auditing
column2: most of the decrease in the STRI is linked to less restrictive policies regarding the entry of professionals in high-income and middle-income economies
column3: as well as the loosening of restrictions for cross-border supply for high-income economies. Restrictions on commercial presence were reduced only slightly
column4: with highly restrictive economies remaining so in 2016 (India
column5: Korea
column6: Panama
column7: the Philippines
column8: Turkey).

column1: The high-income economies presenting the biggest reductions in restrictiveness are Japan and some EU members
column2: where reforms in the auditing subsector came into force in June 2016 in the aftermath of the financial crisis. One of the aims was to improve auditing quality
column3: and to introduce rotation of auditors because of the concentration of the market. One of the tools envisaged in that regard was to facilitate cross-border provision of statutory audit services. Focusing more specifically on the temporary movement of natural persons supplying services
column4: restrictions have decreased since 2008-2011 in European economies and in some other high-income countries (e.g. Canada
column5: Japan
column6: US). This was accomplished either by relaxing some of the economy-wide restrictions on the movement of persons (quantitative limitations)
column7: the lifting of nationality or residency requirements to obtain a license to practice
column8: or the recognition of foreign qualifications.

column1: To conclude
column2: the last decade has seen steady and widespread liberalisation
column3: but with a twist. While markets in services
column4: e.g. finance and telecommunications
column5: are increasingly free from explicit restrictions on entry and ownership
column6: they are increasingly subject to greater regulatory scrutiny (e.g. economic needs tests
column7: FDI screening)
column8: especially in higher income economies. This raises several"|1

column1: 2020-06-20|"The COVID-19 crisis is depressing growth globally
column2: and lockdown measures are causing widespread job losses. This column illustrates that women are amongst the worst affected. Women are vulnerable not only because of their jobs
column3: but also because of gender inequalities within housework division
column4: education
column5: and health. There is an urgent need to support women
column6: repair gender disparities aggravated by crisis
column7: and to reduce women’s vulnerability going forward. Gender-responsive fiscal measures are viable tools that work in the interests of women
column8: as well as supporting economic growth and reducing poverty and inequality.

column1: The COVID-19 pandemic has killed more than 400
column2: 000 people worldwide and has generated a massive global economic crisis. The world economy is projected to contract sharply by 3% in 2020 (IMF 2020) and poverty is set to rise for the first time since 1998
column3: bringing 40-60 million people into extreme poverty (World Bank 2020). However
column4: unlike previous economic crises
column5: this crisis will negatively affect women more than men
column6: creating a significant blow for gender equality. Policymakers should step up their efforts to reestablish the path towards a more equal society for men and women.

column1: A huge setback in the quest for gender equality
Gender inequality had diminished over the past 30 years. For instance
column2: the gap between male and female labour force participation decreased by eight percentage points due to the large gains in female labour force participation
column3: especially within advanced economies (Figure 1). Educational attainment gaps also narrowed around the world with 35 countries having achieved full parity
column4: and 120 countries closing at least 95% of their educational gender gaps (WEF 2020). The maternal mortality ratio had dropped by about 38% worldwide.

column1: This encouraging progress
column2: however
column3: is likely to suffer huge setbacks during the COVID-19 crisis. There are various reasons why the current crisis disproportionally impacts women. First
column4: women are more likely than men to work in social sectors (such as hospitality
column5: retail
column6: restaurants
column7: and tourism)
column8: which require face-to-face interactions (Figure 2). These are the sectors that are being hit the hardest by social distancing (Hupkau and Petrongolo 2020). For example
column9: in the US
column10: almost 74% of women work in social sectors
column11: compared to 48% of men (in 2019). Further
column12: data for the first four months of the year indicate that employment in these sectors shrank by 18%
column13: compared to 10% in other sectors (Shibata 2020). In developing countries
column14: women are also more likely to be employed in social sectors than men. Notwithstanding
column15: an even bigger concern in many of these countries is that women often work in the informal sector more frequently than men
column16: and therefore have less job security and social protection
column17: as well as lower pay (ILO 2018). Second
column18: women
column19: who usually carry the highest-burden of housework (Alonso et al. 2019
column20: Alon et al. 2020)
column21: are bearing most of the epidemic-related costs triggered by school closures and the health risks posed to elderly family members. Uncertainty about schools reopening and fears of contagion of the most vulnerable can lead to women exiting the labour force for a prolonged period of time
column22: entailing long-term costs to their careers. Third
column23: in developing countries
column24: the burden on the healthcare system is reducing access to family planning and increasing the chances of maternal mortality (UNPA Women 2020). Finally
column25: in many developing economies (where girls in normal times already feel the pressure to drop out of school)
column26: the COVID-19 crisis may induce even more female dropouts. Dropping out from school creates a permanent loss in human capital and narrows girls’ chances of improving their living standards.

column1: Note: Social sectors are defined as the sum of the following sectors: wholesale and retail trade
column2: accommodation and food service activities
column3: real estate
column4: business and administrative activities
column5: education
column6: human health and social work activities and other services.

column1: The policy challenge: Gender equality
column2: boosting growth
column3: and reducing poverty and inequality

column1: Policymakers around the world are focusing on responding to the crisis’ immediate effects
column2: fighting the devastating impact of the pandemic on people’s lives and national healthcare systems (Deb et al. 2020
column3: Queisser at al. 2020)
column4: as well as trying to maintain functioning economies. Nevertheless
column5: policymakers must also plan for the future. How can we return to a path of sustainable economic growth and regain the lost ground in gender equality
column6: while fighting poverty and inequality? These are daunting tasks – but gender-responsive fiscal policies can help. The appropriate set of policies will depend
column7: among other things
column8: on the country’s level of development. For example
column9: ensuring access to caregiving support (when economic activities outside of the household resume) is crucial for women to be able to go back to work in the developed world. In developing countries
column10: increasing efforts to keep girls in school is key for building and protecting future human capital.

column1: As shown in our recent paper (Fabrizio et al. 2020)
column2: fiscal policies that address gender equality (such as investing in education and infrastructure
column3: subsidising childcare
column4: and offering parental leave) can create economic opportunities for women. These policies also generate economic growth and reduce poverty and inequality
column5: while paying for themselves in the long run. For example:

column1: • Subsidised childcare. The high cost
column2: and uneven supply
column3: of childcare represents a barrier for many women (particularly the low-skilled and poor) to participate in the labour force. Poor women typically face higher childcare costs relative to their income. For example
column4: in the US
column5: poorer women spend 17.4% of their income on childcare
column6: compared to 7.8% for richer women. These women are also at higher risk of losing their jobs because of the current pandemic. Subsidising childcare is a ‘win-win’ policy. It stimulates female labour force participation and generates jobs in the childcare sector. For illustration
column7: life-cycle model simulations suggest that expanding childcare subsidies in order to reduce its cost by half (for middle-class working mothers) in the US would lead to an increase in female labour force participation by almost five percentage points. Women at the bottom of the income distribution (that currently do not have access to the Child Care Development Fund) would benefit the most. Our paper shows that this policy would reduce poverty in the US by up to 0.2 percentage points
column8: and increase economic activity by up to 0.5 percent by widening the pool of workers.

column1: • Investing in education. As argued above
column2: the COVID-19 crisis can hamper progress made in closing gender gaps in education
column3: as girls are usually the first to drop out of school if families need additional help at home. A more educated labour force is more resilient and flexible. Closing gender gaps in education boosts female human capital
column4: raising women’s expected salaries and giving them more incentives to pursue careers. On aggregate
column5: this would also positively impact productivity for the future
column6: thus accelerating economic growth. For illustration
column7: life-cycle model simulations suggest that investing sufficiently in education to close gender gaps at each income level in Senegal could boost output by almost 9%
column8: while reducing poverty by more than ten percentage points
column9: and cut inequality (as measured by the Gini coefficient) by almost three percentage points.

column1: The COVID-19 pandemic is affecting all countries
column2: destroying jobs
column3: increasing poverty
column4: and putting at risk the hard-won gender equality gains of the last few decades. Policymakers around the world are rightly focusing on responding to the immediate crisis
column5: fighting the devastating effects of the pandemic on healthcare systems whist trying to keep their economies alive. The next step is to find the tools to sustain economic growth
column6: fight poverty
column7: and regain the lost ground in gender equality―gender-responsive fiscal policies are a viable answer.

column1: 2020-06-20|"The impact of COVID-19 on insurers
The grim impact of COVID-19 – extensive financial dislocations across asset classes and potentially large increases in morbidity and mortality – could pose a challenge to the insurance industry
column2: particularly life insurers. This column urges central banks looking to preserve credit supply to account for changes in insurer risk appetite
column3: which could take place well before capital levels approach regulatory thresholds. Financial stability assessments should examine the implications of the pandemic for insurers
column4: which operate in some countries on a comparable scale to banks.

column1: While much attention has been paid to the impact of COVID-19 on banks (for examples of prominent early work
column2: see Beck 2020
column3: Cecchetti and Schoenholtz 2020)
column4: insurers have received less attention. Insurers are important financial intermediaries
column5: holding more than $30 trillion in assets globally (FSB 2020)
column6: and operating on a comparable scale to banks in some countries.

column1: COVID-19 will affect insurers both directly
column2: via health shocks (increases in mortality and morbidity)
column3: and indirectly
column4: via financial shocks (higher credit spreads
column5: potentially widespread downgrades
column6: lower interest rates
column7: and lower equity prices). The financial impact of pandemics is often much larger than the direct health impact
column8: as even comparatively mild outbreaks can have a large economic footprint (McKibbin and Fernando 2020).

column1: Insurers’ exposure to COVID-19 varies by their line of business. For example
column2: life insurers’ liabilities commit them to payouts decades ahead
column3: and are very sensitive to changes in interest rates. Although these long-term liabilities permit longer investment horizons
column4: potentially supporting financial stability (Chodorow-Reich et al. 2020
column5: IAIS 2019)
column6: life insurers are more directly affected by pandemics through their liabilities. If insurers are hit hard
column7: risk appetite may be impaired—as was the case following the global financial crisis (Kirti 2019)—affecting the availability of credit for riskier borrowers. Policymakers working to preserve credit supply to the economy should account for any changes to insurers’ risk appetite.

column1: We present estimates of the impact of COVID-19 on capitalisation levels for US life insurers
column2: considering both the direct pandemic shock and the indirect financial shock.

column1: Life insurers provide protection against both mortality and longevity risk. Joint provision of both types of protection can help insurers manage risk. In a pandemic with significant mortality impact
column2: life insurance claims rise immediately
column3: whereas expected future payments on life-contingent annuities fall. These risks can therefore offset each other from a long-term solvency perspective
column4: although large life insurance claims may have a meaningful short-term impact. Moreover
column5: for annuities in the accumulation phase
column6: as is the case for a majority of US annuities
column7: account values are typically payable upon death.

column1: We focus on the impact of potentially larger mortality on life insurance claims. We base key assumptions (share of population with coverage and average size of policy by age group
column2: and the extent to which mortality may be lower conditional on coverage) on SOA (2007) and apply case fatality rates by age group as experienced in Korea (a more benign scenario) or Italy (a more severe scenario with limited health care capacity) as of early June.

column1: Although the pandemic appears to be tapering in Europe and even in the US as of early June 2020
column2: it is difficult to exclude further waves of infections. Figure 1 shows the impact on US life insurers as a share of capital given the share of the population affected by COVID-19. Insurers
column3: regulators
column4: and industry observers typically use an excess death ratio of 1.5 per 1
column5: 000 as a standard pandemic stress test scenario. In the US
column6: this would imply about 500
column7: 000 deaths (about 8% of the population affected with case fatality rates in Korea
column8: and about 4% with case fatality rates in Italy)
column9: larger than current estimates of the potential death toll released by US authorities. In such a scenario
column10: losses would be about $15 billion
column11: or about 3% of pre-shock industry capital.4 Should the pandemic prove challenging to control (with treatment and vaccines remaining elusive)
column12: an extreme scenario more comparable to the 1918 Spanish flu (closer to 30% of the population affected with case fatality rates in Korea) could become relevant. In such a scenario
column13: losses would be about $45-55 billion—about 10% of pre-shock capital. Such a scenario would likely unfold over multiple years
column14: giving insurers time to accumulate additional net premium income.

Sources: S&P Global Market Intelligence and IMF staff analysis.

column1: US life insurers are generally not required to mark bonds to market for the purpose of determining regulatory capital. Capital requirements for US insurers are tied to regulatory risk categorisation of assets. For most asset classes
column2: regulatory risk categories are a function of credit ratings. US life insurers’ holdings are somewhat skewed toward bonds only one or two rating notches above regulatory thresholds for significantly higher risk weights (Kirti and Shin 2020
column3: Becker and Ivashina 2015).[vii] Risk weights for junk bonds are more than triple those for investment grade bonds. Downgraded bonds tend to be sold by insurers facing capital pressure (Ellul et al. 2011). We focus on the impact of bond downgrades on required capital.

column1: Despite unprecedented policy responses from monetary and fiscal authorities

column3: capital requirements would increase. Downgraded bonds may see fire sales

column2: after the release of certain soft indicators on 2 March 2020
column3: the GWI increased sharply – much faster than in the 2008 crisis. Moreover
column4: the index remained at a record high at the time of writing

column1: The COVID-19 crisis has once again shown how important it is to be able to assess economic conditions in real time. Although it has been clear since early March that some economies are sliding into recession

column1: In order to solve this problem
column2: various researchers have developed non-linear models based on several timely indicators. Unlike many other models
column3: the Markov-switching dynamic factor (MSDF) models introduced by Chauvet (1998) have been successfully used to account for co-movements and non-linearities across several economic indicators. These models have widely proven their ability to quickly identify turning points.

column1: In MSDF models
column2: the economy is assumed to switch between expansions and recessions with constant probabilities. Expansions and recessions are respectively characterised by high and low growth rates of the various activity indicators. Conditional on being in each state
column3: the indicators

column5: move around these high/low growth rates. Following Hamilton (1989)
column6: previous MSDF models have assumed that these two growth rates are the same for all the expansions and recessions in the sample.

column1: This article explains how we (Leiva-Leon et al. 2020) estimate such a model using timely indicators
column2: while also allowing for recessions to differ in depth. To allow for this possibility has two advantages. First
column3: allowing for the mean to vary across recessions is helpful because once an economy has suffered a ‘severe’ recession
column4: such as the Global Crisis
column5: the model might not be able to identify an upcoming ‘mild’ recession. This lack of sensitivity of the model comes from the fact that the estimated growth rate of recessions might be too low to capture ‘mild’ recession periods. Second
column6: as the growth rate of every recession is different
column7: the model delivers real-time estimates of the depth of every recession
column8: which provides valuable information to rapidly design and implement the necessary policy responses. This is especially important in the deep COVID-19 recession that we are currently experiencing.

column1: An MSDF with recessions of varying depth is estimated independently for twelve of the largest economic regions of the world
column2: which together account for more than 70% of world GDP. Six of them are advanced

column1: We present a new indicator of global economic weakness which uses real-time information available to estimate the proportion of the world economy that is in a recession. column1: 2020-06-21|"Women leaders are better at fighting the pandemic

The effectiveness of female leaders in handling the COVID crisis has received a lot of media attention. This column examines whether the gender of the national leader truly makes a significant difference to the number of COVID-19 cases and deaths in the first quarter of the pandemic
column2: with differences in lockdown timing examined as a plausible explanation for these patterns. The findings show that COVID outcomes are systematically better in countries led by women. Insights from behavioural studies and leadership literature are used to speculate on the sources of these differences
column3: as well as on their implications.

column1: On 8 June 2020
column2: New Zealand was declared virus-free and Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern lifted all restrictions except stringent border controls (Graham-McLay 2020). With fewer than 500 confirmed cases and seven deaths from the virus
column3: Taiwan under the presidency of Tsai Ing-Wen is seen to have performed very well. Germany under Angela Merkel has done better than most European countries in the first quarter of the COVID pandemic (Hartl et al. 2020). The performance of these female leaders in the COVID pandemic offers a unique global experiment in national crisis management and has given rise to much media attention. This is a significant shift from the male-dominated view of history within which events are typically considered as determined by the instrumental and causal influence of a small number of ‘Great Men’ (e.g. Keegan 2003). But does this association stand up to systematic scrutiny?

column1: Leader’s gender in the fight against the pandemic
In a new paper (Garikipati and Kambhampati 2020)
column2: we consider whether there are significant differences in the COVID-outcomes of male and female led-countries in the first quarter of the pandemic. We also consider whether these differences can be explained by differences in policy measures adopted by male and female leaders. In particular
column3: we consider the timing of lockdown in these countries.

column1: Anything said about the pandemic now has to be qualified by the fact that we are only at the start of the pandemic. Much could change in the next few months. Our analysis therefore relates to the immediate reaction of leaders to the first wave of the crisis. Another qualification to keep in mind is the quality of data currently available. In particular
column2: with the shortage of test kits
column3: testing has been poor (Baunez et al. 2020) and therefore case numbers are an underestimate. While data on deaths are more reliable
column4: there are concerns about its comparability across countries. In some countries
column5: if a COVID-positive individual dies
column6: the death is registered as a COVID death irrespective of any other previous illness (such as tuberculosis or cancer). But this is not standard or mandatory
column7: so practice varies across countries.

column1: We begin by looking at some summary statistics. Table 1 presents COVID-19 cases and deaths by gender of the country’s leaders. It confirms that female-led countries have fared better in terms of absolute number of COVID-19 cases and deaths
column2: with male-led countries having nearly double the number of deaths as female-led ones. However
column3: drawing anything conclusive from these raw comparisons is difficult due to the massive underrepresentation of female-led countries in the sample. We have only 19 countries across the world being led by women
column4: compared with the 174 in our sample that are male-led.

column1: Table 1 COVID-19 cases and deaths in countries by gender of national leader
Source: Dataset constructed by authors from various sources.
To overcome the difficulty of imbalanced sample sizes
column2: we ‘match’ each of the female-led countries with their nearest neighbour. We use several socio-demographic and economic characteristics that have been seen as important in the transmission of COVID-19 as matching variables. We begin by considering key demographic and national wealth indicators (including GDP
column3: population over 65 years
column4: and population in urban agglomerations) as these have emerged as the most relevant (Sá 2020). Figure 1 below illustrates some examples of comparing COVID-19 cases and deaths in female-led countries with their near neighbour matched by size of population. When matched like this
column5: it is clear that female-led countries have fewer cases and fewer deaths and have locked down earlier than male countries with respect to cases and deaths. Following discussions in the literature
column6: we also extend matching to include other variables such as expenditure on health and tourism. We also include gender equality as a matching variable as having equitable institutions may contribute to a general resilience that becomes confounded with having a female leader.

column1: Nearest neighbour analysis clearly confirms that when women-led countries are compared to countries similar to them along a range of characteristics
column2: they have performed better
column3: experiencing fewer cases as well as fewer deaths. This is true whether we consider the nearest neighbour
column4: the nearest two
column5: three or even five neighbours. The results are especially highly significant in the case of the number of deaths experienced by female-led countries. These results remain robust when we drop countries that have been in the COVID spotlight – the US
column6: Germany
column7: and New Zealand – from our sample to see if they might be driving the results. We find that these changes in the sample only strengthen the results.

column1: What is also clear from our analysis is that timing of lockdown has been driving the better outcomes in female-led countries. Female-led countries locked down significantly earlier
column2: i.e. when they were seeing fewer deaths (22 fewer) than male-led countries. Our nearest neighbour matching estimates confirm this result at a very high level of significance. While this may have longer-term economic implications
column3: it has certainly helped these countries to save lives (Assenza et al. 2020). Why have women leaders decided to lock down their countries earlier than male leaders?

column1: Figure 1 COVID-19 cases and deaths: Comparing female-led and male-led countries with similar populations
Source: COVID-19 cases and deaths extracted from the Worldometer website (https://www.worldometers.info/)
One explanation for gender-differences in the propensity to lock down early might be found in the literature on attitudes to risk and uncertainty
column2: which suggests that women
column3: even those in leadership roles
column4: appear to be more risk-averse than men (e.g. Croson and Gneezy 2009
column5: Charness and Gneezy 2012). Indeed
column6: in the current crisis
column7: several incidents of risky behaviour by male leaders have been reported. Particularly noteworthy among these are Brazil’s Jair Bolsonaro’s dismissal of COVID-19 as “a little flu or a bit of a cold” (Ajzenman et al. 2020) while attending an anti-lockdown protest in April. Similarly
column8: Britain’s Boris Johnson is reported to have said
column9: “I was at a hospital where there were a few coronavirus patients and I shook hands with everybody” (as reported in Lewis 2020).

column1: However
column2: while women leaders were risk averse with regard to lives
column3: they were prepared to take significant risks with their economies by locking down early. Thus
column4: risk aversion may manifest differently in different domains – human life versus economic outcomes – with women leaders being significantly more risk averse in the domain of human life
column5: but more risk taking in the domain of the economy. We find some support for this idea in studies that examine risk taking behaviour when lotteries are framed as losses. Men are found to be more risk averse than women when lotteries are framed as financial losses rather than gains (Schubert et al. 1999
column6: Moore and Eckel 2006). It could well be that the relatively late lockdown decisions by male leaders may reflect male risk aversion to anticipated losses from locking down the economy.

column1: The neuroscience literature also throws light on sex-differences in feelings of empathy which cannot be fully explained as cultural derivatives of socialisation alone but have deeper neurobiological drivers (Eckel and Grossman 2002). There exist quantitative gender differences in the basic networks involved in affective and cognitive forms of empathy
column2: as well as a qualitative divergence between the sexes in how emotional information is integrated to support decision making processes (Christov-Moore et al. 2014). When combined with the findings from the risk literature
column3: we begin to see how women leaders could have been risk-averse about anticipated losses to human life
column4: while at the same time taking risk with negative financial outcomes associated with early lockdown.

column1: Another explanation of gender differences in response to the pandemic is to be found in the leadership literature
column2: where strong evidence can be found to suggest that men and women differ in their leadership styles. Eagly and Johnson (1990)
column3: through a meta-analysis of research that compares male and female leadership styles
column4: find that leadership styles were gender stereotypic
column5: with men likely to lead in a ‘task-oriented’ style and women in an ‘interpersonally oriented’ manner. Consistent with this finding
column6: women tended to adopt a more democratic and participative style. Evidence also suggests that good communications skills are important for women to be chosen as leaders and that this is one of the key attributes in managing a crisis (Lemoine et al. 2016).

column1: Indeed
column2: the decisive and clear communication styles adopted by several female leaders have received much praise in the ongoing crisis (e.g. Henley and Roy 2020
column3: McLean 2020
column4: Taub 2020). Thus
column5: in Norway Prime Minister Erna Solberg spoke direct to children answering their questions
column6: while in New Zealand Prime Minster Ardern was praised for the way in which she communicated and for checking in with her citizens through Facebook Live.

column2: to some extent
column3: this may be expla"|2

column1: 2020-06-22|"The COVID-19 pandemic is the biggest public-health crisis in a century
column2: and the development of medical interventions to combat the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus is a top priority. Writing in Nature
column3: Pinto et al.1 provide evidence needed to take one of the crucial first steps for such efforts in the developing arena of antibody immunotherapy.

column1: Read the paper: Cross-neutralization of SARS-CoV-2 by a human monoclonal SARS-CoV antibody

The level of protection provided by the immune system in response to SARS-CoV-2 exposure and infection is a hotly debated topic2. It is thought that one major arm of the immune response to such infection is the development of antibodies that recognize the virus. Of particular interest are antibodies that bind to a protein on the viral surface known as the spike protein. Coronaviruses derive their name from their distinctive
column2: crown-like (coronal) viral silhouettes
column3: which are due to these proteins.

column1: Antibodies that recognize and bind to the viral ‘spike’ can block its ability to bind the ACE2 receptor protein on human cells. An interaction between the spike protein and ACE2 is part of a process that can enable coronaviruses to enter human cells. Thus
column2: antibodies that could hinder spike-protein function would block infection; such antibodies are termed neutralizing antibodies.

column1: Much remains to be learnt about the immunological responses to SARS-CoV-2. Nevertheless
column2: it is becoming clear that antibodies taken from the blood serum of people who have recovered from COVID-19 can be used for treatment by being transfused into other people who have the disease3. Such ‘convalescent sera’ approaches are highly attractive
column3: particularly as an immediate treatment option. That’s because more-conventional therapeutics
column4: such as drugs or vaccines
column5: are unlikely to be available for some time. A more high-tech approach to using convalescent sera is the manipulation of antibody-producing B cells taken from the blood of people who had COVID-19 or other coronavirus infections. Each B cell makes one unique antibody
column6: and clonal populations of a B cell of interest can be used to generate an identical pool of a particular desired antibody known as a monoclonal antibody.

column1: To accelerate the process of therapeutic development
column2: Pinto and colleagues ‘went back in time’
column3: and turned to samples of B cells collected from a person who had been infected by the coronavirus SARS-CoV. This virus
column4: which is similar to SARS-CoV-2
column5: caused an outbreak in 2003 of a disease called severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). The hope with such an approach is that the resemblance between the two viruses might mean that some antibodies that recognize SARS-CoV also recognize and neutralize SARS-CoV-2.

column1: The ‘head’
column2: or receptor-binding domain (termed S1)
column3: of the spike protein is the most accessible region of the protein for antibodies to bind to. However
column4: this domain exists in different dynamic states
column5: and debate has arisen over whether it is ‘masked’ from the immune system by a shell of carbohydrate molecules4. The identification of a functional antibody that targets this region is therefore not a trivial process. Pinto et al. combined blood cells taken in 2004 and 2013 from a person who had recovered from SARS
column6: and searched for antibodies that could recognize SARS-CoV-2 (Fig. 1). Of the 25 different monoclonal antibodies that the authors studied
column7: 4 recognized the receptor-binding domains of both SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 spike proteins. One antibody
column8: termed S309
column9: was selected for further study on the basis of its high-affinity binding to this domain when tested in vitro.

column1: Pinto and colleagues used cryo-electron microscopy to visualize the interaction between the S309 antibody and the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. This revealed that S309 binds to an accessible site in the receptor-binding domain of the spike protein that has an attached carbohydrate molecule. This region is not part of the key area that directly binds to ACE2. The site that S309 recognizes is evolutionarily conserved in spike proteins across a range of bat coronaviruses (in the genus Betacoronavirus lineage B; subgenus Sarbecovirus) that have similarities to the SARS-like coronaviruses. This raises the possibility that such an antibody could have wide applicability in tackling related viruses. Not only
column2: then
column3: is this antibody of interest when investigating ways to manage the COVID-19 pandemic in the years ahead
column4: but it might also be considered for use in preventing future outbreaks of related animal viruses
column5: if they make the leap to causing infection in humans.

column1: Read the paper: Cross-neutralization of SARS-CoV-2 by a human monoclonal SARS-CoV antibody
Ultimately
column2: it seems unlikely that a robust treatment for COVID-19 will rely on a single antibody. Rather
column3: as was the case for SARS
column4: a synergistic approach combining different monoclonal antibodies in an antibody cocktail might be more effective5. For such approaches to move forwards
column5: evidence of effective antibody neutralization from in vitro studies will be needed
column6: along with in vivo data assessing how well an antibody can boost other aspects of the immune response — by enlisting other immune cells to tackle the infection
column7: for example. There are many promising avenues to explore in these efforts.

column1: Pinto and colleagues got a head start with their work by exploring pre-existing antibodies
column2: and they should now have more B-cell populations to mine. Many other teams
column3: to give just some examples2
column5: have also presented useful discoveries in the hunt for antibodies that can target SARS-CoV-2. The next steps will be to test individual antibodies and antibody cocktails in animal models
column6: to determine whether they offer protection
column7: and then to assess their safety and effectiveness in human clinical trials. An accelerated path might narrow the time lag between antibody discovery and proof-of-concept trials in humans to as little as five or six months14.

column1: The most recent prominent example of immunotherapy for infectious disease relates to battling the Ebola virus. In concert with vaccines and conventional
column2: small-molecule-drug trials
column3: the development of monoclonal-antibody therapies for Ebola has progressed rapidly. Cocktails of antibodies
column4: beginning with one called ZMapp
column5: that target a key Ebola viral protein called GP in two crucial regions of the protein
column6: are continuing to be developed15–17. This progress in efforts to tackle Ebola gives hope for similar immunotherapy achievements in targeting SARS-CoV-2. Pinto and colleagues’ work marks a major step towards that much-anticipated
column7: and much-needed
column8: success."|2

column1: 2020-06-22|"At the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic
column2: it was hoped that warm weather and younger populations would shield many developing countries from the virus. This hope has not been in realised. Infected cases in Africa
column3: South Asia and Latin America are still growing
column4: with Latin America having surpassed the number of cases in Europe and growing rapidly. This column introduces a new eBook that describes the early work focusing on developing and emerging markets. It concludes that the international community should step up
column5: by providing aid
column6: technical assistance and debt relief so that countries will not need to decide between saving lives and servicing their debts.

column1: The COVID-19 pandemic started in China but soon moved to Europe and to the US
column2: and by the end of March the number of cases in advanced economies had surpassed that in East Asia. At the beginning of the pandemic
column3: it was hoped that warm weather and younger populations would shield many developing countries from the virus. However
column4: this hope has not been in realised. Infected cases in Africa
column5: South Asia and Latin America are still growing
column6: with Latin America having surpassed the number of cases in Europe and still growing rapidly. This is not only due to the fact that many developing and emerging countries are populous. If we focus on cases per inhabitants in countries with a population of at least 5 million
column7: we find that about half of the countries in the list are developing or emerging market economies. And these figures are likely to underestimate the problem as the number of reported cases is closely linked to testing capacity which is limited in many developing and emerging market countries.

column1: Notes: Black: advanced economies (the dashed line excludes the US)
column2: Gray: East Asia and Pacific; Dark blue: East Europe and Central Asia; Light blue: Latin America and Caribbean
column3: Green: Middle East and North Africa; Purple: South Asia; Red: Sub-Saharan Africa

column1: The economic impact of the pandemic is global. While in October 2019
column2: the IMF estimated that 2020 world GDP growth would be close to 3.4%
column3: the IMF now forecasts that in 2020 world GDP will contract by 6%. The global contraction affects every country covered by the IMF forecasts. The IMF now expects that in 2020 there will only be 16 countries with positive growth in GDP per capita. For the sake of comparison
column4: in the aftermath of the global financial crisis
column5: nearly 80 countries registered positive growth in income per capita.

column1: There is a large rapidly growing literature on the economic effect of COVID-19 in advanced economies (for summaries
column2: see Baldwin and Weder di Mauro 2020a
column3: 2020b and Bénassy-Quéré and Weder di Mauro 2020). Research that focuses on developing and emerging market countries is more limited.

column1: In a new VoxEU eBook
column2: we describe the early work focusing on developing and emerging markets (Djankov and Panizza 2020. Developing and emerging market countries differ from advanced economies in both the structure of the economy and the tools that can be used to implement macroeconomic policies aimed at reducing the amplitude and the economic costs of recession associated with the pandemic (see the chapter by Hevia and Neumeyer). The most important amplifying factors include:

column1: • A large share of informal workers or workers employed in micro-firms
• A small share of jobs that can be done from home
The eBook is divided into five sections. The first three sections frame the problem
column2: present regional perspectives
column3: and discuss how the pandemic affects poverty
column4: inequality and informality. The last two sections discuss policy responses and highlight the macro-financial effects of the crisis
column5: including a narrative on the role of the international financial institutions.

column1: The global economic impact of the pandemic is due to the fact that the economic risk of COVID-19 is distinct from its health risk. The chapter by Noy and co-authors compares these two risks and show that
column2: in some instances
column3: the two might be orthogonal. This is especially the case for countries that have a small number of reported cases but are heavily reliant on tourism receipts and have fairly limited fiscal space for battling the ensuing recession.

column1: Djiofack and co-authors focus on Africa and show that COVID-19 is likely to create a lasting impact on labour productivity. They estimate that
column2: in an optimistic scenario
column3: African GDP would be permanently 1% lower than in the pre-COVID scenario.

column1: Arezki and co-authors focus on the Middle East and North Africa. Unsurprisingly
column2: they show that low oil prices will have a negative effect on oil-exporting countries growth. However
column3: they also show that low oil prices will have a negative effect on oil-importing countries in the Middle East and North Africa because these countries will suffer from reduced foreign direct investment
column4: remittances
column5: tourism
column6: and official assistance.

column1: Levy Yeyati and Valdes show that there is substantial heterogeneity within Latin America
column2: with Peru and Chile able to implement a sizeable fiscal reactions
column3: Colombia
column4: Mexico
column5: and Uruguay with limited fiscal space and Argentina
column6: Brazil and Ecuador with no access to private capital

column1: Developing Asia is an interesting case because
column2: as shown by Abiad and co-authors
column3: it includes countries with very strict containment measures. Within the region
column4: East Asian economies are expected to observe smaller contractions as these countries have been able to contain domestic outbreaks through aggressive testing and contact tracing
column5: and have avoided stringent containment measures. However
column6: tourism-dependent countries in the Pacific sub-region are expected to observe large drops in GDP even if none of these countries has had a significant outbreak. The chapter by Mooney and Zegarra explicitly focuses on tourism and show that the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on tourism flows to the Caribbean is without precedent in terms of its speed and severity.

column1: The second section of the eBook starts with a chapter by Gómez and co-authors which uses data from the International Coronavirus Survey. The chapter shows that in low- and middle-income countries
column2: individuals report complying less with the containment measures and express higher levels of worries and depression
column3: with women being more worried and depressed than men. Perceptions are important because divergent beliefs about the ‘facts on the ground’ can be a source of social tension which can ultimately lead to conflict during economic crises. Berman and co-authors focus on conflict and
column4: using a counterfactual exercise
column5: find that that the lockdown has reduce conflict intensity in the short run but that the pandemic may amplify inter-religious and inter-ethnic tension and that violence may explode once mobility restrictions are relaxed.

column1: The chapter by Bosio and co-authors studies how long firms in a sample of 34 low- and lower-middle income economies can survive without revenues. They find that the median firm in a low-income country can survive between 6 weeks and 18 weeks and that in middle-income countries the median survival time ranges between 7 weeks and 11 weeks. This disturbing microeconomic picture leads to two predictions: the potential for massive job losses; and a rapidly growing budget deficit for 2002
column3: and perhaps some years after that. To address the former topic
column4: Cespedes and co-authors develop a model to show that the elimination of jobs in a pandemic is inefficient because of the interaction of two ingredients: (i) while workers may be unproductive during the pandemic
column5: eliminating jobs harms productivity in the recovery; and (ii) employers may be unable to preserve jobs during the pandemic because of frictions that limit the credit needed for paying the wage bill.

column1: The third section of the eBook focuses on how the pandemic will affect informality
column2: inequality
column3: and poverty.

column1: Valensisi evaluates the effect of COVID-19 on global poverty using three different poverty lines ($1.90/day
column2: $3.20/day and $5.50/day) and finds that the pandemic will erode much of the poverty-reduction gains recorded over the last decade. These estimates focus on changes in GDP and assume that the crisis will not affect income distributions. However
column3: the pandemic is likely to increase income inequality as less-skilled people are often unable to work from home and are either more likely to suffer job loss or have to continue working outside home
column4: with a greater probability of being infected. The chapter by Furceri and co-authors uses data from past epidemic to estimate the effect of COVID-19 on inequality and job prospects. Their findings are in line with the hypothesis that the current pandemic could lead to a large increase in inequality which
column5: in turn
column6: will amplify its effect on poverty.

column1: The chapter by Nonvide evaluates the economic policy responses implemented by selected African countries and shows that these measures often exclude informal workers which
column2: in Africa
column3: account for 86% cent of total employment. She suggests that cash transfer programmes and larger social assistance systems need to be a key component of the policy response in Africa. Dhingra also focuses on informal workers and points out that income policies are hard to implement in developing countries. A universal job guarantee programme is an appealing option for getting people back to work once the acute phase of the pandemic is over.

column1: The chapters in section four of the eBook focus on some of the policy responses in the post-COVID recovery phase. These include job protection (Bircan and co-authors)
column2: work from home (Gottlieb and co-authors)
column3: the protection of export-oriented firms (Woodruff)
column4: the streamlining of bankruptcy procedures (Balloch and co-authors)
column5: regulatory reforms to increase firm productivity (Djankov and co-authors)
column6: and policies for preserving the human capital of the young (Corral and Gatti). The last chapter of this section by Freund and co-authors discusses the disruption of global value chains brought by COVID-19.

2020-06-22|"In addition to stretching outward
column2: the border is also seeping inward. Faced with the challenge of defeating an invisible virus
column3: a growing number of countries are turning to futuristic tracing measures
column4: deploying surveillance tools once used for anti-terrorism and international espionage against their own populations at home. These include measures such as geolocating the cellphones of those who have tested positive for the virus (in some cases
column5: without seeking consent for such tracking); erecting “geo-fences” to draw virtual enclosures around quarantine zones; and activating AI-powered thermal cameras that detect change in a person’s body temperature in order to identify whom in a crowd has a fever (as has been done in Beijing’s Qinghe Railway Station).

column1: Another new possibility is conditioning movement on color-coded QR or numerical scales of individualized “risk assessments” based on big-data-driven algorithms incorporating information on one’s health condition
column2: travel history
column3: and contact tracing. In the United States
column4: Google and Apple will collaborate to use Bluetooth technology to create a new interoperable platform that will permit to “reverse engineer” the movements of the COVID-positive—and those who came in contact with them. Even European countries that adhere to stricter data privacy regulations have warmed to such ideas.

column1: Questions of volitional versus coerced use of such technologies—and their architectures—will have to be debated. The answers may come to serve as a new fault line between democratic and authoritarian regimes. Once put into operation
column2: however
column3: it may prove difficult to return the genie of bio-surveillance back to the bottle
column4: as it provides governments unprecedented technological “see-all” eyes to monitor and track everyone’s mobility everywhere.

column1: Even prior to the current crisis
column2: the European Union funded a pilot project
column3: entitled iBorderCtrl designed to help protect its borders. This monitoring system is designed to prescreen incoming travelers
column4: who are required to “perform a short
column5: automated
column6: non-invasive interview with an avatar [and] undergo a lie detector.” The data is then linked to any pre-existing authority data and stored in large databases that are connected with “portable
column7: wireless connected iBorderCtrl units that can be used inside buses
column8: trains
column9: or any other point [to] verify the identity of each traveler … [and] calculate a cumulative risk factor for each individual.”"|0

column1: 2020-06-22|"Effective State control over the bulk of Ireland’s private hospitals will come to an end in just over a week’s time. The arrangement was broadly welcomed when first announced in response to the Covid-19 pandemic
column2: but has since proven to be a costly and controversial one.

column1: The Cabinet decided in late May not to take up an option to extend the agreement for a further two months
column2: but said it would look at other ways to make use of private hospital capacity in future.

column1: The agreement represented the State’s largest single investment in its effort to manage coronavirus
column2: with the Cabinet hearing that the total cost over three months could be close to €340 million.

column1: Documents published in recent days by the Department of Public Expenditure confirm that the HSE wanted to retain the 2
column2: 000 beds
column3: operating theatres and intensive care and other facilities available under the deal.

column1: Official minutes of the Health Budget Oversight Group – a body comprised of officials from the Department of Health
column2: the HSE and the Department of Public Expenditure – maintain that the HSE board wrote to Department of Health seeking to extend the arrangement.

column1: The documents show that from early on there were concerns among senior officials about the extent to which the private hospital facilities were being used as the anticipated surge of Covid-19 cases did not materialise.
They state that on April 16th “all parties expressed concern in relation to the utilisation of private hospital capacity”.
“Maximising the use of facilities available to the HSE is of the utmost importance in the current crisis; it was acknowledged
column2: however
column3: that the Government had agreed to the arrangement on the basis that there would be a significant and urgent requirement for additional capacity.

column1: “In this regard
column2: it was confirmed there was activity taking place in the private hospitals and public patients had moved across.”

column1: The Department of Health had written directly to HSE chief executive Paul Reid a week earlier urging that the private capacity be effectively and fully utilised in the interest of patient care and with immediate effect. It said Minister for Health Simon Harris wanted to have specific arrangements put in place to oversee the volume and type of patients seen in the private hospitals and the costs involved.
The minutes say the group on April 24th noted that there “appears to be excess unused capacity in public and private hospital system at present
column2: attributable to both delays in finalising an agreement with private consultants
column3: and to lower-than-projected levels of activity in acute hospitals”.

column1: The group heard that the clinical opinion “indicated a continuing need to retain this level of capacity”. However
column2: the Department of Public Expenditure argued that “data would be needed to support a case for continuing retention of high levels of capacity beyond the minimum period
column3: e.g. in scenarios where the levels of Covid-19 might be effectively suppressed”.

column1: The group heard on April 30th that occupancy of private hospitals at that stage was estimated to be running at 33 per cent “but there is opportunity in May and June to increase usage subject to public health advice and clinical and operational judgement”.
The group was also told that the occupancy rate at the CityWest hotel complex
column2: which the HSE also took over to increase capacity during the pandemic
column3: was “currently low”. Minutes from the following week note “a growing number of questions regarding the occupancy rate of CityWest Hotel at the time
column4: and potential alternative uses for the facility”.

column1: Two weeks later
column2: on May 21st
column3: the HSE told the group that “on balance” it was “inclined toward the view that some level of supplementary private hospital capacity should be maintained and that the continuation of the current arrangement
column4: for some or all of the private hospitals
column5: until end-August would be appropriate”.

column1: The Department of Public Expenditure pointed to “the need for evaluation of alternatives for securing needed capacity; and that differentials in capacity usage between various types of private hospital would be expected to have a bearing upon considerations of value-for-money and upon the final recommendations”.

The Government has separately instructed the HSE to engage with the private hospitals to secure ongoing access to the facilities in collaboration with the National Treatment Purchase Fund (NTPF) to address essential needs including delays in public patients obtaining treatment. These talks are under way and this week the HSE is expected to meet with doctors’ representatives before the Cabinet considers the issue again."|1
2020-06-22|"Maura Byrne had to watch from her carer’s mobile phone as a funeral service for her husband of almost 70 years took place.
“It knocked the bottom out of my world
column2: ” she says of not being able to attend.

column1: Stephen Byrne (93) died of Covid-19 at St James’s Hospital in Dublin on April 19th. Mrs Byrne (94) was recovering from the disease at St Luke’s Hospital in Rathgar at the time.
“I couldn’t see much
column2: ” she says of watching the funeral
column3: held at St Agnes’s Church in Crumlin
column4: on the phone. “There was a young nurse
column5: she was lovely
column6: holding my hand
column7: but I felt I should be with my people. I just didn’t understand it.”

column1: Mrs Byrne entered St James’s Hospital with shingles on February 14th and was transferred to St Luke’s for respite two weeks later. She tested positive for Covid-19 on April 11th and returned to St James’s
column2: where she remained until June 8th.

column1: “I was in hospital for a total of 16 weeks
column2: ” she says. “I didn’t know what to do with myself. I must have read about 20 books . . . All I wanted to do was come home.”

column1: Mrs Byrne
column2: originally from Ballsbridge
column3: met her husband
column4: a plumber at the Guinness brewery from Arbour Hill
column5: at a Dublin cycling club and they married on September 5th
column6: 1950. They bought the family home on Dowland Road in Walkinstown and had six children – Máire
column7: Stephen
column8: Bernadette
column9: Deirdre
column10: Paul and Dermot. There are now 17 grandchildren and 15 great grandchildren.

column1: Mr Byrne suffered from dementia later in his life and was cared for by his wife until last year
column2: when he moved to the Croft nursing home in Inchicore. He was brought into St James’s Hospital on April 16th after being diagnosed with Covid-19 and died there three days later.

column1: “I’d ring every night and one of the girls would say he’s fine
column2: as always. Then Máire rang me and said ‘Dad’s not well and he’s in James’s’
column3: ” Mrs Bryne recalls.

column1: “I said ‘I’ll go over and see him’. She [Máire] said ‘Mam you can’t
column2: you’re in lockdown you can’t go over to see him.’ So Deirdre and Bernadette were allowed to go in . . . He died the next morning.

column1: “I couldn’t believe it
column2: that I wouldn’t be allowed go [to the funeral]. I maintain I’ve had no closure. A funeral is a closure.

column1: “Yesterday evening Máire and I were looking at photographs and there was a photograph of the coffin in the church and a photograph of the coffin in the crematorium and I felt good after it. I sort of felt weepy but that’s all the finish I’m ever going to get.”

Mrs Byrne says not being able to go to the funeral was very difficult as all she wanted to do was “hold his hand”. The Byrnes plan to arrange a Mass later in the year to remember Stephen that can be attended by all his family and friends.
“He was the kindest and most loving man
column2: ” she says. “You always had that feeling that you could depend on him. He never ever let you down . . . Deirdre’s girls were asking me one day ‘how did you know he was the right person?’ I said ‘you just know’.”

column1: As his dementia progressed
column2: Mr Bryne would fail to remember or recognise relatives but Mrs Byrne says “now and again he would say ‘I like you
column3: you’re a nice lady’”.

column1: Since being released from hospital
column2: Mrs Byrne has been cared for at home by Máire and is feeling better with each passing day.

column1: “My health is wonderful. I’m doing a little bit more every day. I can now dress myself. I can put on my shoes
column2: which I couldn’t do
column3: ” she says.

column1: “At night I say ‘good night Stephen’ and I say a Hail Mary
column2: because that’s the only prayer he knew
column3: .I say ‘Good night
column4: Stephen’ and then I go to sleep.”"|0

column1: 2020-06-22|"Unmasked! The effect of face masks on the spread of COVID-19
Confronted with a novel
column2: aggressive coronavirus
column3: Germany implemented measures to reduce its spread since March 2020. Requiring people to wear face masks in public places has
column4: however
column5: been a subject of controversy and isolating the effect of mask-wearing on the spread of COVID-19 is not simple. This column looks at the town of Jena and other German regions that introduced face masks before the rest of the country to see whether the requirement makes a difference in the number of new COVID-19 cases. Requiring face masks to be worn decreases the growth rate of COVID-19 cases by about 40% in Germany.

column1: On a global scale
column2: the extent of COVID-related lockdowns is massive
column3: and their socio-economic impact is expected to be far-reaching (Barba Navaretti et al. 2020
column4: McKibbin and Fernando 2020). When it comes to the estimated effects of containment measures
column5: timing seems to matter (Deb et al. 2020).

column1: In Germany
column2: significant actions to reduce the spread of the virus have been taken from mid-March onwards (Hartl et al. 2020). However
column3: the obligation to wear face masks in public has been the subject of controversy and was introduced only relatively late throughout Germany (around 27 April 2020).

column1: At present
column2: virologists are collecting more and more clinical evidence that face masks catch infectious particles produced from speaking
column3: coughing
column4: or sneezing
column5: which may reduce the risk of infecting another person (Prather et al. 2020). Proper wearing of a face mask could thus help to reduce the spread of COVID-19 and protect risk groups from infections in a cheap and simple way.

column1: Finding out whether face masks indeed reduce the spread of COVID-19 is thus important. Against the available evidence from clinical studies or previous pandemics
column2: we ask: Can we identify a significant effect of face masks on the spread of COVID-19 by looking at the development of registered COVID-19 cases? Yes
column3: we can. We zoom in on the case of Jena
column4: a town of 110
column5: 000 inhabitants in the federal state of Thuringia
column6: Germany.

column1: Jena presents a unique case in Germany (see also Mitze et al. 2020)
column2: as the obligation to wear face masks in public transport
column3: shops
column4: and workplaces was introduced much earlier there (on 6 April) than in all other regions in Germany (around 27 April). The introduction of obligatory face masks was accompanied by a public campaign “Jena zeigt Maske” (“Jena shows mask”)
column5: which started one week earlier to make the local population aware of this novel measure.

column1: We can observe differences in the timing of introducing face masks across German regions due to the institutional setup of the German federal system: according to the German Infection Protection Act
column2: federal states are in charge of formulating and prescribing public health measures to fight the spread of infections. Local municipalities and health authorities then decide on the implementation of specific measures
column3: e.g. the timing of their introduction. And Jena was the first to act.

column1: If we look at the number of COVID-19 cases in Jena
column2: masks seem to have a positive effect. The number of registered new infections fell to almost zero in the days after masks were introduced. But was this really due to the introduction of masks and a publicly visible campaign? Unfortunately
column3: there is no second Jena in Germany
column4: which would allow us to measure the spread of COVID-19 if face masks had not been introduced under otherwise identical conditions.

column1: Our solution is to apply the synthetic control method (Abadie and Gardeazabal 2003
column2: Abadie et al. 2010
column3: Abadie 2020) to construct a counterfactual that closely follows the COVID-19 trend in Jena before masks were introduced. The idea is to construct a weighted average of similar regions in Germany (with no mask obligations) at the time when mask-wearing became compulsory in Jena.

column1: Regions and their respective sample weights are chosen based on the cumulative number and changes in newly registered COVID-19 cases before 6 April
column2: together with structural regional characteristics such as regional population density
column3: average age of the population
column4: proportion of senior citizens
column5: and average number of doctors and pharmacies per inhabitants. In the baseline
column6: both West and East German cities such as Rostock
column7: Darmstadt
column8: and Trier constitute this synthetic Jena (see Mitze et al. 2020 for the full list).

column1: We then use this counterfactual to estimate the hypothetical change in cases in Jena after 6 April. This tells us approximately what would have happened if no masks had been introduced in the city.
Table 1 shows a significant difference in the number of cases in Jena and the comparison group without masks after 6 April. Twenty days after the introduction of mandatory masks in Jena
column2: the cumulative number of COVID-19 cases increased from ‘only’ 142 to 158. In the synthetic Jena
column3: the number rose from 143 to 205. This corresponds to a reduction in the number of cases by around 23%.

column1: Notes: The sample of all municipal districts in Germany covers 401 regions; the subsample of cities covers 105 larger cities (kreisfreie Städte). For details
